PREFACE
This code of the Village of Green Oaks, as supplemented, contains ordinances up
to and including ordinance 2025-O-07, passed May 28 2025. Ordinances of the
Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to
the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the
code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

publisher, and they may not affect the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
 
2025-O-08
Passed 09/24/25
 
AN ORDINANCE REQUIRING MAINTENANCE OF THE PARKWAY AREA BY ADJACENT PROPERTY
OWNERS
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Green Oaks has a legitimate interest in maintaining the
safety, cleanliness, and aesthetic character of public rights-of-way, including
parkway areas between sidewalks and curb lines; and
 
WHEREAS, the Village Board finds it in the public interest to require adjacent
property owners to maintain those portions of the public parkway adjoining
their property to preserve sightlines for traffic safety and promote the
general welfare;
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Green Oaks, Lake County, Illinois, as follows:
 
New Chapter 9 of Title 7 “Maintenance of Parkway Area By Adjacent Property
Owners” Green Oaks Code of Ordinances
 
SECTION I: There is herby established a new Chapter 9 of Title 7 of the Green
Oaks, Illinois, Code of Ordinances entitled “Maintenance of Parkway Area by
Adjacent Property Owners” to provide in Sections and subsections as follows:
 
Section 7-9-1   Definitions.
 
For purposes of this Chapter 9:

“Parkway” shall mean the portion of the public right-of-way located between the
edge of the street and the nearest edge of the public sidewalk (or property
line where no sidewalk exists), excluding any paved driveways, sidewalks, or
other public infrastructure.

“Adjacent property owner” shall mean the record owner of the private lot or
parcel of land which immediately abuts the public parkway.
 
Section 7-9-2 Parkway Maintenance Obligations.
 
Each adjacent property owner shall be responsible for maintaining the parkway
contiguous to their property in accordance with the following standards:
 
A. Mowing and Vegetation Control.
Grass and weeds within the parkway shall be maintained at a height not to
exceed eight (8) inches. The area shall be kept free of invasive or noxious
vegetation and trash or debris.
 
 
 
 
   
B. Sightline Obstructions.
 
No tree, shrub, bush, fence, structure, or other vegetation or object located
within the parkway shall obstruct the view of drivers or pedestrians. The
following clearance zones shall be maintained:
 
1.    Corner Lots: No vegetation or object over 30 inches in height shall be
permitted within a visibility triangle formed by measuring 25 feet from the
intersection of two property lines at a street corner.
 
2.    Sidewalk and Street Clearance: Tree limbs must be maintained to provide a
minimum clear vertical clearance of:
 
-7 feet over public sidewalks
-14 feet over streets or roadways
 
C. Safety Hazards Prohibited.
 
No condition in the parkway shall be permitted to pose a danger to pedestrians,
cyclists, or motorists, including but not limited to tripping hazards,
obstructions of signage, or concealment of fire hydrants.
 
Section 7-9-3   Enforcement and Penalties.
 
A. Notice and Cure. In the event of noncompliance, the Village may issue
written notice to the adjacent property owner directing corrective action
within ten (10) days.
 
B. Abatement by Village.
 
If the owner fails to take corrective action, the Village may perform the
necessary maintenance and assess the cost thereof to the property owner as a
lien or claim pursuant to applicable law; or the Village may initiate
proceedings under its administrative adjudication process.
 
C. Fine.
 
Violation of this Ordinance shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $75 per
day for each day the violation continues.
 
SECTION II: EFFECTIVE DATE
 
This Ordinance shall be effective from and after its passage, approval, and
publication in pamphlet form as provided by law.
 
SECTION III:   Nothing in this Ordinance shall be construed to affect any suit
or proceeding pending in any court, or any rights acquired, or liability
incurred, or any cause or causes of action arising, acquired or existing under
any act or ordinance or portion thereof hereby repealed or amended by this
Ordinance; nor shall any just or legal right, claim, penalty or remedy of any
character of the corporate authority existing on the effective date hereof be
lost, impaired or affected by this Ordinance.
 
SECTION IV:   All Ordinances or parts of Ordinances in conflict herewith are,
to the extent of such conflict, hereby paused.
 
SECTION V:      If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part
of this Ordinance or application thereof to any person, firm, corporation,
public agency or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudged by a court of
competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall
not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this ordinance and the
application of such provision to other persons, firms, corporation, or
circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause,
sentence, paragraph, section, or part thereof directly involved in the
controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and to the person,
firm, corporation, or circumstances involved. It is hereby declared to be the
legislative intent of the Corporate Authorities that this ordinance would have
been adopted had such unconstitutional or invalid provision, clause, sentence,
paragraph, section, or part thereof not been included.
 
Passed this 24 th day of September, 2025.

2025-O-09

AN ORDINANCE REGULATING EXTERIOR PROPERTY
MAINTENANCE FOR RESIDENTIAL PREMISES
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees find that the accumulation of
junk, debris, and inoperable vehicles on residential premises creates harborage
for rodents, insects, and other vermin, thereby constituting a hazard to the
public health and safety of Village residents; and
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees further find that the accumulation
and outdoor storage of junk, debris, and inoperable vehicles negatively impact
the appearance and desirability of residential neighborhoods, thereby
diminishing property values and impairing the overall tax base of the
community; and
WHEREAS , the President and Board of Trustees further find that the presence of
junk materials, abandoned equipment, and inoperable vehicles creates an
attractive nuisance to children, posing risks of injury, entrapment, or
exposure to hazardous substances; and
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees further find that the outdoor
accumulation of combustible materials, rubbish, and debris increases the risk
of fire and creates obstacles to safe emergency access, thereby endangering the
lives and property of Village residents; and
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees further find that the maintenance
of orderly, safe, and sanitary exterior premises contributes to the overall
welfare of the community, preserves neighborhood character, and protects the
enjoyment and use of private property by residents, and
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Green Oaks find
that the public health, safety and welfare require the regulation of exterior
property maintenance to preserve the appearance, value, and safety of
residential neighborhoods.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Green Oaks, Lake County, Illinois, as follows:
SECTION I:    There is hereby created a new Chapter 6-4 entitled “Exterior
Property Maintenance” to Title 4 of the Green Oaks Code of Ordinances to
provide in Sections and Subsections as follows:
Section 6-4-1. PURPOSE.
The purpose of this Chapter 6-4 is to protect the health, safety, and welfare
of the residents of the Village by prohibiting the accumulation of junk,
debris, inoperable or unlicensed motor vehicles, and the outdoor storage of
materials on residential properties.
Section 6-4-2. DEFINITIONS.
For the purposes of this Chapter 6-4, the following terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them:
“Junk” means discarded, unused, or unusable materials, including appliances,
furniture, scrap metal, and similar items.
“Debris” means refuse, rubbish, or other waste materials scattered or stored
outdoors.
“Inoperable motor vehicle” means a motor vehicle that is not capable of being
driven in its existing condition, including vehicles without valid license
plates or registration.
“Outdoor storage” means the keeping of building materials, equipment,
machinery, or other items not customarily used outdoors on residential
premises.
Section 6-4-3. PROHIBITIONS.
A. No owner or occupant of residential premises shall allow or suffer the
accumulation of junk or debris upon the exterior premises of such property.
B. No owner or occupant of residential premises shall permit the parking or
storage of inoperable or unlicensed motor vehicles on the exterior premises of
residential property, except within a fully enclosed structure.
C. No owner or occupant of residential premises shall maintain outdoor storage
of building materials, equipment, machinery, or similar items on the exterior
premises, except where such materials are temporarily stored during ongoing
construction under a valid building permit.
Section 6-4-4. ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES
A. Inspection Authority: The Village Building Commissioner or Code Enforcement
Officer is authorized to enter upon any residential property at reasonable
times to determine compliance with this Chapter.
B. Notice of Violation: If a violation is found, the Code Enforcement Officer
shall issue a written Notice of Violation to the property owner and occupant,
specifying the nature of the violation, the corrective action required, and the
compliance deadline.
C. Compliance Period: The property owner or occupant shall have not less than
seven (7) days, nor more than thirty (30) days, as determined by the Code
Enforcement Officer, to remedy the violation, unless immediate action is
required to protect public health or safety.
D. Administrative Hearing: If the violation is not corrected within the
compliance period, the matter shall be referred to the Village’s administrative
adjudication system for hearing and determination. The owner or occupant shall
have the opportunity to present evidence and testimony.
E. Abatement by Village: If the violation remains uncorrected after a final
administrative order, the Village may, upon ten (10) days’ written notice,
cause the violation to be abated, including the removal of junk, debris, or
inoperable vehicles, with all costs assessed against the property owner and
recorded as a lien against the property.
F. Penalties: Any violation of this Chapter 6-4 shall be subject to fines of
not less than $100 or more than $750 for each offense, and each day a violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense.
SECTION II:     Nothing in this Ordinance shall be construed to affect any suit
or proceeding pending in any court, or any rights acquired, or liability
incurred, or any cause or causes of action arising, acquired or existing under
any act or ordinance or portion thereof hereby repealed or amended by this
ordinance; nor shall any just or legal right, claim, penalty or remedy of any
character of the corporate authority existing on the effective date hereof be
lost, impaired or affected by this Ordinance.
SECTION III:   If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part
of this ordinance or application thereof to any person, firm, corporation,
public agency or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudged by a court of
competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall
not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this ordinance and the
application of such provision to other persons, firms, corporation, or
circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause,
sentence, paragraph, section, or part thereof directly involved in the
controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and to the person,
firm, corporation, or circumstances involved. It is hereby declared to be the
legislative intent of the Corporate Authorities that this ordinance would have
been adopted had such unconstitutional or invalid provision, clause, sentence,
paragraph, section, or part thereof not been included.
SECTION IV:   This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its passage and approval and publication in pamphlet form as required by law.
Passed this 24 th day of September, 2025.

AN ORDINANCE IMPOSING A NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL
RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX AND
A NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Green Oaks, Lake County, Illinois ("Village") is a non-
home rule Illinois municipality pursuant to the Constitution of the State of
Illinois of 1970, as amended; and,
WHEREAS, the Village is authorized under Section 8-11-1.3 and 8-11-1.4 of the
Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3 and 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4, to impose a
non-home rule municipal retailers’ occupation tax and a non-home rule municipal
service occupation tax; and,
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Green Oaks Code of Ordinances provides for the
imposition of a Retailers' Occupation Tax and a Service Occupation Tax in
Sections 2-3-1 and 2-3-2, which is not currently collected by the Village and
which language is outdated due to Illinois law prior to Public Act 107-0381
requiring a referendum prior to the imposition of such taxes; and,
 
WHEREAS, through Public Act 107-0381, the Illinois Municipal Code was amended
to allow non-home rule municipalities to implement said taxes without a
referendum; and,
 
WHEREAS, proceeds generated must be used for public infrastructure or property
tax relief as defined at Section 8-11-1.2 of the Illinois Municipal Code or for
additional uses as may be otherwise authorized by law; and,
 
WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village find that it
appropriate, necessary, and is in the best interests of the Village to impose
such taxes at the rate of one percent (1%) on all eligible sales and services
within the Village.
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Green Oaks, Lake County, Illinois, as follows:
 
SECTION I:   RECITALS ADOPTED.
 
The recitals set forth above are incorporated into this Section I by this
reference as findings of the Village Board of Trustees.
 
SECTION II:    AMENDMENTS TO CODE OF ORDINANCES.
 
The following provisions within Section 2-3-1 Chapter 3 of Title 3 of the Code
of Ordinances of the Village of Green Oaks entitled “MUNICIPAL RETAILERS'
OCCUPATION TAX” is hereby amended to add the following language, with double
underline (insert) denoting inserted language, and to delete the following
language, with strikeout (delete) denoting deleted language:
 
2-3-1: IMPOSITION OF NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX.
 
 
A.   Tax Imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of selling tangible personal property at retail in this Village at the
rate of one percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the
course of such business while these provisions are in effect, in accordance
with the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-11-1. A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible
personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's
government, at retail in this municipality at the rate of one percent (1%) of
the gross receipts from such eligible sales made in the course of such
business The imposition of this tax is in accordance with and subject to the
provisions of Section 8-11-1.3 and of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-
11-1.3).
 
B. Report Required: Every such person engaged in such business in the Village
shall timely file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report
required by to the Illinois Department of Revenue. required by section three of
"An Act in Relation to a Tax Upon Persons to Purchasers for Use or
Consumption", approved June 28, 1933, as amended.
 
C. Payment of Tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the
State Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed, or as otherwise
provided by law. on account of the receipts from sales of tangible personal
property during the preceding month.
 
SECTION III: The following provisions within Section 2-3-2 of Chapter 3 of
Title 3 of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Green Oaks entitled
“MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX” is hereby amended to add the following
language, with double underline (insert) denoting inserted language, and to
delete the following language, with strikeout (delete) denoting deleted
language:
 
2-3-2:  IMPOSITION OF NON-HOME RULE MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX.
 
A. Tax Imposed: A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this
Municipality in the business of making sales of service at the rate of one
percent (1%) of the gross receipts received from such business, in accordance
with the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-11-5. A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the
selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such servicemen
as an incident to a sale of service. The imposition of this tax is in
accordance with and subject to the provisions of Section 8-11-1.4 of the
Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1.4).
 
B. Report Required: Every serviceman required to account for Municipal Service
Occupation Tax for the benefit of this Municipality shall timely file on or
before the last day of each calendar month, the report required by to the State
Department of Revenue. required by section three of "An Act in Relation to a
Tax Upon Persons to Purchasers for Use or Consumption", approved June 28, 1933,
as amended.
 
C. Payment Of Tax: At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the
Illinois Department of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed, or as
otherwise provided by law.
 
SECTION IV: COLLECTION AND ADMINISTRATION BY DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE.
 
The taxes imposed by this Ordinance, and all civil penalties that may be
assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the
Illinois Department of Revenue. The Department of Revenue shall have full power
to administer and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance.
 
SECTION V: LIMITATIONS AND EXEMPTIONS.
 
The taxes imposed by this Ordinance shall not be applicable to the sales of
tangible personal property which are exempted therefrom by law.
 
SECTION VI: EFFECTIVE DATE.
 
This Ordinance shall take effect on: (i) the first day of July next following
the adoption and filing of this Ordinance with the Department of Revenue, if
filed on or before the preceding April 1st; or, (ii) the first day of January
next following the adoption and filing of this Ordinance with the Department of
Revenue, if filed on or before the preceding October 1st.
 
SECTION VII: LIMITATION ON USE OF PROCEEDS. 
 
The Village shall only expend the proceeds generated from any tax imposed by
virtue of this Ordinance on: (a) expenditures related to “municipal roads and
streets, access roads, bridges, and sidewalks; waste disposal systems; and
water and sewer line extensions, water distribution and purification
facilities, storm water drainage and retention facilities, and sewage treatment
facilities; (b) efforts to “reduce the levy for real estate taxes or avoid an
increase in the levy for real estate taxes that would otherwise have been
required” by the Village; or (c) any other or further permitted uses under
Section 8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1) as may now or
hereafter be authorized therein.
 
SECTION VIII: QUALIFIED EXEMPTION OF AVIATION FUEL FROM BOTH TAXES. 
 
No provision of this Ordinance shall be interpreted to impose any tax on
aviation fuel, as defined in Section 3 of the Retailers’ Occupation Tax Act (35
ILCS 120/3), unless the proceeds of said tax are expended for airport-related
purposes, as that term is defined in Section 6z-20.2 of the State Finance Act
(30 ILCS 105/6z-20.2), and said expenditures are made in compliance with the
certification requirements for airport-related purposes under Section 2-22 of
the Retailers' Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/2–22).
 
SECTION IX:   Nothing in this Ordinance shall be construed to affect any suit
or proceeding pending in any court, or any rights acquired, or liability
incurred, or any cause or causes of action arising, acquired or existing under
any act or ordinance or portion thereof hereby repealed or amended by this
Ordinance; nor shall any just or legal right, claim, penalty or remedy of any
character of the corporate authority existing on the effective date hereof be
lost, impaired or affected by this Ordinance.
 
SECTION X:      All Ordinances or parts of Ordinances in conflict herewith are,
to the extent of such conflict, hereby paused.
 
SECTION XI:   If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part
of this Ordinance or application thereof to any person, firm, corporation,
public agency or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudged by a court of
competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall
not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this ordinance and the
application of such provision to other persons, firms, corporation, or
circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause,
sentence, paragraph, section, or part thereof directly involved in the
controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and to the person,
firm, corporation, or circumstances involved. It is hereby declared to be the
legislative intent of the Corporate Authorities that this ordinance would have
been adopted had such unconstitutional or invalid provision, clause, sentence,
paragraph, section, or part thereof not been included.
 
SECTION XII:   That the Village Attorney is hereby directed to file a certified
copy of this Ordinance with the Illinois Department of Revenue on or before
October 1, 2025.
 
Passed this 24 th day of September, 2025.
 
                  Ayes:      Nays:      Absent/Abstain

26/74.39/ORDINANC/00048208.DOC
 
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 88-16
   AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE VILLAGE CODE OF
   THE VILLAGE OF GREEN OAKS, ILLINOIS
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Green Oaks
have heretofore employed Sterling Codifiers, Inc. to prepare a codification of
the ordinances of the Village; and,
   WHEREAS, Sterling Codifiers have submitted a Village Code which has been
reviewed by the President and Board of Trustees, and they are of the opinion
that the said Code fairly and reasonably codifies all of the existing
ordinances of the Village other than those relating to tax levies, special
services areas, annexations and other similar special situations; and,
   WHEREAS, the President and Board of Trustees deem it in the best interests
of the Village to adopt the said codification as the Village Code of Green
Oaks, Illinois;
NOW, THEREFORE BE IT AND IT IS HEREBY ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF
TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF GREEN OAKS, COUNTY OF LAKE, STATE OF ILLINOIS, AS
FOLLOWS:
   SECTION 1. The loose leaf document, entitled "Village Code of Green Oaks,
1988" consisting of nine Titles and an Index thereto, a copy whereof is
attached to this Ordinance, is hereby adopted as the Village Code of the
Village of Green Oaks.
   SECTION 2. The Village Code herein adopted, as hereafter amended from time
to time, shall be the Code of the Village and the provisions thereof shall
supersede the terms and provisions of any ordinances of the Village heretofore
adopted in so far as there is any conflict between said Code and the said
heretofore adopted ordinances.
   SECTION 3. Notwithstanding the adoption of this Village Code, the terms and
provisions of any ordinance of the Village heretofore adopted shall remain in
full force and effect in so far as the said Code does not deal with the topic
thereof or conflict with the terms thereof.
   SECTION 4. That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith
be and the same are hereby repealed.
   SECTION 5. That this ordinance shall be published by authority of the
Village Authorities in pamphlet form and placed on file in the office of the
Village Clerk, and the Village Clerk shall record the passage hereof in the
Ordinance Record Book.
   SECTION 6. That this ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and
after its passage, approval and publication according to law.
PASSED AND APPROVED THIS 28th DAY OF SEPTEMBER, 1988.
AYES:   6
NAYES:   0
ABSENT:   0
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees, this Village Code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of Green Oaks. This
Village Code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the GREEN OAKS VILLAGE
CODE, and it is hereby published by authority of the Board of Trustees and
shall be kept up to date as provided in Section
1-1-3 of this Chapter under the direction of the Village Attorney, acting for
said Village Board of Trustees. Any reference to the number of any section
contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same
number, its appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty
clause relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is
made to this Village Code by title in any legal document.
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this State as the ordinances of the Village of general and
permanent effect, except the excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1 of this Code.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Village Code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Village Code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be forwarded to the codifiers
and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in its proper
place in each copy of this Village Code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this
Village Code.
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the Village Board. The Clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the Clerk. Any
person having in his custody an official copy of this Village Code shall make
every effort to maintain this Code in an up to date and efficient manner. He
shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such are
delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the Village
Clerk. Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and other
interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the Village and shall
be returned to the office of the Clerk when directed so to do by order of the
Village Board. (1988 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this
Village Code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this Village
Code or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances;
appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
Village; zoning variations; zoning district special uses; special assessments;
special service areas; designation of depositories; and all special ordinances.
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be replaced by virtue of the preceding section, excepting as
this Village Code may contain provisions for such matters, in which case this
Village Code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in
respect to such provisions only.
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or in any way whatever to affect any such
offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that proceedings thereafter shall conform to
the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable.
If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the Village herein
repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code
shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this Village Code.
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this Village Code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this Code, or any part thereof. The Village Board of
Trustees hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the
fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective. (1988 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction of Words
1-3-2: Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this Village Code importing the plural
number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons,
any single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or
person is referred to in this Village Code by words importing the singular
number only, or the masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and
females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included;
provided, that these rules of construction shall not be applied to any section
of this Village Code which contains any express provision excluding such
construction or where the subject matter or content may be repugnant thereto.
The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the Village has been
changed in the content of this Village Code to "title", "chapter", "section"
and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to the Village's ordinances is not
meant to amend the passage and effective dates of such original ordinances.
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
BOARD: Unless otherwise indicated, the Board of Trustees of the Village.
CODE: The Municipal Code of Green Oaks, Illinois, and amendments thereto.
COUNTY: The County of Lake, State of Illinois.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words, "of the
Village of Green Oaks".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MAYOR: See Village President.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in
other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the Village; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a
hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or
to the community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any person
who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or
with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this Code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the Village
of Green Oaks".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any part
owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of
a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Every description of money, goods, chattels, effects,
evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any pecuniary
obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred,
increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right of interest
therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, this term shall be understood
to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small
quantities direct to the consumer.
STATE: The State of Illinois.
STREET: This term shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any person
who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or
with others.
VILLAGE: The Village of Green Oaks, County of Lake, State of Illinois.
VILLAGE PRESIDENT: The President of the Village may be referred to as "Mayor"
or "President" of the Village.
WHOLESALER and WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, such
terms shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles
or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: These terms may include printing and any other mode of
representing words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is
required by law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it
shall be in the proper handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to
write, by his proper mark.
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this Village Code are intended as
mere catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed
or taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify
or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-
enacted. (1988 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this Code,
where no other penalty is set forth, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any offense 1 . (Ord. 97-03, 3-26-
1997)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this Chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this Code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a
continuing nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each
day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless
otherwise specifically provided in this Code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this Code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this Chapter
shall apply. (1988 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the Board of Trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1988 Code)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-5-1: Election, Term of Office
1-5-2: Duties
1-5-3: Designation of Duties
1-5-4: Bond, Oath, Salary
1-5-5: President Pro Tem
1-5-6: Voting Powers
1-5-1: ELECTION, TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village President shall be elected for a term of four (4) years and he
shall be the President of the Board of Trustees as is provided by statute 1 .
(Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-5-1.
1-5-2: DUTIES:
The Village President shall be the chief executive officer of the Village and
he shall perform all duties that may be required of him by statute or
ordinance. He shall:
   A.   Have supervision over all executive officers of the Village;
   B.   Have the power and the authority to inspect all books and records kept
by any Village officer or employee at any reasonable time; and
   C.   Appoint all Village officers with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-5-3: DESIGNATION OF DUTIES:
Whenever there is a question as to the respective duties or powers of any
appointed officer of the Village, this shall be settled by the President. He
shall have the power to delegate to any such officer any duty which is to be
performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform that duty.
(Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-5-4: BOND, OATH, SALARY:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the President shall give a bond
with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees conditioned upon the
faithful performance of his duties, in the amount as required in Section
1-8-6 of this Code or such higher sum as may be directed by the Board of
Trustees. He shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute and shall
receive such compensation as may be set, from time to time, by the Board 1 .
(Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  1-8-7A of this Code.
1-5-5: PRESIDENT PRO TEM:
During a temporary absence or disability of the Village President, the Board of
Trustees shall elect one of its number to act as President Pro Tem, who during
the absence or disability of the President shall perform the duties pertaining
to the office. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-5-6: VOTING POWERS:
The Village President shall cast a vote at Village Board meetings only in the
event of a tie; or where one-half (1/2) of the Trustees elected have voted in
favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion; or when more than a majority vote
of the corporate authorities is required by ordinance or by State statute. The
President Pro Tem, however, shall cast his vote on all questions on which a
roll-call vote is taken, in his capacity as a Trustee. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
CHAPTER 6
BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election, Functions
1-6-2: Oath, Salary
1-6-3: Meetings
1-6-4: Presiding Officer
1-6-5: Quorum
1-6-6: Standing, Special Committees
1-6-6-1: Appointment, Membership
1-6-6-2: Duties
1-6-6-3: Meetings
1-6-6-4: Standing Committees Designated
1-6-7: Rules Of Order, Procedure
1-6-7-1: Robert's Rules Of Order
1-6-7-2: Order Of Business
1-6-7-3: Duties Of Presiding Officer
1-6-7-4: Duties Of Members
1-6-7-5: Visitors
1-6-7-6: Procedure
1-6-8: Rescinded Action
1-6-9: Suspension Of Rules
1-6-10: Disorderly Conduct Of Members; Censure, Expulsion
1-6-1: ELECTION, FUNCTIONS:
The board of trustees (hereinafter, the board), consisting of six (6) members,
shall be elected to office for a four (4) year term as is provided by statute 1
. The board shall be the legislative department of the village government, and
shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by
statute. The term corporate authorities shall refer to the board of trustees
and the village president, acting together by vote. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-1980)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-5-1 et seq.
1-6-2: OATH, SALARY:
The members of the board shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute,
and shall receive such compensation as may be from time to time provided by
ordinance 1 . (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-1980)
 
Notes
1 2. See subsection
  1-8-7C of this title.
1-6-3: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular monthly meeting of the board shall be
held on the fourth Wednesday of each month beginning at seven thirty o'clock
(7:30) P.M., and no notice of such regular meeting shall be required. The
meeting place of the said board shall be at the village hall of the village of
Green Oaks, unless otherwise ordered by the board; provided that if such
meeting date should fall on a legal holiday, the meeting shall be held on the
following Wednesday.
   B.   Adjourned Regular Meetings: Should the trustees not dispose of all
pending village business on the regular meeting date, an adjourned regular
meeting may be held on a date set by the board through motion.
   C.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the president of
the village or any three (3) trustees upon at least forty eight (48) hours'
notice to all members and the president. Notice of the special meeting shall be
posted at the regular meeting place at least forty eight (48) hours before such
meeting.
   D.   Open To The Public: All meetings of the board including special and
adjourned meetings, except executive sessions exempt by statute, shall be open
to the public, as is required by statute 1 .
   E.   Conduct Of Meetings: No person other than the president or a member of
the board shall address that body at any time at any regular or special meeting
except upon consent of a majority of the members present. The meetings shall be
conducted under the rules of order set forth in section
1-6-7 of this chapter.
   F.   Calling Meetings To Order: Every regular or special meeting of the
board of trustees shall be called to order within twenty (20) minutes of the
time set for such meeting. In the absence of the president, the village clerk,
or a member of the board may call the meeting to order and call the roll of the
members. If a quorum is present, the clerk shall ask for election by majority
vote of a president pro tem to conduct the meeting as presiding officer. If no
quorum is present, the members present shall be competent to adjourn the board
meeting or recess the board meeting by a majority vote to a time certain prior
to the next regularly scheduled meeting.
   G.   Disturbing Meetings Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to
disturb any meeting of the board or any committee thereof. (Ord. 2008-O-10, 8-
27-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-6-4: PRESIDING OFFICER:
The village president shall be the presiding officer of all regular and special
meetings of the board and at all times when the board meets as a committee of
the whole. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-1980)
1-6-5: QUORUM:
A majority of the Trustees elected, or three (3) Trustees and the Village
President, shall constitute a quorum to do business, but no ordinance shall be
passed except upon a favorable vote of a majority of the corporate authorities.
(Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-6-6: STANDING, SPECIAL COMMITTEES:
1-6-6-1: APPOINTMENT, MEMBERSHIP:
All standing and special committees shall consist of three (3) members,
including the chairman, unless the Board directs otherwise. All committees
shall be appointed by the Village President. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-6-6-2: DUTIES:
Any matters not specified herein may be directed to the most appropriate
standing committee by the President, or special committees which may be created
from time to time by the Board to perform such duties as may be directed. (Ord.
80-06, 5-28-80)
1-6-6-3: MEETINGS:
Each standing committee shall establish a regular monthly meeting date, on a
day of the month other than Saturday or Sunday, which shall be published
annually by the Village Clerk and such other special meetings as the chairman
or two (2) committee members shall call. Notice of special meetings shall be
given by posting at the Oak Grove School at least two (2) days before the
meeting. In the event there are no matters proposed to be on the agenda of a
regular meeting five (5) days before the meeting date, the chairman forthwith
may cancel the meeting by notifying the Clerk and the committee members and
causing a notice to be posted at the Oak Grove School. There shall be no quorum
requirements for a committee meeting but any reports or recommendations made by
concurrence of less than two (2) members shall be identified as a minority
action of the committee. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80; 1988 Code)
1-6-6-4: STANDING COMMITTEES DESIGNATED:
The following shall be the standing committees of the Board which shall have
the duties as set forth herein:
   A.   Annexation, Planning, Zoning Committee: The Annexation, Planning,
Zoning Committee shall:
      1.   Make the short- and long-term plans for the growth and development
of the Village in accordance with the desires and in the best interests of the
residents of the Village;
      2.   Evaluate recommendations made to the Board by the Plan Commission
relating to those matters that properly come before the Plan Commission;
      3.   Consider proposed annexations to the Village and recommend actions
to be taken by the Village;
      4.   Review proposed subdivisions, zoning variations, amendments to
zoning ordinances and to the Comprehensive Village Plan.
   B.   Building Committee: The Building Committee shall:
      1.   Review the Village building regulations and codes and recommend such
changes and additions as may be deemed necessary to provide a safe living
environment for the residents of the Village;
      2.   Review the enforcement of building codes;
      3.   Review all matters relating to public health and sanitation and
Zoning Ordinance enforcement;
      4.   Review all matters relating to the permitting process;
      5.   Coordinate and oversee the work of the Building Commission;
      6.   Coordinate and oversee the work of the Enforcement Officer.
   C.   Finance Committee: The Finance Committee shall:
      1.   Plan and implement programs and/or studies for maintaining the
financial health of the Village, including the budgeting of anticipated costs
of operation of the various departments of the Village, review and modification
of programs and cost with the responsible departments and the recommendation of
funding or source of revenue to provide for the programs;
      2.   Review and make recommendations concerning expenditures,
collections, savings and investments;
      3.   Review and oversee the work of the Treasurer and Collector;
      4.   File all necessary County, State and Federal financial statements;
      5.   Review all audits required to be made;
      6.   Review all matters relating to any licensing process in the Village.
   D.   Public Affairs Committee: The Public Affairs Committee shall:
      1.   Review the conditions affecting the general health, welfare and
safety of the residents and recommend such actions as are needed to correct any
problems;
      2.   Develop and implement a system of communication between the Village
Board, the residents and other governmental bodies such as schools and other
municipalities;
      3.   Review all matters relating to civil defense, emergency programs,
law enforcement and the general enforcement of ordinances;
      4.   Investigate the insurance requirements of the Village, recommend
insurance coverages and secure bids for such coverages as may be required by
statute or ordinance;
      5.   Prepare and edit the newsletter;
      6.   Review and advise the Board on any relevant legal or health matters
affecting the Village.
   E.   Public Works Committee: The Public Works Committee shall:
      1.   Plan and implement programs for the maintenance, improvement and
protection of physical assets of the Village utilities, including sanitary
sewers which are the responsibility of the Village, pumping and/or lift
stations and associated distribution systems associated with sanitary sewers,
public buildings and grounds, potable water, electricity, telephone, gas and
cable utilities;
      2.   Review all matters relating to stormwater drainage systems and
sanitary sewer permit allotments;
      3.   Coordinate and oversee recycling and waste hauling in the Village;
      4.   Coordinate cleanup of debris, leaves and brush in the Village;
      5.   Oversee and coordinate land resource management of the Village;
      6.   Develop and maintain trail system in the Village.
   F.   Roads And Streets Committee: The Roads and Streets Committee shall:
      1.   Plan and implement maintenance, protection and improvement programs
for roads, streets, bridges, ditches and swales within public right-of-way for
the Village, including, but not limited to, the development of priorities for
roadway, review of proposals from engineering advisors, participation in
selection of contractors, snowplowing, crack filling, grass cutting and review
of both physical and financial results;
      2.   Determine the need or removal of signs in the Village and the
maintenance of the signs;
      3.   Oversee the sale and enforcement of Village stickers;
      4.   Coordinate and oversee the work of the Village Road Superintendent;
      5.   Review and advise the Board concerning traffic movement and
automobile violations. (Ord. 93-23, 5-26-1993)
   G.   Tax Increment Finance (TIF) Committee: The TIF Committee shall consist
of all Trustees and the Mayor. The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the
TIF Committee and shall be the Chief Administrative Officer of the TIF
District. The TIF Committee shall:
      1.   Foster communications between staff and the Village Board to
expedite the efficient approval of TIF Assistance Applications that meet the
Village's stated goals as expressed in the redevelopment plan and in adopted
policies.
      2.   Be a two-way communications conduit between staff and the Board of
Trustees for the continuing development and implementation of policies
pertaining to TIF marketing, development, and project monitoring.
      3.   Develop, with the assistance of staff, and to the extent possible,
uniform reporting formats on matters to be reported to the committee and to the
Village Board.
      4.   Additional duties and responsibilities of the TIF Committee shall
be:
         a.   Recommend to the Mayor and Board of Trustees staffing levels and
staff assistance needed by the committee to properly perform its duties and
responsibilities.
         b.   Review redevelopment project proposals and redevelopment project
progress within the redevelopment area; the committee should be prepared to
report on any significant issues at a Board of Trustees meeting and shall
otherwise keep the Mayor and Board of Trustees informed of the activities of
the TIF Committee.
         c.   Review and qualify, with the assistance of staff, all
applications for redevelopment project financial assistance for presentation
and recommendations to the Board of Trustees for final decision on any
redevelopment project assistance request.
         d.   Work with staff in analyzing and then recommending to the Board
of Trustees changes, modifications or revisions to the Village policies,
procedures, and forms pertaining to the implementation of the redevelopment
plan.
         e.   Review and recommend to the Board of Trustees contracts with
consultants and inter-governmental agreements pertaining to the implementation
of the redevelopment project plan.
         f.   Such other redevelopment project area related assignments as may
be referred to the TIF Committee by the Mayor or Board of Trustees.
      5.   Regular meetings of the TIF Committee shall be held concurrently
with the first Committee of the Whole meeting of each month but may, for good
cause, be scheduled to another date during any month upon the determination of
the Mayor. Additional meetings may be scheduled as needed for the business of
the TIF Committee. All TIF Committee meetings are subject to the requirements
of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. (Ord. 2019-O-12, 5-22-2019)
1-6-7: RULES OF ORDER, PROCEDURE:
1-6-7-1: ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER:
The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest published edition
of "Robert's Rules of Order" shall govern the Board in all cases to which they
are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with the special rules of
this Board, or in conflict with any of the rules and regulations contained
within this section
1-6-7. (Ord. 60-05, 5-23-1960; amd. Ord. 80-06, 5-28-1980)
1-6-7-2: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The order of business of the Board shall be as follows:
   1.   Call to order by President or Clerk;
   2.   Roll call, establish quorum;
   3.   Prayer;
   4.   Presentation and approval of minutes of previous meeting;
   5.   Report of President;
   6.   Reports of standing committees;
   7.   Reports of special committees;
   8.   Reports of boards and commissions;
   9.   Communications, petitions, resolutions, orders, ordinances, bills;
   10.   Old business;
   11.   Public discussion or comments from the floor;
   12.   New business;
   13.   Adjournment.
(Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-6-7-3: DUTIES OF PRESIDING OFFICER:
The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum and may speak to points
of order in preference to other members, and shall decide all questions of
order subject to appeal. In case of any disturbances or disorderly conduct, the
presiding officer shall have the power to require the chamber to be cleared.
(Ord. 60-05, 3-23-60)
1-6-7-4: DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
While the presiding officer is putting the question, no member shall walk
across or out of the council chamber. Every member, previous to speaking,
making a motion or seconding the same, shall address himself to the presiding
officer and say: "Mr. President", and shall not proceed with his remarks until
recognized and named by the Chair. He shall confine himself to the question
under debate, avoiding personalities and refraining from impugning the motives
of any other member's argument or vote. When two (2) or more members rise at
the same time, the presiding officer shall name the member who is first to
speak. (Ord. 60-05, 3-23-60)
1-6-7-5: VISITORS:
No person other than a member of the Board of Trustees shall address that body,
except with the consent of a majority of the members present. (Ord. 60-05, 3-
23-60)
1-6-7-6: PROCEDURE:
   A.   Presentation of New Business: When a member wishes to present a
communication, petition, order, resolution, ordinance or other original matter,
he shall send it to the desk of the Clerk who shall read such matter when
reached in its proper order.
   B.   Debate: No member shall speak more than once on the same question,
except by unanimous consent, and then not until every other member desiring to
speak shall have had an opportunity to do so; provided, however, that the
proponent of the matter under consideration or the chairman of the committee
whose report is under consideration, as the case may be, shall have the right
to open and close debate. No member shall speak longer than ten (10) minutes at
any one time, except by consent of the Board; and in closing debate on any
question, as above provided, the speaker shall be limited to five (5) minutes,
except by special consent of the Board. While a member is speaking, no member
shall hold any private discussion, nor pass between the speaker and the Chair.
   C.   Call of Members to Order: A member, when called to order by the Chair,
shall thereupon discontinue speaking and take his seat and the order or ruling
of the Chair shall be binding and conclusive, subject only to the right of
appeal.
   D.   Appeals from Decisions of the Chair: Any member may appeal to the Board
of Trustees from a ruling of the Chair and, if the appeal is seconded, the
member making the appeal may briefly state his reason for the same, and the
Chair may briefly explain his ruling; but there shall be no debate on the
appeal and no other member shall participate in the discussion. The Chair shall
then put the question. "Shall the decision of the Chair be sustained?" If a
majority of the members present vote "No", the decision of the Chair shall be
overruled; otherwise, it shall be sustained.
   E.   Question of Personal Privilege: The right of a member to address the
Board on a question of personal privilege shall be limited to cases in which
his integrity, character or motives are assailed, questioned or impugned.
   F.   Voting: Every member who shall be present when a question is stated
from the Chair shall vote thereon, unless excused by the Board, or unless he is
personally interested in the question, in which case he shall not vote.
   G.   Special Order of Business: Any matter before the Board may be set down
as a special order of business at a time certain if two-thirds (2/3%) of the
Trustees present vote in the affirmative, but not otherwise.
   H.   Seconding of Motions Required, Written Motions: No motion shall be put
or debated in the Board of Trustees or in committee unless it be seconded. When
a motion is seconded, it shall be stated by the presiding officer before a
debate, and every motion in the Board of Trustees, except motions of procedure,
shall be reduced to writing, if required by a member, and the proposer of the
motion shall be entitled to the floor.
   I.   Withdrawal of Motions: After a motion or resolution is stated by the
presiding officer, it shall be deemed to be in possession of the Board, but it
may be withdrawn at any time before decision, by consent of the Board.
   J.   Division of Questions: If any question under consideration contains
several distinct propositions, the Board by a majority vote of the members
present may divide such question.
   K.   Record of Motions: In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered
in the Journal, the name of the member moving the same shall be entered also,
as well as the name of the member seconding the same.
   L.   Taking, Entering the Votes; Explanations of Votes not Permitted: The
yeas and nays upon any question shall be taken and entered in the Journal. When
the Clerk has commenced to call the roll of the Board of Trustees for the
taking of a vote by yeas and nays all debate on the question before the Board
shall be deemed concluded and during the taking of the vote no member shall be
permitted to explain his vote but shall respond to the calling of his name by
the Clerk by answering yea or nay, as the case may be.
   M.   Announcement, Changes of Votes: The result of all votes by yeas and
nays shall not be announced by the Clerk, but shall be handed by him to the
chairman for announcement, and no vote shall be changed after the tally list
has passed from the hands of the Clerk.
   N.   Precedence of Motions: When a question is under debate, the following
motions shall be in order and shall have precedence over each other in order,
as listed:
      1.   To adjourn to a day certain;
      2.   To adjourn;
      3.   To take a recess;
      4.   To lay on the table;
      5.   The previous question;
      6.   To refer;
      7.   To amend
      8.   To defer or postpone to a time certain;
      9.   To defer or postpone (without reference to time);
      10.   To defer or postpone indefinitely;
Numbers 2, 4, and 5 are to be decided without debate.
   O.   Motions to Adjourn: A motion to adjourn the Board of Trustees meeting
shall always be in order except:
      1.   When a member is in possession of the floor;
      2.   While the yeas and nays are being called;
      3.   When the members are voting;
      4.   When adjournment was the last preceding motion; and
      5.   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
A motion simply to adjourn shall not be subject to amendment or debate, but a
motion to adjourn to a time certain shall be. The Board may at any time adjourn
over one or more regular meetings, on a vote of a majority of all the Trustees
authorized by law to be elected.
   P.   Previous Question: When the previous question is moved on the main
question, and seconded, it shall be put in this form: "Shall the main question
now be put?" If such motion be carried, all further amendment and all further
motions and debate shall be excluded, and the question put without delay, upon
the pending amendments in proper order, and then upon the main question.
   Q.   Motions to Lay on the Table and to Take from the Table:
      1.   A motion simply to lay a question on the table shall not be
debatable, but a motion to lay on the table and publish, or with any other
condition, shall be subject to amendment and debate.
      2.   A motion to take any motion or other proposition from the table may
be proposed at the same meeting at which such motion or proposition was laid
upon the table, provided two-thirds (2/3) of the Trustees vote therefor.
      3.   A motion to lay any particular motion or proposition on the table
shall apply to that motion or proposition only.
      4.   An amendment to the main question or other pending question may be
laid on the table and neither the main question nor such other pending question
shall be affected thereby.
   R.   Indefinite Postponement, Motion to Defer or Postpone without Reference
to Time: When consideration of a motion or other proposition is postponed
indefinitely, it shall not again be taken up at the same meeting. A motion to
postpone indefinitely shall not open the main question to debate. A motion to
defer or postpone, without any reference to time, shall not be construed as a
motion to postpone indefinitely, but shall be considered to be of the same
general nature, and to possess the same general attributes so far as applicable
under these rules, as a motion to postpone indefinitely or to a time certain.
   S.   Motion to Refer: A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take
precedence over a similar motion to refer to a special committee.
   T.   Motion to Amend: A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but
one to amend an amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained. An
amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order, but an
amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order. On an
amendment to "strike out and insert", the paragraph to be amended shall first
be read as it stands, then the words proposed to be stricken out, then those to
be inserted, and finally the paragraph as it will stand if so amended shall be
read. An amendment to the main question or other pending question may be
referred to a committee and neither the main question nor such other pending
question shall be affected thereby.
   U.   Filling of Blanks: When a blank is to be filled and different sums or
times proposed, the question shall be taken first on the least sum or the
longest time.
   V.   Motion to Substitute: A substitute for any original proposition under
debate or for any pending amendment to such proposition may be entertained
notwithstanding that at such time further amendment is admissible; and if
accepted by the Board of Trustees by vote shall entirely supersede such
original proposition or amendment, as the case may be, and cut off all
amendments appertaining thereto.
   W.   Reconsideration: A vote or a question may be reconsidered at any time
during the same meeting, or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A
motion for reconsideration, having been once made and decided in the negative,
shall not be renewed, nor shall a motion to reconsider be reconsidered. A
motion to reconsider must be made and seconded by members who voted on the
prevailing side of the question to be reconsidered, unless otherwise provided
by law; provided, however, that where a motion has received a majority vote in
the affirmative, but is declared lost solely on the ground that a greater
number of affirmative votes is required by statute for the passage or adoption
of such motion, then in such case a motion to reconsider may be made and
seconded only by those who voted in the affirmative on such question to be
reconsidered. (Ord. 60-05, 3-23-60)
1-6-8: RESCINDED ACTION:
No vote or action of the Board shall be rescinded at any special meeting unless
there be present at such special meeting as many members of the Board of
Trustees as were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken.
1-6-9: SUSPENSION OF RULES:
The rules of order, other than those prescribed by statute, may be suspended at
any time by the consent of a majority of the corporate authorities. (Ord. 80-
06, 5-28-80)
1-6-10: DISORDERLY CONDUCT OF MEMBERS; CENSURE, EXPULSION:
Any member acting or appearing in a lewd or disgraceful manner, or who uses
approprious, obscene or insulting language to or about any member of the Board,
or who does not obey the order of the Chair, shall be, on motion, censured by a
majority vote of the members present, or expelled by a two- thirds (2/3) vote
of all members elected. (Ord. 60-05, 3-23-60)
CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-7-1: Appointment, Term of Office
1-7-2: Bond
1-7-3: Salary
1-7-4: Duties
1-7-5: Records
1-7-6: Monies Received
1-7-7: Vouchers
1-7-8: Vacancy in Office
1-7-9: Deputy Clerk
1-7-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village Clerk shall be appointed by the Village President with the
concurrence of the Village Board. The Village Clerk shall be appointed for a
term concurrent with the term of the Village President; provided, that the
appointment may be terminated by majority vote of the Village Board. (Ord. 92-
25, 10-31-92, eff. 5-1-93)
1-7-2: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of office, the Clerk shall execute a bond as
required in Section
1-8-6 of this Code. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-7-3: SALARY:
The compensation of the Village Clerk shall be fixed by the corporate
authorities 1 . (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  1-8-7B of this Code.
1-7-4: DUTIES:
   A.   Corporate Seal: The Clerk shall keep the Corporate Seal, to be provided
under the direction of the corporate authorities, and all papers belonging to
the Village. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
   B.   Journal, Records: The Clerk shall attend all meetings of the President
and Board of Trustees and keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal.
Within not more than ten (10) days after each meeting of the Board, the Clerk
shall supply to each member at his residence a copy of the proceedings. The
Clerk shall keep copies of all papers duly filed in the Village Clerk's office.
Transcripts from the journal and other records and files of the Village Clerk's
office, certified by the Clerk under the Corporate Seal, shall be evidence in
all courts in like manner as if the originals were produced. The Clerk shall
keep a full index of the journal, keeping the same up-to-date from month to
month. (Ord. 60-05, 3-23-60; amd. Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
   C.   Additional Duties: The Clerk shall in addition to the above, as imposed
upon that officer by law, perform the following duties:
      1.   Issue notices to the members and to all officers of the Board of
Trustees and other persons, when directed to do so by the Board, or the
chairman of any committee of said Board, and whenever required by law.
      2.   Attest to all documents required to be signed by the President.
      3.   Without delay, deliver to the officers of the Village and to all
committees of said Board, all resolutions and communications referred to those
officers or committees by the Board and, without delay, deliver to the
President of said Village all ordinances or resolutions under his charge, which
may require to be approved or otherwise acted upon by the President, with all
papers on which the same were founded.
      4.   Within five (5) days after the result of any election is declared or
appointment is made, notify such person so elected or appointed to any Village
office of his election or appointment, and unless such person shall qualify
respectively within ten (10) days after such notice, the office shall become
vacant and the Clerk shall notify the President and Board of Trustees.
      5.   File with the County Clerk of Lake County, Illinois, a certified
copy of the Tax Levy Ordinance, in which the total amount of appropriations for
all corporate purposes of the Village are levied and assessed as provided in
the statutes 1 . (Ord. 88-11, 5-25-88)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/8-3-1 et seq.
1-7-5: RECORDS:
In addition to the record of ordinances 1  and other records which the Clerk is
required by statute 3 to keep, he or the Village Collector, as designated by
the corporate authorities shall keep a register of all licenses and permits
issued, and the payments thereon; a record showing all of the officers and
regular employees of the Village; and such other records as may be required by
the corporate authorities. The Clerk shall file and preserve in convenient form
for reference and use, according to date of filing and subject matter, all
official bonds, oaths of office, written reports of officers and committees,
vouchers and all papers and documents filed with him or deposited in his care,
and promptly turn over the same to his successor in office, taking a receipt
therefor. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
The Clerk shall provide copies of any ordinance, resolution, regulation,
minutes of meetings, or other public document in the Clerk's care and
possession upon request by any person. Such copies shall be delivered
reasonably promptly during regular business hours after payment of such copy
fees as may be established from time to time by resolution of the Board of
Trustees 3 . (Ord. 88-11, 5-25-88)
 
Notes
1 2. See Section
  1-9-5 of this Code.
3 3. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-10-7, 5/3-10-8.
  1. See Sections
3 1-9-6 and
  7-3-8-3 of this Code.
1-7-6: MONIES RECEIVED:
The Clerk shall turn over all money received by him on behalf of the Village to
the Village Treasurer promptly upon receipt of the same, and with such money
the Clerk shall give a statement as to the source thereof. The Clerk shall keep
accounts showing all money received by said Clerk and the source and
disposition thereof, and such other accounts as may be required by statute or
ordinance. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-7-7: VOUCHERS:
The Clerk shall issue vouchers or orders to the Treasurer. No voucher shall be
issued unless ordered by a majority of the corporate authorities by roll call
vote at a regular or special meeting duly convened. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-7-8: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
In case the office of Village Clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the
corporate authorities shall appoint a successor as is provided by statute 1 .
(Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
 
Notes
1 2. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-7-1, 5/3-8-1.
1-7-9: DEPUTY CLERK:
The Clerk may appoint a Deputy, by and with the consent of the corporate
authorities who, in the temporary absence of the Clerk, in case of sickness, or
otherwise, shall be empowered to perform all, or specifically designated duties
of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
