1-8-1: VILLAGE TREASURER:
1-8-1-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Treasurer who shall be appointed
by the President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, as is
provided by statute 1 . He shall serve for one year, and until his successor
shall have been appointed and shall qualify. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-8-1.
1-8-1-2: BOND:
The Village Treasurer shall give a bond, before entering upon his duties, in an
amount not less than that required in Section
1-8-6 of this Chapter. This bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful
performance by the Treasurer of his duties and shall be conditioned to
indemnify the Village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act
of the Treasurer. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80)
1-8-1-3: DUTIES:
The Treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute
or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the Village either directly
from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or
employee who may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or
orders properly signed by the Clerk. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80)
1-8-1-4: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
The Treasurer shall deposit the Village funds in such depositories as may be
selected from time to time as is provided by law 1 , and he shall keep the
deposit of the Village money separate and distinct from his own money, and
shall not make private or personal use of any Village money. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-
80)
 
Notes
1 2. See Title 2, Chapter 2 of this Code.
1-8-1-5: RECORDS:
The Treasurer shall keep the records showing all money received by him, showing
the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid, and
he shall keep accurate records at all times showing the financial status of the
Village. The Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by
ordinance, and shall keep them in the manner required by the corporate
authorities. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80)
1-8-1-6: REPORTS:
The Treasurer shall make a monthly report to the corporate authorities showing
the receipts and disbursements during the month previous, and the state and
condition of every account not closed on his books. He shall also make an
annual report, during the last month of the fiscal year, showing all the
activities of his office. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80)
1-8-2: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
1-8-2-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Administrator who shall be
appointed by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The Village Administrator shall be appointed for a term concurrent
with the term of the Village President. The Administrator shall be subject to
removal at any time by a majority vote of the corporate authorities. (Ord. 93-
22, 4-28-93)
1-8-2-2: BOND:
The Village Administrator shall give a bond, before entering upon his duties,
as provided by the terms of, and in an amount not less than that required in
Section
1-8-6 of this Chapter. This bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful
performance by the Administrator of his duties, and shall be conditioned to
indemnify the Village for any loss by reason of the neglect of duty or any act
of the Administrator. (Ord. 93-22, 4-28-93)
1-8-2-3: DUTIES:
The Village Administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the
Village, subordinate only to the Village President. He shall perform all of the
administrative duties of the Village President as directed by and under the
supervision of the Village President, including directing and supervising the
activities of all other appointed officers and employees of the Village. In
addition, he shall perform the following specific duties:
   A.   The Administrator shall perform the duties set forth in the statutes of
the State for the office of Village Collector 1 , including but not limited to
the following:
      1.   Collect all monies due to the Village under any and all special
assessments, license fees, special taxes of any kind, or any other sums to be
received by or be collected by the Village as authorized by the Village
authorities, except such sums as may be paid over directly to the Village
Treasurer.
      2.   Turn over all money received by him on behalf of the Village
promptly upon receipt thereof to the Village Treasurer, and give therewith a
statement as to the source thereof.
      3.   To keep accounts of all monies received and the source and
disposition thereof and such other accounts as the Village authorities may
direct, and to make a detailed monthly report to the Village Board of the
accounts, and an annual report in the last month of the fiscal year showing all
collection activities.
   B.   The Administrator shall be the ex officio comptroller of the Village
and shall perform the duties set forth in the statutes of the State for said
office 2 .
   C.   The Administrator shall be the official purchasing agent for the
Village 3 , and shall perform the following duties:
      1.   Whenever directed by the Village Board, obtain and provide
information, along with his recommendations, concerning the cost and quality of
any items which the Village proposes to purchase or lease.
      2.   When authorized by the Village Board, purchase or otherwise contract
for acquisition of such items on the best terms and price available.
   D.   The Administrator shall attend all meetings of the Village Board, and
such Board committee meetings, Plan Commission meetings and hearings, and
Zoning Board hearings as the Village Board may direct.
   E.   The Administrator shall conduct Village business at the Village office
during regular business hours as may be established from time to time by the
Village Board.
   F.   The Administrator shall perform all such additional duties as may from
time to time be assigned to him by action of the Village Board. (Ord. 93-22, 4-
28-1993)
   G.   The Administrator is authorized to execute all contracts, work orders,
change orders, and other agreements (hereinafter "contracts") which are
specifically authorized by the Village Board. Without specific Village Board
approval, the Administrator may execute contracts for routine day-by-day
Village operations in accordance with the limitations hereinafter set forth.
      1.   Contracts for routine operation and maintenance activities
specifically included in the approved fiscal budget up to the amounts provided
in the budget for each activity, and for other routine activities not specified
in the budget up to three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
      2.   Contracts for professional services of engineers, attorneys,
foresters, and other professionals usually retained by the Village for specific
services not included in the budget up to three thousand dollars ($3,000.00).
      3.   Contracts for inspection services, etc., when petitioner, developer
or builder has deposited funds with Village to cover the cost thereof.
   H.   In case of accident, disaster, or other circumstances creating a public
emergency, the Administrator, for the purpose of meeting the emergency, may
contract for work or purchases up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) without
further authorization, and for an additional ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
with the verbal approval of the President of the Board of Trustees, or in his
absence, the verbal approval of two (2) Trustees. (Ord. 96-07, 4-24-1996)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-11-25 et seq.
2 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-11-21 et seq.
3 2. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/3-6-4.
1-8-2-4: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the Village Administrator shall be established from time to
time by the Village Board by ordinance or in the annual appropriation
ordinance. The compensation of the Village Administrator for the fiscal year
beginning May 1, 1996, and until revised by the Village Board shall be two
thousand seven hundred ninety dollars ($2,790.00) per month and shall be
payable during any vacation period which the Village Board may approve. (Ord.
96-14, 6-26-1996)
1-8-3: VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
1-8-3-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Attorney. The Village Attorney
shall be appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The appointment of a Village Attorney may be either of an individual
attorney or of a professional corporation from which one or more individual
attorney members may be designated to perform the duties of Village Attorney
with the consent of the Board of Trustees. The Village Attorney shall be
subject to removal at any time by a majority vote of the corporate authorities.
(Ord. 96-03, 3-20-1996)
1-8-3-2: LEGAL ADVISOR:
The Village Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the Village and shall render
advice on all legal questions affecting it, whenever requested to do so by any
Village official. Upon request by the President or by the Board, he shall
reduce any such opinion to writing. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-1980)
1-8-3-3: DUTIES:
   A.   Judgments: It shall be the duty of the Village Attorney to see to the
full enforcement of all judgments or decrees rendered or entered in favor of
the Village and of all similar interlocutory orders.
   B.   Special Assessments: It shall be the duty of the Village Attorney to
see to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation
proceedings. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80)
1-8-3-4: SUITS AND ACTIONS:
The Attorney shall, when directed by the Board, prosecute or defend any and all
suits or actions at law or equity to which the Village may be a party, or in
which it may be interested, or which may be brought against, or by, any officer
of the Village on behalf of the Village or in the capacity of such person as an
officer of the Village. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-8-3-5: FEE SCHEDULE:
   A.   Monthly retainer as established from time to time by corporate
authorities, which:
      1.   Covers and includes:
         a.   Time at regular monthly Village Board meetings and occasional
special or adjourned Board meetings; and
         b.   Preparation of regular ordinances and resolutions based upon
materials and rough drafts supplied by Board members and committees; and
         c.   Submitting general advice and information on legal matters of
general interest to Village;
      2.   But does not cover and excludes:
         a.   Time attending committee or commission meetings; and
         b.   Time or expenses in prosecuting or defending all suits or actions
at law or equity; and
         c.   All extraordinary (unusually complex, lengthy or comprehensive)
ordinances or resolutions or written reports; and
         d.   All ordinances, resolutions, reports, negotiations, drafts,
investigations and other legal work not on behalf of Board, including but not
limited to, work required to plan and approve annexations, subdivisions, land
plans, building projects and other matters benefitting specific private owners;
and
         e.   Special assessments and condemnation proceedings.
   B.   Additional time at sixty five dollars ($65.00) per hour (to be adjusted
to market increases). Whenever any work required by the corporate authorities
requires additional time charges and specific or general authorization has not
been given for such charges, the Attorney shall notify the corporate
authorities or the Village President of the estimated proposed charges and not
proceed unless authorized by the corporate authorities or the Village
President. (Ord. 80-06, 8-28-80; 1988 Code)
1-8-3-6: SPECIAL COUNSEL:
The President may, by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees,
from time to time, retain an attorney to represent or advise the Village on
legal matters if no Village Attorney has been appointed. He may likewise retain
special counsel to advise or represent the Village on special matters or to
assist the Village Attorney.
1-8-4: VILLAGE MARSHALL:
1-8-4-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Marshall. The Village Marshall
shall be appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees, for a period of one year and until his successor shall have been
appointed and shall qualify. He shall be subject to removal at any time by a
majority vote of the corporate authorities at any regular or special meeting
called in accordance with the law.
1-8-4-2: QUALIFICATIONS FOR OFFICE:
No person shall be qualified for the office of Village Marshall if he has ever
been convicted of a felony or any other crime involving moral turpitude.
1-8-4-3: BOND:
The Village Marshall, before entering upon his duties, shall file with the
Village Clerk a bond as required in Section
1-8-6 of this Chapter with sureties to be approved by the Board, conditioned to
indemnify the Village for any loss or liability due to or occasioned by any act
or failure to act on the part of the Village Marshall.
1-8-4-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Village Marshall shall have the power:
   A.   To arrest or cause to be arrested, with or without process, all persons
who break the peace, or are found violating any Municipal ordinance or any
criminal law of the State.
   B.   To commit arrested persons for examination.
   C.   If necessary, to detain arrested persons in custody overnight or Sunday
in any safe place, or until they can be brought before the proper court.
   D.   To exercise all other powers as conservators of the peace that the
corporate authorities may prescribe.
It shall be the duty of the Village Marshall to see to the enforcement of all
ordinances of the Village and the statutes applicable thereto and to preserve
order and prevent infractions of the law and arrest violators thereof. It shall
be his duty to conduct himself in a proper and law-abiding manner at all times
and to avoid the use of unnecessary force.
1-8-4-5: WARRANTS:
All warrants for the violation of Municipal ordinances, or the State Criminal
Law 1 , to whomsoever directed, may be served and executed within the limits of
the Municipality by the Village Marshall. For this purpose, the Village
Marshall has all the common law and statutory power of sheriffs.
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 720, 725, 730 and 740 ILCS.
1-8-4-6: TRAINING:
Prior to performing any of his duties, the Village Marshall shall receive
necessary and appropriate training and course of study as determined and
provided by the corporate authorities to assure that he has adequate knowledge
of police procedure and of the use of weapons. (Ord. 80-06, 5-28-80)
1-8-5: BUILDING COMMISSIONER 1 :
 
Notes

1-8-5-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Building Commissioner. Appointment to
said office shall be made by the Village President with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees.
1-8-5-2: COMPENSATION:
The compensation, if any, of the Building Commissioner shall be established by
the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 60-08, 4-27-60)
1-8-5-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner to enforce all the provisions
of all ordinances relating to building or zoning 1  and to inspect all
buildings and structures and parts and appurtenances thereof regulated by the
Building Title which are being erected, installed or altered as frequently as
may be necessary to insure compliance with the Village ordinances. (Ord. 60-09,
5-12-60)
The Building Commissioner shall have the power and shall exercise the function
prescribed by the State law and by the terms of all ordinances now in force or
hereafter passed. (Ord. 60-08, 4-27-60)
 
Notes
1 1. See Titles 7 and 8 of this Code.
1-8-5-4: STOP WORK ORDERS:
The Building Commissioner shall have the power to order all work stopped on
construction, installation, alteration or repair of buildings and structures,
and parts and appurtenances thereof regulated by the Building Title in the
Village when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any
ordinance relating thereto, or in violation of the Zoning Title. Work shall not
be resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written permission
of the Commissioner, provided, that if the stop order is an oral one, it shall
be followed by a written stop order within two (2) hours. Such written stop
order may be served by the Building Commissioner. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-60; 1988
Code)
1-8-5-5: RIGHT OF ENTRY POWERS:
The Building Commissioner shall have the power to make or cause to be made an
entry into any building or premises where the work of altering, installing,
repairing or constructing any building and structure and parts and
appurtenances thereof regulated by the Building Title is going on for the
purpose of making inspections at any reasonable hour. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-60)
1-8-5-6: ASSISTANTS:
Such assistants as may be needed and qualified may also be appointed by the
Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, and
they shall be under the supervision and control of the Building Commissioner.
They shall be empowered to act in place of the Building Commissioner. (Ord. 60-
09, 5-12-60; 1988 Code)
1-8-6: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Amount of Bonds: Before entering upon the duties of their respective
offices, Village officers shall execute and deliver a bond with security, to be
approved by the corporate authorities of the Village. The bond shall be payable
to the Village unless otherwise provided by law, in the following sums and
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of their offices and
the payment of all sums received by such officers, according to law and also
the ordinances of the Village:
 
Village President 1         $ 3,000.00
Village Administrator 2      5,000.00
Village Clerk 3             2,000.00
Village Treasurer 4         50,000.00
Village Marshall 5          2,000.00
 
The bond so required may provide that the obligation of the sureties shall not
extend to any loss sustained by the insolvency, failure, or closing of any
bank. The Board of Trustees shall have the right to demand a new or larger bond
or further and additional sureties from time to time as in its opinion may be
necessary for the protection of the Village. If the original bond filed by an
officer shall not be approved, or having been approved by the Board of
Trustees, a new or larger bond or further and additional sureties shall be
required, notice thereof shall be given to the officer, whereupon he shall,
within ten (10) days after receipt of notice, file a bond satisfactory to the
Board of Trustees. Failure to file a satisfactory bond within said ten (10)
days shall create a vacancy in the office involved. (Ord. 93-22, 4-28-93)
   B.   Type of Security: Security may be provided either by personal or
corporate surety. If security is provided by a corporate surety, only one
surety shall be required and any company duly authorized to do surety business
in the State of Illinois shall be sufficient. If security is provided by
personal surety, two (2) sureties shall be required. A personal surety may be
any elector residing within the Village owning property having a value at least
equal to the face amount of the bond. If a bond is executed by a surety or
sureties as provided in this subsection, the requirement as to the approval of
the corporate authorities as to the security of the bond shall have been deemed
satisfied.
   C.   Filing: The bonds herein provided for shall be filed with the Village
Clerk, unless otherwise provided by law. (Ord. 60-01, 3-5-60)

1-8-7: COMPENSATION OF ELECTED OFFICIALS:
   A.   Village President: The Village President shall receive an annual
compensation of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per year, payable in monthly
installments. (Ord. 87-03, 3-25-87)
   B.   Village Clerk: The Village Clerk shall receive compensation of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for each regular or officially called special meeting of the
Board of Trustees attended by the Clerk, payable monthly. Any meeting adjourned
from time to time shall not be considered to be a separate meeting for the
purposes of determining such compensation. (Ord. 93-22, 4-28-93)
   C.   Village Trustees: The Village Trustees shall each receive compensation
of forty dollars ($40.00) for each regular or officially called special meeting
of the Board of Trustees attended by the Trustee, payable monthly. Any meeting
adjourned from time to time shall not be considered to be a separate meeting
for the purposes of determining such compensation. (Ord. 87-03, 3-25-87)
1-8-8: CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
1-8-8-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Code Enforcement Officer. Appointment to
said office shall be made by the Village President with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 89-02, 2-22-89)
1-8-8-2: COMPENSATION:
The compensation, if any, of the Code Enforcement Officer shall be established
by the Board of Trustees by resolution. (Ord. 89-02, 2-22-89)
1-8-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Code Enforcement Officer to enforce all the
provisions of all of the ordinances of the Village other than the building and
zoning ordinances, traffic control ordinances and any other ordinances
specifically designated as the enforcement responsibility of others. He shall
have such other powers and duties as the Board of Trustees may establish from
time to time.
1-8-8-4: RIGHT OF ENTRY POWERS:
The Code Enforcement Officer shall have the power at any reasonable hour to
make or cause to be made an entry upon any premises or into any building where
he has been reliably informed or reasonably believes that a violation of the
ordinances of the Village has been or is being committed.
1-8-8-5: ASSISTANTS:
The Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, may
appoint such assistants to the Code Enforcement Officer as may be needed. Such
assistants shall be under the supervision and control of the Code Enforcement
Officer and shall be empowered to act in the place of the Code Enforcement
Officer. (Ord. 89-02, 2-22-89)
1-8-9: VILLAGE SUPERINTENDENT:
1-8-9-1: OFFICE CREATED, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of Village Superintendent. Appointment to
said office shall be made by the Village President with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees.
1-8-9-2: COMPENSATION:
The compensation, if any, of the Village Superintendent shall be established by
the Board of Trustees by resolution.
1-8-9-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Village Superintendent to perform or to supervise,
as the case may be, all maintenance and construction work to be performed by
the Village to operate and maintain its roads, sewers, drainage structures,
public facilities and improvements, and other properties as required by the
ordinances of the Village. He shall have such other powers and duties as the
Board of Trustees may establish from time to time.
1-8-9-4: RIGHT OF ENTRY POWERS:
The Village Superintendent shall have the power at any reasonable hour to make
or cause to be made an entry upon any premises or into any building where he
reasonably believes that such access is necessary for him to perform his
duties.
1-8-9-5: ASSISTANTS:
The Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, may
appoint such assistants to the Village Superintendent as may be needed. Such
assistants shall be under the supervision and control of the Village
Superintendent and shall be empowered to act in the place of the Village
Superintendent. (Ord. 89-06, 4-26-89)
CHAPTER 9
ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS
SECTION:
1-9-1: Submission to, Action by Board of Trustees
1-9-2: Passage of Ordinances
1-9-3: Ordinance Approval, Veto
1-9-4: Publication, Time of Taking Effect
1-9-5: Record of Ordinances
1-9-6: Fees for Copies
1-9-1: SUBMISSION TO, ACTION BY BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
Any ordinance or resolution submitted to the Board of Trustees shall be reduced
to writing before being voted upon on the request of any member of the Board.
All ordinances shall first be read aloud at an open meeting on a day prior to
the meeting at which it is placed upon the agenda of the Board of Trustees for
vote upon its passage. No ordinance may be voted upon without such first
reading on a prior day unless this rule is suspended as provided in Section
1-6-9 of this Code. (Ord. 81-07, 2-25-81)
1-9-2: PASSAGE OF ORDINANCES:
The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all ordinances and on all
propositions to create any liability against the Village, or for the
expenditure or appropriation of its money, and in all other cases at the
request of any member of the Board, and such vote shall be entered on the
journal of the proceedings, as is provided by statute 1 . (Ord. 60-05, 5-23-60)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1 et seq.
1-9-3: ORDINANCE APPROVAL, VETO:
All ordinances passed by the Board shall, before they take effect, be deposited
with the Village Clerk, and if the President approves thereof, he shall sign
the same, and such as he shall not approve he shall return to the Board with
his objections thereto in writing at the next regular meeting occurring not
less than five (5) days after the passage thereof. Such veto may extend to any
one or more items or appropriations contained in any ordinance making an
appropriation, or to the entire ordinance; and in case the veto only extends to
a part of such ordinance, the residue thereof shall take effect and be in
force. But in case the President shall fail to return any ordinance, with his
objections thereto by the time aforesaid, he shall be deemed to have approved
such ordinances and the same shall take effect accordingly. Upon the return of
any ordinance by the President, the vote by which the same was passed shall be
reconsidered by the Board of Trustees. If after such reconsideration two-thirds
(2/3) of all the members elected to the Board shall agree by yeas and nays to
pass the same, it shall go into effect notwithstanding that the President may
refuse to approve thereof. (Ord. 60-05, 5-23-60)
1-9-4: PUBLICATION, TIME OF TAKING EFFECT:
All ordinances imposing any penalty for a violation thereof or making any
appropriation shall be published as is required by statute 1 . No ordinance
which must be published to comply with the foregoing sentence shall go into
effect until ten (10) days after it is so published, and all other ordinances
shall go into effect upon the passage thereof, as is provided by statute. (Ord.
60-05, 5-23-60)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-4.
1-9-5: RECORD OF ORDINANCES:
The Clerk shall keep a record of all ordinances passed in an ordinance book for
such purpose. (Ord. 60-05, 5-23-60)
1-9-6: FEE FOR COPIES 1 :
Fees pertaining to requests for copies of ordinances of the Village, not within
themselves containing a fee schedule, shall be as follows for purchase of said
ordinance:
 
5 pages or less $1.00
6-10 pages      2.00
Over 10 pages   0.20 per page
 
(Ord. 66-06, 9-28-66)
 
Notes
1 2. See also Section
  7-3-8-3 of this Code for fees for ordinances relating to building.

SECTION:
1-10A-1: Commission Created

1-10A-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created a Combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals
for the Village pursuant to State law.  1 ,  2 . (Ord. 60-04, 3-5-60; amd. Ord.
2022-O-12, 9-28-2022)
 
Notes
1    S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq.
2    S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq.
1-10A-2: MEMBERSHIP, ORGANIZATION:
The Plan Commission hereby created shall consist of a chairman and six (6)
other members to be appointed by the President, with the consent of the Board
of Trustees. In addition, the Village President shall be a member ex officio of
the Commission. (Ord. 68-02, 5-22-68)
The chairman, by and with the consent of the members of the Commission, shall
appoint one of the members or the Village Clerk to act as secretary of the Plan
Commission who shall keep a record of its proceedings in an appropriate
journal. A majority of the full membership of the Plan Commission shall
constitute a quorum to do business and all action of the Commission at which a
quorum is present shall be controlled by a majority vote of those present. The
chairman shall be the presiding officer of the Commission and shall be entitled
to vote on all matters in the same manner as any other member of the
Commission. (Ord. 60-04, 3-5-60; 1988 Code)
1-10A-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
   A.   The Combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals hereby created
and shall consist of a chairman and six (6) other members to be appointed by
the President, with the consent of the Board of Trustees. In addition, the
Village President shall be a member ex officio of the Commission.
   B.   The Combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals may be
referred to as "The Combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals," or
the "Plan Commission," or the "PC/ZBA," or "Zoning Board of Appeals," or
"Commission," and whatever references exist throughout this Village Code of
Ordinances to the former singular Plan Commission or former singular Zoning
Board of Appeals shall mean the Combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of
Appeals.
   C.   The chairman, by and with the consent of the members of the Commission,
shall appoint one of the members or the Village Clerk, or a member of the
Village staff, to act as secretary of the Plan Commission who shall keep a
record of its proceedings in an appropriate journal. A majority of the full
membership of the Plan Commission shall constitute a quorum to do business and
all action of the Commission at which a quorum is present shall be controlled
by a majority vote of those present. The chairman shall be the presiding
officer of the Commission and shall be entitled to vote on all matters in the
same manner as any other member of the Commission. (Ord. 60-04, 3-5-60; amd.
Ord. 2022-O-12, 9-28-2022)
1-10A-4: POWERS:
The Plan Commission shall exercise all the powers conferred and authorized by
State law and shall be governed by their provisions in determining its
purposes, duties and powers. The Plan Commission shall also exercise all the
powers and duties of the former singular Zoning Board of Appeals under Article
B of this Chapter 1-10. (Ord. 60-04, 3-5-60; 1988 Code; amd. Ord. 2022-O-12, 9-
28-2022)
1-10A-5: MEETINGS:
The Plan Commission shall hold regular meetings at such times and places as may
be determined, and special meetings of the Commission may be held upon the call
of the chairman or of any three (3) members thereof in the same manner as
provided for the calling of special meetings of the Board of Trustees 1 . All
official meetings of the Commission shall be open to the public.
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  1-6-3C of this Code.
1-10A-6: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
The Commission may adopt its own rules of procedure for the conduct of its
meetings, but such rules shall not be in conflict with any of the provisions of
this Article or any other ordinances of the Village or with any applicable
statutory requirements. (Ord. 60-04, 3-5-60)

1-10B-4: MEETINGS:
All meetings of the Combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals shall
be held at the call of the chairman or at such other times as such Board may
determine. Such chairman, or in his absence, the acting chairman, may
administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings of said
Board shall be open to the public. The Board shall keep minutes of its
proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon every question, or if absent
or failing to vote indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its
examinations and other official actions. Findings of fact shall be included in
the minutes of each case of a requested variation, specifying the reasons for
making or denying such variation. Every rule or regulation, every amendment or
repeal thereof, and every order, requirement, decision or determination of the
Board shall immediately be filed in the office of the Board and shall be a
public record. The Board shall adopt its own rules of procedure not in conflict
with the statute in such case made and provided. (Ord. 60-08, 4-27-60; amd.
Ord. 2022-O-12, 9-28-2022)

with the following jurisdiction and authority:

decision or determination made by the administrative official, charged with the
enforcement of the Zoning Title 1 or any other ordinance adopted pursuant to
State law 1 .
   B.   To hear and make recommendations to the Village Board upon applications
for variations from the regulations provided in the Zoning Title in the manner
and subject to the standards hereafter set forth; and
   C.   To hear and decide all matters referred to it or upon which it is
required to pass under the Zoning Title. (Ord. 60-08, 4-27-60; amd. Ord. 2022-
O-12, 9-28-2022)
 
Notes
1    S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq.
1-10B-6: DECISIONS:
The concurring vote of four (4) members of the Board is necessary to reverse
any order, requirement, decision or determination of an administrative
official, or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter which it is
required to pass upon under the Zoning Title, or to recommend any variation or
modification in the Zoning Title to the corporate authorities. (Ord. 60-08, 4-
27-60)
ARTICLE C. ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
1-10C-1: Findings Of Fact
1-10C-2: Title
1-10C-3: Intent
1-10C-4: Definitions
1-10C-5: Establishment; Duties
1-10C-6: Organization And Membership
1-10C-7: Appointment And Terms
1-10C-8: Rules Of Procedure
1-10C-1: FINDINGS OF FACT:
The President and Board of Trustees of the Village make the following findings
of fact:
   A.   The Village has planned its development as an essentially residential
community with a rural atmosphere, open spaces, trail systems, and other
amenities which seek to provide a desirable quality of life for the residents
of the community.
   B.   The long-term economic stability of the Village requires careful
consideration of, and precise planning for some economic diversification in the
land uses within appropriate areas of the Village, which includes consideration
of desirable light industrial and commercial land uses and the development of
appropriate mechanisms to attract desirable industrial and commercial
businesses to the Village.
   C.   In order to enhance appropriate economic activity in the Village, and
in order to improve the long-term economic stability of the Village, it is
necessary, desirable and in the public interest to facilitate and encourage the
economic development of the Village through an Economic Development Commission.
(Ord. 97-04, 4-2-1997)
1-10C-2: TITLE:
This Article may be referred to as the VILLAGE OF GREEN OAKS ECONOMIC
DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION ORDINANCE. (Ord. 97-04, 4-2-1997)
1-10C-3: INTENT:
It is the intent of this Article to promote, protect and improve the health,
safety and welfare of the citizens of the Village by fostering diversified
economic development of the local economy through the activities of an Economic
Development Commission. Such Commission shall develop and recommend adoption of
economic development plans to the President and Board of Trustees which guide,
stimulate and promote the coordinated, efficient, appropriate and beneficial
economic development of the Village in accordance with present and future needs
and resources. The Economic Development Commission shall take no action which
will serve to facilitate the transaction of specific business by any of its
members or to promote the private interests of any member or to engage in any
activities which would constitute a regular business of a kind ordinarily
carried on for profit. This Article shall be liberally construed in order to
effectively carry out the purposes hereof. (Ord. 97-04, 4-2-1997)
1-10C-4: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Article, the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:
BOARD: The corporate authority of the Village consisting of the President and
Board of Trustees.
BUSINESS PROSPECT: Any person or representative of a firm or a company actively
considering the location of a business within the Village, provided that such
person, firm or company has local, regional, national or international market
(s) for its goods, services or products.
COMMISSION: The Village of Green Oaks Economic Development Commission
established herein.
VILLAGE: The Village of Green Oaks, Lake County, Illinois. (Ord. 97-04, 4-2-
1997)
1-10C-5: ESTABLISHMENT; DUTIES:
   A.   Commission Established: The Village Economic Development Commission is
established for the purpose of establishing, developing and implementing sound
economic development programs for the Village, consisting of, among other
things, conducting research of available resources and the preparation of
industrial and commercial fact profiles to be made available to prospective
business prospects. Nothing in this Article shall be construed to alter, amend
or otherwise conflict with the powers and duties of the Village's Plan
Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals.
   B.   Duties: The Economic Development Commission shall collect information
on opportunities for business investment in the Village. The Economic
Development Commission shall prepare an economic development plan for the
Village utilizing such resources as are made available to it from private and
governmental sources. Such economic development plan shall be submitted to the
Village Board for adoption or further study. The Commission shall make
expenditures only upon the prior approval of the Village Board and the
Commission shall at all times remain strictly within the budget approved by the
Village Board for such purposes. (Ord. 97-04, 4-2-1997)
1-10C-6: ORGANIZATION AND MEMBERSHIP:
The Commission shall consist of seven (7) members who shall be appointed by the
Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The
Village President shall designate the chairperson and the vice chairperson of
the Commission. The chairperson and vice chairperson shall be designated
annually. Officers of the Commission may be appointed to successive terms.
(Ord. 97-17, 9-10-1997)
1-10C-7: APPOINTMENT AND TERMS:
   A.   All appointments of members to the Commission shall be for terms of
three (3) years, each of which shall expire on April 30, except for initial
appointments, which shall be as follows:
      1.   Two (2) members to serve until April 30, 1998 (1 year);
      2.   Two (2) members to serve until April 30, 1999 (2 years); and
      3.   Three (3) members to serve until April 30, 2000 (3 years). (Ord. 97-
17, 9-10-1997)
   B.   Any member may be appointed to successive terms on the Commission.
Vacancies shall be filled by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees, but only for the balance of the term of the vacant seat.
   C.   The Village President, with the concurrence of the Board of Trustees,
may for good cause shown remove any member of the Commission. (Ord. 97-04, 4-2-
1997)
1-10C-8: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
   A.   Adoption Of Rules: The Commission shall adopt such rules of procedure
as it deems advisable for the conduct of its business.
   B.   Meetings: The Commission shall meet as frequently as its rules of
procedure shall provide, but not less than once every month.
   C.   Records: The Commission shall maintain a record of all its proceedings,
which records shall be placed on file with the Village Clerk.
   D.   Expenses: All members of the Commission shall serve without
compensation. All expenses incurred on behalf of the Commission shall, with the
prior approval of the Village Board, be reimbursed to the person incurring such
expenses.
   E.   Reports: The Commission shall submit reports of its activities to the
Village Board as often as it shall deem necessary or at the request of the
Village Board.
   F.   Quorum: A majority of the members of the Commission shall constitute a
quorum for the purpose of conducting the business of the Commission, and the
affirmative vote of a majority of the members present shall be necessary for
any action taken by the Commission. No vacancy in the membership of the
Commission shall impair the right of a quorum to perform the duties of the
Commission. (Ord. 97-04, 4-2-1997)
CHAPTER 11
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-11-1: Annexation Hearings And Fees
1-11-1: ANNEXATION HEARINGS AND FEES:
   A.   Annexation Hearing: Whenever any person shall petition for the
annexation of territory contiguous to the village, the corporate authorities
shall conduct a hearing on the proposed annexation; provided, however, that the
hearing may be waived upon a two- thirds (2/3) vote of the corporate
authorities. (Ord. 84-03, 3-28-1984)
   B.   Fee For Annexation: The schedule of fees for annexation shall be as
follows:
 
For 1 acre or less of territory sought to be annexed          $200.00
For each additional acre from 1 to 5 acres in same parcel     200.00 per acre
For each additional acre from 6 to 20 acres in same parcel    150.00 per acre
For each additional acre in excess of 20 acres in same parcel 100.00 per acre
 
All such fees are nonrefundable if the parcel is annexed to the village;
provided, however, that the fee may be waived by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the
corporate authorities.
   C.   Annexation Hearing Costs: In addition to the fee for annexation, the
petitioner shall pay all costs and expenses incurred by the village in
connection with said hearing, including, but not limited to, publication of
notice, reporter's fees, attendance of legal counsel, and all related and
incidental expenses. (Ord. 89-23, 9-27-1989)
   D.   Annexation Cost Escrow Deposit: Petitioner shall comply with title 2,
chapter 4, "Development Fees And Costs", of this code at the time of
application, before the village considers any request for annexation. (Ord.
2012-O-10, 8-22-2012)
   E.   Time Of Payment Of Fees And Escrow Deposit: The aforesaid fees and
deposits shall be paid at the time of filing of petition with the clerk of the
village and prior to hearing thereon. (Ord. 84-03, 3-28-1984)
CHAPTER 12
INVESTMENT POLICY, VILLAGE
SECTION:
1-12-1: Scope And Objectives
1-12-2: Delegation Of Authority
1-12-3: Prudence
1-12-4: Eligible Investments
1-12-5: Other Investments
1-12-6: Cash Management
1-12-7: Collateral
1-12-8: Ethics And Conflicts Of Interest
1-12-9: Investment Diversification
1-12-10: Investment Maturity And Liquidity
1-12-11: Selection Of Financial Institutions And Dealers
1-12-12: Safekeeping
1-12-13: Internal Controls
1-12-14: Reporting
1-12-15: Policy Revisions
1-12-1: SCOPE AND OBJECTIVES:
   A.   Scope: This investment policy applies to activities of the Village of
Green Oaks (hereinafter referred to as the Village) with regard to investing
the financial assets of all funds.
   B.   Objectives: The Village's principal investment objectives are:
      1.   Preservation of capital and the protection of investment principal.
      2.   Maintenance of sufficient liquidity to meet anticipated
disbursements.
      3.   Diversification to avoid incurring unreasonable risks regarding
specific security types or individual institutions.
      4.   Attainment of a market rate of return equal to or higher than the
performance measure established by the Village Treasurer.
      5.   Conformance with all Federal, State and other legal requirements.
(Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-2: DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY:
The ultimate responsibility and authority for investment transactions involving
the Village resides with the Village Treasurer. The Village Treasurer shall be
responsible for all investment decisions' activities, and for the operation of
the Village's investment program consistent with this investment policy. (Ord.
99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-3: PRUDENCE:
The standard of prudence to be used for managing the Village's assets is the
"prudent investor rule, which states, investments shall be made with judgment
and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence,
discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs,
not for speculation, but for investment considering the probable safety of
their capital as well as the probable income to be derived". (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-
1999)
1-12-4: ELIGIBLE INVESTMENTS:
The following is a list of authorized securities which may be purchased with
assets of the Village:
   A.   U.S. Treasury obligations (T-bills, T-notes, T-bonds).
   B.   U.S. Treasury strips (book-entry U.S. Treasury securities whose coupon
has been removed).
   C.   Federal instrumentalities; the following only: Federal National
Mortgage Association (FNMA) and Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (FHLMC).
   D.   Fully collateralized repurchase agreements (collateralized with any of
the above).
   E.   Certificates of deposit of commercial banks and savings and loan
associations which are insured by the FDIC or FSLIC.
   F.   Prime commercial paper issued on U.S. corporations which has a maturity
of three (3) months or less and is rated "A-1" by Moody's, "P-1" by Standard &
Poor's, or "Duff 1+" by Duff & Phelps. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-5: OTHER INVESTMENTS:
It is the intent of the Village that the foregoing list of authorized
securities be strictly interpreted and that any deviation from this list must
be preapproved by the Village Board. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-6: CASH MANAGEMENT:
   A.   The Village's policy regarding cash management is based upon the
realization that there is a time-value to money. Temporarily idle cash may be
invested for a period of one day to an excess of one year, depending upon when
the money is needed. Accordingly, the Treasurer shall cause to be prepared
written cash management procedures, which shall include, but not be limited to,
the following:
      1.   Receipts: All monies due the Village shall be collected as promptly
as possible. Monies that are received shall be deposited in an approved
financial institution or with the Village Treasurer no later than the third
business day after receipt by the Village. Amounts that remain uncollected
after a reasonable length of time shall be subject to any available legal means
of collection.
      2.   Disbursements: Any disbursement to suppliers of goods and/or
services or to employees for salaries and wages shall be contingent upon an
available budget appropriation.
      3.   Cash Forecast: At least annually, a cash forecast shall be prepared
using expected revenue sources and items of expenditure to project cash
requirements over the fiscal year of the Village. The forecast shall be updated
periodically to identify the probable investable balances that will be
available.
      4.   Pooling Of Cash: Except for cash in certain restricted and special
accounts, the Village may pool the cash of various funds to maximize investment
earnings. Investment income will be allocated to the various funds based upon
their respective participation.
   B.   One of the objectives of the Village's cash management procedures is to
comply with the Public Funds Deposit Act 1  which states: "When such deposits
become collected funds and are not needed for immediate disbursement, they
shall be invested within two working days at prevailing rates or better". (Ord.
99-09, 4-28-1999)
 
Notes
1 1. 30 ILCS 225/1 et seq.
1-12-7: COLLATERAL:
   A.   It is the policy of the Village to require that funds on deposit in
excess of FDIC, FSLIC, or successor entity's limits be secured by some form of
collateral. High-volume checking accounts under the control of the Treasurer
shall be collateralized based upon the anticipated average balance for the
following weeks. The ratio of fair-market value of collateral to the amount of
funds secured will be reviewed quarterly and additional collateral will be
requested when the ratio declines below the level required.
   B.   The Village will accept any of the following assets as collateral,
provided that the amount of collateral pledged will be not less than one
hundred ten percent (110%) of the fair-market value of the net amount of public
funds secured; and any financial institution pledging collateral from this
Section must place required collateral securities in a restricted account at a
Federal reserve bank, a trust department of a commercial bank or with another
financial institution that is not owned or controlled by the same institution
or holding company. Collateral agreements will preclude the release of the
pledged assets without authorization from the Village, but they will allow for
an exchange of collateral of like value and security.
      1.   U.S. Government securities.
      2.   Obligations of Federal agencies.
      3.   Obligations of Federal instrumentalities.
      4.   Obligations of the State of Illinois.
      5.   Obligations of the County of Lake.
      6.   General obligation municipal bonds rated "AA" or better by Moody's
or "A" or better by Standard & Poor's.
      7.   Any other collateral identified in Illinois statutes as acceptable
for use by the Treasurer of the State of Illinois.
   C.   Pledged collateral will be held in safekeeping and evidenced by a
safekeeping agreement.
   D.   The Village may also accept any of the following assets as collateral
provided that the amount of collateral pledged will not be less than one
hundred ten percent (110%) of the market value of the net amount of the public
funds secured, except subsection D2 of this Section pertaining to mortgages
shall be one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the market value of the net
amount. The aggregate collateral from subsections D1 through D4 of this Section
should not exceed seventy five percent (75%) of the total collateral pledged
from any given institution.
      1.   Bonds, notes and other various types of securities or certificates
of indebtedness issued by taxing bodies located within Lake County.
      2.   Single-family primary residential mortgages and commercial first
mortgages secured by improved property located within Lake County with a
maximum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per pledged mortgage.
      3.   United States Government guaranteed tuition loans made to
individuals residing in or attending school in Lake County.
      4.   Small Business Administration loans generated to businesses located
within Lake County. The value of this collateral shall be only that portion of
the loan guaranteed by the Small Business Administration.
   E.   Any financial institution pledging collateral under this Section shall
supply the following reports:
      1.   A quarterly report at the end of February, May, August and October
of each year listing a description of the collateral pledged and a value for
said collateral. This report shall be signed by the president of the financial
institution and shall contain a certification that each loan listed therein is
current and up to date.
      2.   As of October 31 each year, a report from a CPA firm that does the
financial institution's audit, listing a description of the collateral pledged
and a value for each piece of collateral, a certification that each loan is
current and up to date, and a statement that the collateral is pledged only to
the Village.
      3.   Any reports submitted under subsections E1 and E2 of this Section
shall be considered exempt from public inspection under the Freedom of
Information Act. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-8: ETHICS AND CONFLICTS OF INTEREST:
Officers and employees involved in the investment process shall refrain from
personal business activity that could conflict with the proper execution and
management of the investment program, or that could impair their ability to
make impartial decisions. Employees and investment officials shall disclose any
material interests in financial institutions with which they conduct business.
They shall further disclose any personal financial/investment positions that
could be related to the performance of the investment portfolio. Employees and
officers shall refrain from undertaking personal investment transactions with
the same individual with whom business is conducted on behalf of the Village.
(Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-9: INVESTMENT DIVERSIFICATION:
It is the policy of the Village to diversify the investment instruments within
the portfolio to avoid incurring unreasonable risks inherent in overinvesting
in specific instruments, individual financial institutions and maturities. The
asset allocation in the portfolio should, however, be flexible depending upon
the outlook for the economy and the securities markets. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-10: INVESTMENT MATURITY AND LIQUIDITY:
Investments shall be limited to maturities not exceeding one year. In addition,
the weighted average maturity life of the total portfolio shall at no time
exceed one year. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-11: SELECTION OF FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS AND DEALERS:
The Village shall maintain a list of all authorized brokers/dealers and
financial institutions which are approved for investment purposes, and it shall
be the policy of the Village to purchase securities only from those authorized
institutions and firms. To be eligible for authorization, a broker/dealer must
be recognized as a primary dealer by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Banks and savings and loan associations must be members of the FDIC or FSLIC in
order to be eligible for authorization. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-12: SAFEKEEPING:
Investment securities purchased by the Village will be delivered by either book
entry or physical delivery, and held for safekeeping by the Village Clerk. The
trust department of the bank designated as primary agent will be considered to
be a third party for the purposes of safekeeping of securities.
Demand deposit accounts utilized for the liquidity portion of the Village's
portfolio shall not be subject to these safekeeping requirements as long as the
deposits are fully insured. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-13: INTERNAL CONTROLS:
   A.   The Treasurer is responsible for establishing and maintaining an
internal control structure designed to ensure that the assets of the entity are
protected from loss, theft or misuse. The internal control structure shall be
designed to provide reasonable assurance that these objectives are met. The
concept of reasonable assurance recognizes that: 1) the cost of a control
should not exceed the benefits likely to be derived and 2) the valuation of
costs and benefits requires estimates and judgments by management.
   B.   Accordingly, the Treasurer shall establish a process for an annual
independent review by an external auditor to assure compliance with policies
and procedures. The internal controls shall address the following points:
      1.   Control of collusion.
      2.   Separation of transaction authority from accounting and record
keeping.
      3.   Custodial safekeeping.
      4.   Avoidance of physical-delivery securities.
      5.   Clear delegation of authority to subordinate staff members.
      6.   Written confirmation of telephone transactions for investments and
wire transfers.
      7.   Development of a wire transfer agreement with the lead bank or third
party custodian. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-14: REPORTING:
The Treasurer shall prepare an investment report at least quarterly, including
a succinct management summary that provides a clear picture of the status of
the current investment portfolio and transactions made over the last quarter.
This management summary will be prepared in a manner which will allow the
Village to ascertain whether investment activities during the reporting period
have conformed to the investment policy. The report should be provided to the
Village Board at its regular meeting. The report will include the following:
   A.   Listing of individual securities held at the end of the reporting
period.
   B.   Realized and unrealized gains or losses resulting from appreciation or
depreciation intended to be held until maturity (in accordance with GASB
requirements).
   C.   Average weighted yield to maturity of portfolio on investments as
compared to applicable bench marks.
   D.   Listing of investment by maturity date.
Percentage of the total portfolio which each type of investment represents.
(Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
1-12-15: POLICY REVISIONS:
This investment policy will be reviewed periodically by the Treasurer and the
Village Board. It may be amended as conditions warrant. (Ord. 99-09, 4-28-1999)
CHAPTER 13
ETHICS
SECTION:
1-13-1: Definitions
1-13-2: Prohibited Political Activities
1-13-3: Gift Ban
1-13-4: Ethics Advisor
1-13-5: Penalties
1-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall be given these
definitions:
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to
influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual
to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political
organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities: a) relating to the
support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action,
b) relating to collective bargaining, or c) that are otherwise in furtherance
of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination
or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy
in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a
regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the election code 1 .
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section
3 of the Illinois public labor relations act 2 .
COMPENSATED TIME: With respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited
to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as
a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this chapter, does
not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time,
compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence.
With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensated
time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the
control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is
executing his or her official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee
to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work
time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of
the election code 3 .
EMPLOYEE: A person employed by the village of Green Oaks whether on a full time
or part time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the
direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how
the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor.
EMPLOYER: The village of Green Oaks.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or
other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements
related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of
an officer or employee.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive: a)
compensation for employment, b) service credit towards pension benefits, and c)
health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICER: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by
statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for
service in his or her official capacity.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any
campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not
include activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive,
legislative, or administrative action, b) relating to collective bargaining, or
c) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund, or other
organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under
section 9-3 of the election code 4 , but only with regard to those activities
that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY:
   A.   Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting,
political rally, political demonstration, or other political event.
   B.   Soliciting contributions, including, but not limited to, the purchase
of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political
fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event.
   C.   Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or
report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution.
   D.   Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   E.   Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in
an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political
purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   F.   Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political
organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   G.   Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a
political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in
an effort to get voters to the polls.
   H.   Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or
filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or
against any referendum question.
   I.   Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in
that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
   J.   Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires.
   K.   Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign
literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any
candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
   L.   Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   M.   Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against
any referendum question.
   N.   Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party
convention.
   O.   Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any
election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
   A.   Is seeking official action: 1) by an officer or 2) by an employee, or
by the officer or another employee directing that employee;
   B.   Does business or seeks to do business: 1) with the officer or 2) with
an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee;
   C.   Conducts activities regulated: 1) by the officer or 2) by an employee,
or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or
   D.   Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or
nonperformance of the official duties of the officer or employee. (Ord. 2004-O-
03, 5-26-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. 10 ILCS 5/1-3.
2 2. 5 ILCS 315/3.
3 1. 10 ILCS 5/9-1.4.
4 2. 10 ILCS 5/9-3.
1-13-2: PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
   A.   No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited
political activity during any "compensated time", as defined herein. No officer
or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the village of
Green Oaks in connection with any prohibited political activity.
   B.   At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any
other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 1) as
part of that officer's or employee's duties, 2) as a condition of employment,
or 3) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal
time off).
   C.   No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in
any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee
being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a
salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or
otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation
or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited
political activity.
   D.   Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for
an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or
activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis
which are not prohibited by this chapter.
   E.   No person either: 1) in a position that is subject to recognized merit
principles of public employment or 2) in a position the salary for which is
paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal
standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant in
aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely
because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a
political party, or of a political organization or club. (Ord. 2004-O-03, 5-26-
2004)
1-13-3: GIFT BAN:
   A.   Solicitation Or Acceptance Of Gifts: Except as permitted by this
chapter, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member
living with any officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as
"recipients"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any
"prohibited source", as defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law
or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift
that violates this section.
   B.   Exceptions: Subsection A of this section is not applicable to the
following:
      1.   Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same
conditions as for the general public.
      2.   Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or
immediate family member, pays the fair market value.
      3.   Any: a) contribution that is lawfully made under the election code
or b) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political
organization or candidate.
      4.   Educational materials and missions.
      5.   Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business.
      6.   A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the
individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt,
great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife,
grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-
law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather,
stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half
sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the
individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee.
      7.   Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal
friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the
circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or
employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and
not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is
provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the
circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: a) the history of the
relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the
gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; b)
whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the
gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business
reimbursement for the gift; and c) whether to the actual knowledge of the
recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same
or similar gifts to other officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate
family members.
      8.   Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy five dollars ($75.00) per
person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or
refreshments are: a) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or
prepared or b) catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food
or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any
means.
      9.   Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits
resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities
that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if
the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position
or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to
others in similar circumstances.
      10.   Intragovernmental and intergovernmental gifts. For the purpose of
this chapter, "intragovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or
employee from another officer or employee, and "intergovernmental gift" means
any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another
governmental entity.
      11.   Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death.
      12.   Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any
calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars
($100.00).
Each of the exceptions listed in this subsection B is mutually exclusive and
independent of every other.
   C.   Disposition Of Gifts: An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an
immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate
this chapter if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift
from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to
its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under
section 501(c)(3) of the internal revenue code of 1986, as now or hereafter
amended, renumbered, or succeeded. (Ord. 2004-O-03, 5-26-2004)
1-13-4: ETHICS ADVISOR:
   A.   The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees, shall designate an ethics advisor for the village. The duties of the
ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the village unless
the position has been created as an office by the village.
   B.   The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees
of the village concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the
provisions of this chapter and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall
perform such other duties as may be delegated by the corporate authorities.
(Ord. 2004-O-03, 5-26-2004)
1-13-5: PENALTIES:
   A.   A person who intentionally violates any provision of section
1-13-2 of this chapter may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal
institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three
hundred sixty four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
   B.   A person who intentionally violates any provision of section
1-13-3 of this chapter is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than one
thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00).
   C.   Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation
of any provision of this chapter to the local enforcement authorities, the
state's attorney or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a
term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a
period of not more than three hundred sixty four (364) days, and may be fined
in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
   D.   A violation of section
1-13-2 of this chapter shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney
for the village of Green Oaks by filing in the circuit court an information, or
sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and
conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the
establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt.
A violation of section
1-13-3 of this chapter may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an
attorney for the village of Green Oaks.
   E.   In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether
criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any
provision of section
1-13-2 or
1-13-3 of this chapter is subject to discipline or discharge. (Ord. 2004-O-03,
5-26-2004)
TITLE 2
MUNICIPAL FINANCES
CHAPTER 1
FISCAL YEAR
SECTION:
2-1-1: Fiscal Year Designated
2-1-1: FISCAL YEAR DESIGNATED:
The fiscal year of the Village is hereby established as commencing on May 1,
1968, and ending on April 30, 1969 and on each succeeding year following 1968,
the fiscal year of the Village shall also commence on May 1 and end on April 30
of the following year. (Ord. 67-06, 9-27-67)
CHAPTER 2
VILLAGE DEPOSITORIES
SECTION:
2-2-1: First National Bank of Libertyville, Illinois
2-2-1-1: Depository Designated
2-2-1-2: Endorsement for Deposits
2-2-1-3: Signed Checks, Drafts, Orders
2-2-1-4: Responsibilities of Village
2-2-1-5: Nonliability of Bank
2-2-2: American Security Federal Savings and Loan Association of Libertyville,
Illinois
2-2-2-1: Depository Designated
2-2-2-2: Statement of Resources and Liabilities Required
2-2-2-3: Amount of Uninsured Deposits
2-2-1: FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF LIBERTYVILLE, ILLINOIS:
2-2-1-1: DEPOSITORY DESIGNATED:
The First National Bank of Libertyville, Illinois, be and hereby is designated
a depository in which the funds of this Municipal corporation may be deposited
by its officers, agents, and employees.
2-2-1-2: ENDORSEMENT FOR DEPOSITS:
The President, Treasurer and Finance Chairman Trustee of the Village, Lake
County, Illinois shall be and each of them hereby is authorized to endorse for
deposit or negotiation any and all checks, drafts, notes, bills of exchange and
orders for the payment of money, either belonging to or coming into possession
of this Municipal corporation. Endorsements for deposit may be by the written
or stamped endorsement of the company without designation of the person making
the endorsement.
2-2-1-3: SIGNED CHECKS, DRAFTS, ORDERS:
The President, Treasurer and Finance Chairman Trustee of this Municipal
corporation are authorized to sign any and all checks, drafts, and orders,
including orders or directions in informal or letter form, against any funds at
any time standing to the credit of this Municipal corporation with the said
Bank and the said Bank hereby is authorized to honor any and all checks,
drafts, and orders so signed, including those drawn to the individual order of
any such officer and/or other person signing the same, without further inquiry
or regard to the authority of said officer and/or other person of the use of
said checks, drafts and orders, or the proceeds thereof.
2-2-1-4: RESPONSIBILITIES OF VILLAGE:
This Municipal corporation, by its duly authorized agent, enters into an
agreement with the said First National Bank of Libertyville, Illinois,
contemporaneously with the opening of said account whereby said Municipal
corporation agrees in consideration of the opening of said account to assume
and pay all expenses, costs and attorney's fees incurred by said Bank in any
legal proceedings brought against the said Bank by reason of the said account
and further agrees that any funds in possession of the said Bank to the credit
of this Municipal corporation may at any time be applied toward payment of such
expenses.
2-2-1-5: NONLIABILITY OF BANK:
Each of the foregoing sections shall continue in force until express written
notice of its decision or modification has been received by the said Bank, but
if the authority contained in them should be revoked or terminated by operation
of law without such notice, it is resolved and hereby agreed for the purpose of
inducing the said Bank to act thereunder, that the said Bank shall be saved
harmless from any loss suffered or liability incurred by it in so acting after
such revocation or termination without such notice. (Ord. 77-05, 11-16-77)
2-2-2: AMERICAN SECURITY FEDERAL SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSOCIATION OF LIBERTYVILLE,
ILLINOIS:
2-2-2-1: DEPOSITORY DESIGNATED:
The American Security Federal Savings and Loan Association of Libertyville,
Illinois, is hereby designated pursuant to the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-10-3, as a place of deposit to keep the funds and moneys
of the Village in the custody of the Village Treasurer.
2-2-2-2: STATEMENT OF RESOURCES AND LIABILITIES REQUIRED:
The American Security Federal Savings and Loan Association shall furnish the
Village with copies of the last two (2) sworn statements of resources and
liabilities which it is required to furnish to the Commissioner of Savings and
Loan Associations or the Federal Home Loan Bank. It shall, while acting as such
depository, furnish the Village with a copy of all statements of resource and
liabilities which it is required to furnish to the Commissioner of Savings and
Loan Associations or the Federal Home Loan Bank.
2-2-2-3: AMOUNT OF UNINSURED DEPOSITS:
The amount of all such deposits not collateralized or insured by an agency of
the Federal government shall not exceed seventy five percent (75%) of the net
worth of the Savings and Loan Association as defined by the Federal Savings and
Loan Insurance Corporation. (Ord. 82-09, 9-22-82)
