perform all the conditions thereof; provided, however, that the foregoing
restriction shall not prohibit the Company from mortgaging or pledging its
assets.
3-4-17: TERMINATION OF FRANCHISE:
   A.   If the Company fails to perform any of the material covenants herein
provided for, for a period of ninety (90) days after receiving written notice
from the Village of said breach, the Village shall have the right to terminate
the Company's franchise by written notice to the Company mailed or delivered to
its business office; provided, however, that no termination may occur without
written notice to the Company and a public hearing had. The Company shall be
entitled to a reasonable extension of the ninety (90) day period specified
herein in the event that the Company is unable to cure by reason of acts of
God, earthquake, lightning, flood, fire, explosion, vandalism, strikes or other
industrial disturbances, riots or other civil disturbances, late performance by
suppliers of service, or other similar causes reasonably beyond the Company's
control.
   B.   Upon termination for cause or expiration of the franchise, the Village
may elect to acquire the CATV system of the Company upon payment to the Company
of the fair market value of the CATV system as a going concern. Said valuation
is to be made as a valid and existing franchise. Said valuation shall be made
by a group of three (3) certified public accountants. Each party to this
agreement shall select one certified public accountant. The two (2) certified
public accountants selected by the parties shall select a third certified
public accountant. The decision of the majority shall be binding. The Company
shall transfer to the Village, possession and title to all property of the
Company and the Village shall pay the purchase price within thirty (30) days
after expiration or termination of the grant of authority.
3-4-18: DECLARATION OF FORFEITURE:
In the event the Company fails to perform in accordance with any of the
provisions of this Chapter and a forfeiture is declared, then it is understood
and agreed that the Village shall be entitled to the sum of ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) as liquidated damages, which sum shall be in addition to
any other sum which shall be covered by the bond in this Chapter required to be
posted by the Company.
3-4-19: COMPANY OFFICE:
   A.   Public Use of Facilities: The Company shall maintain studios and
offices, open during normal business hours, within the corporate limits of
Waukegan, Illinois, equipped with color cameras, video tape equipment and
mobile van. This facility shall be available on a time sharing basis to the
Village, its agencies, public service organizations and schools lying wholly or
partly within the Village.
   B.   Complaints Directed to: Said office shall also receive, investigate and
respond to complaints from subscribers. The Company shall make every reasonable
effort to resolve complaints to the satisfaction of the subscriber.
3-4-20: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Discrimination:
      1.   The Company shall not, as to rates, charges, service facilities,
rules, regulations, or in any other respect, make or grant preference or
advantage to any person, nor subject any person to any prejudice or
disadvantage, provided that nothing in this franchise shall be deemed to
prohibit the establishment of a graduated scale of charge and classified rate
schedules to which any customer coming within such classification would be
entitled.
      2.   The Company shall not deny service, deny access, or otherwise
discriminate against subscribers, channel users, or general citizens on the
basis of race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, age, sex, marital
status or physical or mental handicap. The Company shall strictly adhere to the
equal employment opportunity requirements of the FCC, as expressed in section
76.12(g) and 76.311 of chapter I of title 47 of the Code of Federal
Regulations. The Company shall comply at all times with all other applicable
Federal, State and local laws, and all executive and administrative orders
relating to non-discrimination.
   B.   Monitoring: Neither the Company nor any other person, agency or entity
shall monitor or arrange for the monitoring of any cable, line, signal input
device, or subscriber outlet or receiver for any purpose whatsoever, without
the specific authorization of the corporate authorities expressed by resolution
and of affected subscribers. The foregoing notwithstanding, the Company shall
be allowed to perform monitoring which is necessary to the normal delivery of
system services; provided, however, that such monitoring shall be done in a
manner that does not infringe upon the rights of subscribers and provided
further that the Company shall disclose to the Board of Trustees all such
monitoring activities, if any.
   C.   Business of Television Repair: The Company shall not engage in the
business of selling or repairing television sets or other electronic
instruments other than those owned by the Company. This paragraph shall not be
construed to restrict the Company from connecting its distribution system to
television sets or other electronic instruments.
3-4-21: REMOVAL OF COMPANY EQUIPMENT:
Upon the revocation of this franchise by the Board of Trustees, or at the end
of the term of this franchise or any extensions thereof, the Company shall have
the right to go upon the Village property to remove its equipment.
3-4-22: FRANCHISE NON-EXCLUSIVE:
This franchise shall be non-exclusive and shall not restrict the Village in any
manner in the exercise of any franchising or other regulatory power which it
now has or which it may hereafter be granted by Federal, State or local law.
3-4-23: PENALTIES:
For violation of any of the following provisions of this Chapter, the penalties
shall be chargeable as follows:
   A.   For failure to complete construction and installation of the system and
commence providing service in accordance with Section
3-4-12B, of this Chapter unless the Board of Trustees specifically approves the
delay by resolution because of the reasons beyond the control of the Company,
the Company shall be subject to a penalty of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per
day or part thereof that the violation continues.
   B.   For failure to provide data and reports as requested by the Village
within thirty (30) days of written notice of the request, or as required in
Sections
3-4-9 and
3-4-10, the Company shall be subject to a penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) per
day or part thereof that the violation continues.
   C.   Delinquent payments shall bear interest at the rate of one percent (1%)
per month with the minimum delinquency being one month interest charge.
   D.   For persistent failure to comply with such reasonable requests and
recommendations as may be made in writing by the Village pursuant to authority
granted by this Chapter, the Company shall be subject to a penalty of fifty
dollars ($50.00) per day or part thereof that the violation continues.
   E.   The Company shall not be liable for any fines or penalties if the
Company's failure to perform is delayed or obstructed by acts of God,
earthquake, lightning, flood, fire, explosion, vandalism or other industrial
disturbance, riots or other civil disturbances, late delivery of equipment,
supplies or machinery by suppliers, late performance by suppliers of service,
or other similar causes reasonably beyond the Company's control.
3-4-24: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, clause, phrase or portion of this franchise shall
be held unconstitutional, invalid under State or Federal law or inconsistent
with the regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, all other
provisions shall retain their full force and effect. (Ord. 82-03, 3-24-82)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE WATER AND SEWAGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
3-5-1: Designation Of Systems
3-5-2: Connections And Tap-Ins Governed By Building Code
3-5-3: Village Not Liable For Interruption Of Service
3-5-4: Rates And Collections
3-5-5: Water System And Sewer System Use Regulations
3-5-6: Penalties
3-5-7: Outside Water Use Regulations
3-5-8: Assessment Of Proportionate Share Of Special Service Area Costs
3-5-9: Public Water And Sanitary Sewer Main Extensions
3-5-1: DESIGNATION OF SYSTEMS:
   A.   Water And Sewage System:
      1.   The water system of the Village shall be divided into three (3)
districts as follows:
         a.   District 1; the Ashford Trails Water District: This system shall
be limited to the Ashford Trails Subdivision. It shall be operated and
maintained by Lake County under agreement with the Village.
         b.   District 2; the Southeastern Water District: This system shall be
limited to the area in the Village lying westerly of the Illinois Toll Highway
and southerly of the Metra Rail right-of-way and shall be owned, operated and
maintained by Lake County.
         c.   District 3; the North-Central Water District: This system shall
be operated and maintained by the Village and shall comprise the remainder of
the Village area.
      2.   The sewage system of the Village shall be divided into three (3)
districts as follows:
         a.   District 4; the Ashford Trails Sewage District: This system shall
be limited to the Ashford Trails Subdivision. It shall be operated and
maintained by Lake County under agreement with the Village.
         b.   District 5; the Eastern Sewage District: This system shall be
located easterly of the Illinois Toll Highway and shall be operated and
maintained by the Village with treatment service by the North Shore Sanitary
District.
         c.   District 6; the Western Sewage District: This system shall be
located westerly of the Illinois Toll Highway and shall be operated and
maintained by the Village with treatment service by Lake County and the Village
of Libertyville.
The foregoing six (6) districts along with all real and personal property which
comprise such existing systems and all additions thereto, are hereby designated
the "water and sewage system" of the Village.
   B.   County Intergovernmental Agreements: The various intergovernmental
agreements heretofore made between Lake County and the Village relating to the
various water and sewage system districts, as amended from time to time, shall
be incorporated into this chapter by reference, and all of the regulatory and
operating agreements therein shall be enforced as a part of this chapter.
   C.   Lake County Sewer Use Ordinance: The provisions of the Lake County
sewer use ordinances as amended from time to time, shall be incorporated by
reference into and made a part of this chapter, and the use of Districts 4 and
6 sewage systems shall be regulated thereby. The provisions of the North Shore
Sanitary District regulations concerning the use of the sewage system shall be
incorporated by reference into and made a part of this chapter, and the use of
District 5 sewage system shall be regulated thereby. (Ord. 94-O-14, 9-28-1994)
3-5-2: CONNECTIONS AND TAP-INS GOVERNED BY BUILDING CODE:
   A.   General Provisions: All connections or tap-ins to the water and sewage
systems of the Village shall be governed by the provisions of the Building
Code, including, but not limited to, applications for service or connection or
tap-in permits, issuance of permits, payment of fees, regulation of materials
used, and inspection of connections.
   B.   Construction Of Individual Sewage Disposal: No septic tank or other
individual sewage disposal system shall be constructed or installed in the
Village except:
      1.   SR-5 Zone: On land zoned SR-5 when any permitted use is located on a
minimum of five (5) acres of land and when installation is approved by the Lake
County Board of Health, unless the Village Building Commissioner finds that
public sewage mains are reasonably accessible.
      2.   Availability And Accessibility: In any other zoning district when
installation is approved by the Lake County Board of Health and public sewer
mains are not accessible within a reasonable distance or sewage connection
permission is not available due to lack of capacity within the sewer mains and/
or due to limiting sewer service area boundaries to be allocated by the Village
Board within a reasonable period of time. As used herein "reasonable distance"
shall be three hundred feet (300'), or less, from the nearest property boundary
of a lot, tract or parcel upon which a single family dwelling exists or upon
which a single family dwelling is to be constructed, and one thousand feet
(1,000') from the nearest property boundary of an existing or proposed non-
residential building, multi-family dwelling, or a proposed subdivision property
boundary and for which permission to connect is required and granted by the
controlling governmental authority or authorities. The Building Commissioner
shall determine, before issuing a building permit, whether or not connection to
the sewage system is required under this section. Any appeals from the
requirement or determination of the Building Commissioner shall be heard by the
Zoning Board of Appeals under title 1, chapter 10, article B of this Code or,
if so directed by the Mayor, the Plan Commission.
      3.   Septic Systems: These provisions limiting installation of septic
systems shall apply to new installations, replacement, or substantial repair of
existing systems.
   C.   Construction Of Individual Well: No private well or other individual
water supply shall be installed in the Village except when the Village water
mains or other Illinois Environmental Protection Agency approved and regulated
public water system mains are not accessible within a reasonable distance or
water connection permission is not available due to lack of capacity within the
water mains and/or limiting service area boundaries to be allocated by the
Village Board within a reasonable period of time. As used herein "reasonable
distance" shall be two hundred fifty feet (250'), or less, from the nearest
property boundary of a lot, tract or parcel upon which a single family dwelling
exists or upon which a single family dwelling is to be constructed, and one
thousand feet (1,000') from the nearest property boundary of an existing or
proposed non-residential building, multi-family dwelling, or a proposed
subdivision property boundary and for which permission to connect is required
and granted by the controlling governmental authority or authorities. The
Building Commissioner shall determine, before issuing a building permit,
whether or not connection to the water system shall be required. Any appeals
from the requirement or determination of the Building Commissioner shall be
heard by the Zoning Board of Appeals under title 1, chapter 10, article B of
this Code or, if so directed by the Mayor, the Plan Commission. These
provisions limiting installation of private water systems shall apply to both
new installations and replacement of existing systems.
   D.   Connection To Water And Sewage System: No connections shall be made to
the water system or the sewage system without a construction permit issued by
the Building Commissioner. When required by the regulations of the Village,
flow meters for either water or sewage connections shall be installed at the
expense of the permittee.
      1.   Sewer connections in Districts 4 and 6 shall only be made when
allocated by the Village Board and after payment of all connection fees and
permit fees set forth in the Building Code.
      2.   Sewer connections in District 5 shall only be made when approved by
the North Shore Sanitary District and after payment of all connection fees and
permit fees set forth in the Building Code.
      3.   Water connections in District 1 shall only be made when approved by
Lake County and after payment of all connection and permit fees set forth in
the Building Code.
      4.   Water connections in District 2 shall only be made when approved by
Lake County and after payment of all connection and permits fees required by
Lake County.
      5.   Water connections in District 3 shall only be made when approved by
the Village and after payment of all connection and permit fees set forth in
the Building Code.
   E.   Prohibited Connections:
      1.   No person shall connect to a sanitary sewer, any sewer or drain
which is connected directly or indirectly to any sources of stormwater, ground
water, or wastewater, including, but not limited to, roof drains or downspouts;
areaway drains; swimming pool filter backwash water, pool drains or other pool
water sources; or any other source of surface water runoff or ground water.
      2.   No person shall connect any private well or other water source to
any water system which is connected to the Village water system.
      3.   No private sewer or water connection may cross any land owned by
another party.
      4.   No person or entity shall connect to an available sanitary sewer or
water main which is not located adjacent and contiguous to the lot, tract or
parcel to be served (see also section
3-5-9 of this chapter).
   F.   Separate Connection For Each Building: Except as otherwise authorized
in this Code, a separate and independent building sewer, directly connected to
the public sanitary sewer, shall be provided for every building; except where
one (1) building stands at the rear of another on the same interior lot and no
private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through
an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front
building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one
(1) building sewer. Other than as authorized in this section, building sewers
that do not directly connect to the public sanitary sewer are prohibited.
   G.   Who Must Connect To Public Sewer: The owner of all houses, buildings or
properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes
situated within the Village and abutting on any public or private street, alley
or right-of- way in which there is now located or may in the future be located
any public sanitary sewer of the Village, is required at owner's expense to
install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities
directly with the proper public sanitary sewer in accordance with the
provisions of this title, within ninety (90) days after date of official notice
to do so; provided, that said public sewer is available, as defined herein.
(Ord. 2017-O-11, 6-28-2017; amd. Ord. 2023-O-10, 5-24-2023)
3-5-3: VILLAGE NOT LIABLE FOR INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE:
   A.   Liability: All water and sewage service supplied by the water and
sewage system of the Village shall be provided on the express condition that
the Village shall not be liable nor shall any claim be made against it for
damages caused by reason of breakage, failure, or blockage of any main, trunk,
branches, service pipes, lift pump, valve, booster pump, or other part or
apparatus connected with the system; or for any damages due to the condition of
any water supplied to any user, or to the handling of any sewage in the system;
or for any interruption or inadequacy of service for any reason whatsoever,
including, but not limited to, any work, stoppage, alterations or repairs
conducted upon the system.
   B.   Interference With Or Damage To System Prohibited: It shall be unlawful
for any person to, in any manner interfere with, obstruct, or damage in any
manner whatsoever, the operation and equipment of the water and sewage system
of the Village or to cause or permit such interference, obstruction or damage.
No person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy,
uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenances or equipment which
is a part of the water and sewage system. Any person violating this provision
shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct, or
shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided for in this chapter.
(Ord. 94-14, 9-28-1994)
3-5-4: RATES AND COLLECTIONS:
   A.   Rates Established: There are hereby established rates and charges for
the use of the water and sewage system of the Village in the various districts
hereinabove established. Because the districts involve differing costs payable
to providers of services to the Village such as water supply and sewage
treatment, the charges made for services in each district vary accordingly. The
charges include: 1) permit and tap-in fees for the privilege of connecting to
the water and sewer system; 2) charges for the use of the system on the basis
of the volume of use, either as assumed on the basis of the use involved, or as
metered; or 3) final reading charges.
      1.   Water And Sewage Tap-In Charge: There is hereby established a tap-in
fee for making a connection to either the water system or the sewage system of
the Village which shall be in an amount as established in each district by
resolution of the Village Board. The Village may direct that the tap-in charge
is paid directly to the service provider in the district.
      2.   Water And Sewage Service Charge: In addition to the tap-in fee
herein required, there is hereby established a service charge for the use of
the water system and the sewage system of the Village which shall be in an
amount as established by resolution of the Village Board. The Village may
direct that the service charge is paid directly to the service provider in the
district.
      3.   Final Reading Charge: In addition to the other charges herein
required, there is hereby established a charge for the final reading of the
water meter upon termination of service, whether by sale of the serviced real
estate or otherwise. Any person requesting a final meter reading shall be
required to pay to the Village, at the time of application for such final
reading, such amount as established by the Village Board. The amount shall be
sufficient to reimburse the Village for the cost incurred by the Village for
the meter reading service. (Ord. 2000-O-03, 3-22-2000)
   B.   Collections: Tap-in charges shall be collected at the time of issuance
of the building permit for connection to the system. Service charges shall be
collected periodically, including penalties for late payment, at such times and
on such basis as the Village Board shall establish by resolution from time to
time. Final reading charges shall be paid in advance at the time of application
for said service. All bills for service shall be deemed delinquent and subject
to late payment penalties if not paid within fifteen (15) days after the bill
therefor is rendered.
      1.   At any time after an account becomes delinquent under this chapter
the Village may take any or all lawful action necessary to collect the rates,
fees, charges and penalties due under this chapter including, but not limited
to, placing the delinquent account for collection with a debt collection
company. The placing of a delinquent account for collection is in addition to,
and not exclusive of, any other remedy or procedure available to the Village as
provided by law and this title.
      2.   In addition to the rates, fees, charges and penalties as provided
under this chapter, should the Village place a delinquent account for
collection with a debt collection company, then an additional penalty in the
amount of thirty five percent (35%) of the delinquent amount shall be added to
the delinquent amount due the Village. This penalty shall, upon being placed
for collection, be added to the amount due the Village for the respective sewer
and/or water user charges plus all other applicable fees, charges and
penalties. (Ord. 2013-O-13, 10-23-2013)
   C.   Billing And Collection: It is hereby made the duty of the Village
Administrator to render bills for the service charges at such times as the
Village Board may designate by resolution. The Village Administrator shall
collect and forward to the Village Treasurer all monies due thereon. The
Village Administrator shall report to the Village Board within thirty (30) days
after payments are due, a list of all delinquent water and sewage service
charges. The Village Treasurer shall receive all such monies or revenues
incident to the operation of the water and sewage system, or any part thereof,
as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in a separate fund
designated the "Water and Sewage Fund of the Village of Green Oaks", and said
Treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by
the provisions of this chapter.
   D.   Lien Upon Real Estate: In the event service charges are not paid within
ninety (90) days after rendition of a bill for such service, such charges shall
be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter, such
delinquencies shall constitute liens upon the real estate for which the service
is supplied. The Administrator of the Village is hereby authorized and directed
to file a notice of such lien in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Lake
County, Illinois, which notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth
the name(s) of the owner(s) of the real estate, a description of the real
estate for which service was supplied, the amounts of monies due, and the date
or dates when such amount(s) became delinquent. The filing of such statements
as aforesaid shall be deemed notice of lien for the payment of such charges. In
all cases where a lien has been recorded, a release fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00) plus all costs of recording shall be charged in addition to the
delinquent sewer charges with late penalties. The failure to record such a
notice of lien shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for delinquent
charges, or the right to pursue any other legal remedy.
   E.   Foreclosure Of Lien: If the service charges are not paid within one
hundred eighty (180) days after rendition of bill, the lien hereinabove
provided for may be foreclosed by appropriate legal action in the circuit court
of Lake County.
   F.   Liability For Payment: The service charges established in this section
shall be payable by the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the
user of the system, and they shall be jointly and severally liable for payment
thereof. The service is supplied to such premises only upon the condition that
the owner of the premises, the occupant and the user of the service are jointly
and severally liable for payment therefor to the village. (Ord. 94-O-14, 9-28-
1994)
   G.   Recapture Administrative Fee:
      1.   Where any lot, tract or parcel of real estate is subject to the
provisions of a recapture agreement requiring payment of a recapture fee as a
condition to receiving a permit to connect a service line to a village sewer
and/or water main line, then, in such circumstances, the general permit and
tap-in fee established by the village from time to time, shall be increased by
fifteen percent (15%) of the recapture fee applicable to the particular lot,
tract or parcel of real estate for which the respective service connection is
being sought (the "adjusted connection fee"). By way of example, and not
limitation, the adjusted connection fee is computed thusly:
Assumptions:
 
Water connection fee $3,500.00
Recapture fee        5,000.00 (water only)
 
Computation to determine adjustment to permit and tap-in fee:
15% x $5,000.00 = $750.00 (adjustment to permit and tap-in fee)
      2.   The adjustment to permit and tap-in fee as determined by the formula
established in subsection G1 of this section shall be added to the relevant
permit and tap-in fee to determine the total amount due from the applicant for
sewer and/or water service in order to receive a permit for the connection(s).
By way of example, and not limitation, the total amount due using the
assumptions and formula from subsection G1 of this section is computed thusly:
Computation:
 
Adjustment to permit and tap-in fee $ 750.00, plus
Tap-in fee                          3,500.00, plus
Recapture fee                       5,000.00
Total due upon application          $9,250.00
 
(Ord. 2005-O-09, 9-28-2005)
   H.   Disconnection Of Water Supply For Delinquent Payment Of Water Supply
Service Charges:
      1.   Notwithstanding anything hereinbefore provided, the remedy by
enforcement of the lien for the unpaid portion of water bills and charges shall
not be exclusive of any other legal remedy to collect the amount due and unpaid
for water consumed or furnished to the person liable therefor. The water supply
of the premises for which: a) the water service charges remain unpaid; b) the
water user or owner of the premises has refused to allow inspection of the
water meter on the premises by any village officer, employee or agent; or c)
the water user or owner has refused to replace a water meter that the village
has determined is not measuring or reading water usage accurately may be cut
off by the village and such service discontinued conditioned on the following
terms and conditions:
         a.   Hearing Afforded User: Any user who has failed to pay the bill or
deposit for water service within thirty (30) days after the due date thereof,
or refuses to allow an inspection of the water meter, or refuses to replace a
water meter that the village has determined is not measuring or reading water
usage accurately, is declared to be delinquent. Thereupon, the hearing officer,
as hereinafter provided for, shall cause a written notice of delinquency to be
served upon the delinquent user setting forth the time and place of the
hearing, which shall be not less than seven (7) days after the serving of such
notice.
         b.   Hearing: At the time and place of said hearing, the hearing
officer shall give the delinquent user an opportunity to be heard and to
present any and all evidence including testimony on said user's behalf. The
records of payment for said water service by the user, as provided and given to
the hearing officer by the offices of the collector and the village clerk,
shall be prima facie evidence that said bill is due and delinquent. All
witnesses, including the delinquent user, shall be sworn prior to giving any
testimony. A record of the hearing shall be kept electronically or by
stenographic notes.
         c.   Notice Of Findings Of Hearing Officer: The hearing officer,
within five (5) business days after such hearing, if he determines after such
hearing that the user is, in fact, delinquent in payment of said bill for water
services, or refuses to allow an inspection of the water meter, or refuses to
replace a water meter that the village has determined is not measuring or
reading water usage accurately, and that the water service of said user should
be discontinued, shut off and terminated, shall state the basis or reasons for
such termination in a written order of termination, and shall serve a copy of
such order upon the user within five (5) days after said hearing. The order
shall also state the date when the water service shall be shut off and
terminated, said date to be no later than ten (10) days after the hearing date.
         d.   Payment Of Bill For Water Service, Allowing Inspection Of Water
Meters, Or Replacement Of Malfunctioning Water Meter; Reinstatement Of Service:
At any time before or after the hearing is held; at any time before or after
notice of termination is served on the user; and at any time after termination,
the delinquent user shall have the right to have said water service reinstated
upon payment of the delinquent bill in full, allowing an inspection of the
water meter, or replacing a water meter that the village has determined is not
measuring or reading water usage accurately, as the case may be, plus payment
for any necessary costs assessed for the conduct of the hearing and for labor
and materials necessarily required to terminate and reinstate the water service
of said user.
         e.   Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall be any employee or
officer of the village and shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the majority of the members of the village board. The hearing
officer shall serve until his successor has been appointed and is qualified. In
the event there is a vacancy in the office of the hearing officer, or in the
event the hearing officer is unwilling or unable to hold hearing under this
title, then the health and sanitation official shall be the hearing officer and
shall have the duties and responsibilities of the hearing officer.
         f.   Notice: Any notices required to be given under this section shall
be proper if addressed to the user at the address stated on the application,
postage prepaid and deposited in the U.S. mail. The collector or clerk shall
certify to the hearing officer the proper mailing of the required notice and
such certification shall be prima facie evidence of the serving of such notice
as of the date of deposit in the U.S. mail. (Ord. 2010-O-6, 4-7-2010)
3-5-5: WATER SYSTEM AND SEWER SYSTEM USE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The water and sewer systems within the village shall be subject to the
following use regulations:
      1.   Tampering: No person shall tamper with, disturb, disrupt, injure or
interfere with the operation of any part of the public water or sewer systems
of the village.
      2.   Unauthorized Use: No person shall use or connect to a water or sewer
system in the village unless a valid permit for such use or connection has been
issued by the village.
      3.   Fire Hydrants: No person shall open a fire hydrant, or attempt to
obtain water therefrom, except in case of immediate emergency, or under the
direction of a village or fire department official or employee. The fine for
violation of this regulation shall be not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00) plus twice the estimated value of the water permitted to be released
from the hydrant.
      4.   Manholes: No person shall move, disturb or open the cover of a
manhole in a right of way or easement in the village, or place any material in
such a manhole, except in the case of immediate emergency, or under the
direction of a village or fire department official or employee. The fine for
violation of placing material in a manhole shall be not less than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) plus twice the estimated cost of removing such material.
(Ord. 95-O-32, 9-27-1995)
      5.   Water Meters: No person shall tamper with, move, disconnect,
disturb, open, injure, adjust, or otherwise interfere with the operation of any
water meter connected to the public water system of the village for any reason,
except in the case of immediate emergency, or under the direction of a village
or fire department official or employee. The fine for violation of this
subsection shall be not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus twice the
cost of correcting the violation and plus twice the estimated loss of revenues
to the village. (Ord. 96-O-01, 1-24-1996)
   B.   The cross connection regulations promulgated by the village pursuant to
the provisions of section
7-2-10 of this code shall be enforced as a part of these regulations. (Ord. 95-
O-32, 9-27-1995)
3-5-6: PENALTIES:
   A.   Violations Of Provisions: Any person found to be in violation of any
provision of this chapter deemed not to be an immediate risk of damage or harm
to the system shall be served by the village with written notice stating the
nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time for correction thereof;
and the violator shall, within the time stated, permanently correct and cease
the violation. (Ord. 94-O-14, 9-28-1994)
   B.   Continued Or Harmful Violations: Any person who shall continue any
violation beyond the time provided in a notice served as provided in subsection
A of this section, or who is committing a violation deemed to be a risk of
damage or harm to the system, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on
conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day in which any such
violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 94-O-14, 9-
28-1994; amd. Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
   C.   Recapturing Village Expense: Any person violating any of the provisions
of this chapter shall become liable to the village for any expense, loss or
damage occasioned the village by reason of such violation. (Ord. 94-O-14, 9-28-
1994)
3-5-7: OUTSIDE WATER USE REGULATIONS:
   A.   Restrictions On Outside Water Use:
      1.   From May 15 and through September 15 of each calendar year:
         a.   No person shall use water from a municipal water system for lawn
sprinkling or use such water through a hose or pipe to water any lawn, garden,
tree or shrub, between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and six o'clock
(6:00) P.M., when evaporation is at its highest and then only on a day in which
sprinkling is permitted by postal address number.
         b.   The sprinkling and watering of lawns and other vegetation as
directed in subsection A1a of this section shall be permitted for properties
with odd numbered postal addresses on odd numbered calendar days and at
properties with even numbered postal addresses on even numbered days.
         c.   New lawns (less than 3 months old) may be exempted from this
provision by making application to the village under subsection B of this
section and receiving authorization for this limited exemption.
         d.   New or replacement sprinkler systems shall be equipped with a
USEPA specified WaterSense labeled irrigation controller and shall be in
compliance with section 2.5(g) of the Illinois plumbing license law 1 .
   B.   New Lawns And Sod Permit Requirements: Except under the conditions set
forth in subsection A1b of this section, watering and sprinkling of lawns on an
unregulated basis for a period not exceeding three (3) weeks shall be granted
for new sod or seeded lawn installations, providing the following conditions
are met:
      1.   That an unregulated watering permit be obtained by the party or firm
wishing to water or sprinkle a new sod or seeded lawn installation on an
unregulated basis;
      2.   That the applicant for such a permit shall state in his/her
application the date of installation of the sod or seed, and the period to be
covered by such permit not to exceed three (3) weeks in duration;
      3.   That a permit fee of five dollars ($5.00) be paid to the
municipality by the applicant at the time of permit issuance to cover costs of
permit administration. (Ord. 2015-O-17, 10-28-2015)
   C.   Water Restrictions In Emergency: In the event it is determined by the
mayor that, to the best of the information available to him, there exists water
shortage or imminent risk of water shortage, then the following emergency water
use restrictions shall be in effect:
      1.   No person shall use any water from the municipal water supply for
outside use including, but not limited to, those uses described in subsection A
of this section for washing of automobiles, except at places of business where
autos are washed with automatic or manual equipment and the water so used is
recycled at the said place of business, or filling or adding to a swimming
pool.
   D.   Notice Of Restrictions In Emergency: When a water shortage or imminent
risk of water shortage has been declared or determined, as the case may be, the
mayor shall notify the water users in the municipality of such determination by
any one or more of the following means: 1) the prominent posting of such
determination at the main office of the municipality and at least one other
prominent location within the municipality; 2) publication of such
determination in a newspaper of general circulation within the municipality; 3)
mailing of notice of such determination to the users of the municipal water
system. (Ord. 99-O-05, 2-24-1999)
   E.   Violation; Penalty: Any person found to be in violation of this section
shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, and not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the
second or any subsequent offenses. (Ord. 2015-O-17, 10-28-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 320.
3-5-8: ASSESSMENT OF PROPORTIONATE SHARE OF SPECIAL SERVICE AREA COSTS:
   A.   Definition Of Terms: As used in this section:
    ACTUAL DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION COSTS: The actual out of pocket cost of
designing and constructing an extension of public water and/or sewer facilities
from the existing public water and/or sewer system to the lot owned by the
nonincluded owner. The term "actual design and construction costs" specifically
shall exclude any and all costs of extending service from the public water and/
or sewer main to any structure or other private use.
   LOT OR LOTS: Real property owned and improved as one parcel.
   NONINCLUDED PROPERTY OWNER: The person or entity, who owns a lot or owns
lots not located within a special service area, seeking to connect to water
and/or sewer facilities within that special service area.
   PROPORTIONATE SHARE OF THE TOTAL COST: That portion of the total assessment
upon all of the real property located within a special service area, which
shall be paid by the nonincluded property owner before a connection to water
and/or sewer facilities within a special service area is permitted. The
calculation of the proportionate share of the total cost is provided in
subsection C of this section.
   B.   Responsibility To Pay For Proportionate Share Of Total Cost: In
addition to any fees, charges, costs and/or bonds required by this code or
other village ordinance, resolution, or any other action of the village board,
a nonincluded property owner shall pay a proportionate share of the total cost
as provided herein before any permits are issued allowing the connection of a
nonincluded property owner's lot or lots to water and/or sewer facilities
within the special service area. Any nonincluded property owner, who pays the
proportionate share of total cost and receives a permit to connect a lot to
sewer and/or water facilities within a special service area, and thereafter,
divides, conveys, or transfers a portion of that lot, such that the lot is no
longer being owned and improved as one lot, shall pay the proportionate share
of the total cost as provided herein for each additional lot created from the
division, conveyance or transfer before any such additional lot is permitted to
connect to sewer and/or water facilities.
   C.   Calculating Proportionate Share Of The Total Cost: The proportionate
share of the total cost for a nonincluded property owner shall be calculated as
follows: The total cost of the special service area, as assessed against all
lots currently within the special service area, shall be divided by a number
equal to the original number of lots within the special service area plus the
number of lots owned by the nonincluded property owner to determine the
proportionate share of the total cost.
   D.   Credit For Actual Design And Construction Costs: Any nonincluded
property owner shall be provided a credit, to be applied toward the
proportionate share of the total cost, for actual design and construction
costs. The credit provided herein shall not exceed the amount of the
proportionate share of the total cost. No nonincluded property owner shall
receive the credit provided herein unless a list of the design and construction
costs, properly itemized and certified by the property owner's project
engineer, is filed with the village engineer, who shall verify the listed
costs. No credit shall be provided until such time as the actual design and
construction costs are verified by the village engineer. (Ord. 2005-O-02, 1-26-
2005)
3-5-9: PUBLIC WATER AND SANITARY SEWER MAIN EXTENSIONS:
   A.   Sewer: Where connection to a public sanitary sewer system is desired or
is required, the owner of the premises in question shall, at such owner's sole
cost and expense, extend, or provide for the extension of, such sewer to, and
across the entire length or width of, the premises in question and shall, if no
existing public easement for the main to receive the connection is available
adjacent to or across the premises in question, lawfully dedicate, free of any
superior lien interests, such an easement across the entire length or width of
such premises, all in accordance with Village standards and specifications for
the extension, installation, operation and maintenance of the subject component
(s) of the Village sewerage system.
   B.   Water: Where connection to a public water system is desired or
required, the owner of the premises in question shall, at such owner's sole
cost and expense, extend, or provide for the extension of, such water system
to, and across the entire length or width of, the premises in question and
shall, if no existing public easement for the main to receive the connection is
available adjacent to or across the premises in question, lawfully dedicate,
free of any superior lien interests, such an easement across the entire length
or width of such premises, all in accordance with the applicable jurisdictional
standards and specifications for the extension, installation, operation and
maintenance of the public water system.
   C.   Exceptions To Extending Mains Along The Length Or Width Of Premises:
Extension of the public sanitary sewer system or public water system across the
entire length or width of the premises in question will not be required under
the circumstances listed below. Instead, the extension shall be of sufficient
length to service the principal structure on the subject premises:
      1.   When the premises for which the connection is to be made would
extend public sewer and/or public water to the far lot line and the adjoining
property(ies) are currently connected or currently have lawfully available main
lines to connect to public sewer and/or public water.
      2.   When the premises in question are located at the end limits of the
Village service area and, if a corner lot or parcel, no such extension is
necessary to serve adjacent lots or parcels pursuant to the reasonable water or
sewer service area plans of the Village. (Ord. 2017-O-11, 6-28-2017)
CHAPTER 6
REFUSE, RECYCLABLES, AND LANDSCAPE WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSITION
SECTION:
3-6-1: Definitions
3-6-2: Village Contractors
3-6-3: Franchise; Charges; Arbitration
3-6-4: Licenses; Applications
3-6-5: Licenses; Number, Term, Fee
3-6-6: Penalty
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms, phrases and words and their
derivations shall have the meanings given in this section, unless the context
or use clearly indicates another or different meaning is intended:
CONTRACTOR: Any person, firm or corporation being in the business of collecting
and disposing of garbage or refuse, or recyclable materials. Any contractor
wishing to conduct business within the village of Green Oaks for residential
collection and disposal shall obtain a license for such business, issued
pursuant to the franchising authority established by this chapter.
GARBAGE OR REFUSE: As used herein shall include the following:
   A.   All kitchen wastes, including cans, bottles, household food,
accumulations of animal food and vegetable matter attendant on the preparation,
use, cooking and service of foods.
   B.   General household trash and refuse, including ashes, empty cartons,
crates, boxes, wrapping materials, newspapers and magazines, when securely and
neatly bound in convenient size bundles, cloth materials, empty cans, discarded
toys, discarded clothing and similar materials.
   C.   Discarded furniture, including beds, springs, mattresses, overstuffed
furniture and other furniture, appliances, carpeting (securely bound in rolls
not exceeding 4 feet in length), bicycles, sleds, swing sets, tools and other
household items.
   D.   Yard materials, including bagged leaves, grass clippings, weeds,
Christmas trees, bushes, brush clippings and branch clippings, when securely
bound in bundles not exceeding four feet (4') in length.
   E.   Small amounts of earth, sod, rocks and building materials resulting
from do-it-yourself projects, if placed in acceptable containers hereinafter
defined.
   F.   Any garbage or refuse not falling within the above definitions or
categories shall be unacceptable and the contractor shall not be required to
collect such garbage or refuse.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS: Include, but are not limited to, newspapers, cans
(including aluminum, metal, bimetal and tin), glass and other refuse, which
from time to time may be designated by the village as recyclable materials
based on market conditions and available recycling technology, that may be
disposed of through the village's recycling program. (Ord. 2000-O-11, 9-6-2000)
3-6-2: VILLAGE CONTRACTORS:
All garbage and refuse, and all "recyclable materials", as defined in this
chapter, collected from residential dwelling units within the village, whether
single-family, duplex or multiple units, not to exceed four (4) units, shall be
collected and removed only by a contractor having a franchise with the village.
Periodic scheduled pickup of garbage or recyclable materials from residential
units within the village by any contractors not having a franchise with the
village is prohibited. All written contracts in existence on the passage date
of this chapter, by established homeowners' associations for residential
garbage, refuse or recyclable collection and disposal for an entire
subdivision, are exempt from the prohibition set forth above; provided that a
copy of such a contract, certified as accurate by the contractor and the
customer, must be filed in the office of the village clerk within sixty (60)
days hereafter, and provided further that no such contract shall be extended or
renewed, whether automatically or otherwise, after expiration of the term
pending as of the passage date of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-O-11, 9-6-2000)
3-6-3: FRANCHISE; CHARGES; ARBITRATION:
The village will grant one exclusive franchise and license to a contractor to
be the sole franchisee for collection and disposal of garbage, refuse and/or
recyclable materials for any and all residential units, including multiple
dwelling units, in the village during the term of the franchise agreement.
Owners of dwelling units desiring other or additional collection and removal
service will be permitted to do so and may do so by separate agreement with the
franchisee. To the extent that standardization of such charges is possible,
particularly in the case of periodically scheduled collection, such service
charges will be uniform and standard and shall be set forth in the contract
between the village and the contractor. The agreement shall provide that in the
event any controversy over pricing, upon request of the user and/or the
contractor, the village will act as sole arbitrator and the franchisee will
agree to be bound by the decision of the village. (Ord. 2000-O-11, 9-6-2000)
3-6-4: LICENSES; APPLICATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the collection or disposal of
garbage, refuse or recyclable materials from residential dwellings within the
village, without first having obtained a license therefor from the village and
entering into a contract therefor with the village. Applications for
residential garbage, refuse and recyclable collection licenses shall be made in
writing to the village administrator. Each application shall contain such
information as may be prescribed by the village administrator, including, but
not limited to, the name and address of the applicant, and, if the applicant is
other than a natural person, the names and addresses of all partners,
directors, officers, registered agents and/or other persons having any
ownership interest, beneficial or otherwise in the applicant. (Ord. 2000-O-11,
9-6-2000)
3-6-5: LICENSES; NUMBER, TERM, FEE:
Not more than one residential garbage, refuse or recyclable collection and
disposal license shall be issued and in force at any one time. All such
licenses shall be annual licenses, the terms of which shall commence on May 1
of each year, or the date of issuance if later than May 1, and shall terminate
on April 30 of the following year. The fee for a residential garbage, refuse or
recyclable collection and disposal license shall be two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) per year. (Ord. 2000-O-11, 9-6-2000)
3-6-6: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or entity violating the terms and conditions of this chapter
shall be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
with each and every day that the violation is allowed to exist. Each day that a
violation exists constitutes a distinct and separate offense under the terms of
this chapter. In addition, the corporate authority may take whatever action it
deems appropriate to enforce the terms of this chapter, including an action for
injunction. All attorney fees and costs incurred by the municipality in
enforcing the terms of this chapter shall be paid by the violator. (Ord. 2000-
O-11, 9-6-2000)
CHAPTER 7
CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: Cable/Video Service Provider Fee Imposed
3-7-3: Applicable Principles
3-7-4: No Impact On Other Taxes Due From Holder
3-7-5: Audits Of Cable/Video Service Provider
3-7-6: Late Fees/Payments
3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the following meanings:
CABLE SERVICE: That term as defined in 47 USC section 522(6).
COMMISSION: The Illinois commerce commission.
GROSS REVENUES: All consideration of any kind or nature, including, without
limitation, cash, credits, property, and in- kind contributions received by the
holder for the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable service or
video service within the holder's cable service or video service area within
the village.
   A.   Gross revenues shall include the following:
      1.   Recurring charges for cable or video service.
      2.   Event based charges for cable service or video service, including,
but not limited to, pay per view and video on demand charges.
      3.   Rental of set top boxes and other cable service or video service
equipment.
      4.   Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video
service, including, but not limited to, activation, installation, and repair
charges.
      5.   Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or
video service, including, but not limited to, service order and service
termination charges.
      6.   Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds, check charges, and
other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments.
      7.   A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or its
affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation
of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the
village. The allocation shall be based on the number of subscribers in the
village divided by the total number of subscribers in relation to the relevant
regional or national compensation arrangement.
      8.   Compensation received by the holder that is derived from the
operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service
with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the holder's network,
such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to subsection A9 of this
definition.
      9.   In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or
integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the
portion of the holder's revenue attributable to the other services,
capabilities, or applications shall be included in the gross revenue unless the
holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from
its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business.
      10.   The service provider fee permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-801(b).
   B.   Gross revenues do not include any of the following:
      1.   Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt,
subject to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi).
      2.   Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the
amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the state issued
authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is
attributable to cable service or video service.
      3.   Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or
functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues
received from services not classified as cable service or video service,
including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication
services, information services, or the provision of directory or internet
advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and
electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder to
noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the holder's books and
records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable
laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders.
      4.   The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which the
purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the purchaser's
subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will
resell the service within the village and pay the fee permitted by 220 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service.
      5.   Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers
or the transaction by a city, state, federal, or any other governmental entity
and collected by the holder of the state issued authorization and required to
be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes.
      6.   Security deposits collected from subscribers.
      7.   Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors
for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the
cable service or video service.
   C.   Revenue of an affiliate of a holder shall be included in the
calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as
revenue of the affiliate rather than the holder has the effect of evading the
payment of the fee permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b)
which would otherwise be paid by the cable service or video service.
HOLDER: A person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide
cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-401.
SERVICE: The provision of "cable service" or "video service" to subscribers and
the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that has received
authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission
pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401.
SERVICE PROVIDER FEE: The amount paid under this chapter and 220 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/21-801 by the holder to a village for the service areas
within its territorial jurisdiction.
VIDEO SERVICE: Video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is
required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which
is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public
right of way without regard to delivery technology, including internet protocol
technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by
a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 USC section 332(d) or any
video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables
users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services
offered over the public internet. (Ord. 2007-O-16, 11-28-2007)
3-7-2: CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE IMPOSED:
   A.   Fee Imposed: A fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable
service or video service in the village.
   B.   Amount Of Fee: The amount of the fee imposed hereby shall be five
percent (5%) of the holder's gross revenues.
   C.   Notice To The Village: The holder shall notify the village at least ten
(10) days prior to the date on which the holder begins to offer cable service
or video service in the village.
   D.   Holder's Liability: The holder shall be liable for and pay the service
provider fee to the village. The holder's liability for the fee shall commence
on the first day of the calendar month following thirty (30) days after receipt
of the ordinance adopting this chapter by the holder. The ordinance adopting
this chapter shall be sent by mail, postage prepaid, to the address listed on
the holder's application notice sent pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/21-401(b)(6) to the village.
   E.   Payment Date: The payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a
quarterly basis, forty five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter.
If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each
payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of
the fee.
   F.   Exemption: The fee hereby imposed does not apply to existing cable
service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement
with the village in which a fee is paid. Provided, however, if the village
terminates the said agreement(s) or said agreements expire or are not renewed,
then the provisions of this chapter shall apply upon the termination or
expiration of the agreement(s).
   G.   Credit For Other Payments: An incumbent cable operator that elects to
terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
21-301(c) with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement may
deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under
subsection B of this section. (Ord. 2007-O-16, 11-28-2007)
3-7-3: APPLICABLE PRINCIPLES:
All determinations and calculations under this chapter shall be made pursuant
to generally accepted accounting principles. (Ord. 2007-O-16, 11-28-2007)
3-7-4: NO IMPACT ON OTHER TAXES DUE FROM HOLDER:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to exempt a holder from
any tax that is or may later be imposed by the village, including any tax that
is or may later be required to be paid by or through the holder with respect to
cable service or video service. A state issued authorization shall not affect
any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of any duly adopted
simplified municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to
any telephone service provided by the holder. A state issued authorization
shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the
local unit of government's 911 or E911 fees, taxes or charges. (Ord. 2007-O-16,
11-28-2007)
3-7-5: AUDITS OF CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER:
   A.   Audit Requirement: The village will notify the holder of the
requirements it imposes on other cable service or video service providers to
submit to an audit of its books and records. The holder shall comply with the
same requirements the village imposes on other cable service or video service
providers in its jurisdiction to audit the holder's books and records and to
recompute any amounts determined to be payable under the requirements of the
village. If all local franchises between the village and cable operator
terminate, the audit requirements shall be those adopted by the village
pursuant to the local government taxpayers' bill of rights act, 50 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 45/1 et seq. No acceptance of amounts remitted should be
construed as an accord that the amounts are correct.
   B.   Additional Payments: Any additional amount due after an audit shall be
paid within thirty (30) days after the municipality's submission of an invoice
for the sum. (Ord. 2007-O-16, 11-28-2007)
3-7-6: LATE FEES/PAYMENTS:
All fees due and payments which are past due shall be governed by ordinances
adopted by this municipality pursuant to the local government taxpayers' bill
of rights act, 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 45/1 et seq. (Ord. 2007-O-16, 11-
28-2007)
TITLE 4
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
FIREARMS, WEAPONS AND HUNTING
SECTION:
4-1-1: Firearms And Weapons Regulated
4-1-1-1: Purpose
4-1-1-2: Discharge Of Firearms
4-1-1-3: Bow And Arrow, Slingshot, Etc.
4-1-1-4: Hunting
4-1-1-5: Shooting Ranges
4-1-1-6: Penalty
4-1-2: Trespassing, Poaching
4-1-1: FIREARMS AND WEAPONS REGULATED:
4-1-1-1: PURPOSE:
This Section
4-1-1 is intended to regulate the use of firearms and other weapons in the
Village. (Ord. 93-33, 12-22-1993)
4-1-1-2: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS:
   A.   No person shall discharge any smoothbore firearm, rifle or handgun
within the Village limits, except as provided in Section
4-1-1-5 of this Chapter, unless lawfully authorized to bear arms in the
discharge of his duties.
   B.   No person shall kill or wound or attempt to kill or wound within the
Village limits, any bird or animal by the use of any smoothbore or rifled
weapon be it powered by gunpowder, compressed air, gas or spring or by use of a
bow and arrows, slingshot or similar weapon or device. (Ord. 93-33, 12-22-1993)
4-1-1-3: BOW AND ARROW, SLINGSHOT, ETC.:
   A.   No person shall use a bow and arrows, slingshot or other similar
weapons or devices within the Village limits for the purpose of striking or
damaging any public or private property. (Ord. 93-33, 12-22-1993; amd. Ord. 98-
04, 2-25-1998)
   B.   1. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot, release or otherwise
project an arrow, bolt, missile or other projectile from, into, or upon a
residentially zoned property where such arrow, bolt, missile or projectile is:
         a.   Shot or released from a bow device (standard, compound or
crossbow); and
         b.   Such bow device is rated either as having a draw of fifteen (15)
pounds or more, or a velocity of fifty feet (50') per second or more.
      2.   This Section shall not be applicable where:
         a.   The shooting, releasing or projecting activity is carried on
completely indoors; or
         b.   Where the point of the release of such arrow, bolt, missile or
other projectile is one thousand feet (1,000') or more from an adjacent
residentially zoned property.
      3.   No targeting object for purposes of this subsection B shall be
located within two hundred feet (200') of an adjacent residentially zoned
property.
      4.   It shall be unlawful for any person to promote, sponsor, hold or
participate in any outdoor archery competition within or upon a residentially
zoned property unless:
         a.   Such competition complies with the Federation Internationale de
tir a l'arc rules of competition; and
         b.   A permit for such competition is obtained from the Village; and
         c.   The site or sites of the competition is in compliance with
subsection B2a and B2b of this Section.
   C.   An applicant for a permit under this section shall include in the
application a certification of compliance hereunder and shall also show by
sufficient detail that facilities will be installed to assure that no arrow,
bolt or missile will stray beyond twenty feet (20') of the vertical plane of
the competition target. (Ord. 98-04, 2-25-1998)
4-1-1-4: HUNTING:
No hunting of any bird or animal by the use of any weapon or device shall be
permitted within the village limits. (Ord. 93-33, 12-22-1993)
4-1-1-5: SHOOTING RANGES:
The board of trustees may authorize the establishment of any properly organized
public or private shooting range within the village limits. The type of
firearms used on such a range shall be governed strictly by standards of safety
to the general public. (Ord. 61-05, 10-28-1961)
4-1-1-6: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this section
4-1-1 shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 61-05, 10-28-1961; amd.
Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
4-1-2: TRESPASSING, POACHING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass or poach for any reason or
purpose upon any private property located in the village without first securing
the consent of the owner of said property or the consent of a duly authorized
agent of said owner. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 76-05, 9-22-1976; amd. Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-
2001)
CHAPTER 2
SOLICITING, PEDDLING
SECTION:
4-2-1: Permit Required
4-2-2: Application For Permit, Approval
4-2-3: Permit Form
4-2-4: Fee
4-2-5: Regulations Regarding Solicitations
4-2-6: Consent Of Owner Required
4-2-7: Penalty
4-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
All soliciting, selling of goods, wares or merchandise, or the taking of orders
or the solicitation of orders for the sale of any goods, wares and merchandise,
or the distribution thereof from house to house and place to place is hereby
expressly prohibited, unless the person shall first have secured a permit so to
do. No permit shall be required under this chapter for any religious or
political canvassing, or for any effort to enlist support for a cause that does
not involve fundraising. (Ord. 2003-O-6, 5-28-2003)
4-2-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT, APPROVAL:
Any person desiring a permit hereunder shall make application therefor to the
president of the board of trustees of the village in writing, which application
shall state the purpose, object and time for which such permit is desired, and
the name of the party or parties desiring the same. The president of the
village shall grant a permit to the applicant or refuse a permit as in his
judgment shall be most beneficial for the interest of the village. (Ord. 62-O-
04, 5-23-1962)
4-2-3: PERMIT FORM:
The permit shall be under the name of the village; shall be executed by the
clerk of the village; shall state the object and purpose of said permit, and
the amount paid therefor; shall contain a statement that said permit is issued
and accepted subject to the ordinances then in force, or to become in force,
relating to the subject matter thereof, and that the same is subject to
revocation by the president of the village. No permit shall be issued to extend
beyond the last day of the municipal year. (Ord. 62-O-04, 5-23-1962)
4-2-4: FEE:
The fee for a permit hereunder is hereby fixed at ten dollars ($10.00) per day
for each person and at that rate for each and every day said permit is to
continue. (Ord. 62-O-04, 5-23-1962)
4-2-5: REGULATIONS REGARDING SOLICITATIONS:
   A.   No person shall act as a house to house, place to place solicitor,
salesman or canvasser excepting between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
and five o'clock (5:00) P.M., and no such person shall operate on Sunday.
   B.   No person shall canvass, fundraise, solicit, sell goods, wares or
merchandise, or take orders or solicit orders for the sale of any goods, wares
and merchandise, or the distribution thereof on any street, roadway, or
highway, or part thereof, within the village. For purposes of this subsection,
the terms "street", "roadway", and "highway" shall have the definition provided
in the Illinois vehicle code 1 . (Ord. 2003-O-07, 6-25-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/100 et seq.
4-2-6: CONSENT OF OWNER REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to enter any residential premises, for the purpose of
selling or taking orders for any commodity or service, or for soliciting
contributions or memberships of any nature without the express or implied
consent of the occupant of such premises. (Ord. 62-O-04, 5-23-1962)
4-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
or penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense, and each day a violation continues
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 62-O-04, 5-23-1962)
CHAPTER 3
WILD ANIMALS, REPTILES
SECTION:
4-3-1: Purpose
4-3-2: Definitions
4-3-3: Wild Animals, Reptiles Prohibited
4-3-4: Violations
4-3-5: Penalty
4-3-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to maintain the safety, welfare and tranquility
of the residents of the village. (Ord. 76-07, 11-23-1976)
4-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
ANIMAL: Includes wild and tame wild animals and shall not be limited to, but
will include, the following animals: lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar,
cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, hyena, coyote,
and any other wild animal.
RAISING OF WILD ANIMALS, TAME WILD ANIMALS OR REPTILES: Applies to the raising
of wild animals, tame wild animals and reptiles for hobby and/or profit.
REPTILE: Shall not be limited to, but will include, poisonous reptiles or
nonpoisonous reptiles. (Ord. 76-07, 11-23-1976)
4-3-3: WILD ANIMALS, REPTILES PROHIBITED:
No person, business association, corporation, residence, or any other
association, club, or group may keep any lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar,
cheetah, margay, mountain lion, Canada lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, hyena, coyote,
or any other wild animal, poisonous reptile, or nonpoisonous reptile, within
the corporate limits of the village.
Any wild animal or reptile which has been domesticated will not be exempt from
the enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 76-07, 11-23-1976)
4-3-4: VIOLATIONS:
Any person violating this chapter shall be guilty of a petty offense and must
remove the animal or reptile from the village within ten (10) days after
notification that a violation has occurred. (Ord. 76-07, 11-23-1976)
4-3-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
or penalty of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and each day a violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 76-07, 11-23-1976; amd.
Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
CHAPTER 4
MISDEMEANORS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Vandalism
4-4-1: VANDALISM:
   A.   Definitions: Whenever any of the following terms shall be used in this
Section, they shall have the meanings indicated:
    JUVENILE: Includes a person who has attained ten (10) years of age but who
has not yet reached eighteen (18) years of age.
   LEGAL GUARDIAN: Includes a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a
juvenile by a circuit court of this State or any other state, but does not
include a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor under the
Illinois Juvenile Court Act 1 .
   PARENT: Includes the lawful father or mother of an unemancipated juvenile,
whether by birth or adoption.
   PERSON: Includes any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   PROPERTY: Includes any real estate including improvements thereof, and
personalty, whether tangible or intangible.
   B.   Offenses: No person shall commit any of the following acts within the
corporate limits of the Village:
      1.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly damage, deface or destroy any
property of another person without his consent; or
      2.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly, by means of fire or explosive
device, damage, deface or destroy any property of another person; or
      3.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly start a fire on the land of
another person without his consent; or
      4.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly deposit on the land or in a
building of another person, without his consent, any stink bomb, or any
offensive smelling compound and thereby interfere with the use and occupancy by
another of the land or building; or
      5.   Maliciously, recklessly or knowingly and without authority enter
into any building, house trailer, motor vehicle, aircraft or watercraft or any
part thereof of another person without his consent.
      6.   Commit theft. A person commits theft when he knowingly:
         a.   Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the
owner; or
         b.   Obtains by deception control over property of the owner; or
         c.   Obtains by threat control over property of the owner; or
         d.   Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have
been stolen by another or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce
him to believe that the property was stolen, and
            (1)   Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or
benefit of the property; or
            (2)   Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such
manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or
            (3)   Uses, conceals or abandons the property knowing such use,
concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such
use or benefit.
   C.   Penalty: The following penalties shall be imposed upon any person
convicted of a violation of this section:
      1.   Such restitution or reparation as the court may require in an amount
not to exceed actual loss or damage to property or pecuniary loss. Nothing in
this subsection C1 shall preclude such additional civil remedies available to a
complaining party for any sum not recovered. (Ord. 87-10, 8-26-1987)
      2.   In addition or in lieu of such restitution or reparation as
hereinabove provided, a fine of not in excess of seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each such offense. In the event the person convicted is an
unemancipated juvenile, said fine may be imposed upon the parent or legal
guardian of said unemancipated juvenile pursuant to subsection D of this
section. (Ord. 87-10, 8-26-1987; amd. Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
   D.   Liability:
      1.   The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated juvenile who
resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the
wilful or malicious acts of such juvenile which cause injury to a person or
property.
Said juvenile shall be deemed to have committed the offense or offenses
enumerated in this section with the knowledge, consent, acquiescence, and
permission of the parent or legal guardian, in violation of this section.
The said parent or legal guardian shall be liable for fine, requirement of
restitution or reparation imposed by a court upon the juvenile defendant for
violation of this section.
      2.   The sanctions of this section shall apply after said parent or legal
guardian shall have received a written notice thereof, either by certified or
registered mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service, with a
certificate of personal service returned from the village prior to the
institution of any judicial sanction or penalty.
In any action brought against an unemancipated juvenile pursuant to the
provisions of this section, the parent or legal guardian shall be made a party
defendant. Failure to include such parent or legal guardian as a party
defendant shall release him from any liability for fine, restitution or
reparation imposed upon the minor defendant. (Ord. 87-10, 8-26-1987)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.
CHAPTER 5
MINORS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Curfew
4-5-3: Cruelty To Minors
4-5-4: Purchase, Possession Or Use Of Alcoholic Liquors
4-5-5: Parental Responsibility
4-5-6: Firearms For Minors
4-5-7: Truancy Prohibited
4-5-8: Penalty
4-5-9: Liability
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever any of the following terms shall be used in this chapter, they shall
have the meanings indicated:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Any alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or
solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable
of being consumed as a beverage by a human being.
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a
