PUBLIC PROPERTY:      width between the boundary lines publicly maintained for
                      the purposes of vehicular travel, and any other property
                      or facility owned by a public entity.
                      Every vehicle without motive power in operation designed
                      for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a
TRAILER:              motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its
                      weight rests upon the towing vehicle. However, a trailer
                      commonly referred to as a "fifth wheel" trailer is
                      considered a trailer by this definition.
                      A trailer, not used commercially, designed to provide
TRAVEL TRAILER:       living quarters for recreational, camping, or travel use,
                      and of a size or weight not requiring an over dimension
                      permit when towed on a highway or Village street.
UNLICENSED VEHICLE:   Any vehicle which does not display a current and valid
                      license plate currently registered to the vehicle.
                      Any vehicle which is not properly and currently
UNREGISTERED VEHICLE: registered with the office of the Illinois Secretary of
                      State.
                      Every device, in, upon, or by which any person or
                      property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway
                      or Village street or requiring a certificate of title
VEHICLE:              under the statutes of the state of Illinois (625 ILCS 5/
                      3-101) except devices moved by human power, devices used
                      exclusively upon stationary rails and snowmobiles as
                      defined in the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act
                      (625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq.).
                      A person who holds legal title to a vehicle or, in the
                      event a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for
                      conditional sale or lease thereof with the right of
                      purchase upon the performance of the conditions stated in
VEHICLE OWNER:        the agreement and with the immediate right of possession
                      vested in the conditional vendee or lessee or in the
                      event a mortgagor of such vehicle is entitled to
                      possession, then such conditional vendee, lessee or
                      mortgagor shall be deemed the owner for the purposes of
                      this chapter. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
 
4-13-2: DECLARATION OF NUISANCE:
The Corporate Authority finds and declares that abandoned vehicles, inoperable
vehicles and unregistered vehicles, whether located upon private property or
upon public property, constitute a public nuisance detrimental to the health,
safety and welfare of the general public, by harboring disease, providing
breeding places for vermin, inviting plundering, creating fire hazards and
presenting physical dangers to children and others, and by creating scenic
blights which degrade the environment and adversely affect land values and the
proper maintenance and continuing development of the Village. (Ord. 2020-O-09,
9-23-2020)
4-13-3: EXEMPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to the following:
   A.   A vehicle which is kept within a fully enclosed building when not in
use;
   B.   An operable antique vehicle properly and currently registered with the
office of the Illinois Secretary of State;
   C.   A vehicle on the premises of a place of business lawfully engaged in
the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles, or on the premises of a place of
business lawfully engaged in the sale of new or used automobiles permitting
outdoor storage of vehicle inventory, provided, however, that the latter
business does not store or display inoperable vehicles;
   D.   A vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven
under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair
operations for a period of not more than seven days from the date the vehicle
became inoperable. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-4: STORAGE OF UNREGISTERED VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
No person shall accumulate, store or allow any unregistered or unlicensed
vehicle to be located upon any public property or private property within the
Village for a period exceeding seven days. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-5: COVERING OR STORING VEHICLES:
Covering, tarping, or storing an abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle
in an unenclosed building or structure will not be considered to resolve an
abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle as a public nuisance. Any
abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle belonging to an individual who is
in the process of selling the vehicle, will have thirty (30) days from the date
of receiving a notice from the Village as described in this chapter to complete
the sale thereof before the Village may proceed with any or all of the remedies
set forth in Section
4-13-8 or
4-13-9 of this chapter. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-6: DUTY TO DISPOSE OF ABANDONED, INOPERABLE OR UNREGISTERED VEHICLES:
Any person, not exempted under Section
4-13-3, shall dispose of any abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle
owned by him or her, and, if the vehicle is located upon private property, the
owner or person occupying the private property shall dispose of the abandoned,
inoperable or unregistered vehicle as set forth in this chapter, upon written
notice received from the village commanding the disposition thereof. (Ord.
2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-7: NOTICE:
   A.   If the abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle displays
registration plates or decals from which the last known vehicle owner may be
determined in a reasonably expeditious manner, notice as set forth in this
chapter shall be sent to the last registered vehicle owner, and, if the vehicle
is located upon private property, to the owner or occupant of the private
property upon which the vehicle is located.
   B.   All notices provided by this section shall be sent by registered or
certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid. Notice to one
vehicle owner will be considered notice to all vehicle owners and notice to one
owner or occupant of private property will be considered notice to all owners
and/or occupants of private property upon which the vehicle is located. Refusal
to accept delivery of the notice shall be deemed acceptance for purposes of
this section. The date of notice for purposes of this section shall be the day
after the date such notice was deposited with the United States postal service,
first class postage prepaid. Notice may be personally served by a Village
police authority or the Village Code Enforcement Officer, or, if the vehicle is
located upon private property, upon an owner or an occupant of the private
property above the age of fourteen (14) years, in which case the date of notice
shall be the date of personal service.
   C.   If the vehicle is located upon public property and does not constitute
an immediate hazard, danger or threat to health or safety, the notice will be
substantially in the form set forth in this subsection:
   NOTICE TO REMOVE VEHICLE FROM PUBLIC PROPERTY
   TO: Name:                                                Date:
                             
   Address:
                                                                                          
   A Vehicle described as:
   Make:                           ___________   
   Year:                          
   Color:                          
   with registration plates number                    (the Vehicle) is
registered in the name(s) of                           with the State of
                 . The Vehicle is located at                       outside of
an enclosed building and is deemed to be an Abandoned, Inoperable or
Unregistered Vehicle under Section
4-13-1, et. seq. of the Village of Green Oaks Village Code (the Ordinance). You
are hereby notified that the Vehicle must be removed, disposed of or placed in
an enclosed building within seven (7) days of the day after the date this
Notice was deposited with the United States Postal Service. If you fail to
remove, dispose of, or place the Vehicle in an enclosed building within the
specified period, or within any written extension granted by the Village
Administrator, the Village may cause the towing or removal of the Vehicle
without further notice to you, and you may be charged with a violation of the
Ordinance and may be subject to penalties pursuant to the Village of Green Oaks
Municipal Village Code. In addition, the costs of towing and storage, including
court costs and reasonable attorney's fees may be assessed against you.
   D.    If the vehicle is located upon private property, the notice shall be
substantially in the form set forth in this subsection:
   NOTICE TO REMOVE VEHICLE FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY
   TO: Name:                                                Date:
                             
   Address:
                                                                                          
   A Vehicle described as:
   Make:                           ___________   
   Year:                          
   Color:                          
   with registration plates number                                 (the
Vehicle) is registered in the name(s) of                           with the
State of               . The Vehicle is located at                        
outside of an enclosed building and is deemed to be an Abandoned, Inoperable or
Unregistered Vehicle under Section
4-13-1, et. seq. of the Village of Green Oaks Village Code (the Ordinance). You
are hereby notified that the Vehicle must be removed, disposed of or placed in
an enclosed building within seven (7) days of the day after the date this
Notice was deposited with the United States Postal Service. You may request a
hearing on the matter of whether the above described vehicle is an Abandoned,
Inoperable or Unregistered Vehicle in violation of Section
4-13-1 et. seq. of the Ordinance by submitting a written request for such a
hearing to the Village Administrator addressed as set forth below, within ten
(10) days of the day after the date this Notice was deposited with the United
States Postal Service. If you submit such a request for a hearing, a hearing
date will be set and you will be advised of the time, date and place of such
hearing at least three (3) days in advance of the date of such hearing. The
Village Administrator shall, upon good cause being shown, grant an extension of
the hearing of not more than thirty (30) days if you submit to the Village
Administrator an affidavit that the Vehicle is being held for sale or for
expeditious repair as defined by Section
4-13-9(B) of the Ordinance. To request a hearing, you must hand deliver or mail
by certified mail, return receipt requested, a request for such a hearing in
writing to the Village Administrator c/o, Village of Green Oaks, 2020 O'Plaine
Road Green Oaks, IL. 60048. If you fail to request a hearing within seven (7)
days of the day after the date this Notice was deposited with the United States
Postal Service, and you do not remove, dispose of, or place the Vehicle in an
enclosed building within the specified period, or within any extension granted
by the Village Administrator after a hearing, the Village may seek a judicial
warrant to search and to seize the Vehicle and to cause the towing or removal
of the Vehicle without further notice to you, and you may be charged with a
violation of the Ordinance and may be subject to penalties pursuant to Section
1-4-1 of the Village of Green Oaks Municipal Village Code. In addition, the
costs of towing and storage, including court costs and reasonable attorney's
fees may be assessed against you. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-8: HEARING REGARDING VEHICLE LOCATED UPON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   The person or persons to whom the notice as specified in Section
4-13-7(D) is directed, shall have the right to a hearing before the Village
Administrator or his/her designee on the matter of whether the vehicle cited in
such notice is an abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle in violation of
this chapter. To obtain such a hearing, a written request for such a hearing
must be submitted by hand delivery or by certified mail, return receipt
requested, addressed to the Village Administrator c/o, Village of Green Oaks,
2020 O'Plaine Road Green Oaks, IL. 60048, within seven days of the day after
the date this notice was deposited with the United States postal service. In
the event that a hearing is so requested, the Village Administrator shall, as
soon as reasonably practicable, set a time, date and place for the hearing
before the Village Administrator, or his/her designee, and shall cause the
person or persons so requesting the hearing to be provided with written notice
of the time, date and place of the hearing at least three days in advance of
the date of the hearing. Enforcement of this chapter shall be stayed pending
the hearing and determination by the Village Administrator.
   B.   The owner of the vehicle or, the owner or occupant of the private
property upon which the vehicle is located, may apply for an extension of time
of the hearing by submitting to the Village Administrator an affidavit that the
vehicle is being held for sale or expeditious repair. Upon receipt of any such
application for an extension of time, the Village Administrator shall, upon
good cause being shown, grant an extension of the hearing of not more than
thirty (30) days. As used in this section, "expeditious repair" means:
      1.   That the necessary parts for repair have been ordered but are not
available for installation in the vehicle for reasons not within the control of
the owner of the vehicle;
      2.   That the vehicle is scheduled to be repaired by a person whose
regular course of business includes the repair of vehicles and the scheduled
repair date is within thirty (30) days; or
      3.   That the vehicle is in such condition of being inoperable as a
result of a vehicular accident, and the owner of the vehicle or any third party
to whom, or from whom, a claim for the damages sustained in such accident is
anticipated, is investigating or preparing a claim for such damages. (Ord.
2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-9: TOWING:
   A.   Public Property. In the event the notice provided for in Section
4-13-7(C) is not complied with, the Village, may cause the towing or removal of
the abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle from public property without
further notice to the vehicle owner.
   B.   Private Property. In the event the notice provided for in Section
4-13-7(D) is not complied with, the Village, except as provided in subsection
(B)(1) of this section, may seek a judicial warrant to search and to seize the
abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle and to cause the towing or
removal thereof from private property.
      1.   In the event a request for a hearing before the Village
Administrator is made as set forth in Section
4-13-8, and the Village Administrator, or his/her designee, determines the
vehicle is an abandoned, inoperable or unregistered vehicle, the Village
Administrator shall set a reasonable date by which the vehicle shall be
disposed of or enclosed within a building. The date shall be no less than seven
days after the date of the hearing. In the event the vehicle is not disposed of
or enclosed within a building by the date set by the Village Administrator, the
Village may seek a judicial warrant to search and to seize the abandoned,
inoperable or unregistered vehicle and to cause the towing or removal of the
vehicle from private property without further notice to the vehicle owner or to
the owner or occupant of the private property.
   C.   It shall be the responsibility of the vehicle owner or, the owner of
the private property upon which the vehicle is located, if applicable, to
deliver a written notice to the Village Administrator, and to provide
documentation and/or demonstration of operability of the vehicle, and that the
vehicle has been properly registered, if the vehicle has been put into operable
condition and/or registered with the Secretary of State of the State of
Illinois following issuance of the notice described in Section
4-13-7 hereof. In the event no such written notice and evidence of compliance
herewith is received by the Village Administrator, it shall be presumed that
the vehicle remains abandoned, inoperable or unregistered and the Village may
immediately cause the towing or removal of the vehicle from public property,
or, if located upon private property, seek a judicial warrant to search and to
seize the vehicle and to cause the towing or removal of the vehicle from
private property without further notice to the vehicle owner or to the owner or
occupant of the private property.
   D.   Whenever a vehicle is towed or removed by a towing service pursuant to
the provisions of this chapter, the owner of the vehicle and the owner or
occupant of the property upon which the abandoned, inoperable or unregistered
vehicle is located, if applicable, shall be jointly and severally responsible
for all towing and storage charges.
   E.   Within forty-eight (48) hours of the removal of the vehicle, the
Village will send notice to the vehicle owner and any lien holder, if known,
and to the owner or occupant of the private property from which the vehicle was
removed, if applicable, that the vehicle has been impounded and stored for
violation of this chapter. The notice shall give the location of the vehicle
and the costs, if any, incurred by the Village for removal.
   F.   Any vehicle towed or removed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter
will be stored and claimed or disposed of in accordance with the applicable
provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, as amended, entitled "Abandoned, Lost,
Stolen or Unclaimed Vehicles," 625 ILCS 5/4-200 et. seq. which is incorporated
in this chapter by reference. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-10: RECORD OF VEHICLES TOWED:
When a vehicle is authorized to be towed, the Village shall keep and maintain a
record of the vehicle listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's
name, manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and
license plate year and number, if any, displayed on the vehicle. The record
shall also include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location
towed to, reason for towing and the name of the Village official authorizing
the tow. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-11: CUMULATIVE REMEDIES:
Each of the provisions and remedies of this chapter shall be in addition to any
other provisions and remedies provided by this code or the Illinois Compiled
Statutes. (Ord. 2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-12: SEPARABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
Each section, paragraph, sentence, clause and provision of this chapter is
separable and if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any
reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this chapter nor any
part of this chapter, other than that part affected by such decision. (Ord.
2020-O-09, 9-23-2020)
4-13-13: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter will be subject to
penalties pursuant to Section
1-4-1 of this code. If the Village incurs expense, including towing or
reasonable attorneys' fees, in enforcing this chapter, the vehicle owner and
the owner or occupant of private property notified as set forth in Section
4-13-7 will be jointly and severally responsible for the expense. (Ord. 2020-O-
09, 9-23-2020)

Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less
than fifteen dollars ($15.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars

CHAPTER 2
TRAFFIC CONTROL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-2-1: Hazardous Intersections Designated
5-2-2: Stop Intersections Designated
5-2-3: Violation, Penalty
5-2-1: HAZARDOUS INTERSECTIONS DESIGNATED:
The following areas within the village are hereby designated as hazardous
traffic locations within the village:
Intersections of:
   Atkinson and Crest
   Atkinson and St. Mary's
   Benson Lane and Atkinson
   Benson Road at Atkinson
   Bradley Road and Polo Trail
   Braemore Close and N. Reigate Lane
   Crescent Knoll and Park Hill
   Crest Road and Atkinson Road
   Dan Patch and Morgan Court
   Fox Run and Atkinson
   Glenmore Road and Kenton Road
   Greenbrier and St. Mary's
   Greenbrier Drive and Fox Run
   Greenbrier Drive and Sunrise Road
   Hanlon and Guerin
   Horace Court and State Route 137
   Irondale and Guerin
   Kenton Lane and Cranbrook Road
   King Drive and King Court
   Lexington and St. Mary's
   Lexington Road and Belmont Road
   Margate Lane and Crescent Knoll

5-2-3: VIOLATION, PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate, disobey or refuse to comply
with any "STOP" sign or other traffic control sign provided for herein in the
operation of any motor vehicle at the intersections or areas designated, and
any person, upon conviction, shall be fined not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 89-O-24, 9-27-1989; amd. Ord. 2001-O-

CHAPTER 3
VEHICLE WEIGHT AND LOAD LIMITS
SECTION:
5-3-1: Excessive Weight and Load Prohibited
5-3-2: Weight Limits Established
5-3-3: Action by Officials
5-3-4: Failure of Driver to Stop or Weigh
5-3-5: Special Permit
5-3-6: Exceptions to Regulations
5-3-7: Violation, Penalty
5-3-1: EXCESSIVE WEIGHT AND LOAD PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or move or for the owner to cause or
knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any street or road any vehicle with
lugs or a weight exceeding the limitations stated in this Chapter or otherwise
in violation of this Chapter. The maximum weight of vehicles herein specified
shall be lawful throughout this Village. (Ord. 61-04, 9-27-61)
5-3-2: WEIGHT LIMITS ESTABLISHED:
   A.   No vehicle or combination of vehicles equipped with pneumatic tires
shall be operated, unladen or with load, upon the streets or roads of this
Village when the gross weight on the road surface through any axle thereof
exceeds twelve thousand (12,000) pounds. (Ord. 61-04, 9-27-61)
   B.   The gross weight of vehicles and combinations of vehicles, including
the weight of the vehicle or combination and its maximum load, shall be subject
to the foregoing limitations and further shall not exceed the following maximum
weights:
 
Two (2) axle motor vehicles                                 22,000 pounds
Three (3) axle vehicles                                     30,000 pounds
More than three (3) axle vehicles, including trucks, trailers,  
semi-trailers or combinations thereof                          36,000 pounds
 
(Ord. 90-13, 9-26-90)
   C.   During each year from February 15 to May 1, no vehicle shall be
operated on any Village streets when the gross weight on the road surface
through any axle thereof exceeds eight thousand (8,000) pounds or vehicle gross
weight exceeds sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds. (Ord. 80-04, 3-26-80)
5-3-3: ACTION BY OFFICIALS:
   A.   Any official having reason to believe that the weight of a vehicle and
load is unlawful shall require the driver to stop and submit to a weighing of
the same either by means of a portable or stationary scales. If such scales are
not available at the place where such vehicle is stopped, the official shall
require that such vehicle be driven to the nearest public scales.
   B.   Whenever an officer, upon weighing a vehicle and load as above
provided, determines that the weight is unlawful, such official shall require
the driver to stop the vehicle in a suitable place and remain standing until
such portion of the load is removed as may be necessary to reduce the gross
weight of such vehicle to such limit as permitted under this Chapter and shall
forthwith arrest the driver. All material so unloaded shall be cared for by the
owner or operator of such vehicle at the risk of such owner or operator. (Ord.
61-04, 9-27-61)
5-3-4: FAILURE OF DRIVER TO STOP OR WEIGH:
Any driver of a vehicle who fails or refuses to stop and submit the vehicle and
load to a weighing, or who fails or refuses when directed by an official upon
weighing of the vehicle to stop the vehicle and otherwise comply with the
provisions of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 61-04, 9-27-
61)
5-3-5: SPECIAL PERMIT:
   A.   Issuance: The Board of Trustees may, in its discretion, upon
application in writing and good cause being shown therefor, issue a special
permit, in writing, authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or
combination of vehicles of a weight or load exceeding the maximum specified in
this Chapter or otherwise not in conformity with the provisions of this Chapter
upon any road or street under the jurisdiction of the party granting such
permit and for the maintenance of which said party is responsible. Where a
permit is sought for excess weight the applicant shall show that the load to be
moved by such vehicle or combination of vehicles cannot reasonably be
dismantled or disassembled.
   B.   Application: The application for any such permit shall specifically
describe the vehicle or vehicles and load to be operated or moved and whether
such permit is requested for a single trip or for limited continuous operation.
The application shall state, also, the points of origin and destination of
overweight vehicles or loads when specifically requested by the Village Board.
(Ord. 61-04, 9-27-61)
   C.   Continuous Overload Operation; Bond: The Board of Trustees may
delegate, by resolution, to an officer of the Village, the authority to issue
special permits for continuous overload operation during specified periods for
school buses, garbage trucks and residential construction traffic. The officer
may be empowered to require bonds to be furnished assuring the repair of or
payment for damage to roads traversed by such overloaded vehicles as a
condition for issuance of such permits. (Ord. 80-04, 3-26-80)
   D.   Permit, Each Vehicle: Special permits for continuous overload operation
shall be in the form of a permit registration issued under the authority of the
delegated officer. There shall be a permit issued for each individual vehicle
to be operated under such special permit. The owner or operator of the vehicle
shall make application for such permit on forms furnished by the Village, and
register the vehicle annually before the beginning of the calendar year. The
owner shall pay an annual registration fee, in the amount which may be
established, from time to time, by resolution of the Board of Trustees, before
receiving such permit. If the delegated officer determines that a bond is
required, as provided above, the bond shall be submitted an approved before the
permit is issued. The permit registration shall be evidenced by issuance of a
document which shall be displayed on the vehicle at all times when the vehicle
is operating upon the Village streets.
   E.   When Required: Special permits for continuous overload operation shall
be required if the vehicle is over the weight limits set forth in subsection
5-3-2C of this Chapter relating to weight limits between February 15 and May 1.
(Ord. 92-06, 3-25-92)
5-3-6: EXCEPTIONS TO REGULATIONS:
The provisions of this Chapter governing weight and load shall not apply to
fire apparatus, equipment designed for snow and ice removal operations on
streets and roads by or for the Village, to implements of husbandry temporarily
moved upon a street or road, or to a vehicle operated under the terms of a
special permit issued as herein provided. (Ord. 61-04, 9-27-61)
5-3-7: VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of this Chapter
relating to vehicle weight limits, the owner or driver, or both, of such
vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation, and either the owner or the
driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person
convicted of any violation of Section
5-3-2 of this Chapter, including but not limited to a maximum axle or gross
weight limit specified upon any regulatory sign posted under the provisions of
this Chapter, shall be fined according to the following schedule:
Up to and including: 2,000 pounds       $ 50.00
overweight   
From 2,001 through 2,500 pounds         the fine is $135.00
overweight   
From 2,501 through 3,000 pounds         the fine is $165.00
overweight   
From 3,001 through 3,500 pounds         the fine is $260.00
overweight   
From 3,501 through 4,000 pounds         the fine is $300.00
overweight   
From 4,001 through 4,500 pounds         the fine is $425.00
overweight

                                        $750.00 for the first 5,000 pounds

                                        additional increment of 500 pounds or
                                        fraction thereof.
 
(Ord. 90-13, 9-26-90)
CHAPTER 4
VEHICLE LICENSES
SECTION:
5-4-1: Definitions
5-4-2: Application For License, Issuance
5-4-3: License Fees
5-4-4: Time Of Payment, License Year
5-4-5: Transfer Of License
5-4-6: Plates Or Stickers Issued
5-4-7: Use Of Funds
5-4-8: Penalties
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
ANTIQUE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle which properly displays lawfully
issued and currently registered antique motor vehicle license plates from the
state of Illinois.
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle which conveys loads other than passengers
not for hire, as defined in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-41-1.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Any vehicle which is self-propelled by any means other than
muscular power, including, but not limited to, passenger automobiles, trucks,
vans, motorcycles and motor bicycles.
OWNER: Any person, real or corporate, who owns any motor vehicle or trailer.
TRAILER: Any vehicle which is designed to be propelled by attachment to a motor
vehicle is not a motor vehicle under this chapter except when used with a
commercial vehicle. (Ord. 2008-O-9, 8-20-2008)
5-4-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, ISSUANCE:
Every owner or operator of a motor vehicle or motor bicycle required under this
chapter to have a license for such vehicle shall file an application with the
administrator, setting forth the name and address of the applicant and a
description of the vehicle for which the license is desired. Upon payment of
the fee herein provided, the administrator shall issue or cause to be issued a
license which shall be attested by him, authorizing the use of such vehicle
within the village until the expiration of the license. (Ord. 2011-O-11, 9-28-
2011)
5-4-3: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   The owner of every motor vehicle and motor bicycle, including
commercial vehicles, who resides within the village shall pay a license fee to
the village administrator for the use of such motor vehicle or motor bicycle.
   B.   Except as provided in subsection C of this section, the annual fees to
be paid for vehicle licenses shall be as follows:
 
Passenger vehicles                                                              $40.00
Antique motor vehicle                                                           10.00
Commercial vehicles in the following weight classes:                            
   Under 3,000 pounds' gross weight including weight of vehicle and maximum  55.00
load
   Over 3,000 pounds' gross weight but not more than 8,000 pounds' gross     65.00
weight, including weight of vehicle and maximum load
   Over 8,000 pounds' gross weight including vehicle and maximum load        80.00
 
Trailers and tractors or similar vehicles designed for hauling purposes shall
pay license fees according to their gross weight as hereinabove set forth.
(Ord. 2011-O-02, 5-25-2011)
   C.   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection B of this section, any
person over sixty four (64) years of age, and upon proper application for a
vehicle license, shall be entitled to issuance of one passenger vehicle license
for a vehicle registered to that person free of charge; any vehicle with a
disability license plate issued under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616
shall be entitled to the issuance of one passenger vehicle license for that
vehicle for a fee of ten dollars ($10.00); any person who is a full time
college student, upon presentation of a valid student ID from a college or
university, shall be entitled to issuance of one passenger vehicle license for
a vehicle for a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00); and any not for profit
corporation with a tax exempt status granted by the internal revenue service
shall be entitled to issuance of a license according to the following fee
schedule:

   E.   A person moving into the village shall have thirty (30) days from the
time of occupancy to obtain the required vehicle license. For such thirty (30)
day period, the fees as provided in subsection B of this section shall apply.
Commencing with the thirty first day after occupancy, the fees provided in

   F.   At any time on or after July 1 of each license year the village may
take any or all lawful action necessary to collect the license fee due under
this section including, but not limited to, placing the delinquent fee account
for collection with a debt collection company. (Ord. 2008-O-9, 8-20-2008; amd.
Ord. 2012-O-05, 5-23-2012; Ord. 2013-O-03, 2-27-2013; Ord. 2016-O-04, 4-27-
2016; Ord. 2025-O-07, 5-28-2025)
5-4-4: TIME OF PAYMENT, LICENSE YEAR:
Such license fees shall be due and payable annually in advance on July 1 of
each year and the license shall be for one year; provided, that if purchase of
a vehicle is made six (6) months after the start of the license year, then,
upon application being made to the administrator, a license shall be issued for
the remainder of the year upon payment of one-half (1/2) of the fee herein
required. (Ord. 84-06, 4-25-1984)
5-4-5: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A village vehicle license may be transferred to another vehicle of the same
license classification, owned by the person to whom such license was issued,
without any extra charge being made; but the applicant must file an application
for such transfer and such application must include the make and type of such
vehicle. (Ord. 84-05, 3-28-1984)
5-4-6: PLATES OR STICKERS ISSUED:
Each applicant, upon payment of the fee, shall be given a license plate or
windshield sticker, without charge, of such design and material as may be
approved by the village board of trustees. Such plate or sticker shall be
fastened in a prominent and visible place on the front of the vehicle at all
times that such vehicle is operated in the village. (Ord. 84-05, 3-28-1984)
5-4-7: USE OF FUNDS:
All revenue derived from such license fees, except for the cost of issuing the
licenses and plates and collecting the fees, shall be kept as a separate fund
and used only for paying the cost of street repairs and improvements, as is
provided by statute. (Ord. 84-05, 3-28-1984)
5-4-8: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter relating to motor
vehicles shall be fined not less than two dollars ($2.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be
held to have been committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs
or continues. (Ord. 84-05, 3-28-1984; amd. Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
CHAPTER 5
THROUGH TRAFFIC
SECTION:
5-5-1: Main Or Collector Streets Designated
5-5-2: Regulations For Use Of Local Streets
5-5-3: Regulations For One-Way Streets
5-5-4: Regulations For Limited Turns
5-5-5: Regulations For U-Turns
5-5-6: Posting And Penalties
5-5-1: MAIN OR COLLECTOR STREETS DESIGNATED:
The following streets in the village are hereby designated as main or collector
streets for the purpose of use by both through traffic and local traffic:
      Atkinson Road
      Bradley Road
      Buckley Road (State Route 134)
      Guerin Road
      Illinois Tri-State Tollway
      O'Plaine Road
      Rockland Road (State Route 176)
      St. Mary's Road
(Ord. 95-31, 9-27-1995)
5-5-2: REGULATIONS FOR USE OF LOCAL STREETS:
The following regulations shall apply to all streets, public and private, other
than the main or collector streets herein designated:
   A.   Local Traffic Defined: For purposes of this chapter, "local traffic" is
defined as being traffic which either originates or has a destination within
the local area or neighborhood served by the local streets being used, and all
other traffic is defined as "through traffic". A "destination" is defined as
being a specific place within such local area to or from which a person is
traveling for personal or business purposes, and not as a means of travel
through such local area from one other local area to another local area.
   B.   Through Traffic Prohibited On Local Streets: No person shall use local
streets for through traffic purposes. All traffic shall use main or collector
streets for through traffic purposes except in emergencies, or when such main
or collector streets are not passable.
   C.   Notice Of Local Traffic Only Prohibition: The village board of trustees
shall, by resolution passed at a regular or special meeting, designate specific
local streets upon which notice shall be posted indicating that only local
traffic is permitted. (Ord. 95-31, 9-27-1995)
5-5-3: REGULATIONS FOR ONE-WAY STREETS:
Whenever a street is designated for one-way traffic for part or all of a day,
the use of such street shall be restricted to traffic moving in the direction
designated.
   A.   Whenever a street is designated for one-way traffic, the village shall
erect adequate signage indicating the limitation on the movement of traffic and
the time or times when the limitation applies if it is for periods less than
twenty four (24) hours per day. The village may also erect barriers or traffic
guides to indicate the one-way regulation.
   B.   No person shall travel upon one-way streets in a direction other than
that designated by traffic signage and directions.
   C.   Streets shall be designated as one-way streets by resolution of the
village board of trustees passed at a regular or special meeting. (Ord. 95-31,
9-27-1995)
5-5-4: REGULATIONS FOR LIMITED TURNS:
Whenever a street intersection is designated for limited turns for part or all
of a day, turns shall be limited in the manner designated.
   A.   Whenever a street intersection is designated for limited turns, the
village shall erect signage indicating the limitation on the movement of
traffic and the time or times when the limitation applies if it is for periods
less than twenty four (24) hours per day. The village may also erect barriers
or traffic guides to indicate the limited turn regulation.
   B.   No person shall enter or turn into a street in violation of the
limitation on turns designated herein and indicated by traffic signage and
directions.
   C.   Streets shall be designated for limited turns by resolution of the
village board of trustees passed at a regular or special meeting. (Ord. 95-31,
9-27-1995)
5-5-5: REGULATIONS FOR U-TURNS:
Whenever a street is designated for no U-turns, U-turns shall be prohibited in
the manner designated.
   A.   Whenever a street is designated for no U-turns, the village shall erect
signage indicating the limitation on the movement of traffic and the time or
times when the limitation applies if it is for periods less than twenty four
(24) hours per day. The village may also erect barriers or traffic guides to
indicate the no U-turn regulation.
   B.   No person operating a vehicle shall turn such vehicle so as to proceed
in the opposite direction in violation of the limitation on turns designated
herein and indicated by traffic signage and directions.
   C.   Streets shall be designated for no U-turns by resolution of the village
board of trustees passed at a regular or special meeting. (Ord. 2000-O-02, 3-
22-2000)
5-5-6: POSTING AND PENALTIES:
   A.   Posting: The regulations herein shall be in effect upon the erection of
traffic signs indicating the limitation on through traffic, one-way traffic, or
limited turns, as the case may be. The erection of a general sign upon a local
street at each entry into a main or collector street shall be sufficient to
indicate the limitation on use of such local street for local traffic only.
One-way traffic signs shall be posted at each entry to a one-way street
section. Limited turn signs shall be posted at the intersection so regulated.
(Ord. 95-31, 9-27-1995; amd. Ord. 2000-O-02, 3-22-2000)
   B.   Violation, Penalty: It shall be unlawful for any person to violate,
disobey or refuse to comply with any of the regulations or limitations upon
traffic provided for in this chapter in the operation of any motor vehicle at
the intersections or on the local streets indicated; and any person, upon
conviction, shall be fined not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for each offense. (Ord. 95-31, 9-27-1995; amd. Ord. 2000-O-02, 3-22-2000; Ord.
2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
CHAPTER 6
PARKING
SECTION:
5-6-1: Towing Unauthorized Parked Vehicles
5-6-2: Restricted Or Prohibited Parking In Designated Places
5-6-3: Display For Sale Of Certain Vehicles And Wheeled Devices On Nonowned Or
Occupied Residential Properties Prohibited
5-6-4: Resident Permit Parking
5-6-1: TOWING UNAUTHORIZED PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   The Corporate Authorities by and through their designated agent are
hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a
commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle parked in those parking
spaces owned by the Village of Green Oaks which has not been authorized to do
so by the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Green Oaks.
   B.   Cars so towed for unauthorized parking shall be stored in a safe place
and shall be restored to the owner or operator of such car upon payment of the
costs of towing and storage of the vehicle.
   C.   When a motor vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the Village shall
keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed, listing the color, year of
manufacture, manufacturer's trade name, manufacturer's series name, body style,
vehicle identification number, and license plate year and number displayed on
the vehicle. The record shall also include the date and hour of tow, location
towed from, location towed to, reason for towing and the name of the person
authorizing the tow.
   D.   The Corporate Authorities shall cause the posting of notice signs,
pursuant to section 18a-302 of the Illinois Vehicle Code 1 , on the Village
Hall property, prior to enforcement of this section. (Ord. 2003-O-13, 9-24-
2003)

1 1. 625 ILCS 5/18a-302.

Lexington Lane: That portion of Lexington Road abutting the Oak Grove school
property, both sides from Carriage Ct. to Glenmore Drive.
   C.   Parking Prohibited at Certain Times: When official signs, markings or
other devices are erected or placed upon any Village rights-of-way or any
portion thereof regulating parking by vehicles, no person shall park a vehicle
or cause a vehicle to remain on any rights-of-way in violation of such signs,
markings or other devices. Parking is prohibited at the following locations
during the following times of day:
North Forest Lake Lane, both sides of street, between the hours of two o’clock
(2:00) a.m. and six o’clock (6:00) a.m.
   D.   No Truck Parking: It shall be unlawful to park a truck on or along the
following locations:
Baker Road, both sides. Exception: Delivery of goods or materials where the
truck is parked for less than fifteen (15) minutes.
   E.   No Parking Baker Road: It shall be unlawful to park on or along the
following locations:
Baker Road, both sides. Exception: Delivery of goods or materials where the
delivery vehicle is parked for less than fifteen (15) minutes.
   F.   Signage: Proper signage shall be lawfully installed to provide
reasonable notice of the restrictions established in this section. (Ord. 2019-
O-16, 7-24-2019; amd. Ord. 2021-O-01, 1-27-2021; Ord. 2022-O-04, 2-23-2022;
Ord. 2022-O-07, 4-27-2022; Ord. 2022-O-20, 9-28-2022)
5-6-3: DISPLAY FOR SALE OF CERTAIN VEHICLES AND WHEELED DEVICES ON NONOWNED OR
OCCUPIED RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES PROHIBITED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other entity
to display for sale to the general public any motor vehicle, utility trailer,
recreation vehicle, vacation trailer, boat or other licensed, registered,
unlicensed or unregistered vehicle or similar wheeled or nonwheeled device,
upon private residential property not owned by the owner of the aforesaid
wheeled or nonwheeled devices.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other entity
to permit, cause or suffer the display for sale to the general public any motor
vehicle, utility trailer, recreation vehicle, vacation trailer, boat or other
licensed, registered, unlicensed or unregistered vehicle or similar wheeled or
nonwheeled device, upon private residential property not owned by the owner of
the aforesaid wheeled or nonwheeled devices.
   C.   "Motor vehicle" and "recreation vehicle", as used in this section,
shall have the same meanings as those provided in the Illinois Vehicle Code, as
amended. (Ord. 2007-O-07, 5-23-2007)
5-6-4: RESIDENT PERMIT PARKING:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle which does not
bear a current and valid Village vehicle registration sticker or vehicle
registration decal in any space or area designated as "Village Of Green Oaks
Resident Parking Only".
   B.   The Village Board may designate such place or places upon Municipal
parking areas and upon other areas owned or controlled by the Village as
resident only parking areas. Such designation shall be effective only after an
appropriate sign, notice, signs or notices is or are installed or posted at
such place or places stating "Village Of Green Oaks Resident Parking Only".
   C.   The Village Administrator shall cause signs or notices to be painted,
installed or posted as herein contemplated.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully impair any sign or
notice painted, installed or posted under the provisions of this section or to
in any way tamper with, wilfully injure, break, destroy or impair any post,
installation, surface or object upon which any such sign or notice is so
painted, installed or posted.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for any reason to affix a Village vehicle
registration sticker or decal to a vehicle not identified in the application
pursuant to which such sticker or decal was issued or to give, sell, transfer
or convey such sticker or decal for use, or to permit its use, on a vehicle not
identified in the application pursuant to which such sticker or decal was
issued.
   F.   If any place designated by the Village Board as resident parking only
is additionally designated by the Village Board as time limited parking, then a
vehicle bearing a Village vehicle registration sticker or decal issued pursuant
to this title shall also comply with the duly established time limited parking
regulations. (Ord. 2008-O-7, 7-23-2008)
TITLE 6
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTIES
CHAPTER 1
WAGE RATE FOR PUBLIC WORKS EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
6-1-1: Wage Rate Established
6-1-2: Applicability of Wage Rate
6-1-3: Rates to be Posted
6-1-4: Rates Furnished Upon Request
6-1-1: WAGE RATE ESTABLISHED:
To the extent and as required by "An Act Regulating Wages of Laborers,
Mechanics and Other Workmen Employed in Any Public Works by the State, County,
City or Any Public Body or Any Political Subdivision or by Anyone Under
Contract for Public Works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended 1 , the general
prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and other
workmen engaged in the construction of public works coming under the
jurisdiction of the Village is hereby ascertained to be the same as the
prevailing rate of wages for construction work in Lake County area as
determined by the Department of Labor of the State of Illinois as of June,
1980, a copy of that determination being incorporated herein by reference. The
definition of any terms appearing in this Chapter which are also used in the
aforesaid Act shall be the same as in said Act. (Ord. 80-07, 6-25-80)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 820 ILCS 130/1 et seq.
6-1-2: APPLICABILITY OF WAGE RATE:
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general prevailing
rate of wages as herein ascertained to any work or employment except public
works construction of this Village to the extent required by the aforesaid Act.
(Ord. 80-07, 6-25-80)
6-1-3: RATES TO BE POSTED:
The Village Clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any
interested party in the main office of this Village this determination of such
prevailing rate of wage. (Ord. 80-07, 6-25-80)
6-1-4: RATES FURNISHED UPON REQUEST:
The Village Clerk shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and
to any association of employers, and to any person or association of employees
who have filed, or file their names and addresses, requesting copies of any
determination stating the particular rates and the particular class of workmen
whose wages will be effected by such rates. (Ord. 80-07, 6-25-80)

CHAPTER 3
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Specific Improvements
6-3-1-1: Road Improvements In Greenbrier First Addition Subdivision
6-3-2: Regulation Of Work On Public Property And On Public Utilities
6-3-1: SPECIFIC IMPROVEMENTS:
6-3-1-1: ROAD IMPROVEMENTS IN GREENBRIER FIRST ADDITION SUBDIVISION:
   A.   Improvements Designated: A local improvement shall be constructed in
the Village, consisting of:
      1.   Reconstructing the road base and paving all of the Greenbrier Drive
in Greenbrier First Addition Subdivision, a distance of three thousand one
hundred fifty one feet (3,151').
      2.   Reconstructing the road base and paving all of Sunrise Road in
Greenbrier First Addition Subdivision, a distance of three thousand five
hundred feet (3,500').
      3.   Reconstructing the road base and paving all of Fox Run Drive in
Greenbrier First Addition Subdivision (except the portion thereof lying between
lots 33 and 34) a distance of three thousand seven hundred twenty five feet
(3,725').
      4.   Reconstructing portions of the drainage ditches and structures along
portions of the above described roads.
   B.   Construction Requirements:
      1.   The improvements shall consist of excavation and removal of
unsuitable existing road base material, repair of road base by installation of
bituminous asphalt material, construction of road base with aggregate base
course, regrading of ditches, relocation and replacement of culverts, adjusting
catch basins, installation of one and one-half inch (11/2") bituminous concrete
binder and of one and one-half inch (11/2") bituminous concrete surface course
Class I and regrading and replacement of topsoil and sod in all disturbed
parkway areas.
      2.   All materials of every kind and character to be used in the
construction of this improvement shall be first class quality, suitable for the
purpose for which they are to be used, and subject to the inspection and
approval of the Committee on Local Improvements of the Village.
      3.   All construction methods and materials used in construction of the
improvement herein provided for shall conform with the requirements of the
Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, issued by the State
of Illinois, Department of Transportation, Division of Highways and adopted
October 1, 1979, a copy of which is on file with the Village Clerk, except as
modified by the contract special conditions.
      4.   The quantities and types of materials to be used are as set forth in
the plans, specifications and estimate of cost incorporated herein by
reference.
      5.   All work shall be constructed in a workmanlike manner under the
superintendence of the Committee on Local Improvements of the Village.
      6.   Village datum for the purpose of this improvement is fixed and
established as the official datum of the United States Geological Survey.
   C.   Approval Of Plans And Specifications: The plans and specifications for
said improvements and the estimate of cost thereof, all heretofore submitted by
the Committee on Local Improvements and filed with the Village Clerk, are all
incorporated herein by reference and the same hereby are approved.
   D.   Special Assessment To Pay For Improvement:
      1.   The improvement shall be made and the cost thereof which is
estimated to be three hundred seventy nine thousand eight hundred eighty seven
dollars twenty cents ($379,887.20) shall be paid for by special assessment in
accordance with the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-
3-12, and amount not exceeding forty thousand seven hundred two dollars twenty
cents ($40,702.20) is hereby provided for to apply towards the payment of all
lawful costs and expenses incurred in making, levying and collecting the
assessment for said improvement including attorneys fees, engineering
inspection and other costs.
      2.   The aggregate amount herein ordered to be assessed and each
individual assessment shall be divided into ten (10) installments which shall
bear interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum until paid, all in the
manner and in accordance with the provisions of the aforesaid the Illinois
Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-3-22.
      3.   For the purpose of anticipating the collection of the second and
succeeding installments of said assessment for said improvement, bonds shall be
issued payable out of said installments, bearing interest at the rate of five
percent (5%) per annum, payable annually and signed by the President of the
Village and attested by the Village Clerk, under the Corporate Seal of the
Village. The bonds shall be issued in accordance with, and shall in all
respects, conform to the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended,
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-3-35.
   E.   Petition Filed By Village President: Bruce Boyke, President of the
Board of Trustees of the Village, is designated as the person to file a
petition in the Circuit Court of Lake County, as provided by law 1  in the name
of the Village, praying that steps may be taken to ascertain what property will
be benefitted by said improvement and the amount of such benefit and also that
steps be taken to levy a special assessment for said improvement in accordance
with the provisions of this Section and in the manner prescribed by law. (Ord.
80-01, 3-13-80)

6-3-2: REGULATION OF WORK ON PUBLIC PROPERTY AND ON PUBLIC UTILITIES:
No construction, installation or repairs to improvements, excavation, drainage,
landscaping planting, or removal of any trees, shrubbery or natural plants upon
any public street or right of way, or easement running to the Village or the
general public, or upon utilities owned by the Village such as the water or
sewer systems, or other public utilities installed on public streets or
easements including gas or electric or telephone or cable television supply
systems, shall be erected, installed, altered, converted, remodeled,
structurally repaired, moved, demolished or changed except in conformity with
the regulations and requirements hereinafter set forth and only after a
construction permit has been issued under the following terms:
   A.   Request For Public Work Permit: Whenever work upon public property or
utilities is proposed, the person or corporation proposing such work shall
first submit to the Village Administrator an application for a public work
permit to conduct such work setting forth such information, including
preliminary or sketch plans, if needed, as may be required by the Administrator
to identify the location, nature and extent of the proposed work.
   B.   Preliminary Permit: All requests for a permit shall be submitted to the
Village Engineer for preliminary approval of the construction or work concept
based upon the submitted information. When engineering concept approval is
granted, the permit shall be submitted to the Village Board for preliminary
permit approval.
   C.   Construction Permit: When a preliminary permit is granted by the
Village Board, the permittee shall apply for a construction permit by
submitting such plans, specifications and other information to the Village
Engineer as the Engineer deems necessary to determine and approve that the
proposed work is properly designed to meet minimum engineering standards for
such work and will satisfy all of the requirements and standards otherwise set
forth in the ordinances of the Village for construction of improvements on
public streets and easements, or to public and private utilities. When the
Engineer has approved the construction plans and determined the estimated cost
thereof, the approved plans and the required guarantee of performance shall be
submitted to the Village Board for final approval.
   D.   Guarantee Of Performance: Before a construction permit for any work
herein described is issued, the permittee shall provide a guarantee of
performance of the work in the manner and as required in the provisions of
Section
9-4-4 of the Village Code, including the requirement of a two (2) year
guarantee as set forth in subsection
9-4-4E thereof.
   E.   Subdivision Improvements: The provisions of this Section shall not
apply to work that has been approved and is being conducted pursuant to a final
plat of subdivision and under the guarantee of performance provided thereunder.
(Ord. 95-14, 3-22-95)
CHAPTER 4
TRAIL SYSTEM USE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Artificially Powered Vehicles Prohibited
6-4-1: ARTIFICIALLY POWERED VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized vehicle at any time
upon the trail system of the village for purposes of this section. The term
"motorized vehicle" shall include motorcycles, motorbikes, motor scooters,
automobiles and any other mechanical device designed to transport human beings
which is powered by a combustion engine or electrical power or by spring
tension or wind sail. Provided however, motorized vehicles used in performing
maintenance, repair or installation upon the trail system at the direction of
the village shall be exempt from the prohibitions of this section. Any person
convicted of violating this section shall be fined a minimum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per violation to a maximum of seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) per violation. (Ord. 2001-O-01, 1-24-2001)

BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL BUILDING REGULATIONS

7-1-1: TITLE:
This title, including the rules and regulations it adopts by reference, is
entitled the BUILDING ORDINANCE. The "letter" and "number" designations used to
set off or identify its various parts refer to sections, subsections,
paragraphs, rules, regulations, or other divisions as the text or arrangement
may indicate. Reference to any one of these parts may be by such a designation
alone. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-1960)
7-1-2: SCOPE OF REGULATIONS:
   A.   No building or structure, or parts or appurtenances thereof, or
improvements or changes upon any lot or parcel, such as water supply, sewage
disposal, plumbing installation, electrical installation, excavation, drainage,
landscaping, planting or removal of any trees, shrubbery or natural plants
located in the village shall be erected, installed, altered, converted,
remodeled, structurally repaired, moved, demolished, or changed except in
conformity with the regulations and requirements established in this title and
all other ordinances relating to building and zoning 1 . (Ord. 94-29, 10-26-
1994)
   B.   All buildings and structures, and parts and appurtenances thereof, both
existing and hereafter erected or installed shall be so maintained that the
occupants and users thereof and others are reasonably safe from the hazards of
fire, explosion, collapse, contagion and spread of infectious disease. If found
by the building commissioner not so maintained, he may order necessary
corrective work, repair, replacement, or removal.
   C.   These rules and regulations set forth requirements which are considered
reasonable and are held, in every instance, to be the minimum for the promotion
of public health, safety, and the general welfare. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-1960)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 8 of this code for zoning regulations.
7-1-3: INTERPRETATION:
Whenever in the regulations contained in this title, including the regulations
adopted by reference, it is provided that anything must be done to the approval
of or subject to the direction of the building commissioner or any other
officer of the village, this shall be construed to give such officer only the
discretion of determining whether the rules and standards established by
ordinance have been complied with and such provision shall not be construed as
to give any officer discretionary powers as to what such regulations or
standards shall be or power to require conditions not prescribed by ordinance
or to enforce ordinance provisions in an arbitrary or discriminatory manner.
(Ord. 60-09, 5-12-1960)
7-1-4: LOAD AND CAPACITY PLACARD REQUIRED:
An owner shall post and maintain a sign, placard or plate in approved form,
after making application so to do, showing safe loading for each floor, and
safe capacity in persons at entrances of each room, floor, or building built or
used for any of the following purposes: school; church; public assembly;
residential institution; a place for harboring or housing persons for
correctional, medical or other care or treatment; storing materials; dance or
recreation hall, and serving of drinks or food. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-1960)
7-1-5: NONCONFORMING BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES:
   A.   Definition: A "nonconforming building" or "structure" is an existing
building or structure or part or appurtenance thereof not in conformance with
this title.
   B.   Requirements To Repair: Repair work requires a written application and
permit and work is limited to necessary repairs only unless the building or
part is made to conform in whole or part with the requirements of this title.
   C.   Alterations: Altering or enlarging shall be done in a manner conforming
with this title. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-1960)
7-1-6: DANGEROUS BUILDINGS:
A building or structure or part or appurtenance thereof or a construction
condition found to be hazardous to life, limb, or health, upon order of the
building commissioner or enacting authority, shall be corrected, replaced,
repaired, vacated, demolished, or removed and the premises or work restored to
or put in a safe condition within a reasonable period of time, as may be
appropriate in each case, when such a finding has been made in writing, written
notice of the findings and order have been given the owner or his agent or the
contractor, and except in emergencies, a hearing on the order has been held
before the building commissioner. (Ord. 60-09, 5-12-1960)
7-1-7: SEDIMENT AND EROSION CONTROL:
Prior to the issuance of a certificate of compliance or a final occupancy
permit for any new construction, all exposed earth shall be final graded.
Accumulated sediment resulting from said construction shall be removed from all
drainageways, and permanent protective vegetative cover shall be established by
either seeding grass or by laying sod. (Ord. 79-04, 7-25-1979)
7-1-8: DRIVEWAY APRON AND CULVERT STANDARDS:
Prior to the issuance of a certificate of compliance or a final occupancy
permit, the driveway apron(s) on the street right of way parkway shall be
paved. The minimum standards for both the driveway apron pavement and culvert
are set forth in figure number
7-1-8:A at the end of this chapter. (Ord. 76-04, 9-22-1976)
7-1-9: MAILBOX STANDARDS:
Prior to the issuance of a certificate of compliance or an occupancy permit, a
standard U.S. post office mailbox with a street number shall be installed. The
installation, placement and anchoring of the mailbox shall be in accord with
all United States postal service rules and regulations, as they may be amended
from time to time, and with the specifications set forth in figure number
7-1-9:A at the end of this chapter. (Ord. 2007-O-05, 4-25-2007)
7-1-10: MANMADE PONDS 1 :
   A.   Purpose: It is the purpose of this section to control the construction
and use of manmade lakes, ponds and any and all other manmade bodies of water,
except swimming pools, and to protect the health, welfare and safety of the
residents of the village and to eliminate the creation of breeding areas for
mosquitoes.
   B.   Applicability Of Regulations: These regulations shall apply to all
lands within the corporate limits of the village.
   C.   Manmade Lakes, Ponds Prohibited, Exceptions: All manmade lakes, ponds,
and all other manmade bodies of water, covering an area larger than fifty (50)
square feet and having a depth in excess of one foot (1'), other than swimming
pools, are prohibited within the village except as provided in title 9 of this
code. (Ord. 76-04, 9-22-1976)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  8-3-5 of this code.
7-1-11: CONSTRUCTION OF TENNIS COURTS AND RECREATIONAL FACILITIES:
   A.   Purpose: It is the purpose of this section to control the construction
and use of tennis courts and other playing courts or recreational facilities
requiring hard, paved, graded or special surfaces.
   B.   Applicability Of Regulations: These regulations shall apply to all
lands within the corporate limits of the village.
   C.   Building Permit Required: No construction shall commence until an
application for a building permit has been applied for and a building permit
issued. Such application shall include complete plans and specifications,
location sketch, and drainage drawings. Fees for the building permit shall be
established from time to time by the board of trustees of the village 1 .
   D.   Hard Surfaces: All tennis courts and other recreational facilities
requiring hard, paved, graded or special surfaces shall meet the following
requirements:
      1.   Setback shall be the same as those established for accessory
buildings for the zone in which they are to be constructed.
      2.   Coverage shall be included in the computation for total lot coverage
permitted in that zone.
      3.   Construction on a lot served by a septic system shall be in
accordance with the following:
         a.   All such lots shall provide a reserve capacity for a septic
system equivalent in square footage to at least the square footage of the
existing septic system.
         b.   No portion of the tennis court or recreational facility shall
infringe upon the existing septic system or the area reserved for reserve
septic system capacity.
      4.   Said construction shall not change natural drainage or increase the
flow of water from the lot on which it is to be constructed onto adjacent
property. (Ord. 76-06, 3-22-1976)
      5.   A fence not higher than twelve feet (12') may enclose all or part of
the facility. The fence must be designed and constructed to prohibit tennis
balls or other recreational equipment from traveling onto adjacent properties,
and must comply with all other relevant laws, ordinances and regulations. (Ord.
2001-O-07, 5-23-2001)
      6.   In the event lighting is provided, lighting must be installed in
such a manner so as not to cause glare on adjacent property. (Ord. 76-06, 3-22-
1976)
