2 1. See also Section
  1-8-5 of this Code.
3 2. See Title 8 of this Code.
9-1-6: DEDICATIONS, EASEMENTS, RESERVATIONS:
9-1-6-1: DEDICATIONS:
Areas required to be dedicated are as follows:
   A.   New Streets: In all residential developments, all new streets created
by subdivision and shown on plats submitted for approval and recording shall be
dedicated outright to the public. No private streets or roads shall be
permitted within residential developments. Private streets may be permitted
under the conditions hereinafter set forth, by action of the Village Board,
only within nonresidential developments and subdivisions when they only serve
abutting properties, buildings, parking areas and loading areas within the
development or subdivision. Such private streets shall connect with public
streets, and shall not serve properties, or interconnect with other private
streets, outside the development or subdivision. (Ord. 92-01, 1-29-92)
   B.   Additional Street Widths: Additional street widths shall be dedicated
along existing thoroughfares where a width greater than that existing is called
for by the major thoroughfare plan, or this Title.
   C.   Pedestrian Ways: Pedestrian ways, where required, shall be dedicated.
(Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-1-6-2: EASEMENTS:
   A.   Easements Shown: Areas to be shown as easements are as follows:
      1.   Public Utilities: Public utilities, storm water facilities, and
installations shall be located on suitable easements as specified in this
Title.
      2.   Planting Strips: Planting strips or other buffers, located between
reverse frontage lots and a thoroughfare, or between incompatible uses, or
wherever required. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
      3.   Private Roads: As existing upon annexation, or within nonresidential
subdivisions or developments when permitted by Village Board action as provided
in subsection
9-3-2J of this Title. (Ord. 92-01, 1-29-92)
      4.   Scenic Corridor Easement: The scenic corridor easement shall be
depicted on the face of the plat of subdivision.
      5.   Conservancy District Area: The conservancy district area shall
similarly be depicted on the face of the plat of subdivision.
   B.   Identification of Easements: Easements shall be clearly identified on
all plats; e.g., "Drainage Easement", "Utility Easement", etc.
   C.   Description of Purpose: Whenever an easement for planting strip, scenic
corridor or conservancy district is set forth, the plat shall contain or have
attached thereto, a complete description of the purpose of the easement; the
manner in which it is to be maintained and the responsibilities of the owner in
reference thereto. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-1-6-3: RESERVATIONS:
   A.   Areas to be Reserved: Whenever the area being subdivided embraces all
or part of any lands designated on the Official Plan for a school, forest
preserve, or other community facility or any other public use, all land so
designated shall be shown on the preliminary plat as being dedicated or
reserved for that proposed use, and it shall be reserved by the subdivider for
a period of one year from the date of approval of the preliminary plat, during
which time it shall be made available to the public agency concerned at the
undeveloped acreage price, as determined by an appraiser acceptable to both
parties.
   B.   Reservations and Preliminary Plats:
      1.   Areas reserved shall be clearly identified on the preliminary plat
as reserved in accordance with this Title.
      2.   The preliminary plat shall also contain the proposals of the
subdivider as they might otherwise be platted, for the areas under reservation,
to be applied in the event the land is not acquired by the public within the
period of reservation. Upon completion of the one year period of reservation,
the preliminary plat shall remain a valid preliminary plat for the formerly
reserved areas for a period of one year.
   C.   Reservations and Final Plats:
      1.   Where practicable, final plats shall not include areas reserved.
Said final plats should affect only that portion of the subdivider's land which
is unrestricted by the reservations.
      2.   Where final plats must include areas reserved, such areas shall be
clearly identified as reserved in accordance with this Title and shall not
contain any proposals of the developer.
      3.   Final plats may be submitted for reserved land unacquired by the
public at the close of the one year period. Such plats will be considered
additional units of the subdivisions for which initial final plats were
recorded.
   D.   Reversion: If the appropriate public agency having jurisdiction has
not, within one year after receiving notice in writing that the premises are
available at the price and terms set forth in subsection A above, acquired the
site reserved for a public use, the subdivider shall regain full and
unencumbered title to the same, and may use it in any way and for any purpose
permitted by the pertinent regulations then in effect. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-1-6-4: APPROVAL, RIGHT OF REFUSAL:
The number, size and location of dedications, reservations and easements shall
be subject to approval and the Planning Commission shall ascertain that the
proposed sites are suitable for the proposed uses. The corporate authorities
retain the right to refuse any and all dedications. (Ord. 90-19, 11-28-90)
9-1-7: RESUBDIVISION AND REPLATTING STANDARDS:
The Planning Commission shall, in the performance of its plat approving
function, encourage and facilitate the replatting of prematurely and inexpertly
subdivided areas which are now in sharp contrast to current standards of
acceptability. Rehabilitation of these areas shall be implemented through
proper design considerations when adjacent unsubdivided land is proposed for
development.
   A.   Whenever application is made for the resubdivision of existing lots or
parcels of record which qualifies as a "minor subdivision" as defined in
Section
9-1-5 of this Title, and which is for the purpose of adjusting the size or
configuration of a nonresidential lot or parcel to create a single lot from
part or all of one or more lots to permit a specific principal building to be
erected or structurally altered thereon in conformance with the requirements of
Section
8-7-1 of this Code, the following provisions shall apply:
      1.   The filing fee for such resubdivision shall be reduced to one
hundred dollars ($100.00). All other deposits and fees required by this Code
shall be paid, unless previously paid at the time of original subdivision.
      2.   The Plan Commission shall only require a hearing upon the proposed
final plat, although the applicant may submit a sketch or preliminary plat for
informal review and approval prior to the hearing on the final plat.
      3.   The Village Engineer and Village Attorney shall approve the final
plat before it is presented for hearing for the limited purpose of determining
that no changes to existing roadway, utility, drainage or other facilities will
be required to conform to applicable subdivision standards, or if changes are
required, they have been properly designed and performance thereof has been
assured.
      4.   Such resubdivision shall not create any remainder lots or parcels
which fail to conform to the applicable zoning and subdivision standards. (Ord.
95-07, 2-22-95)
9-1-8: LOCAL LAND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANNING ACT:
   A.   Adoption: The corporate authorities of the Village hereby adopt the
provisions and objectives of the Local Land Resource Management Planning Act 1
(the "Act").
   B.   Development of Plan: The Plan Commission of the Village is hereby
authorized and instructed to initiate and develop a proposed "Local Land
Resources Management Plan" as defined in section 3 of the Act, (hereinafter the
"Plan") and within one hundred eighty (180) days after the adoption of
Ordinance 90-08, to report to the Village Board of Trustees and to recommend a
proposed Plan for adoption by the Village.
   C.   Public Hearings: The Plan Commission shall have the authority to call
public hearings on the proposed Plan with due notice, as in its discretion may
be useful to determine the needs of the Village in developing the Plan. In the
event that any changes or amendments to the Zoning Ordinance 2  of the Village
are proposed in conjunction with the Plan, the Plan Commission shall hold such
public hearings in conjunction therewith as may be required by ordinance and by
statute.
   D.   Vote: The Village Board after duly considering the proposed Plan, may
adopt the Plan by the affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the corporate
authorities.
   E.   Funding: The Village Board shall, by ordinance or by resolution,
provide for the necessary funding of the development and implementation of the
Plan; for funding of studies and reports relating to the development of the
Plan; for funding acquisition, maintenance, preservation and conservation of
land resources and open spaces and forest lands; for funding to assure water
quality and quantity, safe and efficient public transit and private auto usage,
public facilities and services, and energy conservation; and such other
programs and objectives as are set forth in section 4 of the Act. (Ord. 90-08,
7-25-90)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 50 ILCS 805/1 et seq.
2 1. See Title 8 of this Code.
9-1-9: SUBDIVISION FEES:
The Village shall collect (in addition to the filing fees and deposits provided
for in Section
9-1-9-2 below), the following fees. (Ord. 90-09, 7-25-90)
9-1-9-1: SCHOOL IMPACT FEES 1 :
The Village shall collect school impact fees upon all lots in the subdivision
in the amounts, manner and times as herein set forth. (Ord. 90-09, 7-25-90)
 
Notes
1 2. See also Section
  9-2-4 of this Title.
9-1-9-2: LOCAL LAND RESOURCES MANAGEMENT FEE:
The village shall collect local land resources management fees upon all lots in
the subdivision in the amounts, manner and times as herein set forth.
   A.   There shall be paid to the village, a cash contribution for the purpose
of defraying the cost of developing and implementing a local land resources
management plan in the sum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for
each lot in the subdivision.
   B.   The cash contribution may be waived or adjusted by agreement of the
subdivider and the village in consideration of other benefits, contributions or
adjustments which may be negotiated with any developer or subdivider.
   C.   The cash contributions shall be paid to the village at the time when a
building permit is ready to be issued upon each lot in the subdivision in the
manner that the village may prescribe.
   D.   The subdivider shall enter into a recordable covenant running with the
land at the time of approval of the final plat where in the obligation to make
the cash contribution or such other agreement as may be entered into in lieu
thereof, shall be duly acknowledged and made an obligation of the owner of the
lots in the subdivision and his successors in title. (Ord. 90-O-09, 7-25-1990)
9-1-10: OPEN SPACE CONVEYANCE:
Whenever any area in a proposed subdivision is designated to be devoted to open
space use, nature conservancy, trailways, storm detention or other use which is
public, or in the interest of the public, the area shall be titled as an
"outlot", and shall be conveyed to an appropriate agency, not for profit
corporation, municipality or other entity which shall own and control the area,
and shall be obligated to control and maintain the character and use of the
area in accordance with the designated purposes. If the village does not have
an appropriate grantee available to take title to said area, it shall be
conveyed to the village subject to the condition that the area be used and
maintained only in accordance with such designated use. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-
1990)
9-1-10-1: MANAGEMENT OF PONDS AND NATURAL AREAS:
   A.   Purpose: It is the purpose and intent of this section to regulate the
care, maintenance, and management of ponds, wetlands, drainageways, prairies,
forested lands and other open space or natural areas on village owned property
in order to enhance, protect and preserve ecological values and the health,
safety, and welfare of the village.
   B.   Regulated Activities: The provisions of this section apply to all
village owned land and water areas within the corporate limits. This section
does not apply to privately owned land or any other lands not owned by the
village. Routine landscape maintenance activities such as roadside mowing
conducted by the village or its contractors and tree trimming, performed by or
on behalf of a public utility along utility rights of way are exempt from the
provisions of this section. Regulated activities include, but are not limited
to:
      1.   Use of aquatic herbicides, algaecides, or pesticides or other
chemicals designed to alter the quality or character of ponds;
      2.   Mechanical or other physical cutting, uprooting, or other removal of
aquatic plants or algae in ponds;
      3.   Installation or use of pond aeration equipment;
      4.   Operation of a water control structure;
      5.   Installation of underwater habitat improvement structure or projects
to attract and/or feed waterfowl;
      6.   Measures to discourage site usage by Canada geese;
      7.   Stocking of fish, forage species, and other aquatic species;
      8.   Cutting, mowing, herbiciding, or controlled burning of any plant
species in wetlands, prairies, forested areas, or other natural areas;
      9.   Installation of seed plants, trees, and shrubs in ponds, wetlands,
prairies, forested areas, or other natural areas;
      10.   Such other ecological management measures as determined by the
board of trustees to be in need of regulation.
   C.   Management Plan:
      1.   All persons, organizations, homeowners' associations, or their
agents seeking to conduct regulated ecological management activities on village
owned lands are required to submit a plan of the proposed management activities
to the village for review and approval. The village, its officers, agents and
employees are specifically exempt from the plan submittal requirement.
      2.   Plans shall include:
         a.   A statement of objectives and a description of the type of
activity(ies) being proposed;
         b.   Identification of invasive, undesirable, or nuisance species
proposed for control;
         c.   Specific method(s) to be used for control (e.g., use of
glyphosate herbicide for control of reed canary grass; professional trapping of
nuisance beaver; copper sulfate applications for algae control in ponds);
         d.   Identification of who will directly conduct or perform the
management activity being proposed (e.g., contractor, individual, homeowners'
group);
         e.   Map or aerial photograph description of natural area or pond to
be managed, keyed to the description of the specific management methods so far
as possible;
         f.   Schedule for initiation and completion of the proposed activity
and an indication of whether the activity will be a one time or a recurrent
event;
         g.   Estimated budget for each major element of the management program
being undertaken, with a total of all such budgeted items;
         h.   Certificate of insurance stating that the person, firm or
organization conducting the proposed activities has continuing coverage for the
following risks in the following amounts:
 
Workers' compensation Statutory limits
General liability     $1,000,000.00
Automobile            1,000,000.00
 
The certificate of insurance shall name the village of Green Oaks as an
additional insured.
         i.   If seeding, planting of vegetation or stocking of fish is
proposed, the management plan shall identify the species (by scientific name)
proposed for seeding, planting, or stocking as well as the quantity or rate of
seeding, planting, or stocking;
      3.   The village will forward the proposed management plan to its
ecological consultant, as identified in the village watershed development
ordinance, for review and approval. No management activities shall be conducted
without prior management plan approval. The village ecological consultant shall
have twenty one (21) days to review and approve or disapprove of the plan
following receipt of the plan from the village. The ecological consultant shall
observe and monitor management activities to ensure conformity with the
management plan and to otherwise safeguard the interests of the village.
      4.   No activities regulated hereby shall be undertaken, nor shall any
plan submitted hereunder be effective, unless approved by the corporate
authorities of the village. The village retains the authority to disapprove any
management activity or plan that alters the essential character of the property
for which it is proposed.
      5.   Before approval of any management plan as provided for herein, the
person, firm or organization submitting such plan must provide a performance
bond, acceptable letter of credit or other guarantee acceptable to the village,
guaranteeing the complete performance of all portions of the plan. The terms
and provisions of this performance guarantee shall be as set forth in
subsections
9-4-4A through H of this title, with the exception that the village ecological
consultant shall be responsible for approving the cost of the plan, approving
reductions to the amount of the guarantee, and certifying completion of the
management activities. (Ord. 2003-O-5, 3-26-2003)
9-1-11: IMPACT FEES FOR ROADS AND SCHOOLS:
9-1-11-1: GENERAL:
As a condition of approval of a final plat of the subdivision, each subdivider
of more than six (6) acres shall be required to dedicate land for a school
site, park site, or other public land to serve the immediate and future needs
of the residents of the development; or cash contributions in lieu of actual
land dedication; or a combination of both, at the option of the village in
accordance with the following criteria and formula:
The comprehensive plan shall be used as a guideline in locating sites. (Ord.
90-O-03, 7-25-1990)
9-1-11-2: PARKS, PRESERVES AND OTHER PUBLIC AREAS:
   A.   Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate density of a proposed
development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required for
dedication. The total requirement shall be one acre of land per one hundred
fifty (1:150) of ultimate population in accordance with the following standards
by types of recreational and park areas:
      1.   Neighborhood park: Minimum one acre.
      2.   Villagewide recreational park: Minimum five (5) acres.
   B.   Population Formula: The formula used shall be four and four-tenths
(4.4) population per lot.
   C.   Location:
      1.   Neighborhood parks are to be located within the subdivision or added
to another adjacent subdivision.
      2.   Villagewide parks shall be located in accordance with the
requirements of the comprehensive plan or as recommended by the plan commission
and approved by the board of trustees.
   D.   Credit For Private Open Spaces And Recreational Areas: When subdividers
provide their own space for recreational areas and facilities, it has the
effect of reducing the demand for public recreational services. Depending on
the size of the subdivision, a portion of the park and recreational area in the
subdivision may, at the option of the board of trustees, be provided in the
form of "public" open space. The extent of same shall be determined by the
board of trustees, based upon the needs projected by residents and in
conformance to the total park and recreation land for the general area.
   E.   Criteria For Requiring A Cash Contribution In Lieu Of Land Dedication:
      1.   Cash Contribution: Where the subdivision is small and the resulting
site is too small to be practical or where the available land is inappropriate
for school site, park site or other public use, the village may require the
subdivider to pay a cash contribution in lieu of land dedication. The cash
contribution in lieu of land dedication shall be held by the village solely for
the acquisition of a school site, park site or public land facilities or
buildings which will be available to serve the immediate or future needs of the
residents of that subdivision and the general village residents or for the
improvement of other existing public land which already serves such needs. This
contribution shall be designated by the board of trustees for a specific use
within ten (10) years of the completion of the subdivision.
      2.   Fair Market Value: The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be
based on the "fair market value" of the acres of land in the area improved as
specified herein, that otherwise would have been dedicated as park and
recreation sites. The subdivider shall submit an appraisal showing the "fair
market value" of such improved land in the area of his development or other
evidence thereof and final determination of said "fair market value" of such
improved land in the area of his development or other evidence thereof and
final determination of said "fair market value" per acre of such improved land
shall be made by the board of trustees based upon such information submitted by
the subdivider.
   F.   Criteria For Requiring Land Dedication And A Contribution: There may be
situations where it will be necessary to require a combination of land
dedication and a contribution to meet the needs of this chapter. Such
recommendations shall be made by the plan commission and approved by the board
of trustees.
   G.   Reservation Of Additional Land: Where the development plan or the
requirements of the village call for a larger amount of park and recreational
land in a particular subdivision than the developer, is required to dedicate,
the land needed beyond the developers contribution shall be reserved for
subsequent purchase by the village or other public body designated by the
village; provided, that such acquisition is made within one year from the date
of approval of the final plat, or an agreement between the developer and the
village is recorded outlining specific conditions for the conveyance of such
property.
   H.   Combining With Adjoining Developments: Where the subdivision is less
than forty (40) acres, public open space which is to be dedicated should, where
possible, be combined with dedications from adjoining subdivisions in order to
produce usable recreation areas without hardship on a particular subdivider.
   I.   Topography And Grading: The slope, topography and geology of the
dedicated site as well as its surroundings must be suitable for its intended
purposes.
   J.   Improvement Of Sites: Parks and recreational sites shall be dedicated
fully developed ready for use. "Fully developed" shall mean all site grading
including surface drainage and seeding and sodding required for the intended
use, but not including final development such as baseball, tennis or like
facilities nor any structures. "Fully developed" shall also mean providing
adequate access to and fully developed perimeter streets. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-
1990)
CHAPTER 2
PLATTING PROCEDURES AND REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
9-2-1: Plat Approval Procedure
9-2-1-1: Application
9-2-1-2: Sketch Plan
9-2-1-3: Preliminary Plat Approval
9-2-1-4: Final Plat Approval
9-2-2: Specifications for Plats
9-2-2-1: Sketch Plan and Supporting Documents
9-2-2-2: Preliminary Plat and Supporting Documents
9-2-2-3: Engineering Plans and Drawings
9-2-2-4: Final Plat
9-2-2-5: Supplementary Documents
9-2-3: Recording Final Plat
9-2-4: Deposits
9-2-5: Supplemental Documents
9-2-1: PLAT APPROVAL PROCEDURE:
   A.   Stages of Process: All subdivision plats shall be processed in three
(3) stages leading to approval for recording: except that, as provided in this
Title the first stage may be waived. The three (3) stages are: the sketch plan,
the preliminary plat and the final plat. (Ord. 90-19, 11-28-90)
   B.   Final Plat Approval Required: No land shall be subdivided and filed for
record, no building permits issued, and no improvements or construction
permitted until a final plat for that development has been approved and
recorded.
   C.   Prior Final Plat Approval: If a final plat of subdivision has
heretofore been approved prior to the effective date hereof but no improvements
have been constructed subsequent to said approval, then the subdivider and/or
developer shall follow the applicable procedures for filing, review and
approval of the preliminary and final engineering plans as are otherwise
provided herein for any new subdivision. All provisions relative to guarantees
of performance (as set forth in Section
9-4-4) and inspection of improvements (as set forth in Section
9-4-5) shall also apply.
   D.   Plat Approval Process: The complete plat approval process shall include
seven (7) steps which are as follows:
      1.   Application form with required additional documents and payment of
fee.
      2.   Sketch plan submitted for conceptual review.
      3.   Preliminary plat submitted for approval.
      4.   Hearings and approval on preliminary plat
      5.   Final plat submitted for approval.
      6.   Village Board approval.
      7.   Recording of final plat (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-2-1-1: APPLICATION:
The Village shall provide an application form to be submitted by the owner or
his authorized agent. The application shall be submitted to the Village Clerk
with supporting documents and the filing fee and deposit. An application shall
be submitted before each of the stages, namely: sketch plan, preliminary plat
and final plat. The application form may be the same for each stage, provided
the information is up to date at the time of each application and it is
accompanied by the supplementary documents required at that stage.
   A.   Application Form: The application form shall contain the following
information: (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
      1.   Land owner with verification of owner as hereinafter required. (Ord.
94-23, 9-28-94)
      2.   Legal description.
      3.   Proposed developer (if different).
      4.   Consultants (if known), including engineer, surveyor, planner, and
others.
      5.   Description of proposed subdivision.
      6.   Approximate acreage and proposed number of lots.
      7.   Name of proposed subdivision.
      8.   Such other information as the board may direct.
   B.   Surveys And Other Documents: Surveys and other documents as set forth
in the following sections shall be submitted with the application. The
applicant shall provide twenty (20) copies (unless otherwise hereinafter
provided), of every document submitted. All documents shall either be on eight
and one-half inch by eleven inch (81/2" x 11") paper or folded into a size not
over nine inches by twelve inches (9" x 12").
   C.   Plan Or Plat: The application shall include a sketch plan or proposed
preliminary or final plat. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-1990)
   D.   Filing Fees And Deposits: The applicant shall pay at the time of filing
each application: 1) a nonrefundable filing fee to defray the costs and
expenses of the village board and plan commission review of the plan or plat
submitted; and where appropriate 2) an escrow deposit consistent with the
provisions of title 2, chapter 4, "Development Fees And Costs", of this code.
Filing fees and deposits are as follows:
For a sketch plan review                 $ 75.00
Filing fees:                              
 For a preliminary plat review:          
    Minor subdivision                250.00
    Major subdivision                 $1,500.00 plus $25.00 per lot over 5
                                          lots
 For final plat review                   None unless no preliminary review,
                                          then preliminary rate applies
Deposits:                                 
  Initial escrow deposit at preliminary   As required by title 2, chapter 4,
 review:                                 "Development Fees And Costs", of this
                                          code
 
   E.   Costs Charged For Plat Review: As required by title 2, chapter 4,
"Development Fees And Costs", of this code.
   F.   Reimbursement Of Escrow Fund: As required by title 2, chapter 4,
"Development Fees And Costs", of this code. (Ord. 2012-O-10, 8-22-2012)
   G.   Filing: The applicant shall submit twenty (20) copies of each of the
application form, the survey, and the sketch plan or preliminary plat or final
plat and supporting documents to the village clerk. At the time of filing,
applicant shall pay the filing fee in cash or certified funds.
   H.   Distribution: Within ten (10) days after applicant has filed a complete
application, the village clerk shall deliver one copy to each of the following:
all village board members, all plan commission members, the Village Engineer,
the Village Attorney and the Village Zoning Officer.
   I.   Board Action: Within forty five (45) days of the filing of the
application, the Board shall direct the Plan Commission, the Village Engineer
and the Village Zoning Officer to meet with applicant. In the case of a sketch
plan, the plan shall be reviewed for guidance and information regarding the
proposed subdivision of the land and the applicant advised accordingly. In the
case of a preliminary or final plat, the plat shall be reviewed for
conformance, hearings conducted as hereinafter required, and reports submitted
to the Village Board within sixty five (65) days after receipt by the Plan
Commission; and the Village Board shall accept or reject the plat within forty
five (45) days after receiving the Plan Commission report thereon.
   J.   Extension of Time: In the event that the Plan Commission or the Village
Board wishes to delay action on making its report of accepting or rejecting, as
the case may be, the date for such action may be extended only by agreement
with the applicant. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   K.   Proof of Ownership: The application form, at each stage shall be
accompanied by a current title commitment from a title insurance company
licensed in the State setting forth the present ownership of all of the
property proposed to be included in the subdivision, along with copies of all
document, plats or other matters of record which are raised as an exception or
objection to clear merchantable title to the premises. Applications, after the
first stage, may be accompanied by the original commitment and documents, etc.,
provided that the owner shall verify that the condition of title has not
changed since the submission of the original commitment.
   L.   Taxes: No parcel shall be considered for resubdivision if there are any
delinquent real estate taxes shown to be due by the title commitment.
   M.   Signature: The application shall be signed by the proposed developer,
and, (if different), the owner or owners of record. (Ord. 94-23, 9-28-94)
9-2-1-2: SKETCH PLAN:
The sketch plan stage is not required and is voluntary for the benefit of the
applicant. In order to avoid preparation of plats which are contrary to the
ordinance requirements and to advise the applicant of the preferences of the
Village, applicants are urged to take advantage of this informal opportunity to
consult with the Village Plan Commission and Village Board.
   A.   Survey: The survey submitted with a sketch plat may be a boundary
survey only.
   B.   Sketch Plan: It is suggested that for major subdivisions the plan
include the following:
      1.   Map: Location map, 1" = 2000'
      2.   Topography: Existing topography, 1 foot intervals
      3.   Flood Plains: Existing flood plains and floodways and wetlands (per
U.S. Army Corps standards)
      4.   Trees: Existing trees/wooded areas
      5.   Lots: Proposed lots with approximate dimensions and areas
      6.   Site Sketch Plan: A site sketch plan showing:
         a.   Boundaries of the property to be subdivided.
         b.   Land characteristics such as natural drainage, swamp areas,
wooded areas, ridges, soil characteristics and flood hazards, as shown on Flood
Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) and Floodway Map dated March 2, 1981, and amendments
thereto.
         c.   Development characteristics such as surrounding streets, existing
structures, and available utilities.
         d.   Proposed layout of streets, blocks, and lots and the proposed
location of park, and other nonresidential areas.
         e.   Existing easements and covenants affecting the property.
         f.   Existing zoning and zoning district boundaries on and adjacent to
the subject site.
      7.   Location Sketch: Location sketch showing the relationship of the
proposed subdivision to traffic arteries, public transportation, Municipal
utilities, schools, and churches.
      8.   Statement of Petitioner's Interest: Written statement of the
petitioner's interest in the proposed subdivision and description of the
features of the proposal that the petitioner believes are in the interest and
benefit of the Village. Included in the written statement shall be a
preliminary development schedule, a year by year projection of estimated
assessed valuation to be added, and a year by year projection of population to
be added by the development. The population projection shall be based on
factors to be supplied by the Plan Commission to the developer.
   C.   Review and Reports: The Plan Commission shall notify the applicant or
his representatives of the meeting, (at their regular meeting times), at which
it will review the sketch plan. At the meeting, (or thereafter in writing at
the applicant's request), the applicant will be advised of the Plan
Commission's, Village Engineer's and Village Zoning Officer's comments on the
sketch plan including any suggestions for change to improve its conformance to
the ordinances and the Village's requirements. Thereafter, at the applicant's
request or the Plan Commission's direction, the sketch plan may be submitted to
the Annexation, Planning, Zoning Committee of the Village Board for further
comment and suggestions. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-2-1-3: PRELIMINARY PLAT APPROVAL:
The preliminary plat is a drawing, and when necessary, accompanied by other
engineering drawings, on which final review for adherence to design standards
and improvement proposals is based.
   A.   Preparation: This plat shall be prepared by a surveyor or engineer
subsequent to and in accordance with the agreements reached in the sketch plan
conference. It shall be prepared in accordance with all applicable provisions
of this Title and other ordinances and shall be submitted in twenty (20)
copies.
   B.   Filing: The preliminary plat shall be considered officially filed after
it is examined by the Plan Commission and found to be in full compliance with
the specifications governing the preparations of plats and plans, and after the
required procedural steps have been duly taken.
   C.   Review: The Village Engineer, Village Zoning Officer and the Village
Attorney shall check the plat for compliance with the appropriate portions of
this Title and other applicable regulations. A written report recommending
approval or disapproval and giving the reasons therefor shall be sent to the
Plan Commission by each of them within forty five (45) days.
   D.   Accompanying Documents and Developer Report Responsibilities:
      1.   Before a preliminary plat may be considered for approval, it shall
be accompanied by the approval in writing of the State for any preliminary plat
containing thereon or bordering on any public waters in which the State has any
property rights or property interest. It shall be the responsibility of the
developer to solicit such approval.
      2.   Before a preliminary plat may be considered for approval, it shall
be accompanied by a natural resource opinion from the Lake County Soil and
Water Conservation District. It shall be the responsibility of the developer to
make such application and pay any required fees to the Lake County Soil and
Water Conservation District.
      3.   Where the preliminary plat contains utility easements, the plat
shall be accompanied by a written statement bearing signature of an authorized
employee of the utility company attesting to the suitability of said easements
for the purpose shown before a preliminary plat may be considered for approval.
      4.   U.S. Army Corps of Engineer/Illinois Department of Transportations
wetlands report.
      5.   Lake County Department of Transportation report and traffic impact
study.
      6.   Documents suggested in subsection
9-2-1-2B are required to be submitted with preliminary plats. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
   E.   Preliminary Plat Approval and Hearing: The Plan Commission shall review
the plat and approve or disapprove the plat, and submit its recommendation
giving written reasons therefor, to the Village Board within ninety (90) days.
The Village Board shall review and accept or reject the recommendation of the
Plan Commission giving written reasons therefor. The Village Board shall
conduct a hearing on the question of accepting or rejecting the recommendation
of the Plan Commission at its next regular meeting held more than ten (10) days
after receiving this report. Within three (3) business days after the
recommendation of the Plan Commission has been received by the Village Board,
the president of the school board of each elementary and high school district
in which a part of the subdivision is located shall be given notice by the
Village Clerk by certified mail as required by statute, of the recommendations
of the Plan Commission and the date and place at which the Village Board shall
conduct a hearing thereon, at which time they may be heard on the issue of
approving or disapproving the plat. (Ord. 90-19, 11-28-90)
   F.   Time Allowed to Submit Final Plat: If a final plat is not submitted
within one year of date of approval, the preliminary plat shall expire unless
approval has been extended, or unless a reservation is shown on the plat for
good cause shown.
Time Extension: One, and only one extension, not to exceed six (6) months, may
be granted by the Plan Commission.
   G.   Distribution: In addition to furnishing twenty (20) copies of all
documents filed, the applicant shall at the time of filing the application for
preliminary plat, submit to the Village Clerk, evidence that he has delivered a
copy of all documents filed to each of the following persons:
      1.   Heath Officer (being the Lake County Health Department).
      2.   Chief of the Libertyville Fire Protection District.
      3.   Superintendent of Lake County Department of Transportation.
      4.   Superintendent of Lake County Department of Public Works.
      5.   The superintendent of each school district in which part or all of
the subdivision is located.
      6.   Such other persons as the Village may hereafter designate. (Ord. 90-
03, 7-25-90)
9-2-1-4: FINAL PLAT APPROVAL:
The final plat is a record of the subdivision as surveyed in the field. It
shows property lines and other dimensions important to the subdivider in
selling lots, and to the public in keeping records of street lines, easements,
and utility locations. Recording of the final plat authorizes the issuance of
building permits, but does not constitute acceptance of proffered or required
dedications.
   A.   Procedures: After the Plan Commission and the Village Board have
approved the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall prepare and submit to said
Plan Commission a final plat of subdivision in recordable time together with
the following supporting documents:
      1.   Complete plans and specifications, approved by the Engineer of the
Village, providing for the improvements to be made in the subdivision,
including sanitary sewers, storm water sewers, drains, water distribution
system, pavements, and all other improvements proposed or required.
      2.   A property executed subdivision agreement, wherein the subdivision
and/or owner agrees (subject to approval of the final plat of subdivision by
the Village Board) to install at his expense the improvements, proposed and
required in accordance with the plans and specification, required in subsection
A1 above, within the time limit set forth in said agreement.
      3.   A properly completed and executed letter of credit or other
comparable financial guarantee as may be approved by the Village Attorney with
an expiration date of not less than ninety (90) days after all improvements are
to be completed in accordance required in subsection A2 above, unless otherwise
approved by the Village Board. Said letter of credit or other comparable
financial guarantee shall be provided in an amount as required by the Village
Engineer, but in no case shall it be less than one hundred fifty percent (150%)
of the Engineer's estimate of the cost of the improvement, as set forth in the
plans and specifications required in subsection A1 above, plus the cost of
engineering inspections, as set forth in the schedule of fees, as provided in
Section
9-2-4 of this Chapter. Such letter of credit or other financial guarantee shall
always be maintained in an amount not less than one hundred fifty percent
(150%) of the estimate aforesaid of any balance due for improvements.
      4.   Evidence satisfactory to the Plan Commission, showing that all taxes
and past due installments on special assessments due on the property to be
subdivided have been paid.
      5.   Evidence satisfactory to the Plan Commission, showing that all other
conditions and requirements of tentative approval have been met.
   B.   Staff Review: The documents required to be approved by the Village
Engineer and Village Attorney shall be submitted to them within ten (10) days
after the filed documents have been reviewed by the Plan Commission and found
to be complete. These officers shall submit their required reports to the Plan
Commission within forty five (45) days after receiving the documents to be
approved.
      1.   Village Attorney: When the final plat is submitted, the subdivider
shall submit therewith a proposed form of guarantee of performance as required
by Section
9-4-4 of this Title. The Village Attorney shall examine and approve the final
plat and form of guarantee of performance as to conformance to Village
requirements before the final plat is submitted to the Plan Commission for
review.
      2.   Village Engineer The Village Engineer shall examine the final plat
and determine if the plat meets the Village's engineering requirements. Upon
such determination, the Village Engineer shall sign the plat and submit it to
the Plan Commission. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   C.   Plan Commission and Village Board Review: The Plan Commission shall
review the final plat to determine if it conforms with the approved preliminary
plat. Upon approval or disapproval of the final plat, the Plan Commission shall
submit its recommendation giving written reasons therefor, to the Village Board
within ninety (90) days. The Village Board shall review and accept or reject
the recommendation of the Plan Commission giving written reasons therefor. The
Village Board shall conduct a hearing on the question of accepting or rejecting
the recommendation of the Plan Commission at its next regular meeting held more
than ten (10) days after receiving the report. Within three (3) business days
after the final plat with the Plan Commission recommendation has been submitted
to the Village Board for approval, the Village Clerk shall notify by certified
mail as required by statute, the president of the school board of each
elementary and high school district in which a part of the subdivision is
located that the plat has been submitted for approval and the date, time and
place of the hearing by the Village Board on approval or disapproval of the
plat.
   D.   Conditioned Approval: In the event that the Village Board finds that
the final plat is satisfactory in form and substance, but is lacking certain
specific items, including but not limited to payment of various fees; final
performance guarantees; approval documents of other agencies of government; and
other documents or items the Village may require, the subdivision may be
approved conditioned upon the applicant submitting the missing items and
receiving the approval of such items by the Village officer designated by the
Village Board in such conditional approval.
   E.   Final Plat: The final plat is a record of the subdivision as surveyed
in the field. It shows property lines and other dimensions important to the
subdivider in selling lots, and to the public in keeping records of street
lines, easements and utility locations. It is intended that approval be
automatic if the final plat conforms to the approved preliminary plat and meets
the criteria in this Title for approval of a final plat. Upon determining that
the final plat has been approved by the Plan Commission, the Plat Officer shall
sign the plat and submit it to the Village Board for approval. Countersigning
by the Village President after approval by the Village Board shall constitute
final approval and authorize the recording of the final plat.
   F.   Recording: Recording of the final plat authorizes the issuance of
building permits, provided that the developer has installed all improvements
or, in the alternative, has posted bond or other sufficient security as set
forth in Section
9-4-4 of this Title, and the recording of the final plat constitutes acceptance
of proffered or required dedications. Recording of the plat does not constitute
acceptance of any streets or other improvements required to be made, whether or
not on dedicated rights of way.
   G.   Building Permits: If building permits are to be issued prior to the
completion of all improvements required to be made as a condition of approval
of the plat at the time of issuance, the property owner must sign the building
permit indicating that he or she acknowledges that no occupancy permit shall be
issued unless and until all improvements required to be made as a condition of
approval of the plat of the subdivision in which the construction is to take
place have been fully completed and received the approval of the Village Board.
No occupancy permit shall issue for a residence situated within a subdivision
unless and until all improvements required to be made as a condition of the
approval of the plat, with the exception of the one inch (1") final bituminous
concrete course described in subsection 9-4A-6G, within the subdivision have
been completely installed and received the approval of the Village Board.
   H.   Conditions for Disapproval: Disapproval is warranted upon, but not
limited to, the following conditions:
      1.   There are deviations from the preliminary plat;
      2.   More than one year has elapsed since preliminary plat approval;
      3.   A new street, highway, pipeline or other construction or major
feature that has been constructed planned or has directly affected the site by
virtue of such improvement being placed on the Official Plan of the Village.
      4.   If the required written consent has not been obtained from the
Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Highways or Water Resources,
Lake County Highway Department. Lake County Public Works, or Lake County Health
Department, the final plat shall not be approved.
      5.   If the plat or the supporting documents fail to meet the
requirements of this Title. (Ord. 90-19, 11-28-90)
   I.   Staged Development: Submission of a final plat covering only a portion
of the area by a preliminary plat may be permitted after consideration of the
effect on the continuity of roads, utilities, and services; provided, that all
of the requirements of the entire subdivision, e.g., major access roads,
retention basins, buffer zones and open space dedication are included in the
first portion of the staged development. Validity of the preliminary plat may
be extended to one year from the date of final approval of any portion thereof.
   J.   Variations and Modifications: Whenever a proposed subdivision fails to
conform to the strict terms of this Title or of the Zoning Title, so that
either a hardship modification as provided in subsection
9-6-3A of this Title, or a variation as provided in the Zoning Title 1  is
required, to warrant approval of the proposed subdivision, hearings as required
in either instance, shall be conducted and the hearing report and
recommendations of the Plan Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals shall be
submitted to the Village Board prior to its review and consideration of the
final plat. Thereafter, consideration of said final plat and the proposed
hardship modification and zoning variations shall be concurrent. (Ord. 90-03,
7-25-90)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  8-10-2 of this Code.
9-2-2: SPECIFICATIONS FOR PLATS:
9-2-2-1: SKETCH PLAN AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS:
The subdivider shall meet with the Plan Commission in a preliminary conference
which shall be scheduled by appointment. Prior to the conference he shall
submit to the Plat Officer the following:
   A.   Site Sketch Plan: A site sketch plan showing:
      1.   Boundaries of the property to be subdivided.
      2.   Land characteristics such as natural drainage, swamp areas, wooded
areas, ridges, soil characteristics and flood hazards, as shown on Flood
Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) and Floodway Map dated March 2, 1981, and amendments
thereto 1 .
      3.   Development characteristics such as surrounding streets, existing
structures, and available utilities.
      4.   Proposed layout of streets, blocks, and lots and the proposed
location of park, and other nonresidential areas.
      5.   Existing easements and covenants affecting the property.
      6.   Existing zoning and zoning district boundaries on and adjacent to
the subject site.
   B.   Location Sketch: Location sketch showing the relationship of the
proposed subdivision to traffic arteries, public transportation, Municipal
utilities, schools, and churches.
   C.   Statement of Petitioner's Interest: Written statement of the
petitioner's interest in the proposed subdivision and description of the
features of the proposal that the petitioner believes are in the interest and
benefit of the Village. Included in the written statement shall be a
preliminary development schedule, a year by year projection of estimated
assessed valuation to be added, and a year by year projection of population to
be added by the development. The population projection shall be based on
factors to be supplied by the Plan Commission to the developer. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
 
Notes
1 2. See Title 8, Chapter 8 of this Code for Flood Plain Regulations.
9-2-2-2: PRELIMINARY PLAT AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS:
The preliminary plat shall be drawn or printed on paper at a scale of one
hundred feet to one inch (100' = 1"), unless a different scale is approved at
the sketch plan conference. This plat shall show or be accompanied by the
following information:
   A.   Title and Certificate: Name under which the proposed subdivision is to
be recorded, location and position by quarter-quarter section, section,
township, range, meridian, county, and state; names and addresses of
subdividers; notation stating scale, north arrow; and the following
certificate:
State of Illinois, County of Lake, Village of Green Oaks
Approved by                              ( ) day of                      ,
19    A.D.
Name of subdivision must be original and not duplicate or be substantially
similar to any existing Lake County subdivision.
   B.   Boundary Lines: Complete survey data such as angles, bearings,
dimensions, curve data, etc., shall be shown for the exterior lines of the
subdivision. The error of linear closure of said boundary survey shall be not
greater than one in ten thousand (1 in 10,000).
   C.   Existing Easements: Location, width, and purpose of easements and other
existing restrictions, reservations, or covenants.
   D.   Existing Streets: Existing streets showing pavement width, right-of-way
width, and name; also existing curbs, gutters, culverts, sidewalks, and
building setbacks.
   E.   Existing Utilities: Existing utilities showing location and size of
sanitary and storm sewers; fire hydrants, and location and size of water mains;
location of gas lines, electric and telephone lines.
   F.   Ground Elevations: Ground elevations on the tract, based on 1929 USGS
Sea Level Datum, including: contours at two foot (2') intervals for land that
slopes more than two percent (2%); contours at one foot (1') intervals for land
that slopes less than two percent (2%); and spot elevations at all breaks in
grade, along all drainage channels or swales, and at selected points not more
than one hundred feet (100') apart in all directions. Contours shall not be
taken from USGS maps.
   G.   Surface Conditions: Surface conditions on the tract including
watercourses and surface drainage patterns, marshes, bogs, wooded areas,
isolated preservable trees, natural prairie, and rock outcroppings. The limits
and elevations of flooding as shown on the National Flood Insurance Program
Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) and Floodway Maps dated March 2, 1981, and
amendments thereto shall be indicated.
   H.   Man-Made Features: Man-made features including houses, barns and other
structures, and other constructed features.
   I.   Location Map: A small-scale two thousand feet to one inch (2,000' = 1")
drawing of the region in which the subdivision is situated, showing the
location of the subdivision, and indicating its relationship to traffic
arteries, community facilities, railroads and other nonresidential land uses or
adverse influences within a radius of two (2) miles. Current boundary lines of
all municipalities within the area of this drawing shall be shown.
   J.   Proposed Public Improvements: Proposed public improvements for future
construction on or near the tract, according to the information received from
the Plat Officer at the sketch plan conference.
   K.   Subsurface Conditions: Subsurface conditions describing depth of ground
water unless test pits are dry at a depth of eight feet (8'); location and
results of any tests made to ascertain subsurface soil and rock conditions.
   L.   On-Site (Septic) Sewage Disposal Systems: A report from the Lake County
Health Department indicating approval of the subdivision for septic systems
shall be submitted for any subdivision with lots to be served by individual on-
site (septic) sewage disposal. The report shall be prepared in accordance with
the regulations and procedures of the Lake County Board of Health Ordinance,
article V, rule II, which regulates the approval of new subdivisions throughout
Lake County. In the event the said Lake County Health Department Regulations
are amended or revised, the report shall be prepared in accordance with the
then current regulations and procedures of the Department, relating to approval
of the subdivision for septic systems.
   M.   Proposed Streets: Proposed streets showing right of way, pavement or
roadway width and proposed names.
   N.   Proposed Easements: Proposed easements showing location, width and
purpose.
   O.   Lot Lines, Building Setback Lines: Lot line approximate dimensions and
building setback lines.
   P.   Reservations, Dedications: Sites to be reserved or dedicated for any
public or semi-public use.
   Q.   Conservancy Areas: The conservancy areas shall be depicted on the face
of the plat and the following language shall be included verbatim on the face
of the plat:
Prohibited Uses:
1. No man-made structure of any kind shall be constructed in the flood plain.
2. The flood plain shall not be filled nor shall the grade be altered in any
respect.
3. No materials shall be utilized or stored which shall have the potential for
polluting either surface or ground water.
4. There shall be no floodway alteration.
5. There shall be no disturbing of natural vegetation.
   R.   Water Facilities: The location of all lakes, ponds, detention sites,
retention sites and dams shall be depicted, and accurately located on the final
plat.
   S.   Data Tabulation: Tabulation of data on gross area, street area, other
dedicated area, net subdivided area, number of lots, average lot size, typical
lot dimensions, and lineal feet of street.
   T.   Proposed Contours: Proposed contours of the finished subdivision.
   U.   Proposed Agreements: Proposed agreements, bylaws, provisions or
covenants which govern the use, maintenance, insurance and continued protection
of the proposed development and its common open areas and other facilities.
   V.   Supplementary Plans and Drawings: When unusual site conditions exist,
the Plat Officer may require such additional plans, specifications and drawings
as he finds necessary for an adequate review of the plat. The Plat Officer
shall request this additional material from the subdivider by letter, stating
therein the information requested and the particular or unusual site conditions
which make this information necessary.
All of the requirements of plat preparation shall apply equally to the site
being subdivided and to all land within two hundred feet (200') of its
boundaries, waiving accuracy requirements as to scale of features but not as to
boundary lines. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-2-2-3: ENGINEERING PLANS AND DRAWINGS:
Whenever improvements are required in the development of a subdivision, the
Engineer shall submit to the Plat Officer triplicate copies of the hereinafter
mentioned plans, specifications, and estimates bearing his signature and the
imprint of his seal.
   A.   Streets: Plans and specifications for street construction, including
center line profile of each street with a typical cross section of the roadway.
The street plan shall show the location of drainage structures and their sizes.
The profile shall be shown to a scale of one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50')
horizontal and one inch equals five feet (1" = 5') vertical (standard Federal
aid sheets are required).
      1.   Traffic Control Analysis: A study of traffic and traffic control
requirements to be incorporated into the subdivision plans.
   B.   Water Supply: Plans, details, specifications, and cost estimates of
proposed community water supply facilities.
   C.   Drainage: Plans, details, specifications, and cost estimates of
proposed storm drainage improvements.
   D.   Sanitary Sewers: Plans, details, specifications, and cost estimates of
proposed community sanitary sewer facilities.
   E.   Individual Lot Plat: Individual lot plat setting forth building site
area, minimum building grade, lot grading plan, drainage structures, easements,
nature preservation areas, individual tree preservation requirements, and any
other restrictions or conditions relating to the use, development and occupancy
of the lot.
   F.   Utilities: Where the plans, details, specifications, and cost estimates
of utility easements, with a written statement bearing the signature of an
authorized employee of the utility company attesting to the suitability of said
easement for the purpose shown. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-2-2-4: FINAL PLAT:
The final plat shall be drawn in waterproof black (India) ink on tracing cloth,
or in their equivalents. Permitted page sizes shall be as follows: thirty six
inches by thirty inches (36" x 30") or eighteen inches by thirty inches (18" x
30"). Other sizes will not be accepted. Scale shall be one hundred feet to one
inch (100' = 1") or larger. Variation in scale may be allowed when determined
by the Plat Officer to be necessary for a proper exhibit of the subdivision.
When one or more sheets are used for any plat, they shall be numbered
consecutively and each sheet shall contain a notation showing the whole number
of sheets in the plat and its relation to the other sheets (e.g., sheet 1 of 3
sheets). Linear dimensions shall be given in feet and decimals of a foot. The
final plat shall show on the face thereof:
   A.   Name: Name of the subdivision.
   B.   Location: Location and position of the subdivision indicated in each of
the following ways: by quarter-quarter section, section, township, range,
meridian, county and state; by distance and bearings from true north and angles
with references to a corner or corners established in the United States Public
Land Survey; and by a written legal description of the exterior boundaries of
the land as surveyed and divided.
   C.   Scale: Scale of the plat, true north arrow and date of preparation. The
top of the plat shall be oriented north.
   D.   Boundary: Boundary of plat, based on an accurate traverse, with angular
and lineal dimensions. The error of linear closure of said boundary survey
shall not be greater than one in ten thousand (1 in 10,000). The length of
boundary lines of all streets, blocks, lots, parcels, easements, and rights of
way or enough information so that the length of these lines can be derived by
simple calculation. Where a boundary line is an arc of a circle, the radius
interior angle and length of chord shall be shown.
   E.   Monuments: The description and location of all survey monuments, survey
data sufficient to reproduce any line or reestablish any monument. True
bearings and distances to the nearest established street lines or official
monuments (not less than 2), which shall be accurately described in the plat.
   F.   Streets:
      1.   Exact location, right-of-way widths, and names of all streets within
and adjoining the plat. The length of boundary lines of all streets, alleys,
blocks, lots, parcels, public grounds, easements, and rights of way, or enough
information so that the length of these lines can be derived by simple
calculation. Where a boundary line is an arc of a circle, the radius interior
angle and the length of the chord shall be shown.
      2.   The abutting street lines of all adjoining subdivisions, shown in
their correct locations by broken lines, shall be indicated.
   G.   Easements: Exact location, dimensions and description of purpose for
all easements, walkways, bicycle paths, and walking trails.
   H.   Lots: Location of all block, lot and parcel lines with accurate
dimensions in feet and hundredths. All blocks, lots and parcels shall be
consecutively numbered throughout the plat and the area indicated on each lot
or parcel.
   I.   Reserved Areas: Accurate outlines and legal description of any area to
be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purposes indicated thereon,
and of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for common uses of all property
owners.
   J.   Conservancy Areas: The conservancy areas shall be depicted on the face
of the plat and the following language shall be included verbatim on the face
of the plat:
The following prohibitions pertain to all conservancy areas depicted on the
face of this plat:
Prohibited Uses:
1. No man-made structure of any kind shall be constructed in the flood plain.
2. The flood plain shall not be filled nor shall the grade by altered in any
respect.
3. No materials shall be utilized or stored which shall have the potential for
polluting either surface or ground water.
4. There shall be no floodway alteration.
5. There shall be no disturbing of natural vegetation.
   K.   Water Facilities: The location of all lakes, ponds, detention sites,
retention sites and dams shall be depicted, and accurately located on the final
plat.
   L.   Building Setback Lines: Building setback lines accurately shown with
dimensions.
   M.   Protective Covenants: Protective covenants which meet the approval of
the Plan Commission shall be lettered on the final plat.
   N.   Water: The graphic location and labeling of any water bodies including
lakes, ponds, streams, and storm water detention and retention facilities and
showing the permanent surface water elevation and the elevation and high-water
marks of such bodies and the boundary lines and elevations of the base 100-year
flood plain.
   O.   Certificates: The final plat shall show thereon the following
certificates duly processed and signed using waterproof ink.
      1.   Owner's Certificate:

9-2-2-5: SUPPLEMENTARY DOCUMENTS:
In addition to the final plat of subdivision, the developer shall submit and
the Board shall approve for recording, the following documents:
   A.   Individual lot plats as required in subsection
9-2-2-3E, duly prepared with a surveyors certificate and a Village certificate
as above required in Section
9-2-2-4 for the final plat.
   B.   Covenants and restrictions as may be required under the Title duly
executed by the owner and with a Village certificate.
   C.   As a condition of approval of a final plat, prior thereto, a subdivider
or developer shall submit a development plan of all open space easements,
showing the dimensions thereof, the extent and nature of all significant
natural vegetation, both forest and prairie, all berms sought to be
constructed, the amount and size and type of all planting sought to be
installed. Such plan shall be reviewed by the landscape architect with the
landscape architect's written comments being forwarded to the Plan Commission
to be considered by the Plan Commission. Said Plan Commission shall approve,
disapprove, or suggest whatever modifications are necessary in keeping with
this subsection and may require a bond in the amount of one hundred fifty
percent (150%) of the cost of the proposed development, if the Plan Commission
determines that it is in the best interests of the Village to do the same.
(Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-2-3: RECORDING FINAL PLAT:
After the plat is approved, the Village Clerk shall submit the approved final
plat to the Lake County Recorder for recording. The Village Clerk shall also
record any other documents of conveyance, declaration, deeds, grants of
easement of other documents submitted with the final plat and directed by the
Village Board to be recorded. The Village Clerk shall, within five (5) working
days after recording, notify the Plat Officer of the time of recordation and
supply the Plat Officer with an exact copy on mylar or linen of the plat as
recorded and a reproducible copy of the approved engineering plans and
specifications which shall become the property of the Village. Recording of the
approved final development plat authorizes the issuance of building permits,
but does not constitute acceptance of proffered or required dedications. (Ord.
90-03, 7-25-90)
9-2-4: DEPOSITS 1  :
   A.   Deposits: Deposits required with each application shall be used to
defray the expenses hereinafter set forth. The amount of each deposit after the
initial deposit shall be sufficient to bring the deposit balance to the amount
required for that level of review after crediting the balance remaining on
deposit from the previous deposits made. It no further application is made for
one hundred eighty (180) days after the last application was processed, or
after the processing of the final plat the Village Treasurer shall return any
unexpected balance in the deposit fund to the applicant as directed by Village
Board.
   B.   Examination Costs: The subdivider shall pay all costs and fees, and
hearing costs, reproduction expenses, miscellaneous costs for engineering
examination and Attorney's examination provided for in subsections
9-2-1-1D, E, F, as well as all costs of recording the proposed subdivision.
   C.   Fee Expense Deposit: The amount of the deposit shall be estimated by
the Village Engineer and the Village Attorney on the basis of the facts set
forth in the preliminary plat. After the final plat has been approved, before
recording, the subdivider shall deposit additional sums sufficient to pay the
cost of inspections and other costs and fees which may become due as provided
in Section
9-4-7 of this Title. The amount of the deposit shall be estimated by the
Village Engineer and the Village Attorney, and, if the funds are determined to
be insufficient at anytime to meet anticipated costs, the subdivider shall, on
ten (10) days' notice, make additional deposits as required. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-
90)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  9-19-1 of this Title.
9-2-5: SUPPLEMENTAL DOCUMENTS:
The subdivider shall secure and maintain such insurance from an insurance
company authorized to write casualty insurance in the State where the work is
located as will protect himself, his subcontractors, the Village and the
engineer and his employees from claims from bodily injury, death or property
damage which may arise from subdividing the property. The subdivider shall not
commence work until he has obtained all insurance required under this Section
and shall have filed the certificate of insurance or the certified copy of the
insurance policy with the Village. Each insurance policy shall contain a clause
providing that it shall not be canceled by the insurance company without ten
(10) days written notice to the Village of intention of cancel. The amount of
such insurance shall be not less than the following:
   A.   1. Workmen's compensation and employer's liability insurance shall be
secured and maintained as required by the State.
      2.   Public liability, bodily injury and property damage:
         a.   Injury or death of one person - $500,000.00.
         b.   Injury to more than one person in a single accident -
$1,000,000.00.
         c.   Property damage - $250,000.00.
      3.   Automobile and truck public liability, bodily injury and property
damage:
         a.   Injury of death of one person - $500,000.00.
         b.   Injury to more than one person - $1,000,000.00.
         c.   Property damage - $250,000.00.
   B.   Indemnify: The subdivider shall indemnity and save harmless the Village
and the Engineer and his employees from and against all losses and all claims,
demands, payments, suits, actions, recoveries and judgments of every nature and
description brought or recovered against him by reason of any omission or act
of the subdivider, his agents or employees in the execution of the work or in
the guarding of it. The subdivider shall obtain in the name of the Village fire
insurance and shall maintain and pay the premiums for such insurance in such
amount and with such provisions as will protect the Village from contingent
liability and a copy of such insurance policy or policies shall be delivered to
the Village. Full compliance by the Village with the terms and provisions of
such insurance policy or policies shall be a condition precedent to the
insurance policy or policies shall be a condition precedent to the Village's
right to enforce against the subdivider any provisions of this Chapter.
   C.   Fire Insurance: In addition to such fire insurance as the subdivider
elects to carry for his own protection, he shall secure and maintain in the
name of the Village policies upon such structures and material and in such
amounts as shall be designated. The policies shall be secured from a company
which is satisfactory to the Village and delivered to the Village. (Ord. 90-03,
7-25-90)
CHAPTER 3
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
9-3-1: General Requirements
9-3-2: Streets
9-3-3: Blocks
9-3-4: Lots
9-3-5: Easements
9-3-6: Landscaping
9-3-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Conformity to Plans: All subdivisions shall conform to the Village
Official Plan, to the Zoning Title and subdivision regulations of the Village
and to all other applicable ordinances, resolutions and plans.
   B.   Natural Features: Each subdivision shall be appropriate to the
topography, the drainage, and other natural features of the site. Developments
shall be so laid out that they will tend to preserve the natural scenic beauty
of the Village and its environs.
   C.   Land Subject to Flooding: Land subject to flooding and land deemed by
the reviewing authorities to be uninhabitable shall not be platted for
residential occupancy, nor for such other uses as may increase danger to
health, life or aggravate the flood hazard. But such land within the plat shall
be set aside for such uses as shall not be endangered by periodic or occasional
inundation, shall not produce unsatisfactory living conditions, shall not
reduce the ability of the flood plain to retain flood waters and shall be in
conformity with the flood plain provisions of the Zoning Title 1 . (Ord. 90-03,
7-25-90)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 8, Chapter 8 of this Code.
9-3-2: STREETS:
   A.   Layout: The layout of streets in a subdivision plan shall conform to
existing regulations and policies and shall be based on thorough consideration
of:
      1.   Topography and drainage;
      2.   Public convenience and safety;
      3.   The existing street pattern;
      4.   The future circulation needs of nearby lands; and
      5.   The proposed uses of the land being subdivided.
   B.   Rights of Way: Street right-of-way widths shall be designated by the
major thoroughfare plan and/or Official Plan of the Village. In all other
instances the following table shall apply:
State highways with route numbers    120'
State highways without route numbers 100'
Major County highways*               100'
Other County highways*               80'
Major Township highways              80'
Other Township highways              80'
Collector streets                    80'
Minor streets                        60' with a 10' easement on either side for
                                     utility and ditch back-slope purposes.
 
*Master County Map on file in the office of the County Superintendent of
Highways.
   C.   Collector and Minor Streets: Collector streets shall be Village streets
designed to be main thoroughfares from one section of the Village to another.
Minor streets shall be so designed as to discourage high-speed or through
traffic.
   D.   Boundary Streets: Streets shall not be laid out on the boundary of a
subdivision. Exceptions to this may be permitted where the Plat Officer finds
that such streets are desirable for further expansion or where such streets
will conform to the existing street system.
   E.   Intersections:
      1.   Street intersections with thoroughfares shall be limited to not more
than one per quarter mile unless topographic and physical conditions require a
lesser distance. Street intersections shall be at right angles as may be
permitted by the plat officer. Where unusual conditions exist, the plat officer
may permit intersections of less than ninety degrees (90°) but not less than
sixty degrees (60°).
      2.   In all cases street intersections and junctions shall be laid out so
as to facilitate the safe flow of traffic. In no case shall two (2) junctions
be offset less than one hundred twenty five feet (125').
   F.   Cul-De-Sacs:
      1.   If the cul-de-sac is drained by open ditches, the right of way shall
be one hundred forty feet (140') in diameter with a ten foot (10') utility
easement along each front lot line. If storm sewers are used for drainage, the
right of way may be reduced to one hundred twenty feet (120') with a twenty
foot (20') utility easement along the front lot line.
   G.   Marginal Access Streets: Wherever a subdivision borders on or contains
the right of way of a limited access street, highway or thoroughfare, a
railroad or a utility right of way, a street may be required approximately
parallel to and on either side of such right of way for a distance suitable to
service such uses as front thereon. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-1990)
   H.   Location Of Sewer And Water Mains:
      1.   No public sewer or water mains shall be located in back yard or side
yard easements, except where no public or private street, alley or right of way
exists where any public sanitary sewer or water main of the village is now or
may in the future be available, as defined herein, and the location is approved
by the village engineer. In such cases, an easement in favor of the village
must be provided, which shall be subject to the approval of the corporate
authorities.
      2.   A public sewer or water main shall be considered "available", as
used herein, if it is located less than two hundred fifty feet (250') from a
single-family residence property or a commercial establishment of less than one
thousand five hundred (1,500) gallons usage per day, or less than one thousand
feet (1,000') from a commercial establishment over one thousand five hundred
(1,500) gallons usage per day, a multi-family dwelling, or a new subdivision.
      3.   In the event that a property owner elects to voluntarily extend an
existing public sewer or water main to serve his property, the owner shall be
required as a condition of approval of such work, to extend the main from its
existing location, all the way to the far side of the subject property, so as
to provide accessibility to the next adjacent property. Upon application of the
person, firm or corporation extending any public utility as provided in this
subsection H3, the corporate authority may vary the requirement of extending
the utility to the extreme boundaries of the property if and only if each of
the following conditions are present:
         a.   The real property to be served is residentially zoned and is
located within, or at the extreme boundary of a series of contiguous
residentially zoned parcels, lots or tracts; and
         b.   The public utility to be extended is available at each extreme
end of the said contiguous parcels; and
         c.   The village master plan for utilities extension does not
contemplate extension of the particular public utility from the one extreme end
of the contiguous parcels, to the other; and
         d.   No subdivision can be made of the property to which the public
utility is being extended; and
         e.   The village engineer, using reasonable engineering judgment,
finds that requiring extension of the public utility to the extreme boundary of
the subject property would serve no reasonable village purpose and will not
further the master utility plan of the village. (Ord. 2004-O-05, 5-26-2004)
   I.   Reserve Strips: Reserve ("spite" or "devil") strips controlling access
to streets are not permitted. Streets roughly paralleling the subdivision
boundary shall be located not less than one lot depth from said boundary. All
streets intended to provide the subdivision with future means of ingress and
egress shall extend to the subdivision boundary. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-1990)
   J.   Private Streets:
      1.   Private streets are not favored and will generally not be permitted
except: a) in cases where a condominium ownership or similar common ownership
arrangements are involved, or b) where a peculiarly shaped and relatively small
area is involved in which the regular pattern of public streets would create a
hardship upon the developer.
      2.   Private streets within nonresidential subdivisions and developments
may be approved by action of the village board where the public interest is
best served thereby and where the provisions of subsection J2a through J2f of
this section has been satisfied. Unless specifically waived by action of the
village board, private streets must be constructed to the same design standards
as public streets or as otherwise provided for in this title.
         a.   There shall be a finding by the village board that the unusual
shape, size or circumstances of the property or its ownership would create a
hardship upon the developer if required to develop regular public streets in
the development or subdivision, and the public interest is best served by
permitting private streets in the development or subdivision.
         b.   There shall be adequate provisions made for the perpetual care
and maintenance of the private street, including the removal of snow and ice
accumulations.
         c.   There shall be provisions made to enable the village to make
demand upon the owners of the properties served by the private street to
