provide care and maintenance to the satisfaction of the village, and, if such
care and maintenance is not provided as demanded, to permit the village, in its
sole discretion, to enter upon the private street and provide such care and
maintenance at the expense of the owners of the said properties.
         d.   There shall be provisions made to enable the village to enforce
its claims for payment of its expenditures for such care and maintenance by the
properties served by the private street by legal action, including, but not
limited to, the right to impose superior liens upon the said properties.
         e.   There shall be common ownership of the private street right of
way by all entities benefited thereby, or an easement of record running with
the land for the benefit of all properties served by the private street. The
ownership or easement documents shall assure that all such owners or easement
documents shall be legally obligated, severally and jointly, to pay the costs
of care and maintenance of the private street.
         f.   There shall be included in the care and maintenance expenses of
the private street, provisions for adequate liability insurance to cover any
liability which might be imposed upon the village in connection with the
private street. (Ord. 92-O-01, 1-29-1992)
      3.   In all cases where private streets are approved in accordance with
the above standards, adequate provision shall be made for location of public
utilities in properly designated easements within the private street. (Ord.
2004-O-05, 5-26-2004)
   K.   Streetlights: A system of streetlights on all public streets within the
subdivision shall be required to provide a standard streetlight at all
intersections, cul-de-sacs, or as the village may otherwise direct. (Ord. 90-O-
03, 7-25-1990)
   L.   Parkway Trees And Landscaping: Street trees and other landscaping shall
be installed in all subdivisions in accordance with the requirements of
chapters 5 and 6 of this title. Wherever sodding of ditches and other areas is
not required parkways shall be graded and seeded to provide a turf crop. (Ord.
90-O-19, 11-28-1990)
9-3-3: BLOCKS:
   A.   Design: The length, width and shape of blocks shall be determined with
due regard for the following:
      1.   Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs
of the types of use contemplated;
      2.   Zoning requirements as to lot size and dimensions;
      3.   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of
street traffic; and
      4.   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
   B.   Length: No block shall exceed one thousand eight hundred feet (1,800')
in length except where required by unusual topographic conditions, nor shall
they be less than six hundred feet (600') in length.
   C.   Pedestrian Or Bicycle Ways: Where blocks exceed one thousand feet
(1,000') in length or where orientation or pedestrian circulation requirements
indicate, pedestrian or bicycle ways may be required. Pedestrian or bicycle
ways shall not be less than ten feet (10') in width. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-1990)
9-3-4: LOTS:
   A.   Configuration Of Lots: The lot size, width, depth, shape and
orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for
the type of development and use contemplated. Due regard shall be shown for all
natural features, such as tree growth, watercourses, historic spots, or similar
conditions which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the
proposed development.
   B.   Conformance With Zoning Regulations: Width and area of lots shall
conform to or exceed the lot width and area requirements set forth in the
zoning ordinance of the village (title 8 of this code) or that of the
appropriate county in the unincorporated areas beyond the village limits,
except that subdivisions contiguous to the village shall conform to all
applicable requirements of the village zoning ordinance. Corner lots shall be
sufficiently larger than interior lots to allow maintenance of building lines
on both sides fronting on a street.
   C.   Nonresidential Lots: Width, area and depth of lots in an industrial or
business subdivision shall be as recommended by the plan commission and
approved by the board of trustees.
   D.   Adequate Building Site Required: Lots abutting a watercourse,
drainageway, channel or stream shall have additional minimum width and depth as
required to provide an adequate building site and afford the minimum usable
area required in the zoning ordinance (title 8 of this code) for front, rear,
and side yards, as recommended by the plan commission.
   E.   Driveway Location: Lots shall be arranged to provide for a minimum of
driveway openings on primary and secondary streets. Driveway locations and
corner lots shall be indicated on the final plat and the location shown shall
appear as a covenant running with that lot.
   F.   Frontage:
      1.   All lots shall front directly on a minor or collector street. Lots
adjoining state highways, expressways, and thoroughfares shall be provided with
marginal access streets or shall front on a local street.
      2.   Double frontage lots are not permitted, except where lots back upon
a thoroughfare and in such instances, vehicular and pedestrian access between
the lots and the thoroughfare is prohibited.
   G.   Lot Lines: Side lines of lots shall be at right angles or radial to the
street line or substantially so and along curvilinear street lines. No lot
shall have a frontage at the street or a width at the rear lot line less than
the sum of required side yards as provided in the zoning title.
   H.   Deep Lots: Lots abutting an expressway or major thoroughfare, a
railroad, utility right of way, or other inharmonious use shall have width or
depth of twenty feet (20') in excess of the typical interior lot in the same
subdivision. Such twenty feet (20') shall be in excess of required yard. A
planting screen easement, across which there shall be no right of access may be
required on such deep lots.
   I.   Topography: The topography shall be preserved wherever possible in its
natural state by minimizing grade changes and the like. Topography shall not
increase the discharge rate of storm water onto neighboring properties
consistent with storm water requirements of this title.
   J.   Preservation Of Landscape: The landscape shall be preserved in its
natural state, insofar as practicable, by minimizing tree and soil removal, so
that the resulting development will be in keeping with the general appearance
of neighboring developed areas and will not adversely affect the ecology of the
area. Prior to any removal of trees the developer must secure written
permission from the village board. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-1990)
   K.   Utility Services: Electric and telephone lines shall be underground.
Any utility installations remaining aboveground shall be located so as to have
harmonious relation to neighboring properties and the site. The proposed method
of sanitary sewage disposal for all buildings shall be indicated, and shall be
in conformance with the provisions of this code. (Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-1990; amd.
Ord. 2004-O-05, 5-26-2004)
   L.   Noise Abatement: On property located along expressways, major arterial
streets, railroads and other nonresidential land uses, noise abatement berms or
equivalent natural materials of sufficient size and/or quantities to provide
the desired noise abatement shall be located on the property adjacent to said
expressways and the like.
   M.   Floodplains: All floodplain land shall be preserved in its natural
state or as farmland and no subdivision in the floodplain shall be permitted.
(Ord. 90-O-03, 7-25-1990)
9-3-5: EASEMENTS:
Easements shall be in conformity with the requirements of title 8 of this code.
(Ord. 90-O-19, 11-28-1990)
9-3-6: LANDSCAPING:
Landscaping shall be in conformity with the requirements of title 8 of this
code. (Ord. 90-O-19, 11-28-1990)
CHAPTER 4
REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Purpose
9-4-2: Monuments
9-4-3: Improvements Required
9-4-4: Guarantees of Performance
9-4-5: Inspection of Improvements
9-4-6: "As Built" Plans
9-4-7: Fees
9-4-1: PURPOSE:
It is deemed necessary and essential to require and control the provision and
installation of improvements when property is subdivided and developed in order
to:
   A.   Ensure conformity to the statutes governing the subdivision of land in
the State;
   B.   Cause the installation of the utilities and public service facilities
necessary to serve the property developed;
   C.   Provide for the current financing of said facilities;
   D.   Spread the costs of required improvements upon the property benefitted;
   E.   Prevent the dissipation or the improper use of public funds in
providing these improvements or maintaining faulty installation; and/or
   F.   Protect the living standards, public safety, and common welfare of
residents within and without the subdivision. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4-2: MONUMENTS:
   A.   Preservation of Existing Monuments: All U.S., State, County or other
official bench marks, monuments or triangulation stations in or adjacent to the
subdivision shall be preserved. When a proposed improvement in a subdivision
makes necessary the moving of bench marks, monuments or stations, the authority
having jurisdiction shall be notified and given sufficient time to take
appropriate action.
   B.   Placement of New Monuments: Permanent monuments shall be erected at all
street corners and all points where street lines intersect the exterior lines
of the subdivision and at all lot corners, block corners, angles in the streets
or lot lines, and points of beginning and ends of curves.
   C.   Materials: Permanent monuments shall be of galvanized iron pipe not
less than three-fourths inch (3/4") in diameter and not less than twenty four
inches (24") in length, or of concrete not less than four inches (4") in
diameter and not less than twenty four inches (24") in length. In no case shall
thin-wall pipe or electrical conduit be permitted. If concrete is used, an iron
bar one-half inch (1/2") in diameter and twenty four inches (24") in length
shall be set in the concrete to accurately locate the corner. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
9-4-3: IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED:
   A.   Streets:
      1.   Unless otherwise specified, the type, design and construction of
streets shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section
9-4A-6-1 of this Title.
      2.   Street profile plans and cross sections and street lighting plans
for all subdivision streets shall be prepared by an engineer and the engineer,
as agent for the subdivider, or his contractor, shall be responsible for
establishing the proper lines and grades for all work. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
      3.   At least one street of full width, including private streets within
nonresidential developments or subdivisions, shall be provided to furnish the
subdivision or development with access to an existing improved public street.
Said access street shall be improved by the subdivider or developer in
accordance with the standards appropriate to its function, whether or not it
lies partly or entirely outside the subdivision or development. (Ord. 92-01, 1-
29-92)
   B.   Storm Drainage:
      1.   The storm drainage improvements shall conform to the system designed
and established by the engineer and approved by the Village Engineer.
Computations shall be required for the entire watershed or drainage basin of
which the subdivision is a part.
      2.   In residential subdivisions containing lots less than forty thousand
(40,000) square feet in area, underground storm sewer systems will be required.
      3.   Special consideration shall be given to the avoidance of problems
which may arise from storm water runoff onto adjacent properties. All storm
drainage shall be conducted and/or connected to an outfall approved by the
Village Engineer.
      4.   In all Office District subdivisions underground storm sewer systems
shall be required.
   C.   Culverts and Bridges: Adequate drainage structures shall be provided.
The design, installation, and construction of drainage structures shall comply
with Section
9-4A-6-2 of this Title.
   D.   Curbs and Gutter: In all subdivisions where underground storm drainage
systems are required or proposed, curbs and gutters shall be provided.
   E.   Street Signs: Signs giving names of streets shall be erected at all
street intersections. Signs shall meet the minimum requirements for similar
signs and posts as shown and set forth in the "Manual of Uniform Traffic
Control Devices for Streets and Highways" as prepared and published by the
Department of Transportation, State of Illinois.
   F.   Traffic Control Signs: Signs for controlling the movement of traffic
shall be erected as required by the Village Engineer, or as designated in
subdivision plans. Signs shall meet the requirements of the "Manual of Uniform
Traffic Control Devices".
   G.   Water Supply: In any subdivision in which the Health Officer finds that
individual private water supply systems would create health problems, a central
water supply system shall be required. This type of subdivision as well as the
ones listed herein shall be provided with a water supply and a distribution
system.
      1.   Any subdivision required to have a central water supply and
distribution system and lying within the service area of an existing
governmental agency which is providing water service, shall consider such
governmental agency as a potential source of water. The Plat Officer shall have
full authority to inquire into all matters relating to the utilization of all
existing developed sources of water. Where the Plat Officer finds that an
existing developed source of water cannot reasonably be used, a separate source
of water may be developed.
      2.   Where central water systems cannot be provided, individual private
water systems may be permitted, provided such water systems meet all
requirements of the Lake County Health Department.
   H.   Planting Screens: The subdivider shall plant, install, construct or
otherwise provide fences, planting strips, or buffers along lot lines which
adjoin any existing or planned commercial or industrial area, and shall enclose
any hazard which exists or which the plat reviewing authorities find will
result from the development of the subdivision. The Village Plan Commission
shall determine whether the fences, plant strips, buffers, or enclosures are
adequate.
   I.   Office Development: In all Office District subdivisions, all uses shall
be served by sanitary sewer facilities and a community water system approved by
the Village Engineer, the Lake County Public Works Department, and the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4-4: GUARANTEES OF PERFORMANCE:
In order to provide for the orderly growth of the Village and to further
provide for the orderly development of land and the installation of all
required improvements in newly developed areas, no plat of a proposed
subdivision shall be given final approval, or permit issued to construct any
other improvements as provided for in Section
9-1-4 of this Title, until the requirements of this Section have been met.
Before approval of a final plat, or approval or issuance of a permit to
construct any development improvements, a performance bond, acceptable
irrevocable letter of credit, or other guarantee acceptable to the Village must
be provided as set forth hereunder: (Ord. 92-01, 1-29-92)
   A.   Amount: The amount of the guarantee shall be equal to one hundred fifty
percent (150%) of the estimated cost of construction of the required
improvements as approved by the Village Engineer.
   B.   Time Limit: All guarantees shall run to the Village and shall require
performance of work to be completed within eighteen (18) months from the date
of final plat approval. Letters of credit or cash deposit guarantees shall not
expire until at least ninety (90) days after date of required performance
completion.
   C.   Release: Release of portions of the required performance bond is
expressly prohibited, but if the guarantee is in the form of a cash deposit or
of a letter of credit, the amount of the guarantee may be reduced from time to
time upon approval of the Village Engineer in a sum equal to ninety percent
(90%) of the original estimated value of work which has been completed,
approved, fully paid for, and accepted by the Village. No guarantee shall be
released until the work has been finally approved and accepted by the Village
and a two (2) year guarantee submitted as hereinafter provided in subsections E
and F. Separate guarantees for different kinds of improvements shall be
minimized.
   D.   Bond Company: The bonding company, bank, financial institution or
escrowee utilized shall meet with the approval of the Village.
   E.   Two Year Guarantee: After the work has been completed and accepted and
approved by the corporate authorities, the subdivider and the owner shall
guarantee said public improvements against defects in materials and workmanship
for a period of two (2) years from the date of the acceptance of said public
improvements by the Village. The owner and subdivider agree to repair or
replace any of said public improvements which, during said two (2) year period
after acceptance shall become damaged or deficient due to defective materials
or workmanship and to maintain said public improvements in a good and safe
state of repair, ordinary wear and tear excepted, for said two (2) year period
after acceptance.
   F.   Acceptance of Improvements, Two Year Guarantee: Upon certification to
the Village Board by the Village Engineer that all of said improvements have
been completed and have been approved by him and when all of the costs of
construction of said improvements and all engineering costs including the
Village's engineering inspection fees have been paid, the Village Board shall
thereupon accept said public improvements; provided however, that the
subdivider shall first post a guarantee in a form acceptable to the Village in
an amount not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the cost of the construction of
public improvements being accepted to assure performance of the two (2) year
guarantee of maintenance and replacement of defective improvements hereinabove
required in subsection E. Said two year (2) guarantee shall be in similar form
to the original guarantee, and letters of credit or cash deposit guarantees
shall not expire until ninety (90) days after the two (2) year guarantee
period.
   G.   Release of Guarantees: When the said improvements have been accepted
and approved and the two (2) year guarantee posted as hereinabove provided, the
guarantee of performance hereinabove required shall be released by the
corporate authorities. When the two (2) year guarantee period has expired and
when all obligations under the two (2) year guarantee have been satisfied, the
subdivider shall be entitled to release thereof by the corporate authorities.
   H.   Default: If the improvements are not completed within the required
time, the corporate authorities of the Village may use the performance bond,
letter of credit, or other guarantee or any portion thereof, to complete
construction of the improvements. In addition thereto or in lieu thereof, the
corporate authorities may deem such failure to complete the improvements within
the required time sufficient cause for the revocation and cancellation of the
Village's approval of said plan of subdivision or any part thereof. Default is
failure to install herein required improvements or to maintain or replace the
same as required in subsection F.
      1.   Performance Bond: In the event of default, when the guarantee is in
the form of a performance bond, the corporate authorities shall seek completion
of the improvements or two (2) year maintenance and replacement, as the case
may be, in the manner provided in said bond.
      2.   Letter of Credit: In the event of default, when the guarantee is in
the form of a letter of credit, the corporate authorities shall obtain from the
Village Engineer, an estimate of the cost of completion of the improvements, or
of the two (2) year maintenance and replacement, as the case may be, and
immediately draw against said letter of credit, a sight draft in a sum equal to
one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the said cost estimate. Said sum shall be
deposited in a special fund and used only to pay the cost of curing said
default including any engineering and attorney's fees. When all costs of curing
said default have been paid, and within one year after drawing said funds, the
balance thereof, if any, shall be returned to the subdivider. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
   I.   Approval with Conditions: Notwithstanding the provisions of this
subsection, the Village Board may waive the requirements herein that bond or
other security be posted prior to final approval if the following conditions
are met:
      1.   The final plat shall bear a legend which clearly provides that no
building permits may be issued for, nor any construction allowed upon any lot
in the subdivision unless there shall first have been provided to and approved
by the Village, an adequate security in the form provided in this Section to
assure that all public improvements necessary for the use and occupancy of the
lot will be installed and completed.
      2.   That a deed conveying all of the public interest or open space areas
of the subdivision is delivered to the Village.
      3.   That the developer meets such other conditions that the Village
Board determines to be necessary to assure that the approval of the final plat
shall not create a condition under which the developer can avoid any of its
obligation to complete all of the improvements required to be made by the
developer in the subdivision.
      4.   No lots shall be sold by the developer before providing security in
the form required in this Section unless the proposed buyer shall first be
provided with a notice that no building permits will be issued and no
construction allowed until such security is provided. Developer shall file a
copy of such notice signed by buyer with the Village before delivering a deed.
      5.   The provisions of this subsection shall apply only to residential
subdivisions of one hundred (100) acres or more in which at least thirty five
(35) acres thereof are being conveyed to the Village as per open space areas as
referred to in subsection I2 of this Section. (Ord. 93-19, 4-21-93)
9-4-5: INSPECTION OF IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Required: All required land improvements to be installed under the
provisions of this Title shall be inspected at the subdivider's expense. The
Engineer, at the expense of the subdivider, shall provide an inspector on the
job during the process of construction. When the work has been completed, the
Engineer shall certify that the improvements comply in all respects with the
approved plans and specifications, and with the requirements of this Title. All
required land improvements to be installed under the provisions of this Title
shall be inspected at the subdivider's expense. All work shall also be at all
times subject to inspection by the Village Road Commissioner, the Health
Officer, the Village Engineer and other Village officials and their
representatives.
   B.   Notification to Village Officials: Before starting the construction of
any improvements, the subdivider shall ascertain from the Village Road
Commissioner, Health Officer and the Village Engineer what inspections are
required and the amount of notification desired in each case, and shall comply
with all their rules, regulations, and instructions pertaining to such required
inspections.
   C.   Reports: Any inspection which requires that the Village Road
Commissioner, the Health Officer or the Village Engineer be present shall be
made by that official or his agent and reported in written form, and one copy
shall be furnished to the Engineer or other agent of the subdivider.
   D.   Responsibility of Subdivider: Regardless of contracts, agreements or
inspections performed, final responsibility for the installation of all
improvements, in accordance with the applicable standards, rests with the
subdivider.
   E.   Approval and Acceptance:
      1.   Street; Drainage Improvements: When street, water, sewer and
drainage improvements and all appurtenances thereto, based on approved plans,
have been constructed or installed and passed all inspections, the corporate
authorities shall provide the developer with a letter of approval, completion,
and acceptance by the Village subject to the requirements of subsection
9-4-4F of this Chapter.
      2.   Health and Sanitation Facilities: When health and sanitary
facilities, based on approved plans, have passed all inspections, the Health
Officer shall provide the developer with a letter of approval and completion.
Such letter shall not constitute acceptance by the public; it shall be the
responsibility for the agency intending to maintain and operate the facility to
provide the developer with a letter of acceptance subject to the requirements
of subsection
9-4-4F of this Chapter.
      3.   Water and Sewer Improvements: When any required sewer or water
improvement is not intended for public ownership, the appropriate inspecting
agency shall provide the developer with a letter of approval and completion.
Such letter shall not constitute acceptance by the public but shall permit the
owner to operate and maintain the facility. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4-6: "AS BUILT" PLANS:
After completion of all public improvements and prior to final acceptance of
said improvements, the subdivider shall make, or cause to be made, "as-built"
plans showing the actual location of all valves, manholes, stubs, sewer and
water mains, and other improvements. This plan shall be in black (India) ink on
tracing cloth, or materials of equal permanence and durability, and shall bear
the seal and signature of the engineer. The presentation of this plan shall be
a condition of final acceptance of the improvements and release of the surety
bond assuring their completion. This plan or a reproducible (intermediate)
copy, shall become the property of the Village. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4-7: FEES:
The subdivider shall pay to the Village such fees as defray the cost of
inspections and whatever other engineering services which may be involved in
the installation of the improvements, and such attorney's fees as may be
involved in the approval and acceptance of improvements, release of guarantees,
or enforcement of guarantees 1 . (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  9-2-4 of this Title.
ARTICLE A. CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS AND SPECIFICATIONS
SECTION:
9-4A-1: Qualifications of Contractors
9-4A-2: Time of Construction
9-4A-3: Sequence of Construction
9-4A-4: Grading
9-4A-5: Debris Removal
9-4A-6: Engineering Design Specifications
9-4A-6-1: Streets
9-4A-6-2: Storm Drainage
9-4A-6-3: Storm Water Detention
9-4A-6-4: Water Wells
9-4A-6-5: Sewage Disposal Facilities
9-4A-6-6: Parking Lots and Driveways in Nonresidential Developments and
Subdivisions
9-4A-1: QUALIFICATIONS OF CONTRACTORS:
The developer shall file with the Village a list of all contractors and
subcontractors who are to participate in the construction of public
improvements. Such contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to
disqualification by reason of faulty performance of prior construction work
done in the Village. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-2: TIME OF CONSTRUCTION:
All improvements required herein shall be installed after recording of the
final plat and must be completed within eighteen (18) months after approval of
the final plat. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-3: SEQUENCE OF CONSTRUCTION:
All underground utilities, sanitary sewers, and storm sewers installed in
streets, alleys, service roads, or
highways shall be constructed or installed prior to the surfacing of such
streets. Service connections to such underground utilities and sewers shall be
extended to the property line of each lot so as to obviate disturbing the
surface improvements in such public ways when service connections are later
made. Where underground utilities are located in the parkway adjacent to the
paved roadway, service connections to properties across such road shall only be
made by drilling under the pavement in such a way that surfacing is not
disturbed or weakened. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-4: GRADING:
Where it is proposed to alter ground elevations more than two feet (2'),
proposed as well as existing contours shall be shown on the grading or on the
contour map. Where topsoil is removed during the course of construction, that
area shall be recovered with topsoil to a depth of at least four inches (4").
All exposed areas shall be reseeded or sodded to prevent erosion. Seeding and
sodding shall conform to the specifications as set forth in Section
9-4A-6 of this Chapter. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-5: DEBRIS REMOVAL:
The subdivider shall clean and maintain all public ways, sewers and drains free
from debris and trash or other extraneous material prior to acceptance and at
such other times during construction as the Village Road Commissioner or
Village Engineer may deem necessary to prevent the creation of a public
nuisance. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-6: ENGINEERING DESIGN SPECIFICATIONS:
9-4A-6-1: STREETS:
The improvements required by this Title shall be in accordance with the
criteria set forth hereunder, and unless otherwise specified, shall be
constructed in accordance with the provisions of the current "Standard
Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction" adopted by the Department of
Transportation, Division of Highways of the State. The standards set forth
herein are the minimum acceptable and are not intended to prevent the
subdivider from constructing a higher type street structure.
   A.   Street Grades:
      1.   The maximum grades of collector streets shall not exceed six percent
(6%).
      2.   The maximum grades for minor streets shall not exceed eight percent
(8%).
      3.   In no case shall the grade of any street be less than five- tenths
of one percent (0.5%).
   B.   Vertical Alignment:
      1.   The vertical curves of collector and larger streets shall not be
less than two hundred feed (200') in length.
      2.   The vertical curves for minor streets shall be not less than one
hundred feet (100') in length.
      3.   Exception to the above minimums may be made at intersections where
the length of vertical curves shall be no less than fifty feet (50').
      4.   In no case shall stopping sight distance be less than two hundred
seventy five feet (275'). (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   C.   Horizontal Alignment:
      1.   For public streets, the minimum radius of center line horizontal
curvature shall be as follows: collector street, three hundred feet (300');
minor street, one hundred feet (100'). For private streets, the minimum
interior back of curb radius shall be fifty feet (50') minimum, and shall be
designed to permit a fifty foot (50') semi-trailer combination vehicle to pass
through the curve while maintaining an unobstructed twelve foot (12') lane
width in the opposite direction.
      2.   Street jogs with center line offsets of less than one hundred twenty
five feet (125') shall be avoided.
      3.   Angles on the center line of a street are not permitted.
      4.   For public streets, reverse curves are allowed; provided, a minimum
of one hundred feet (100') of tangent is introduced between the curves. For
private streets, reverse curves without a tangent are allowed.
      5.   For minor public streets in nonresidential developments
subdivisions, the minimum radius of center line horizontal curvature shall be
two hundred feet (200'). (Ord. 92-01, 1-29-92)
   D.   Intersection Radii: Radii at intersections shall not be less than
twenty five feet (25') measured to the edge of the street surfacing. (Ord. 73-
10, 10-4-73)
   E.   Surface Width: Public residential street shall be improved to the
following pavement widths according to classification:
 
Collector street 24 feet
Minor street     20 feet
Cul-de-sac       22 feet
 
For minor streets in all nonresidential developments or subdivisions, the back-
to-back curb width shall be thirty four feet (34'), and on cul-de-sacs, twenty
seven feet (27'). For private streets in nonresidential developments and
subdivisions, the back-to-back of curb width shall be thirty feet (30').
   F.   Surface Crown: The surface of all roadways shall have a uniform slope
from the center line to the edge of 0.02 feet per foot. Private streets in
nonresidential developments and subdivisions without a crown shall have a cross
pavement slope from side to side of 0.02 feet per foot.
   G.   Surface Material: Residential streets shall be improved with a minimum
of two inch (2") bituminous concrete binder course, Class I, plant mix followed
at a later date with a one inch (1") thick bituminous concrete surface course,
Class I, Type 2, Mixture D. All minor streets and private streets in all
nonresidential developments and subdivisions, shall be improved with a minimum
two and one half inch (21/2") thick bituminous concrete binder course, Class I,
followed at a later date by one and one-half inches (11/2") thick bituminous
concrete surface course, Class I.
   H.   Sub-Base and Base Course Materials:
      1.   Residential streets shall have a sub-base course material conforming
to gradation CA-8, crushed gravel or crushed stone, which shall be placed to a
minimum compacted thickness of seven inches (7") and to a width one foot (1')
wider than either the edge of pavement where shoulders are used or the back of
curb on each side; and shall have a base course material conforming to
gradation CA-6 (grade 8), which shall be placed a minimum compacted thickness
of seven inches (7") between curb faces or extended one foot (1') past the edge
of the pavement where shoulders are used.
      2.   In no instance will sub-base course material be placed on a soft
subgrade. If a soft subgrade is encountered, it shall be removed to stable
material. Backfill material will consist of properly compacted earthen material
with an adequate supporting value or of granular material.
      3.   For minor streets and private streets in all nonresidential
developments or subdivisions, streets shall have a sub-base course material
conforming to gradation CA-8 crushed gravel or crushed stone, which shall be
placed a minimum compacted thickness of six inches (6") and to a width one foot
(1') wider than the back of the curb on each side and shall have a base course
material conforming to gradation CA-6 (grade 8 or 9), which shall be placed a
minimum compacted thickness of nine inches (9") between curb faces. (Ord. 92-
01, 1-29-92)
   I.   Shoulders: Earthen shoulders will be constructed on each side and
adjacent to the roadway surface. Shoulder widths to each side shall be eight
feet (8') on collector streets and four feet (4') on minor streets. All
shoulders shall slope away from the surface edge at a rate of three-fourths
inch (3/4") per foot. For all streets with curb and gutter and storm sewer,
earthen shoulders shall not be required. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   J.   Cul-De-Sacs: For all street cul-de-sacs, the minimum radius for the
outside edge of pavement shall be fifty feet (50'). Center islands are required
on all residential area cul-de- sacs. Center islands are not permitted on
nonresidential area cul-de-sacs. The pavement radius at the throat of each cul-
de- sac shall be fifty feet (50'). The pavement in residential cul-de-sacs
shall be twenty two feet (22') in width. The pavement in nonresidential cul-de-
sacs shall be twenty seven feet (27') back-to-back of curb in width.
   K.   Curbs: Type B-6 curbs shall be required for all streets in all
nonresidential developments and subdivisions. Curbs in residential subdivisions
shall be Type M-4.12. A drain system shall be installed continuous with the
curb with discharge to storm water manholes. The drain system shall consist of
pipe, washed stone and filter fabric. When the storm sewer also serves as the
underdrain for a roadway, it shall be located along the low point of the
pavement or curb line; the storm sewer shall be open jointed and filter fabric
shall be provided along the trench bottom and walls and extend up to one foot
(1') above the top of the storm sewer pipe. The storm sewer pipe shall be
bedded with number 6 or 8 washed stone. (Ord. 92-01, 1-24-92)
   L.   Street Lights: A system of street lights on all public streets within
the subdivision shall be required as set forth in subsection
9-3-2K. The Village Engineer shall from time to time establish and the Village
shall approve standards for street lighting fixtures and controls. (Ord. 90-03,
7-25-90)
9-4A-6-2: STORM DRAINAGE:
   A.   Design Storm Criteria: All storm water runoff shall be calculated by
means of the Rational Method. Drainage structures for fifty (50) acres or less
in size shall be designed to accommodate a five (5) year storm frequency for a
storm duration equal to the time of concentration, but not less than ten (10)
minutes. For watersheds over fifty (50) acres in size, the design storm
frequency shall be ten (10) years.
   B.   Ditches:
      1.   Ditches shall be constructed on both sides of the roadway outside of
the shoulder line. Ditches shall have a minimum depth of two feet (2') below
the edge of the roadway surface with maximum backslopes of four to one (4:1) on
the roadway side and two to one (2:1) on the property side.
      2.   Maximum ditch gradient without erosion protection shall be two
percent (2%). The ditch shall be protected from erosion by means of sodding,
ditch paving, ditch checks, storm sewers or combinations thereof as deemed
necessary.
      3.   Minimum ditch gradient shall be three tenths of one percent (0.3%).
If this gradient cannot be maintained, the ditches shall be paved or storm
sewers installed.
      4.   Continuous with the bottom of the ditch shall be installed an
underdrain system with rigid perforated piping, washed stone envelope and
filter fabric. At intervals of not less than two hundred feet (200') shall be
installed a washed stone and filter fabric envelope connecting the CA-8 sub-
base and under drain system.
   C.   Culverts:
      1.   Minimum culvert sizes shall be fifteen inches (15") for driveways
and roadway crossings. At locations where culverts cross roadways, a minimum
distance of sixteen inches (16") will be maintained between the top of the pipe
and the roadway surface.
      2.   All roadway culverts shall extend a sufficient distance beyond the
shoulder line so as to intersect the backslope at the culvert spring line.
Flared end sections shall be provided on all roadway culverts.
      3.   Prior to acceptance of the street improvement or the issuance of any
building permits, the subdivider will furnish the Village an overall map of the
subdivision showing the proper size culvert for each lot.
   D.   Restoration: All shoulders, backslopes and parkways within the street
right of way shall be restored by placing three inches (3") of topsoil and
seeding with a Class II mixture per the "Standard Specifications".
   E.   Flood Fringe Changes: Whenever the characteristics of the flood fringe
of an existing man-made pond or detention area denoted on any FEMA National
Flood Insurance map or report is modified, the project engineer for the
developer shall submit to the Village all plans and documents required by FEMA
for amending and revising said map or report prior to final approval by the
Village Engineer of any said changes or modifications. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-6-3: STORM WATER DETENTION:
   A.   General: It is recognized that the receiving streams within the area of
the Village do not have the capacity to receive and convey the increased storm
water runoff resulting from development occurring in the area. These receiving
streams are subject to frequent flooding which results in a growing rate of
property damage.
   B.   Storage: A combination of storage and controlled release of storm water
runoff is required for all commercial developments exceeding one acre in area,
for all residential developments exceeding ten (10) acres in area and for all
residential developments between five (5) and ten (10) acres which have an
imperviousness of sixty percent (60%) or greater. However, a residential
development of ten (10) acres or less must have an adequate outlet as signified
by the Village Engineer. If the outlet is not adequate, then detention, as
determined by the Village Engineer, will be required to store that portion of
the runoff exceeding the outlet capacity.
   C.   Release Rate:
      1.   The release rate of storm water from all developments requiring
detention shall not exceed the storm water runoff rate from the area in its
natural undeveloped state.
      2.   Because of the flat conditions of the land in this area, channel
configuration cut by nature are generally unable to handle the runoff from high
intensity rainfall and results in flood plain storage or spreading of runoff
over the land areas during the larger storm periods. In order not to increase
the runoff from such areas after development, the release rate must be limited
to the carrying capacity of these natural channels. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
      3.   A maximum release rate of not greater than 0.10 cfs/acre when the
basin is at full capacity is acceptable unless the downstream channel is not
capable of handling this flow. A manual shut-off shall be provided in order to
reduce the release of storm water flow equal to zero cfs. (Ord. 90-16, 11-28-
90)
   D.   Drainage System: Drainage systems shall have adequate capacity to
bypass through the development, the flow from all upstream areas for a storm of
design frequency assuming that the land is in a fully developed state under
present zoning or zoning proposed under the Village Official Plan. The bypass
flow rate shall be computed utilizing a runoff coefficient of not less than
0.35. An allowance will be made for upstream detention when such upstream
detention and release rate has previously been approved by the Village and that
evidence of its construction can be shown.
   E.   Live Detention Storage: The live detention storage to be provided will
be calculated on the basis of the 100-year frequency rainfall as published in
Illinois State Water Survey (Bulletin 70) for this area. The detention volume
required will be that necessary to handle the runoff of a 100-year rainfall,
for any and all durations, from the fully developed drainage area tributary to
the reservoir, less that volume discharged during the same duration at the
approved release rate. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   F.   Calculations: The line detention volume shall be sized using the most
critical 100-year storm event not to exceed forty eight (48) hours in duration,
with a release rate equal to zero cfs. One method of calculation, which will be
acceptable to the Village for the determination of the capacity of storm water
detention reservoirs is as follows:
 
Live Detention Storage (acre/feet) =
(c) (i100) (td) (0.0833)
       Maximum storage volume calculated by this equation for any and all
      duration (td) will be the required storage. The terms of the above
       equation are defined as follows:
       The intensity in inches per hour of rainfall from the Illinois State
i100 = Water Survey (Bulletin 70), Table 13, for 100-year frequency for any and
       all durations, not to exceed forty eight (48) hours in duration.
td =   The duration of the 100-year storm, which must be varied to determine
       the most critical and therefore maximum required detention.
       The coefficient of runoff for the completely developed drainage area
c =    tributary to the reservoir A coefficient 0.30 shall be used for lawn and
       landscaped areas; 0.95 for impervious areas; and 1.0 for detention
       basins and bodies of water.
      Note: i100 varies with td.
 
   G.   Freeboard: A minimum of two feet (2') of freeboard shall be provided on
all basins. (Ord. 90-16, 11-28-90)
9-4A-6-4: WATER WELLS:
Individual wells shall be located and constructed in accordance with the
requirements of the Lake County Health Department. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-6-5: SEWAGE DISPOSAL FACILITIES:
Individual sewage disposal facilities shall be designed and constructed in
accordance with the requirements of the Lake County Health Department. (Ord.
90-03, 7-25-90)
9-4A-6-6: PARKING LOTS AND DRIVEWAYS IN NONRESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENTS AND
SUBDIVISIONS:
The improvements required by this Section shall be in accordance with the
criteria set forth hereunder, and shall be constructed in accordance with the
provisions of the then current "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction" adopted by the Department of Transportation, Division of Highways
of the State. The standards set forth herein are the minimum acceptable
standards and are not intended to prevent the developer from constructing a
higher type street structure.
   A.   Parking Lot and Driveway Grades:
      1.   The maximum pavement slope shall not exceed five percent (5%).
      2.   The minimum pavement slope shall be one percent (1%), except where
the pavement is adjacent to and sloping towards a curb.
      3.   The minimum curb slope shall be five-tenths of one percent (0.5%)
when used to provide drainage.
   B.   Surface Material: Parking lots and driveways shall be improved with a
minimum two inch (2") thick bituminous concrete binder course, Class I followed
at a later date with one inch (1") thick course bituminous concrete surface
course, Class I.
   C.   Base Course Material:
      1.   Parking lots shall have a base course material conforming to
gradation CA-6 (grade 8 or 9), which shall be placed a minimum compacted
thickness of ten inches (10") between curb faces.
      2.   Driveways shall have a base course material conforming to gradation
CA-6 (grade 8 or 9), which shall be placed a minimum compacted thickness of
fourteen inches (14") between curb faces.
      3.   In no instance will sub-base course material be placed on a soft
sub-grade. If a soft sub-grade is encountered, it shall be removed to stable
material. Backfill material will consist of earthen material with an adequate
supporting value or of granular material.
   D.   Curbs:
      1.   All parking lots and driveways shall have curbs.
      2.   All curbs shall be type B-6.12. A drain system shall be installed
continuous with the curb with discharge to storm water manholes. The drain
system shall consist of pipe, washed stone and filter fabric. When the storm
sewer is located along the low point of the pavement or curb line, it may also
serve as the underdrain for the parking lot; in this case the storm sewer shall
be open jointed and filter fabric shall be provided along the trench bottom and
walls and extending up to one foot (1') above the top of the storm sewer pipe.
The pipe shall be bedded with number 6 or 8 washed stone.
   E.   Parking Stall Dimensions:
      1.   All parking stalls shall be a minimum of eighteen feet deep by nine
feet wide (18' x 9'), except where the parking stall fronts a curb, the stall
depth then may be sixteen feet (16'). If a sidewalk abuts a curb parking stall,
then said sidewalk shall be a minimum of eight feet (8') wide.
      2.   Handicapped parking shall be provided as required by State and
Federal laws and regulations.
   F.   Parking Lot Aisle Dimensions:
      1.   All parking lot aisles shall be a minimum of twenty six feet (26')
wide for right angle parking. (Ord. 92-01, 1-29-92)
CHAPTER 5
VACATIONS
SECTION:
9-5-1: Procedure
9-5-2: Standards
9-5-3: Petition Form and Content
9-5-4: Easements
9-5-5: Bond
9-5-6: Limitations
9-5-7: Resubdivision in Lieu of Vacation
9-5-8: Cancellation of Bonded Contracts
9-5-1: PROCEDURE:
In all cases the vacation of any plat or part thereof or any public right of
way, easement or part thereof shall follow the procedure for the review of
plats established in this Title except that:
   A.   Final action shall be taken by the Village Board, and
   B.   The Plat Officer shall recommend to the Village Board a sum to be paid
by the owners of abutting properties in consideration of any public property
involved in the vacation. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-5-2: STANDARDS:
The Plat Officer and the other administrative officers shall recommend
disapproval of any petition for vacation which fails to meet the following
standards:
   A.   A vacation shall be approved which creates a condition which would not
be permitted under the standards of design set forth in this Title, unless such
vacation will at the same time correct a more serious condition which exists
contrary to the standards of this Title.
   B.   No vacation shall be approved which will result in a conflict with the
Official Plan of the Village.
   C.   No vacation shall be approved which will result in a violation of the
Village Zoning Title or other applicable ordinances or regulations, unless such
vacation will at the same time correct a more serious condition which exists
contrary to such ordinances or regulations. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-5-3: PETITION FORM AND CONTENT:
The sketch and preliminary plat of vacation shall be accompanied by a certified
statement of the assessed valuation of all properties surrounding any public
right of way to be vacated. Final petitions for vacation shall include the
following items:
   A.   Three (3) copies of the original plat certified by the Recorder to be a
true copy of same, on which is shown the portion to be vacated outlined in a
heavy line and hatched.
   B.   The following petitions, deeds, and certificates, all drafted from
models obtainable from the Plat Officer:
      1.   Deed of vacation
      2.   Petition (3 copies)
      3.   County Clerk's certificate
      4.   Resolution of the Village Board
      5.   Assessor's certificate
   C.   The petition as it is presented to the Village Board shall be
accompanied by a written recommendation from the Plat Officer. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
9-5-4: EASEMENTS:
The vacation of any plat or part thereof, or right of way, easement or part
thereof shall not be deemed to be a vacation of the rights of any public
utility where said public utility has installed its facilities therein. All
such vacations shall be made upon the express condition that the abutting
property owner or owners grant to all public utilities, their successors and
assigns, the right of way or easement to operate, maintain, renew and
reconstruct their facilities in, over or under the public right of way or
easement vacated and such condition shall be noted on the deed or plat of
vacation and in the ordinance or resolution of vacation. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-5-5: BOND:
The Village may require the petitioner to furnish bond in an amount sufficient
to protect the Village, indemnifying it for any suit which may be filed for
damages sustained as a result of such vacation. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-5-6: LIMITATIONS:
Nothing contained herein, nor any required certificate, shall be deemed in any
way to limit the right and authority of the Village to vacate any plat or part
thereof, or any right of way or easement or part thereof where it finds that
such vacation will serve the public interest. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-5-7: RESUBDIVISION IN LIEU OF VACATION:
It shall not be necessary to vacate a plat or part thereof in order to proceed
with a resubdivision of said plat or part thereof. Resubdivision according to
the procedure and standards for subdivision required by this Title shall
automatically constitute vacation of a prior plat or part thereof, provided
that monetary remuneration shall be paid to the Village in consideration of any
excess of public property vacated over that dedicated in the resubdivision.
(Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-5-8: CANCELLATION OF BONDED CONTRACTS:
Bonded contracts for the improvement of platted streets or alleys shall be
automatically cancelled upon vacation of such platted streets. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
CHAPTER 6
SUBDIVISION ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
9-6-1: Administration
9-6-2: Permits; Certificates of Occupancy
9-6-3: Variances
9-6-4: Hearings
9-6-5: Amendments
9-6-6: Enforcement
9-6-7: Penalty
9-6-1: ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Plat Officer: The office of Plat Officer is hereby created and the
chairman of the Plan Commission is hereby designated Plat Officer of the
Village. The Plat Officer and the Plan Commission shall administer this Title.
   B.   Approval of Plats: The Plat Officer shall approve and sign all maps or
plats of subdivision in accordance with the provisions of this Title; provided,
that no map or plat of subdivision shall be approved by the Plat Officer
without the consent of a majority of the Plan Commission in quorum (the vote
and presence of the Plat Officer shall be counted as any other member of the
Plan Commission). (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   C.   Objections to Decisions, Procedure: Within fifteen (15) days after a
sketch or plat of subdivision has been finally acted upon, the subdivider shall
file any objections which he may have in writing with the Plan Commission which
shall thereupon consider and act upon same. The Plat Officer, after said
objections have been duly considered and acted upon, shall inform the
subdivider in writing of the action taken on said objections. If the subdivider
is dissatisfied with the action taken thereon, and if the action of the Plan
Commission is not to become a recommendation submitted to the Village Board he
shall, within fifteen (15) days, request the Plat Officer, in writing, to
present the matter to the Village Board. The Plat Officer shall then refer the
matter to the Village Board at its next regular meeting and the Village Board
may approve the plat or take whatever other action it considers to be in the
public interest. The Village Board shall not approve any plat which has been
disapproved by the Plan Commission except by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the
Village Board in quorum. (Ord. 90-19, 11-28-90)
9-6-2: PERMITS, CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY:
   A.   Building Permits: Building permits shall not be issued until the Zoning
Officer has been notified by the Plat Officer that the final plat has been
approved and recorded.
   B.   Public Utilities, Permits Required: Public utilities shall obtain
permits from the Village Board for the installation of communication, electric
power, gas or other utility services before any installation is started.
   C.   Certificates of Occupancy: Certificates of occupancy shall not be
issued until the Zoning Officer has been notified by the Plat Officer that the
required improvements have been completed and approved. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-6-3: VARIANCES:
   A.   Reasons for Variations: When the Plan Commission, in interpreting this
Title, finds that extraordinary hardship or injustice will result from strict
compliance with this Title, it may vary the terms thereof to the extent deemed
necessary and proper to grant relief, provided that the modification is due to
physical features of the site; is the least deviation from this Title which
will mitigate the hardship; is not detrimental to the public interest, and in
keeping with the general spirit and intent of the Title.
   B.   Application for Variance: Application for any modification shall be
made in writing by the subdivider at the time the preliminary plat is filed for
consideration, stating fully and clearly all facts relied upon by the
petitioner; and shall be supplemented with maps, plans, or other additional
data which may aid the Plan Commission in the analysis of the proposed project.
The plans for any development shall include such covenants, restrictions, or
other legal provisions necessary to guarantee the full achievement of the plan.
Once the terms of any modification have been agreed upon, the review of the
subdivision shall proceed as set forth in this Title. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
   C.   Granting Variances: Whenever the Plan Commission has approved or
disapproved the granting of a variance as provided in this Section, the
proposed variance and a full statement of the reasons for approval or
disapproval of the variance shall be reported in writing to the Village Board
along with the recommendations of the Plan Commission for approving or
disapproving the proposed plat as required in Chapter 2 of this Title. The
Village Board shall consider the proposed variance along with the
recommendations of the Plan Commission. The Village Board shall not approve any
variance except by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the Village Board in quorum.
(Ord. 90-19, 11-28-90)
9-6-4: HEARINGS:
   A.   Procedure: Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Plan Commission in
enforcing the terms of this Title may request a hearing before the Village
Board. Requests for such hearings shall be made in writing to the Plat Officer.
Upon notification by the Plat Officer, the Village President shall schedule an
appointment for a hearing within thirty (30) days of the receipt of the
request. The petitioner shall be notified of the date, time and location of the
hearing at least three (3) days in advance.
   B.   Decision of Board of Trustees: If, upon hearing the evidence of both
the Plan Commission and the petitioner, the Board finds that the decision of
the Plan Commission is in error, the Village Board shall instruct the Plan
Commission to modify its decision. Such modification shall not conflict with
this Title and shall in no case adversely affect the orderly development of the
area. The decision of the Village Board shall be made known in writing to the
petitioner within ten (10) days after the date of the hearing. (Ord. 90-03, 7-
25-90)
9-6-5: AMENDMENTS:
Any person wishing to propose an amendment to this Title may submit his
proposal to the Plan Commission. The Plan Commission may, without a public
hearing, submit the proposed change or a modification thereof to the Village
Board for appropriate action. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-6-6: ENFORCEMENT:
All laws of the State and ordinances of the Village are made a part hereof the
same as if fully set forth herein, and all officers and employees of the
Village and specifically those herein referred to are directed to compel
compliance with such laws of the State and all the requirements of the Village.
(Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
9-6-7: PENALTY:
Whoever shall sell, or offer for sale, or lease for any time exceeding five (5)
years, any lot or block in any subdivision before complying with all the
requirements of this Title and the State statutes governing plats, shall be
subject to a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each lot or block, or
part thereof, so disposed of, offered for sale, or leased. Each day that sales
or offers to sell or lease in violation of this Title continue shall constitute
a separate offense, subject to the above penalty. (Ord. 90-03, 7-25-90)
TITLE 10
LIQUOR CONTROL
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
10-1-1: Short Title
10-1-2: Purpose
10-1-3: Words and Phrases Defined
10-1-4: Local Liquor Control Commissioner
10-1-5: Penalty
10-1-1: SHORT TITLE:
This Title shall be known, cited or referred to as the LIQUOR CONTROL ORDINANCE
OF GREEN OAKS, ILLINOIS.
10-1-2: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this Title:
   A.   To establish provisions for the licensing of persons and premises
qualified to sell alcoholic beverages in the Village.
   B.   To establish regulations controlling the sale of alcoholic beverages in
the Village, and regulating the operation of premises licensed under this
Title.
   C.   To create the office of Local Liquor Control Commissioner and to define
the duties and powers of the office.
   D.   To provide for fees for licenses to sell alcoholic beverages in the
Village.
   E.   To provide for the limitation of the number of persons and premises
licensed to sell alcoholic beverages.
   F.   To promote the public health, safety, morals and general welfare by
regulating the conduct of persons licensed to sell alcoholic beverages and of
persons consuming alcoholic beverages at licensed premises.
   G.   To provide penalties for the violation of any of the provisions of this
Title.
10-1-3: WORDS AND PHRASES DEFINED:
All words and phrases used in this Title and defined in the Illinois Liquor
Control Act of 1934 (235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, et seq.) shall have the
same meaning as they have in said Act unless otherwise herein defined as
follows: (Ord. 89-10, 7-26-89)
NOT-FOR-PROFIT SPONSORED RESTAURANT: A restaurant which is owned and operated
by a not-for-profit corporation which operates the restaurant for the purpose
of providing vocational, residential and social support services for mentally
retarded or developmentally disabled individuals. Pursuant to such purpose,
alcoholic liquor may be dispensed on a regular basis within buildings housing a
not-for-profit sponsored restaurant, and on a temporary basis at other
locations as may be approved by the Board of Trustees on the same premises on
which the building housing the not-for-profit sponsored restaurant is located.
(Ord. 89-20, 8-10-89)
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to
the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals actually are
served and regularly served, such space being provided with adequate and
sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed
therein sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook, and serve
suitable food for its guests; provided, that the revenues of premises licensed
as a restaurant to sell alcoholic liquor shall be derived at least sixty
percent (60%) from the sale of food; and provided further, that no premises
licensed as a restaurant shall sell alcoholic liquor except to persons having
or about to have a meal. (Ord. 89-10, 7-26-89)
10-1-4: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
   A.   Office Created: There is hereby created the office of local liquor
control commissioner. The village president shall be the local liquor control
commissioner and shall be vested with the duties and powers provided in the
Illinois statutes and by this title.
   B.   Compensation: The local liquor control commissioner shall be paid such
remuneration as the village board of trustees shall determine by resolution of
the village board.
   C.   Assistants: The local liquor control commissioner shall be empowered to
appoint with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees, such
assistant local liquor control commissioners as may, in his opinion, be
necessary to conduct the office and perform its duties. Such assistant local
liquor control commissioners shall be clothed with and have all of the
authority of the local liquor control commissioner while performing their
duties. (Ord. 89-10, 7-26-1989)
10-1-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this title shall be fined not
less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be held to have been
committed each day such violation shall occur or continue. (Ord. 89-10, 7-26-
1989; amd. Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
CHAPTER 2
LIQUOR LICENSES
SECTION:
10-2-1: License Required
10-2-2: Application
10-2-3: Restrictions On Licenses
10-2-4: Classes Of Licenses
10-2-5: Maximum Number Of Licenses
10-2-6: Change In Maximum Number Of Licenses Permitted
10-2-7: Term; Prorating Fee
10-2-8: License Fee
10-2-9: Disposition Of Fees
10-2-10: List Of Licenses In Force
10-2-11: Transfer Of License
10-2-12: Change Of Location
10-2-13: Revocation, Suspension, Refusal Of License
10-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail in the village any
alcoholic liquor without having a village retail liquor dealer's license, or in
violation of the terms of such license. (Ord. 89-10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-2: APPLICATION:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village local liquor
control commissioner in writing, signed by the applicant, if an individual, or
by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a club or corporation. Application fee
in the amount of four hundred dollars ($400.00) shall be submitted with the
application. Application shall be verified by oath or affirmation, and shall
contain the following information and statements: (Ord. 89-20, 8-10-1989)
   A.   The name, age, and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in
the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit, or a club,
the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, and names
and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a five percent (5%)
interest of the stock of such corporation is owned by any one person or his
nominees, the name and address of each such person.
   B.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the date and place of his naturalization.
   C.   The character of business of the applicant.
   D.   The length of time that said applicant has been in business of that
character.
   E.   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application is made.
   F.   The location and description of the premises or place of business which
is to be operated under such license.
   G.   A statement whether applicant has made similar application for a
similar other license on premises other than described in this application, and
the disposition of such application.
   H.   A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is
not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in the laws of this state, or in this code or village ordinances.
   I.   Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by
the federal government, has been revoked and the reasons therefor. (Ord. 89-10,
7-26-1989)
10-2-3: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSES:
No such license shall be issued to or continue to be held by: (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-
26-1989)
   A.   A person who is not a resident of Lake County. (Ord. 2009-O-12, 8-26-
2009)
   B.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community.
   C.   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   D.   A person who has been convicted of a felony.
   E.   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a
house of ill fame.
   F.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   G.   A person whose license issued under this code has been revoked for
cause.
   H.   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   I.   A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall
be qualified to obtain a license.
   J.   A corporation, if any officer, manager, or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
village.
   K.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   L.   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
subsequent to the passage of this chapter, or shall have forfeited his bond to
appear in court to answer charges for any such violation.
   M.   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought,
or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is
to be issued.
   N.   Any person, association or corporation not eligible for a state retail
liquor dealer's license.
   O.   Any member of the village police department or board of trustees or the
village president.
   P.   Any person who does not have dramshop insurance in the amount of at
least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) covering the premises and the
licensee, issued by an insurance company qualified to issue such insurance
under the statutes and regulations of the state. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-4: CLASSES OF LICENSES:
   A.   Class I licenses may be issued for sale at retail on the premises
specified in such license of alcoholic liquor for use and consumption upon the
premises specified, which premises shall qualify as a "restaurant" as herein
defined. Notwithstanding any other provision in this title to the contrary, it
shall be lawful for the holder of a Class I license to sell or offer for sale
alcoholic liquor in the village between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) A.M.
and one o’clock (1:00) A.M. the next day on the following days: Sunday, Monday,
Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. It shall also be lawful for the holder of such
Class I license, during any week, to sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in
the village between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. on Friday and two
o’clock (2:00) A.M. Saturday morning, and between the hours of ten o’clock (10:
00) A.M. on Saturday and two o’clock (2:00) A.M. Sunday morning. Nothing
contained herein shall be construed to affect the hours of operation for any
other licensee in the village. It shall be unlawful for the holder of a Class I
license to sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquors at any hours other than
those set forth herein, however, the licensed premises may remain open for
other business operations other than the sale or offering for sale of alcoholic
liquors.
   B.   Class II licenses may be issued for sale at retail on the premises
specified in such license of alcoholic liquor for use and consumption upon the
premises specified, which premises shall qualify as a not for profit sponsored
"restaurant" as herein defined. Notwithstanding any other provision in this
title to the contrary, it shall be lawful for the holder of a Class II license
to sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the village between the hours of
ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. and one o’clock (1:00) A.M. the next day on the
following days: Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. It shall also
be lawful for the holder of such Class II license, during any week, to sell or
offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the village between the hours of ten o’clock
(10:00) A.M. on Friday and two o’clock (2:00) A.M. Saturday morning, and
between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. on Saturday and two o’clock (2:
00) A.M. Sunday morning. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to affect
the hours of operation for any other licensee in the village. It shall be
unlawful for the holder of a Class II license to sell or offer for sale
alcoholic liquors at any hours other than those set forth herein, however, the
licensed premises may remain open for other business operations other than the
sale or offering for sale of alcoholic liquors.
   C.   Class III licenses may be issued for sale at retail on the premises
specified in such licenses of alcoholic liquor for use and consumption upon the
premises specified, which premises need not qualify as a "restaurant" as herein
defined, provided that such premises shall be classified as general business
district under the zoning ordinances of this code. Notwithstanding any other
provision in this title to the contrary, it shall be lawful for the holder of a
Class III license to sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the village
between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. and one o’clock (1:00) A.M. the
next day on the following days: Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and
Thursday. It shall also be lawful for the holder of such Class III license,
during any week, to sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the village
between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. on Friday and two o’clock (2:00)
A.M. Saturday morning, and between the hours of ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. on
Saturday and two o’clock (2:00) A.M. Sunday morning. Nothing contained herein
shall be construed to affect the hours of operation for any other licensee in
the village. It shall be unlawful for the holder of a Class III license to sell
or offer for sale alcoholic liquors at any hours other than those set forth
herein, however, the licensed premises may remain open for other business
operations other than the sale or offering for sale of alcoholic liquors.
   D.   Class IV licenses may be issued for sale at retail, on the premises
specified in such licenses, of alcoholic liquors by means of bar service, for
consumption on the premises only. The premises licensed under this subsection
will be those serving alcohol as a subsidiary use to the primary use of the
premises, other than premises which are primarily restaurants. Such premises
and licensees shall at all times comply with the following terms and
conditions:
      1.   Notwithstanding any other provision in this title to the contrary,
it shall be lawful for the holder of a class IV license to sell or offer for
sale alcoholic liquor in the village between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00)
A.M. and one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the next day on the following days: Sunday,
Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. It shall also be lawful for the holder
of such class IV license, during any week, to sell or offer for sale alcoholic
liquor in the village between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on Friday
and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Saturday morning, and between the hours of ten
o'clock (10:00) A.M. on Saturday and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Sunday morning.
Nothing contained herein shall be construed to affect the hours of operation
for any other licensee in the village. It shall be unlawful for the holder of a
class IV license to sell or offer for sale alcoholic liquors at any hours other
than those set forth herein, however, the licensed premises may remain open for
other business operations other than the sale or offering for sale of alcoholic
liquors.
      2.   No premises licensed under this class IV license provision shall
contain more than twenty two (22) coin operated amusement devices nor more than
six (6) pool tables or billiard tables. The area of the premises where the
amusement devices and/or pool tables are located shall be physically separated
from the area where alcohol is served or offered for sale by a wall or other
solid divider to regulate entry into the area. Minors shall not be allowed to
be in the area where the amusement devices are located after nine o'clock (9:
00) P.M. on any day, nor shall alcohol be allowed in the area where the coin
operated amusement devices are located prior to nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. on any
day.
      3.   The licensee of any premises licensed hereunder agrees that no
portion of the premises shall be utilized for any accessory uses as defined in
the zoning code of the village of Green Oaks, including, but not limited to,
cellular transmission towers; the sale or other transfer of all or any portion
of the licensed premises to any other party or entity will constitute a change
of location as described in section
10-2-12 of this chapter.
   E.   Class V licenses may be issued for sale at retail, but not for
consumption on the premises where sold, alcoholic liquor in the original
package, and without any limitation of inside display area or advertising by a
person so engaged in the retail sale of alcoholic liquor.
   F.   Class VI licenses shall be for a craft distiller holding a craft
distiller license issued by the state of Illinois. This license shall
authorize: 1) the on site production and storage of alcohol in quantities not
to exceed the limit imposed by the state of Illinois under 235 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/5-1, 2) the sale of such site distilled alcohol to persons
of at least twenty one (21) years of age for consumption on and off premises,
and 3) on site sampling of such alcohol. If permitted to do so by the State of
Illinois, the Class VI licensee may also serve vermouth, beer, wine and other
distilled spirits obtained from a duly licensed Illinois distributor. Such
craft distillery licenses shall be issued subject to the following conditions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for a class VI licensee to sell a container of
alcohol for off premises consumption unless the container is greater than or
equal to three hundred seventy five milliliters (375 ml) in volume and is
properly sealed for transport in a motor vehicle without violation of law.
      2.   Class VI licensees may, during authorized hours of business and to
the extent permitted by the Illinois liquor control act, as amended, sell their
alcoholic products manufactured on the licensed premises at retail for off and
on premises consumption, and sell other alcoholic products for on-premises
consumption as permitted under license from the State of Illinois. In addition,
class VI licensees may offer samples of the alcohol permitted to be produced
and sold pursuant to this classification. Licensees shall not provide more than
three (3) free samples, each of which shall not exceed one-third (0.33) fluid
ounce, to any person in a day. Licensees may sell samples, but the volume of
any sample sold shall not exceed one fluid ounce and the total volume of all
samples sold or given to a person in a day shall not exceed three (3) fluid
ounces. Class VI licensees must have at least one BASSET certified site manager
on premises. All servers and persons selling any form of alcoholic beverages
shall be BASSET certified.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for the holder of a class VI license to provide
a sample of or sell any alcohol before the hour of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. or
after the hour of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. The village liquor commissioner
is hereby authorized to extend the time by which sampling and sales must cease
by no more than two (2) hours upon application of the licensee. Such extensions
may be made no more than six (6) times in any calendar year. A class VI
licensee is allowed to sample and sell alcohol on Sundays, subject to the hour
restrictions provided in this chapter.
      4.   Every class VI licensee must have a valid craft distiller license or
distilling pub license from the State of Illinois.
      5.   Every employee of a class VI licensee who participates in the
serving or sale of alcohol, pursuant to this license class, must be BASSET
certified.
      6.   The annual single payment fee for initial issuance or renewal of
such license shall be as provided in section
10-2-8 of this chapter. There shall be no proration of the class VI license
fee.
      7.   No more than one such license shall be in force at any one time.
      8.   Compliance with the applicable regulations of the state of Illinois,
as amended and with the regulations of this chapter, as amended.
      9.   The licensee shall obtain and maintain an Illinois Retailer's Sales
Tax number and report and pay, when due, all sales taxes accordingly. Point of
sale shall be the Village of Green Oaks. The licensee may sell, at retail,
merchandise related to its operations, provided however, retail sales of
merchandise, as distinguished from the craft distilled spirits, shall be
incidental to the sale of such spirits. Such retail sales, in gross, shall not
exceed thirty three percent (33%) of gross retail sales from the licensed
premises.
   G.   Class VII licenses may be issued which shall authorize the sale,
serving and consumption, only on the premises specified, of alcoholic liquor
only for consumption upon the premises while food service is available. Such
