licenses shall be issued only to premises owned, operated and maintained by a
"senior housing facility". Establishments holding Class VII licenses must
provide meals as part of the price of accommodations within the senior housing
facility. Sales of alcoholic liquor by Class VII licensees shall be to provide
alcoholic beverage service to residents of the facility, invited guests and
staff of the licensee only, and alcoholic beverages, when served, shall be
available only with meals and only during the regular meal service hours of the
facility. As used in this subsection, "senior housing facility" is defined as
housing developed, planned, designed, and operated to provide a full range of
accommodations and services for older adults including independent living,
assisted living, sheltered care, and nursing home care. This term shall
include, but not be limited to, continuing care communities and life care
retirement communities.
   H.   Class VIII licensees may be issued for the sale at retail at
convenience stores within gas stations. This license shall permit the holder to
sell at retail, but not for consumption on the premises where sold, alcoholic
beverages in the original package only and subject to the following conditions:
      1.   Not more than fifteen percent (15%) of the total floor area of the
licensed premises may be devoted to the storage and display of alcoholic
beverages.
      2.   An employee of the holder of the age of twenty-one (21) years or
older shall be present at all times alcoholic beverage containers are being
sold.
      3.   No signage advertising alcoholic beverage products shall be
displayed upon the exterior windows of the premises or affixed to the buildings
upon the premises.
      4.   If video gaming is permitted within the premises, there shall be no
consumption of alcoholic beverages at or within the area devoted to the video
gaming facilities.
      5. Sales of packaged alcoholic beverages shall be permitted only between
the hours of six o’clock (6:00) A.M. and midnight (12:00) A.M.
      6.   All retail sales of alcoholic beverage containers must be rung up by
an employee of the holder of the age of twenty-one (21) years or older.
      7.   It shall be unlawful for the holder of a class VIII license to
provide a sample of or permit the sampling of an alcoholic beverage upon the
licensed premises.
(Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989; amd. Ord. 95-O-19, 6-28-1995; Ord. 2003-O-04, 3-26-
2003; Ord. 2009-O-12, 8-26-2009; Ord. 2010-O-16, 12-15-2010; Ord. 2016-O-01, 1-
27-2016; Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-22-2017; Ord. 2020-O-01, 3-31-2020; Ord. 2023-O-04,
3-22-2023; Ord. 2023-O-06, 4-26-2023)
10-2-5: MAXIMUM NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The number of licenses of each class to be issued shall not exceed the
following:
   A.   Class I: One (1) license.
   B.   Class II: One (1) license.
   C.   Class III: One (1) license.
   D.   Class IV: One (1) license. (Ord. 2010-O-16, 12-15-2010)
   E.   Class V: Two (2) licenses. (Ord. 2011-O-01, 5-25-2011)
   F.   Class VI: One (1) license. (Ord. 2010-O-16, 12-15-2010)
   G.   Class VII: Two (2) licenses.
   H.   Class VIII: One (1) license. (Ord. 2017-O-02, 2-22-2017; amd. Ord.
2023-O-04, 3-22-2023)
10-2-6: CHANGE IN MAXIMUM NUMBER OF LICENSES PERMITTED:
In the event that at any time any one (1) of the licenses provided for in
section
10-2-5 of this chapter shall lapse, be canceled or terminated in any manner,
the Village Authorities may reduce the maximum number of such licenses by
resolution of the Village Board of Trustees, but the maximum number of such
licenses may not be increased except by amendment to this chapter. (Ord. 89-O-
10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-7: TERM; PRORATING FEE:
Each such license shall terminate on the December 31 next following its
issuance. The fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full
calendar months which have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the
license. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-8: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee to obtain or renew a craft distiller license or to otherwise
sell alcoholic liquor at retail shall be as follows:
   A.   Class I: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   B.   Class II: Eight hundred dollars ($800.00).
   C.   Class III: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   D.   Class IV: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   E.   Class V: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   F.   Class VI: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   G.   Class VII: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   H.   Class VIII: Two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). (Ord. 2010-O-16, 12-15-
2010; amd. Ord. 2017-O-09, 6-28-2017; Ord. 2023-O-04, 3-22-2023)
10-2-9: DISPOSITION OF FEES:
All such fees shall be paid to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner at the
time application is made, and shall be forthwith turned over to the Village
Treasurer. In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be
returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be
deposited in the General Corporate Fund or in such other fund as shall have
been designated by the Board of Trustees, by proper action. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-
26-1989)
10-2-10: LIST OF LICENSES IN FORCE:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall keep or cause to be kept a complete
record of all such licenses issued by him and shall furnish the Village
Treasurer and Finance Chairman Trustee with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance
of any new license, or the revocation of any old license, the village president
shall give written notice of such action to each of these officers within forty
eight (48) hours of such action. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-11: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
   A.   A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed
one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as provided in this chapter, and
shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment,
garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable voluntarily
or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license
shall not descend by the laws of the state or intestate devolution, but it
shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that the executor or
administrator of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any
insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic
liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor and may
exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee;
provided further, that:
      1.   Such executor, administrator or trustee shall be subject to sections
10-2-2 and
10-2-3 of this chapter other than with respect to citizenship and residence
within the village; and
      2.   The authority granted hereunder shall be for a period not to exceed
one hundred eighty (180) days after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such
licensee.
   B.   A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fee paid for any
period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such
license in accordance with the provisions of this section.
   C.   Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof provided
he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such
renewal license is sought are suitable for such purposes; and provided further,
that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a
vested right which shall in any case prevent the village authorities from
decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within the village. (Ord. 89-O-
10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-12: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A retail liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only
in the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be
changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the local
liquor control commissioner. No change of location shall be permitted unless
the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor under the law of this state and the code and ordinances of the village.
(Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-2-13: REVOCATION, SUSPENSION, REFUSAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   The local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend any license
issued by him under this chapter if he determines that the licensee has
violated any provisions of the Illinois liquor control act, or of this code, or
of any regulations established by the local liquor control commissioner or
Illinois liquor control commission which are not inconsistent with state
statutes, or if the restrictions in section
10-2-3 of this chapter become applicable, or for just cause.
   B.   In addition, the local liquor control commissioner may, on complaint of
the department of revenue of the state, refuse the issuance or renewal of a
retailer's license, or suspend or revoke such license, for any of the following
violations of the retailers' occupation tax act as amended: failure to make a
tax return; the filing of a fraudulent tax return; failure to pay all or part
of any tax or penalty finally determined to be due; failure to keep books and
records; failure to secure and display a certificate or subcertificates of
registration; or wilful violation of any rule or regulation of the department
of revenue relating to the administration and enforcement of tax liability.
   C.   In lieu of suspending or revoking a license for violations as provided
in subsection A of this section, the local liquor control commissioner may
instead levy a fine against the licensee for such violation in a sum not to
exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation; each day on which a
violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. Not more than ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in fines may be imposed against any licensee
during the period of his license (1 year), and all such fines shall be imposed
as provided in section 7-5 of the liquor control act of 1934 1 , as amended
from time to time.
   D.   No such license shall be so revoked or suspended, or fine imposed in
lieu thereof, except after a hearing by the local liquor control commissioner
with a three (3) day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an
opportunity to appear and defend; provided, that if the local liquor control
commissioner has reason to believe that any continued operation of a particular
licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community, he
may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason for such
conclusion and without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed
for not more than seven (7) days, giving the licensee an opportunity to be
heard during that period. If such licensee shall also be engaged in the conduct
of another business or businesses on the licensed premises, any orders issued
under this section shall not be applicable to such other business or
businesses.
   E.   All hearings conducted by the local liquor control commissioner shall
be conducted with all persons giving testimony or making statements being
placed under oath; and a certified official record of the proceedings shall be
taken and prepared by a certified court reporter or certified shorthand
reporter and placed on file with the local liquor control commissioner.
   F.   The local liquor control commissioner shall within five (5) days after
such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be
revoked or suspended, or fine levied, state the reason or reasons for such
determination in a written order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a
copy of such order upon the licensee.
   G.   Any resident of the village shall have the right to file a complaint
with the local liquor control commissioner stating that any retailer licensee
under this chapter has been or is committing one or more violations set forth
in subsection A of this section. Such complaint shall be in writing in the form
prescribed by the local liquor control commissioner and shall be signed and
sworn to by the parties complaining. The complaint shall state the particular
provision, rule or regulation believed to have been violated and the facts in
detail upon which belief is based. If the local liquor control commissioner is
satisfied that the complaint substantially charges a violation and that from
the facts alleged there is reasonable cause for such belief, he shall set the
matter for hearing and shall serve at least three (3) days' written notice upon
the licensee and the complainants of the time and place of such hearing and of
the particular charge in the complaint. The local liquor control commissioner
shall then comply with this section.
   H.   Within twenty (20) days after the local liquor control commissioner
shall give notice of issuing an order granting or refusing to grant; revoking,
suspending or refusing to revoke or suspend a license; or fining a licensee in
lieu thereof, under this chapter; or after the local liquor control
commissioner shall have failed or refused for more than twenty (20) days to
grant a hearing upon a resident's complaint to revoke or suspend a license, any
village resident or interested person may appeal to the Illinois liquor control
commission in the manner provided by state statute.
   I.   All appeals from the orders of the local liquor control commissioner to
the Illinois liquor control commission shall be limited to a review of the
official record of the proceedings of the local liquor control commissioner as
provided in section 7-9 of the Illinois liquor control act of 1934 2 . Within
five (5) days after notice of filing of such appeal, the local liquor control
commissioner shall file with the Illinois liquor control commission the
certified official record of the proceedings as prepared in accordance with
subsection E of this section. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS.
