CHAPTER 3
REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS
SECTION:
10-3-1: Peddling
10-3-2: Sanitary Conditions
10-3-3: Employees
10-3-4: Business Location
10-3-5: Closing Hours
10-3-6: Signs And Advertising
10-3-7: Minors
10-3-8: Additional Regulations
10-3-9: BASSET Program
10-3-10: Reporting Of Disorderly Conduct, Violations Of Law
10-3-11: Nudity
10-3-1: PEDDLING:
It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the village. (Ord. 89-O-10,
7-26-1989)
10-3-2: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage
of such liquor for such sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition,
and shall be kept in full compliance with the sections of the code and
ordinances regulating the conditions or premises used for the storage or sale
of food for human consumption. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-3-3: EMPLOYEES:
   A.   The term "employee" shall mean any person hired to work at the premises
and listed on the establishment's payroll.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises for the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor any person under the age of twenty one (21) years of age for
the purpose of drawing, pouring, or mixing any alcoholic liquor. However, a
person less than twenty one (21) years of age, but at least eighteen (18) years
of age, may serve or deliver alcoholic liquor when in the presence of and under
the direct supervision and control of an employee twenty one (21) years of age
or older. A class V license holder must employ a person twenty one (21) years
of age or older for the purpose of selling package liquor.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the retail sale
of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a carrier of any
contagious, infectious or venereal disease; and it shall be unlawful for any
person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such disease to work in or
about the premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or
distribution of such liquor. (Ord. 2009-O-12, 8-26-2009)
10-3-4: BUSINESS LOCATION:
No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor
within two hundred feet (200') of any church, school, hospital, home for aged
or indigent persons or veterans, their wives or children or any military or
naval station; provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels
offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food
shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal
business carried on, if such place of business so exempted shall have been
established for such purposes prior to the taking effect of this code; nor to
the renewal of a license for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on premises
within one hundred feet (100') of any church where such church has been
established within such one hundred feet (100') since the issuance of the
original license. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-3-5: CLOSING HOURS:
Except as provided in subsection
10-2-4D of this title relating to class IV licenses, it shall be lawful to sell
or offer for sale alcoholic liquor in the village on each day of the week,
between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight each day, except on Saturday and Sunday, on which days all premises
licensed hereunder may be open from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. until twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight. It shall be unlawful to keep open for business or to
admit the public to any premises in or on which alcoholic liquor is sold at
retail during the hours within which the sale of such liquor is prohibited;
provided, that in case of restaurants, clubs, and hotels, such establishments
may be kept open during such hours, but no alcoholic liquor may be sold to or
consumed by the public during such hours. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989; amd. Ord.
2003-O-04, 3-26-2003)
10-3-6: SIGNS AND ADVERTISING:
No premises which are licensed hereunder shall have any signs on or outside the
building which advertise any particular brand or kind of liquor, or the fact
that alcoholic liquors are for sale on the premises; provided, that small
lighted signs not larger than twenty four inches by thirty six inches (24" x
36") mounted in windows may be displayed. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-3-7: MINORS:
   A.   Sales By Licensees To Minors And Certain Others: No licensee, or
officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of a licensee,
shall give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under twenty one (21)
years of age, to any intoxicated persons, or to any person known to him to be a
habitual drunkard.
   B.   Gifts Or Resales To Minors: No person, after purchasing or otherwise
obtaining liquor shall sell, give, or deliver it to another person under twenty
one (21) years of age except in the performance of a religious ceremony or
service under the authority of an organized church.
   C.   Purchases By Minors: No person under twenty one (21) years of age shall
purchase or attempt to purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor or have
alcoholic liquor in his or her possession.
   D.   Proof Of Age:
      1.   If a licensee or his agents or employees believe, from appearance or
other circumstances, or has reason to believe, that a prospective recipient of
alcoholic liquor is under twenty one (21) years of age, he shall, before making
such sale or delivery, demand from that person positive identification
providing proof of age issued by a public officer in the performance of his
official duties.
      2.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall purchase,
obtain or attempt to purchase or obtain alcoholic liquor in any place in the
village where alcoholic liquor is sold.
      3.   No person shall transfer, alter, or deface any identification card
containing proof of age and issued by a public officer in the performance of
his official duties, or use the identification card of another, or carry or use
a false or forged identification card or obtain an identification card by means
of false information.
      4.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall by any means
misrepresent his or her age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining
alcoholic liquor in any place in the village where alcoholic liquor is sold.
   E.   Responsibility Of Parent: No parent or guardian shall knowingly suffer
or permit any child under twenty one (21) years of age of which he or she may
be the parent or guardian to violate any provision or provisions of this title.
(Ord. 89-O-10, 7-26-1989)
10-3-8: ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS:
Nothing in this title shall excuse or relieve the licensee of any place in the
village where alcoholic liquor is sold from the restrictions and requirements
of any other provisions of this title, or of the ordinances of the village or
of the provisions of the statutes of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 89-O-10, 7-
26-1989)
10-3-9: BASSET PROGRAM:
   A.   Training Program:
      1.   For licenses effective on or after the effective date hereof, the
original or renewal application for a class I, II, III or IV license shall be
accompanied by a proof of completion of a state certified beverage alcohol
sellers and servers education and training (BASSET) program for all persons who
serve and sell alcoholic beverages pursuant to that license.
      2.   For licenses effective on or after the effective date hereof, the
original or renewal application for a class I, II, III or IV license shall be
accompanied by a proof of completion of a state certified beverage alcohol
sellers and servers education and training (BASSET) program for the manager of
the licensee. (Ord. 2004-O-12, 10-27-2004)
      3.   All persons who serve or sell alcoholic liquor shall, prior to
serving or selling any alcoholic liquor within the village of Green Oaks,
register for a BASSET course by contacting the village administrator's office
to advise them of the student's name and establishment. This course is to be
completed within ninety (90) days of employment with establishment.
Registration of employees is the responsibility of the licensee.
      4.   After the effective date hereof, all persons who serve or sell
alcoholic liquor, including the manager of every licensee, shall complete the
BASSET program within ninety (90) days from the beginning of their employment
with that licensee, and shall, until completion of the BASSET program, work
under the supervision of a person who has completed the BASSET program.
      5.   A photocopy of the certificate of completion of the BASSET program
will be on file with the village administrator and maintained in the manager's
office on the premises of the licensee.
      6.   BASSET completion cards are to be carried and exhibited on demand.
Every student who has successfully completed the BASSET program shall have his/
her BASSET completion card in his/her immediate possession at all times when
selling or serving alcoholic liquor within the village of Green Oaks and, for
the purpose of indicating compliance with this requirement, shall display his/
her BASSET course completion card if it is in his/her possession upon demand by
any police officer or other authorized agent of the liquor commissioner.
      7.   The liquor commissioner of the village may, in his/her discretion,
extend the time for the completion of the training, for renewal of the license
only, for an additional ninety (90) day period. Said extensions shall be given
on a case by case basis for good cause shown. Request for said extension will
be in writing and presented to the liquor commissioner a minimum of thirty (30)
days prior to original required completion date.
      8.   Employees of liquor license establishments that are of a "temporary
status" (Christmas, summer help, etc.) whose employment does not extend past
ninety (90) days from the date of employment are not required to complete the
training program but must, for the duration of their employment work under the
immediate supervision of a person who has completed the BASSET program. Proof
of employment hiring date is to be exhibited upon the demand of a police
officer or other agent authorized by the liquor commissioner. "Temporary
status" sellers and servers must also contact the village administrator to
advise the village administrator of their name, the hiring establishment and
hiring date prior to selling or serving any alcoholic liquor within the village
of Green Oaks. Responsibility for registration of all "temporary status"
employees rests with the licensee. (Ord. 2001-O-18, 8-22-2001)
   B.   Service, Sale And Management Without Required Training Prohibited: It
shall be unlawful to permit any person in a class I, II, III or IV
establishment to serve or sell alcoholic beverages unless that person has
completed the BASSET program as required by this section. It shall be unlawful
to employ a manager in a class I, II, III or IV licensed establishment unless
that person has completed the BASSET program as required in this section. (Ord.
2004-O-12, 10-27-2004)
   C.   Repeating Course: In addition to other penalties imposed in this
chapter, a person violating any regulation of this chapter may be required to
again complete the BASSET program as required in this section.
   D.   Violation: Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of
this section shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and each day a violation continues
shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 2001-O-18, 8-22-2001)
10-3-10: REPORTING OF DISORDERLY CONDUCT, VIOLATIONS OF LAW:
   A.   All licensees are under an affirmative duty of reporting to the police
any and all incidents of disorderly conduct or any and all criminal violation
or violations of this chapter which take place within or upon premises for
which a liquor license has been issued pursuant to this chapter immediately
upon observance or notification of the incident. The licensee, employee or
agent making a report of an incident shall identify himself to the police
dispatcher and state the nature of the incident. For the purposes of this
chapter, "disorderly conduct" as used herein shall mean such act or behavior of
any person that in any unreasonable manner alarms or disturbs another or
provokes a breach of the peace within, or upon such premises. Failure to report
to the police as herein provided shall be a violation of the license hereunder.
(Ord. 2001-O-18, 8-22-2001)
10-3-11: NUDITY:
No nudity shall be allowed within or upon the licensed premises. For purposes
of this title, "nudity" shall be defined as a state of dress or undress that
exposes to view: a) less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals;
pubic region; anus; or female breast below a point immediately above the top of
the areola, but not including any portion of the cleavage of the female breast
exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing
apparel, provided the areola is not exposed, or b) human male genitals in a
discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered, or any
device or covering that, when worn, simulates human male genitals in a
discernibly turgid state. (Ord. 2003-O-04, 3-26-2003)
TITLE 11
SIGN REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
PURPOSE
SECTION:
11-1-1: Title
11-1-2: Purpose
11-1-3: Scope
11-1-1: TITLE:
This Title shall be known and may be cited as the SIGN ORDINANCE OF THE
VILLAGE. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-1-2: PURPOSE:
The regulations set forth herein are established in order to promote and
protect the public health, safety, comfort, prosperity and welfare and in order
to accomplish the following specific purposes:
   A.   To enhance the economy, business and industry of the Village by
promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective use and display of signs;
   B.   To enhance the physical appearance of the Village;
   C.   To protect the general public from damage and injury which might be
caused by the faulty and uncontrolled construction and use of signs within the
Village;
   D.   To protect the public use of streets and highways by reducing sign and
advertising distractions that may increase accidents;
   E.   To preserve the value of private property by assuring the compatibility
of signs with surrounding land uses;
   F.   To establish a permit system to allow a variety of types of signs in
all use districts (zones);
   G.   To allow certain signs that are small, unobtrusive, and incidental to
the principal use of the respective lots on which they are located, subject to
the substantive requirements of this Title, but without a requirement for
permits;
   H.   To prohibit all signs not expressly permitted by this Title; and
   I.   To provide for the enforcement of the provisions of this Title. (Ord.
91-06, 8-28-91)
11-1-3: SCOPE:
This Title shall not relate to building design. Nor shall this Title regulate
official traffic or government signs; the copy and message of signs; signs not
intended to be viewed from a public right of way or street; window displays;
product dispensers and point of purchase displays; scoreboards on athletic
fields; flags of any nation, government, or noncommercial organization;
gravestones; religious symbols; commemorative plaques; the display of street
numbers; or any display or construction not defined herein as a "sign". (Ord.
91-06, 8-28-91)
CHAPTER 2
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
11-2-1: Rules Of Construction
11-2-2: Definitions
11-2-1: RULES OF CONSTRUCTION:
The language set forth in the text of this title shall be interpreted in accord
with the following rules of construction:
   A.   The singular number includes the plural, and the plural the singular;
   B.   The present tense includes the past and future tenses, and the future
tense includes the present tense;
   C.   The word "shall" is mandatory, while the word "may" is permissive,
unless the context indicates otherwise;
   D.   The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter;
   E.   Whenever a word or term defined hereinafter appears in the text of this
title, its meaning shall be construed as set forth in the definitions thereof;
   F.   The use in this title of the phrase "any sign or other advertising
device" or similar phrase shall mean all of the signs and devices defined in
this title; and
   G.   Where terms are not defined through methods authorized by this title,
they shall have their ordinarily accepted meaning such as the context may
imply. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
11-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
Certain terms are defined for the purposes of this title as follows:
BALLOON SIGN: Any sign which is printed or painted on or suspended into the air
by a hot air balloon, kite, or similar device. All balloon signs shall be
considered temporary signs.
BANNER SIGN: Any sign printed or painted on fabric, lightweight plastic, paper,
or flags or pennants, and used for attracting the attention of the public. All
banner signs shall be considered temporary signs.
BILLBOARD: Any sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service
or activity not necessarily conducted, sold or offered upon the premises where
such sign is located. A temporary construction sign that is located on a
property that indicates a business, or use that is located off-site, but that
may be expanding, re-locating or beginning a new business or use on the
property where the temporary construction sign is located is not to be
considered a "billboard" sign, by definition.
BUILDING COMMISSIONER: The Building Commissioner of the Village of Green Oaks.
BUILDING DEPARTMENT: The Building Department of the Village of Green Oaks.
BUILDING FRONTAGE: The horizontal width of a building fronting on a street and
measured between lines perpendicular to the street or perpendicular to the cord
line of a curved street (see figure
11-2-2:A, set out in section
11-9-3 of this title).
CANOPY OR MARQUEE: Any permanent roof-like structure constructed of metal or
other noncombustible material projecting beyond a building or extending along
and projecting beyond the wall of a building, generally designed and
constructed to provide protection from the weather.
COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL: A material which cannot be classified as "noncombustible"
in accord with that definition.
CONSTRUCTION SIGN: A construction sign is a temporary sign identifying a
business or use to be constructed on the subject property and may also include
the name of the architect, engineer, contractor, subcontractor, or material
supplier participating in construction on the lot where the sign is located.
DEVELOPER'S SIGN: Any freestanding nonilluminated sign which promotes and
describes only the sale or rental of land or buildings in any development on
that lot.
ELECTRONIC CHANGEABLE MESSAGE SIGN: An illuminated sign whose message content,
either in whole or in part, may be changed by means of electronic programming
and may include visual graphics with or without motion or animation with a
fixed or changing display/message composed of a series of lights. Fuel price
signs for an automobile service station that only display and change the
numerical price value of fuel once daily shall be considered only an
illuminated sign and not an electronic changeable message sign. Similarly,
signs whose changeable message content only indicate the time and/or
temperature shall be considered only an illuminated sign and not an electronic
changeable message sign.
FESTOON SIGN: A string of ribbons, tinsel, small flags, or pinwheels. Festoon
signs shall be considered temporary signs.
FLASHING SIGNS: Any illuminated sign on which such illumination is not kept
stationary or constant in intensity and color at all times, but not including
electronic changeable message signs.
FREESTANDING SIGN: Any sign supported by post, poles, pylons, uprights, braces
or other supports placed upon the ground and not attached to any building.
IDENTIFICATION SIGN: Any sign which directs attention to an institution or
public use, business, profession or to a commodity, service or entertainment
sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located.
ILLUMINATED SIGN: Any sign which is illuminated by electric lights or luminous
devices as part of the sign proper.
ILLUMINATED TRAFFIC SIGNAL: Any official traffic control device or sign which
is illuminated by electric lights or luminous devices.
INCIDENTAL SIGNS: A sign pertaining to goods, products, services or facilities
which are available on the premises where the sign is located, such as signs
pertaining to trading stamps, credit cards, service information and pricing.
LOT: Any property, improved or unimproved.
LOT, UNIMPROVED: Any platted lot or tract of land used as a whole which is
completely unoccupied by a building or structure and upon which no building or
structure has been commenced.
MONUMENT SIGN: Any free standing decorative sign which advertises the business
conducted on the premises.
MOVING SIGN: Any sign that has any external or visible part or parts that move,
rotate or spin.
NONCOMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL: Any material which will not ignite at or below a
temperature of one thousand two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (1,200°F) and will
not continue to burn or glow at that temperature.
PERMITTEE: Any person, firm or corporation holding a permit pursuant to this
title.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or organization
of any type or kind.
PORTABLE SIGN: Any sign designed to be moved from place to place.
PREMISES: Any property, improved or unimproved.
PROJECTING WALL SIGN: Any sign which is attached directly to a building wall
and which extends more than eight inches (8"), but not more than thirty six
inches (36") from the face of the wall.
REAL ESTATE SIGN: A freestanding sign advertising the real estate upon which
the sign is located as being for rent, lease or sale.
ROOF SIGN: Any sign erected, constructed or maintained wholly or partially upon
or above the facia or parapet line of any building.
SHOPPING CENTER: Any concentration of two (2) or more retail stores or service
establishments in one or more buildings, or on one or more adjacent lots, under
single ownership or management, or with one or more of the following:
   A.   Common parking facilities;
   B.   Common stormwater detention or storm sewer facilities;
   C.   Common water distribution facilities;
   D.   Common sanitary sewer facilities; or
   E.   Without exclusive ingress or egress from public streets.
SIGN: Any device, including exterior clocks, temperature indicators, marquees,
canopies, placards or other representations containing words, letters,
printing, pictures, designs or combinations thereof used in the nature of
advertisement, or directions calculated to attract public attention.
STORE FRONTAGE: The length of any wall of a store which fronts a street,
customer parking area or customer entrance, but not including exterior walls of
service and loading areas (see section
11-9-3, figure
11-2-2:B of this title).
SURFACE AREA OF SIGN: The entire area within a single continuous perimeter
enclosing the extreme limits of the sign surface. It does not include any
structural elements outside the limits of such sign and not forming an integral
part of the display. All sides of a double or multiple faced sign structure
shall be used in computing the total surface area except where specific
provision is made to the contrary.
TEMPORARY SIGN: Any balloon sign, banner sign, festoon sign or pennant sign
without a structural frame. The previously itemized types of temporary signs
without a sign structure may not need to meet the construction standards of
section
11-4-6 of this title as part of the approval by the Village Board. Some signs
with a sign structure may also be included in the definition of a temporary
sign in any district when the temporary sign, its dimensions and its structure
are approved by the Board of Trustees as a special permit/temporary sign that
may be displayed for more than thirty (30) days with a maintenance agreement
approved by the Board of Trustees and shall be subject to the restrictions and
conditions imposed by the Board of Trustees as part of the permit for this type
of temporary sign including, but not limited to, the duration the sign is to be
displayed.
VEHICLE SIGN: Any sign attached to an automobile, truck, trailer, vehicle or
movable device which is parked for the purpose of display of same.
VILLAGE BOARD: The President and Board of Trustees of the Village.
WALL SIGNS: Any sign which is attached directly to a building wall, canopy or
marquee and which does not have a sign cabinet that projects more than eight
inches (8") from the face of the wall, canopy or marque.
WINDOW SIGN: Any sign installed inside a window and intended to be viewed from
the outside.
ZONING ORDINANCE: The zoning ordinance of the Village of Green Oaks. (Ord. 91-
06, 8-28-1991; amd. Ord. 2015-O-20, 11-18-2015; Ord. 2017-O-15, 9-27-2017; Ord.
2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
CHAPTER 3
PERMITS
SECTION:
11-3-1: Permit Required
11-3-2: Signs Exempt from Permits
11-3-3: Sign Erection Permit Application
11-3-4: Sign Erection Permit Fees
11-3-5: Examination and Approval of Application and Plans
11-3-6: Annual Sign Inspection
11-3-7: Annual Sign Inspection Fees
11-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall hereafter erect, construct, relocate, structurally alter any
sign, billboard or other advertising device, within the Village without having
first obtained a permit as provided in this Title. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-3-2: SIGNS EXEMPT FROM PERMITS:
The following types of signs are exempt from the permit requirements but must
conform with all other requirements of this Title:
   A.   Real Estate signs, which are freestanding and unilluminated and which
do not exceed twelve (12) square feet in surface area per face;
   B.   Window signs, which are located on private property, with the consent
of the owner and not exceeding twelve (12) square feet in total cumulative sign
surface area;
   C.   Instructional signs, which provide direction or instruction and are
located entirely on the property to which they pertain and do not in any way
advertise a business and do not exceed four (4) square feet in total sign
surface area;
   D.   Public facilities signs, which identify restrooms, public telephones
and walkways and do not exceed four (4) square feet in sign surface area;
   E.   Directional signs, provide direction, such as parking lot entrance and
exit signs, and those of a similar nature and do not exceed four (4) square
feet in sign surface area; and
   F.   Political or noncommercial signs, which are regulated in each use
district of this Title, which are located on private property, provided that
said signs shall be removed no later than three (3) days after the election or
activity to which the sign pertains or sixty (60) days after erection of the
sign, whichever is sooner. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-3-3: SIGN ERECTION PERMIT APPLICATION:
Application for a sign erection permit under this Title shall be made upon
forms provided by the Building Department (see Appendix B, Section
11-9-2) and shall contain or have attached the following information:
   A.   Name, address and telephone number of the owner of the premises and the
person erecting the sign;
   B.   Signature of owner or authorized agent;
   C.   Location of the building, structure or property to which the sign or
other advertising device is to be attached or erected;
   D.   Description of sign including the general sign type, type of
illumination, number of sign faces, and sign function;
   E.   Cost or estimated contract value of the proposed work;
   F.   Plot plan accurately showing the location of the proposed sign along
with the location and square footage areas of all existing signs on the same
premises;
   G.   Scale drawings and specifications showing the materials, design,
dimensions, structural supports, electrical components, and color chip samples
for the proposed sign;
   H.   Other required documents including the following:
      1.   Design review approval report from the Village Board for all signs
in the business, office and industrial use districts;
      2.   Special permit from the Village Board for all signs that require
special permits;
      3.   Approval report from any property owners' association or similar
private body established by covenants or agreements approved by the Village
Board; and
      4.   Other documents as may be required by the Building Commissioner.
   I.   Filing and plan review fee for the proposed sign. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-3-4: SIGN ERECTION PERMIT FEES:
Every applicant being granted an original permit hereunder shall pay the
following permit fee for each sign structure:
   A.   Nonilluminated Signs: Twenty dollars ($20.00) plus forty cents ($0.40)
per square foot of sign surface area of the proposed sign.
   B.   Illuminated Signs: Thirty five dollars ($35.00) plus fifty cents
($0.50) per square foot of sign surface area of the proposed sign.
   C.   Temporary Signs: Twenty five dollars ($25.00) as defined by this Title.
   D.   Developer's Sign: Twenty dollars ($20.00) plus forty cents ($0.40) per
square foot of sign surface area of the proposed sign. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-3-5: EXAMINATION AND APPROVAL OF APPLICATION AND PLANS:
It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner, after examination of an
application for a sign erection permit, to issue said permit if in the opinion
of the Building Commissioner the application is in good form and complies with
all requirements as set forth in this Title and other Village ordinances. If
the work authorized under a sign erection permit has not been completed within
one year after the date of issuance, the said permit shall be null and void.
(Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-3-6: ANNUAL SIGN INSPECTION:
The Building Commissioner, or his agent, shall inspect annually, or more
frequently as deemed necessary, all of the following signs in all use districts
in the Village:
   A.   Signs above any walkway or which may endanger passers-by upon any
walkway on which the public is invited or encouraged to pass; and
   B.   Freestanding signs wherever located within the village. (Ord. 91-06, 8-
28-91)
11-3-7: ANNUAL SIGN INSPECTION FEES:
No annual inspection fee, except for "temporary signs" as defined in this
Title, shall be charged during the fiscal year in which the sign or other
advertising device is erected. To meet the expenses of such annual inspection,
the sign owner or permittee thereof shall pay the Village the following fees:
   A.   Temporary Signs: Ten dollars ($10.00) per month for such signs erected
for a period in excess of thirty (30) days or fraction thereof.
   B.   Nonilluminated Signs: Ten dollars ($10.00) plus twenty cents ($0.20)
per square foot of sign surface area per year.
   C.   Illuminated Signs: Seventeen dollars fifty cents ($17.50) plus twenty
five cents ($0.25) per square foot of sign surface area per year.
   D.   Developer's Sign: Ten dollars ($10.00) plus twenty cents ($0.20) per
square foot of sign surface area per year. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
11-4-1: General Provisions
11-4-2: Signs Prohibited
11-4-3: Illuminated Signs
11-4-4: Wall Signs
11-4-5: Obstructions
11-4-6: Construction
11-4-7: Temporary Signs
11-4-8: Maintenance Of Signs
11-4-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
The following provisions and restriction of this title shall apply to all signs
in all use districts:
   A.   All signs shall be so constructed, erected and maintained so that all
danger to persons or property shall be eliminated;
   B.   No sign shall be erected or maintained so as to obstruct traffic
control signals at street intersections, or traffic sight lines or signals at
railroad grade crossings;
   C.   Signs visible from a street shall not contain an arrow or the words
"stop" or "danger" or otherwise resemble or simulate official traffic control
signs; and
   D.   Every sign, except for signs for which no permit is required, shall be
plainly marked with the name of the person erecting and maintaining same. Such
person or the owner of the premises on which the sign is located shall be the
responsible party for the purpose of receiving notice under any section of this
title. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
11-4-2: SIGNS PROHIBITED:
All signs not expressly permitted under this title are prohibited and include,
but are not limited to the following:
   A.   Exposed neon tubing on freestanding signs;
   B.   Flashing signs and devices;
   C.   Illuminated signs with revolving or rotating beams or beacons;
   D.   Moving signs;
   E.   Signs painted on walls;
   F.   Roof signs, except signs painted upon a flat roof surface that can be
seen only from the air are permitted in all business, office and industrial use
districts; and
   G.   Vehicle signs. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
11-4-3: ILLUMINATED SIGNS:
All illuminated signs shall meet all of the following standards:
   A.   Wiring: All illuminated signs shall be wired in accordance with the
regulations as prescribed by the Village's Electrical Code 1 ;
   B.   Preventing Glare: Gooseneck reflectors and spotlights shall be
permitted on freestanding and wall signs, provided that any lights be installed
in such a manner that the direct rays of such lights be concentrated on the
sign and be prevented from causing a glare on or striking any street or nearby
property. Reflectors shall be provided with proper lenses or baffles
concentrating the illumination upon the area of the sign;
   C.   Hours Of Operation: Illuminated signs located on a lot adjacent to,
across the street from, or in the next use district to any residential use
district, shall be turned off and not operated between the hours of eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. unless the premises on which
or for which the sign is specifically operated is engaged in the operation of
that business, office or industry, in which event the sign shall not be
operated past one o'clock (1:00) A.M.;
   D.   Distraction: No illuminated sign shall be placed within one hundred
feet (100') of any illuminated traffic signal if it will interfere with,
confuse or distract driver compliance with said illuminated traffic signals;
and
   E.   Illuminated Lettering Only: Illuminated signs may have back lighted
letters or internally lighted letters, but not illuminated backgrounds. (Ord.
91-06, 8-28-91)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  7-2-3 of this Code.
11-4-4: WALL SIGNS:
All wall signs shall meet the following standards:
   A.   Height: All wall signs shall not be higher than the facia or parapet
line of the building, canopy or marquee to which they are attached; and
   B.   Clearance: Except for wall signs which are completely flush with the
wall surface, the minimum clearance below wall signs shall be ten feet (10')
above any pedestrian walkway, fifteen feet (15') above any driveway or road,
nor below the soffit line of any canopy or marquee. Wall signs located over
landscaping features shall be three feet (3') minimum above the grade level
below said signs (see Figure
11-4-4:A, set out in Section
11-9-3). (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-4-5: OBSTRUCTIONS:
All signs shall not create any of the following obstructions:
   A.   Building Obstructions: No sign shall obstruct any window, door, fire
escape, stairway or opening intended to provide light, air, ingress or egress
for any building or structure;
   B.   Clear Vision Requirements: No sign which obstructs sight lines at
elevations between eighteen inches (18") and six feet (6') above the roadway
shall be placed or permitted to remain on any corner lot within the triangular
area formed by the street property lines connecting them at points fifty feet
(50') from the intersection of the street lines, or in the case of a rounded
corner, from the intersection of the street property lines extended. The same
sight line limitations regarding height shall apply on any interior lot within
the triangular area formed by the street property line and the edge of the
driveway and the line connecting them at points ten feet (10') from the
intersection of the property line and the driveway (see Figure
11-4-5:B, set out in Section
11-9-3). (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-4-6: CONSTRUCTION:
All signs shall meet the following construction standards:
   A.   Materials: All signs shall be constructed of metal, noncombustible or
approved combustible material or materials approved for signs by the Building
Code and Electrical Code of the Village 1 , except for signs for which no
permit is required;
   B.   Wind Loads: All signs shall be constructed to withstand wind pressures
as required by the Building Code of the Village, except for signs for which no
permit is required; and
   C.   Glass: Any glass forming a part of any sign shall be safety glass. Any
single pane or piece of glass having an area exceeding three (3) square feet
shall be wire glass. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 7, Chapter 2 of this Code.
11-4-7: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
"Temporary signs" as defined in this Title shall be subject to the following
conditions:
   A.   Location: Temporary signs shall be completely on private property;
   B.   Restrictions: Temporary signs shall be subject to the restrictions
imposed by the Board of Trustees upon the grant of a special permit;
   C.   Maintenance: Evidence of a maintenance agreement whereby all temporary
signs displayed for more than thirty (30) days shall be regularly maintained at
not less than thirty (30) day intervals. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-4-8: MAINTENANCE OF SIGNS:
All signs shall be properly maintained and meet the following standards:
   A.   All sign components, including without limitation supports, braces, and
anchors, shall be kept in a state of repair;
   B.   With respect to freestanding signs, components (supporting structures,
backs, etc.) not bearing a message shall be constructed of materials that blend
with the natural environment or shall be painted a neutral color to blend with
the natural environment;
   C.   If a sign other than a billboard advertises a business, service,
commodity, accommodation, attraction or other enterprise or activity that is no
longer operating or being offered or conducted, that sign shall be considered
abandoned, and shall within thirty (30) days after such abandonment be removed;
   D.   If the message portion of a sign is removed, leaving only the
supporting "shell" of a sign or the supporting braces, anchors, or similar
components, that message portion of the sign shall be replaced within thirty
(30) days or the remaining components of the sign shall be removed; and
   E.   The area within ten feet (10') in all directions of any part of a
freestanding sign shall be kept clear of all debris and weed undergrowth more
than five inches (5") in height. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
CHAPTER 5
RESIDENTIAL USE DISTRICTS SIGNS
SECTION:
11-5-1: Residential Use Districts Signs
11-5-2: Setbacks
11-5-3: Permitted Signs
11-5-3-1: Construction Sign
11-5-3-2: Identification Sign
11-5-3-3: Landscaped Subdivision Identification Sign
11-5-3-4: Name Plate
11-5-3-5: Political or Noncommercial Signs
11-5-3-6: Real Estate Sign
11-5-4: Special Permit Signs
11-5-4-1: Developer's Sign
11-5-4-2: Temporary Signs
11-5-1: RESIDENTIAL USE DISTRICTS SIGNS:
In addition to the general provisions of this Title, all signs shall meet the
following standards provided herein. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-2: SETBACKS:
Permitted signs may be located in any required yard, but shall not be less than
eight feet (8') from any lot line adjacent to any street, nor less than five
feet (5') from any other lot line (see Figure
11-5-2:A, set out in Section
11-9-3). (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3: PERMITTED SIGNS:
Signs permitted without a special permit include only the following and no
others: (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3-1: CONSTRUCTION SIGN:
One single or double face freestanding unilluminated sign per lot, which shall
meet the following standards (see Figure
11-5-3-1:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of the sign shall not exceed twelve (12)
square feet per face;
   B.   Height: The sign shall be not more than eight feet (8') high; and
   C.   Removal: The sign shall be removed within ten (10) days following
occupancy of the building. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3-2: IDENTIFICATION SIGN:
One single or double face freestanding sign or one wall sign per building
frontage per building, either of which may be illuminated, for each permitted
public use or similar institutional building. Such signs shall be solely for
the purpose of displaying the name of the institution or its activities or
services, and shall meet the following standards (see Figure
11-5-3-2:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not be greater than
twenty five (25) square feet per sign face; and
   B.   Height: The height of a freestanding sign shall not be higher than ten
feet (10'). (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3-3: LANDSCAPED SUBDIVISION IDENTIFICATION SIGN:
One single or double face unilluminated freestanding sign at each street
entrance to a subdivision for the sole purpose of displaying the name of the
subdivision, and which shall meet the following standards (see Figure
11-5-3-3:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not be greater than
twelve (12) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: The height of such sign shall not be higher than six feet (6')
above the ground at the base of the sign, nor higher than ten feet (10') above
the edge of the street pavement nearest the sign, whichever is less; and
   C.   Easement: Any such sign shall be located within a permanent easement
for the sign and landscaping. The easement shall include provisions for the
continued maintenance of the sign and landscaping, and shall be recorded as
part of the plat of subdivision. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3-4: NAME PLATE:
One single face unilluminated name plate identifying the owner or occupant of
the building, provided the surface area does not exceed two (2) square feet and
the sign is attached to the wall of the building within five feet (5') of the
main door. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3-5: POLITICAL OR NONCOMMERCIAL SIGNS:
Any number of sign, which shall not exceed six (6) square feet of cumulative
total surface area per lot. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-3-6: REAL ESTATE SIGN:
One single or double face unilluminated freestanding sign facing each street
frontage of a lot, and meeting the following standards (see Figure
11-5-3-6:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not exceed twelve
(12) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than six feet (6'); and
   C.   Removal: These signs shall be removed within three (3) days after the
sale or lease of the property. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-4: SPECIAL PERMIT SIGNS:
A special permit sign shall be any sign approved by the Board of Trustees upon
granting of a special permit. Such signs shall be installed completely on
private property and shall be subject to the restrictions imposed by the Board
of Trustees. Special permit signs in residential use districts include the
following: (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-5-4-1: DEVELOPER'S SIGN:
One unilluminated freestanding single or double faced sign facing only one
street of a subdivision, and which shall also meet the residential use
districts setback standards as well as the following requirements (see Figure
11-5-4-1:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not be greater than
thirty two (32) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than eight feet (8'); and
   C.   Removal: Such signs shall be removed upon the installation of either a
landscaped subdivision identification sign, or as otherwise required by
restrictions imposed by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 92-30, 12-29-92)
11-5-4-2: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
"Temporary signs" as defined by this Title and for which a maintenance
agreement shall be provided for signs displayed more than thirty (30) days, and
otherwise meeting all other restrictions imposed by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
CHAPTER 6
BUSINESS USE DISTRICT SIGNS
SECTION:
11-6-1: Business Use District Signs
11-6-2: Setbacks
11-6-3: Permitted Signs
11-6-3-1: Construction Sign
11-6-3-2: Freestanding Identification Sign
11-6-3-3: Incidental Signs
11-6-3-4: Monument Sign
11-6-3-5: Political or Noncommercial Signs
11-6-3-6: Real Estate Sign
11-6-3-7: Shopping Center Signs
11-6-3-8: Wall Signs
11-6-4: Special Permit Signs
11-6-4-1: Developer's Sign
11-6-4-2: Electronic Changeable Message Sign
11-6-4-3: Temporary Signs
11-6-1: BUSINESS USE DISTRICT SIGNS:
In addition to the general provisions of this Title, all signs shall meet the
following standards provided herein. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-2: SETBACKS:
Permitted signs may be located in any required yard, but shall be not less than
five feet (5') from any lot line adjacent to any street, nor less than ten feet
(10') from any other lot line (see Figure
11-6-2:A, set out in Section
11-9-3). (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91).
11-6-3: PERMITTED SIGNS:
Signs permitted without a special permit include only the following and no
others: (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-3-1: CONSTRUCTION SIGN:
One single or double face freestanding unilluminated sign per lot, which shall
meet the following standards (see Figure
11-6-3-1:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of the sign shall not exceed sixteen
(16) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: The sign shall be not more than eight feet (8') high; and
   C.   Removal: The sign shall be removed within ten (10) days following
occupancy of the building. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-3-2: FREESTANDING IDENTIFICATION SIGN:
One freestanding identification sign only shall be permitted per lot, or per
shopping center with an aggregate floor area of less than ten thousand (10,000)
square feet. For larger shopping centers, see Section
11-6-3-7. Such signs may be illuminated and shall meet the following standards
(see Figure
11-6-3-2:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Location: These signs shall only be permitted on a lot bordering the
U.S. Interstate 94 (Tri-State Tollway) R.O.W. and the Illinois Route 176
(Rockland Road) R.O.W.;
   B.   Surface Area: The sign shall not exceed forty eight (48) square feet
for single face signs, or a total of ninety six (96) square feet for double or
multi face signs; and
   C.   Height: The sign shall not be higher than eighteen feet (18') nor less
than ten feet (10') high. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-
2022)
11-6-3-3: INCIDENTAL SIGNS:
Up to two (2) single or double face signs per lot which may be illuminated.
Such signs shall be attached to any permitted freestanding identification sign,
wall sign, or other permanent structure. The surface area per face of any such
sign shall not exceed five (5) square feet. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-3-4: MONUMENT SIGN:
One sign only shall be permitted per lot and may be in lieu of, but not in
addition to a freestanding identification sign. Such signs may be illuminated
and shall meet the following standards (see Figure
11-6-3-4:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Frontage: These signs may front any street;
   B.   Surface Area: The surface area of a single face sign shall not exceed
forty-eight (48) square feet, or a cumulative total of ninety-six (96) square
feet for double or multiple face signs;
   C.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than ten feet (10') above the
ground at the base of the sign, nor fifteen feet (15') above the level of the
street or driveway nearest the sign, whichever is less; and
   D.   Width: Such signs shall not have any face greater than ten feet (10')
in width. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
11-6-3-5: POLITICAL OR NONCOMMERCIAL SIGNS:
Any number of signs, which shall not exceed six (6) square feet of surface area
per sign, nor a cumulative total surface area of thirty six (36) square feet
per lot. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-3-6: REAL ESTATE SIGN:
One single or double face freestanding unilluminated sign per street frontage
of a lot, and meeting the following standards (see Figure
11-6-3-6:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not exceed thirty
two (32) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than twelve feet (12'); and
   C.   Removal: These signs shall be removed within thirty (30) days following
the sale or lease of the property, or after reaching ninety five percent (95%)
occupancy of the building. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-3-7: SHOPPING CENTER SIGNS:
For shopping centers only, which have an aggregate floor area of ten thousand
(10,000) square feet or more, the following signs are permitted in addition to
signs otherwise allowed in a business use district:
   A.   Entrance or Exit Monument Signs: One freestanding single or double face
sign at each driveway entrance or exit, which may be illuminated, and which
shall meet the following standards (see Figure
11-6-3-7:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
      1.   Surface Area: The surface area of any sign shall not exceed eight
(8) square feet per face; and
      2.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than six feet (6') above the
level of the street or driveway nearest the sign.
   B.   Monument Sign - Shopping Center: If the shopping center fronts on more
than one public street, then one sign may be permitted on each street, but not
more than two (2) signs in total. These signs may be illuminated and shall meet
the following standards (see Figure 11-6-3-7:B, set out in Section
11-9-3 ):
      1.   Frontage: Such signs may front on any adjacent street, which
provides direct ingress or egress to the shopping center;
      2.   Surface Area: The surface area of a single sign on a lot shall not
exceed ninety six (96) square feet per face or more than a cumulative total of
one hundred ninety two (192) square feet for double or multiple face signs. If
two (2) signs are provided, the surface area of any sign shall not exceed forty
eight (48) square feet per sign face or more than a cumulative total of ninety
six (96) square feet for double or multiple face signs; and
      3.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than eighteen feet (18')
above the nearest street.
   C.   Monument Sign Out Lot: One sign shall be permitted on any “out lot”,
which is both contiguous to the shopping center and contains at least twenty
thousand (20,000) square feet of land area. Such signs may be illuminated and
shall meet the same standards for monument signs set forth in Section
11-6-3-4 . (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
11-6-3-8: WALL SIGNS:
Wall signs, which includes "projecting wall signs" and "canopy and marquee wall
signs" may be illuminated and shall meet the following standards:
   A.   Surface Area: The cumulative total surface area of all wall signs on
any wall shall not exceed one and one-half (11/2) square feet of sign area per
lineal foot of store frontage on that wall;
   B.   Height and Clearance: Such signs shall meet the standards set forth in
the general provisions of this Title, Section
11-4-4; and
   C.   Canopy and Marquee Wall Signs: Such signs shall be considered part of
the cumulative total permitted surface area for wall signs. Projecting wall
signs are not permitted on any canopy or marquee. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-4: SPECIAL PERMIT SIGNS:
A special permit sign shall be any sign approved by the Board of Trustees upon
granting of a special permit. Such signs shall be installed completely on
private property and shall be subject to the restrictions imposed by the Board
of Trustees. Special permit signs in business use districts include the
following: (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-4-1: DEVELOPERS'S SIGN:
One unilluminated freestanding single or double face sign facing each street
adjacent to the lot or subdivision and which shall also meet the business use
district setback standards as well as the following requirements (see Figure
11-6-4-1:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not be greater than
thirty two (32) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than twelve feet (12') above the
nearest street; and
   C.   Removal: Such signs shall be removed upon the installation of either a
real estate sign, freestanding identification sign, or as otherwise required by
restrictions imposed by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-6-4-2: ELECTRONIC CHANGEABLE MESSAGE SIGN:
   A.   Surface Area: Electronic changeable message sign shall not exceed fifty
percent (50%) the allowed sign area of a monument sign or thirty (30) square
feet, whichever is less.
   B.   Quantity: Only one sign shall be allowed per lot or shopping center;
   C.   Minimum Right-of-way Frontage: The lot or shopping center on which the
sign is to be located shall have a minimum of one hundred (100) continuous feet
of R.O.W. frontage along its front lot line;
   D.   Location: The sign may only be located on a lot or shopping center
bordering the Illinois Route 176 (Rockland Road) R.O.W., the North Shore Bike
Path R.O.W., or the Illinois Route 43 R.O.W. (Waukegan Road);
   E.   Prohibition Next to A Residential Use District: The sign is prohibited
on any lot bordering, inclusive of R.O.W., a residential use district if any
part of the sign would be visible from within a residence in the residential
use district;
   F.   Message Content Shall Remain Static: The message content of the sign
shall remain static and unchanging for a period of no less than fifteen (15)
seconds;
   G.   Advertisements: The sign may only be used to advertise services and
products available at the businesses located on the premises, noncommercial
messages from not-for-profit or governmental organizations located within the
Village, and advertisements for public meetings and noncommercial public events
in the Village;
   H.   Prohibition for Flashing Lights, Animation, or Video: The message shall
not consist of flashing, scintillating, chasing, or animated lights. The
message shall not include animated pictorial graphics or live motion video;
   I.   Illumination: The illumination of the sign shall not exceed an
intensity of 0.5 foot-candle as measured with a portable handheld sensor at
either the property line or ten (10) feet from the sign, whichever is lesser.
measurements shall be taken not less than three and one-half (3 ½) feet above
the ground line in a vertical position and vertical readings at heights greater
than three and one-half (3 ½) feet may be required pursuant to the direction of
the Building Commissioner;
   J.   Auditory Prohibition: The sign shall not include sound or auditory
components;
   K.   Dimming: The sign shall incorporate automatic dimmer software or solar
sensors that limit maximum brightness settings to five thousand (5,000) nits
during daylight and to five hundred (500) nits between dusk and dawn. If the
Village finds that the sign causes glare or otherwise impairs the vision of a
motor vehicle driver or creates a nuisance condition on surrounding lots, the
owner of the sign, within twenty four (24) hours of a request by the Village,
shall reduce the intensity of the sign to a level acceptable to the Village;
   L.   Sign Operating Hours: The sign shall only operate between one- half (½)
hour before the premises are opened or six o’clock (6:00) A.M., whichever is
later, and one-half (½) hour after the premises is closed to the public or
eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M., whichever is earlier;
   M.   Repairs: If at any time, more than thirty percent (30%) of the display
lights malfunction or are no longer working, the owner of the sign shall make
repairs to the sign within sixty (60) days or the sign will require removal.
The sign must be equipped with a default mechanism that will stop the messaging
or freeze the image in one position when a malfunction in electronic
programming occurs;
   N.   Conforming Signs: All signs on the lot must be in conformance with
Title 11, Sign Regulations of the Village Code; and
   O.   Departures: The Board of Trustees may grant departures from the above
listed standards based on evidence that such departures will not negatively
impact public safety, community character, property values, or the general
welfare of the area surrounding the proposed sign and the Village as a whole.
(Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
11-6-4-3: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
“Temporary signs” as defined by this Title and for which a maintenance
agreement shall be provided for signs displayed more than thirty (30) days, and
otherwise meeting all other restrictions imposed by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
CHAPTER 7
OFFICE AND INDUSTRIAL USE DISTRICTS SIGNS
SECTION:
11-7-1: Office and Industrial Use Districts Signs
11-7-2: Setbacks
11-7-3: Permitted Signs
11-7-3-1: Construction Sign
11-7-3-2: Directory Monument Sign
11-7-3-3: Monument Sign
11-7-3-4: Help Wanted Sign
11-7-3-5: Landscaped Subdivision Monument Sign
11-7-3-6: Political or Noncommercial Signs
11-7-3-7: Real Estate Sign
11-7-3-8: Wall Identification Sign
11-7-3-9: Freestanding Toll Road Identification Sign
11-7-4: Special Permit Signs
11-7-4-1: Developer's Sign
11-7-4-2: Electronic Changeable Message Sign
11-7-4-3: Temporary Signs
11-7-5: Billboards
11-7-1: OFFICE AND INDUSTRIAL USE DISTRICTS SIGNS:
In addition to the general provisions of this Title, all signs shall meet the
following standards provided herein. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-2: SETBACKS:
Permitted signs, other than billboards, may be located in any required yard,
but shall be not less than five feet (5') from any lot line adjacent to any
street, nor less than ten feet (10') from any other lot line. See Figure
11-6-2:A, Business Sign Setbacks set out in Section
11-9-3, which are the same for office and industrial signs. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-
91)
11-7-3: PERMITTED SIGNS:
Signs, including billboards, which are permitted without a special permit
include only the following and no others: (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-3-1: CONSTRUCTION SIGN:
One single or double face freestanding unilluminated sign per lot, which shall
meet the same standards set forth in Section
11-6-3-1. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-3-2: DIRECTORY MONUMENT SIGN:
One freestanding single or double face sign listing the name of the property
owner or tenants, which may be illuminated and shall meet the following
standards (see Figure 11-7-3-2:A, set out in Section 11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of any face shall not exceed thirty (30)
square feet; and
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not exceed six feet (6') in height above the
grade of the nearest adjoining street or driveway. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd.
Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
11-7-3-3: MONUMENT SIGN:
One single, double or multiple face sign per building frontage, which may be
illuminated and which shall meet the following standards (see Figure
11-7-3-3:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of any face shall not exceed thirty (30)
square feet nor a total cumulative area of sixty (60) square feet for double or
multiple face signs; and
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not exceed six feet (6') in height above the
nearest adjoining street or driveway. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-
21, 10-26-2022)
11-7-3-4: HELP WANTED SIGN:
One unilluminated single or double face freestanding sign for each occupied lot
advertising "Help Wanted" and which shall meet the following standards (see
Figure
11-7-3-4:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of any face shall not exceed twelve (12)
square feet; and
   B.   Height: The height of such signs shall not exceed six feet (6') above
the nearest adjoining street or driveway. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-3-5: LANDSCAPED SUBDIVISION MONUMENT SIGN:
One single, double or multiple face freestanding sign at each street entrance
to a subdivision for the sole purpose of displaying the name of the
subdivision. The sign may be illuminated and shall meet the following standards
(see Figure
11-7-3-5:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of any single face sign shall not exceed
ninety six (96) square feet, or one hundred ninety two (192) square feet of
cumulative total surface area for any double or multiple face sign;
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not exceed eighteen feet (18') in height above
the grade of the street or driveway closest to the sign; and
   C.   Easement: Any such sign shall be located within a permanent easement
for the sign and landscaping. The easement shall include provisions for the
continued maintenance of the sign and landscaping, and shall be recorded as
part of the plat of subdivision. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-
26-2022)
11-7-3-6: POLITICAL OR NONCOMMERCIAL SIGNS:
Any number of signs, which shall not exceed six (6) square feet of surface area
per sign, nor a cumulative total surface area of thirty six (36) square feet
per lot. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-3-7: REAL ESTATE SIGN:
One single or double face freestanding unilluminated sign facing each street
frontage of a lot, and meeting the same standards set forth in Section
11-6-3-6. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-3-8: WALL IDENTIFICATION SIGN:
One "wall sign" per building frontage as defined in this Title, which may be
illuminated and subject to the following standards:
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of any wall sign shall not exceed five
percent (5%) of the area of the building frontage wall, nor one hundred (100)
square feet, whichever is less; and
   B.   Height: The height of any wall sign shall conform to the standards set
forth in the general provisions, Section
11-4-4. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-3-9: FREESTANDING TOLL ROAD IDENTIFICATION SIGN:
One single or double face sign per forty (40) acre single user site fronting on
the I-94 toll road, which may be illuminated and which shall meet the following
standards (see Figure
11-7-3-9:A, set out in Section
11-9-3):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of any face shall not exceed four
hundred fifty (450) square feet; and
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not exceed fifteen feet (15') in height above
the level of the adjacent toll road pavement nearest to the sign;
   C.   Setbacks: Toll road identification signs shall meet the following
setbacks:
      1.   Three hundred feet (300') from any residential use district; and
      2.   Twenty five feet (25') from any public street or road right of way
other than the toll road; and
      3.   No less than five feet (5') or no greater than one hundred feet
(100') from the toll road right of way; and
      4.   One hundred feet (100') from any other property line.
   D.   Spacing: Toll road identification signs shall be at least one thousand
two hundred feet (1,200') away from any other toll road identification sign or
billboard along the same side of the toll road.
   E.   Single User Site: A "single user site" is defined as being a tract of
land comprising one or more contiguous lots or parcels owned by a single owner
upon which that owner or his lessee conducts a single business activity.
   F.   Trade Logos: Brand names, trade symbols or logos of any business or
company, other than the user of the site, shall not be permitted, except that
such trade logos of a company not located on the site may comprise not more
than ten percent (10%) of any sign face for signs donated by that company to a
not-for-profit single user of the site. (Ord. 92-15, 6-17-92)
11-7-4: SPECIAL PERMIT SIGNS:
A special permit sign shall be any sign approved by the Board of Trustees upon
granting of a special permit. Such signs shall be installed completely on
private property and shall be subject to the restrictions imposed by the Board
of Trustees. Special permit signs in office and industrial use districts
include the following: (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-4-1: DEVELOPER'S SIGN:
One unilluminated freestanding single or double face sign facing each street
adjacent to the lot or subdivision and which shall also meet the office and
industrial use district setback standards and the following requirements (see
Section
11-9-3, Figure
11-6-4-1:A, Business Developer's Sign, which are the same for the office and
industrial use districts):
   A.   Surface Area: The surface area of such signs shall not be greater than
thirty two (32) square feet per face;
   B.   Height: Such signs shall not be higher than twelve feet (12'); and
   C.   Removal: Such signs shall be removed upon the installation of either a
real estate sign, freestanding identification sign, or as otherwise required by
restrictions imposed by the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-7-4-2: ELECTRONIC CHANGEABLE MESSAGE SIGN:
   A.   Surface Area: Electronic changeable message sign shall not exceed fifty
percent (50%) the allowed sign area of a monument sign or thirty (30) square
feet, whichever is less;
   B.   Quantity: Only one sign shall be allowed per lot or unified
development, such as an industrial park under common ownership;
   C.   Minimum Right-of-way Frontage: The lot or unified development on which
the sign is to be located shall have a minimum of one hundred (100) continuous
feet of R.O.W. frontage along its front lot line;
   D.   Location: The sign may only be located on a lot or unified development
bordering the Illinois Route 176 (Rockland Road) R.O.W., the North Shore Bike
Path R.O.W., or the Illinois Route 43 R.O.W. (Waukegan Road);
   E.   Prohibition Next to A Residential Use District: The sign is prohibited
on any lot bordering, inclusive of R.O.W., a residential use district if any
part of the sign would be visible from within a residence in the residential
use district;
   F.   Message Content Shall Remain Static: The message content of the sign
shall remain static and unchanging for a period of no less than fifteen (15)
seconds;
   G.   Advertisements: The sign may only be used to advertise services and
products available at the businesses located on the premises, noncommercial
messages from not-for-profit or governmental organizations located within the
Village, and advertisements for public meetings and noncommercial public events
in the Village;
   H.   Prohibition for Flashing Lights, Animation, or Video: The message shall
not consist of flashing, scintillating, chasing, or animated lights. The
message shall not include animated pictorial graphics or live motion video;
   I.   Illumination: The illumination of the sign shall not exceed an
intensity of 0.5 foot-candle as measured with a portable handheld sensor at
either the property line or ten (10) feet from the sign, whichever is lesser.
measurements shall be taken not less than three and one-half (3 ½) feet above
the ground line in a vertical position and vertical readings at heights greater
than three and one-half (3 ½) feet may be required pursuant to the direction of
the Building Commissioner;
   J.   Auditory Prohibition: The sign shall not include sound or auditory
components;
   K.   Dimming: The sign shall incorporate automatic dimmer software or solar
sensors that limit maximum brightness settings to five thousand (5,000) nits
during daylight and to five hundred (500) nits between dusk and dawn. If the
Village finds that the sign causes glare or otherwise impairs the vision of a
motor vehicle driver or creates a nuisance condition on surrounding lots, the
owner of the sign, within twenty four (24) hours of a request by the Village,
shall reduce the intensity of the sign to a level acceptable to the Village;
   L.   Sign Operating Hours: The sign shall only operate between one- half (½)
hour before the premises are opened or six o’clock (6:00) A.M., whichever is
later, and one-half (½) hour after the premises is closed to the public or
eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M., whichever is earlier;
   M.   Repairs: If at any time, more than thirty percent (30%) of the display
lights malfunction or are no longer working, the owner of the sign shall make
repairs to the sign within sixty (60) days or the sign will require removal.
The sign must be equipped with a default mechanism that will stop the messaging
or freeze the image in one position when a malfunction in electronic
programming occurs;
   N.   Conforming Signs: All signs on the lot must be in conformance with
Title 11, Sign Regulations of the Village Code; and
   O.   Departures: The Board of Trustees may grant departures from the above
listed standards based on evidence that such departures will not negatively
impact public safety, community character, property values, or the general
welfare of the area surrounding the proposed sign and the Village as a whole.
(Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
11-7-4-3: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
“Temporary signs” as defined by this Title and for which a maintenance
agreement shall be provided for signs displayed more than thirty (30) days, and
otherwise meeting all other restrictions imposed by the Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91; amd. Ord. 2022-O-21, 10-26-2022)
11-7-5: BILLBOARDS:
Billboards shall be permitted in the office and industrial use districts on
unimproved lots only and shall comply with all the following standards (see
Figure
11-7-5:A):
   A.   Number: Not more than one single face sign for a lot of six hundred
feet (600') of frontage or less and one additional single face sign for each
six hundred feet (600') of additional frontage;
   B.   Spacing: Single faced signs shall be at least six hundred feet (600')
from any other billboard. Back-to-back double face signs shall be at least one
thousand two hundred feet (1,200') from any other billboard;
   C.   Height and Length: Billboards shall be limited to twenty five feet
(25') in maximum height and length;
   D.   Surface Area: Billboards shall be limited to two hundred eighty four
(284) square feet in surface area per face;
   E.   Setbacks: Billboards shall be set back as follows:
      1.   One hundred fifty feet (150') from any adjoining residential use
district; and
      2.   Three hundred feet (300') from any residential use district if any
face is visible from the district; and
      3.   Twenty five feet (25') from any public street or road right of way;
and
      4.   Ten feet (10') from any other property line. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
CHAPTER 8
ADMINISTRATION
SECTION:
11-8-1: Inspection and Removal of Certain Signs
11-8-2: Bond Requirements
11-8-3: Design Review
11-8-4: Variations, Appeals and Special Permits
11-8-5: Penalty
11-8-6: Nonconforming Signs
11-8-7: Separability
11-8-1: INSPECTION AND REMOVAL OF CERTAIN SIGNS:
   A.   Unsafe Signs:
      1.   If the Building Commissioner shall find that any sign regulated
herein is unsafe, insecure or has been constructed or erected in violation of
the provisions of this Title, he or his authorized representative shall give
written notice to the permittee thereof.
      2.   If the permittee fails to remove, relocate or alter the sign so as
to comply with the standards herein set forth within ten (10) days after such
notice, such sign may be removed by the Building Commissioner or his designated
agent at the expense of the permittee or owner of the property upon which it is
located.
      3.   The Building Commissioner shall refuse to issue a permit to any
permittee or owner who refuses to pay costs so assessed.
      4.   The Building Commissioner or his designated agent may cause any sign
improperly placed on public property or which is an immediate peril or
endangerment to persons or property to be removed immediately and without
notice.
   B.   Abandoned Signs:
      1.   Any sign now or hereafter existing which has been abandoned, fallen
into disuse, or which no longer advertises a bona fide business conducted,
product sold or service rendered, shall be removed by the owner, agent or
person having the beneficial use of the building, structure or lot upon which
the sign is located within ten (10) days after written notification from the
Building Commissioner or his authorized representative.
      2.   Upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in
such order, the Building Commissioner or his designated agent is hereby
authorized to cause removal of such sign, and any expense incident thereto
shall be paid by the owner of the building, structure or lot upon which such
sign is located.
   C.   Advertising Bench:
      1.   Any advertising bench or sign which is erected or has been
previously erected within the Village on any Village, County or State right of
way without the permission of the appropriate local or State agency and for
which no permit was issued by the Village, shall be deemed to be a nuisance.
      2.   In such case the Building Commissioner or his authorized
representative shall give written notice to the owner of such sign or bench or
if the owner is unknown, by posting such notice to the sign or bench, advising
that said sign or bench is in violation of this Title and must be removed
within ten (10) days from the notice date.
      3.   Any bench or sign which is not removed within said time period shall
be removed and stored by the Village and any such expense incident thereto
shall be paid by the owner thereof.
      4.   If the owner fails to claim said sign or bench within sixty (60)
days from the date of removal, the Village may cause said sign or bench to be
destroyed or otherwise disposed of same. In such event the owner shall remain
responsible for all costs associated with the removal, storage and disposal of
such sign or bench. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-91)
11-8-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   A person engaged in the business of constructing and erecting
billboards or signs shall file with the Building Department a bond in the penal
sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with a responsible surety company as
surety thereon. Said bond shall be approved as to form by the village attorney.
   B.   Said bond shall indemnify the village and its officials, for the full
period of time provided for by the statute of limitations of the state, for any
and all loss, costs, expenses or liability of any kind or nature whatsoever,
which said village or its officials may suffer or be put to, or which may be
recovered from it or them by reason of the issuance of a sign erection permit.
This requirement shall not apply to any individual, business or corporation
constructing and erecting a sign for his or their own personal use. (Ord. 91-
06, 8-28-1991)
11-8-3: DESIGN REVIEW:
   A.   All signs erected in the business, office and industrial use districts
shall be submitted to the plan commission of the village for design review.
   B.   The plan commission shall submit its design review report and
recommendation to the village board.
   C.   The village board shall thereafter review the report and recommendation
of the plan commission and make the final approval of the design.
   D.   No sign erection permit in the business, office and industrial use
districts shall be issued by the building department without the design
approval of the village board.
   E.   Applications for all design reviews shall be made upon forms provided
by the building department. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
11-8-4: VARIATIONS, APPEALS AND SPECIAL PERMITS:
   A.   All request for variations in the requirements herein set forth or
appeals from any rulings of any officer of the village or for special permits
as herein set forth shall be directed to the village board.
   B.   Applications for all said variations, appeals or special permits shall
be made upon forms provided by the building department. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
11-8-5: PENALTY:
Any person, violating or failing to comply with any provision of this title
shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation or failure to comply occurs or continues to exist. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-
1991; amd. Ord. 2001-O-05, 3-28-2001)
11-8-6: NONCONFORMING SIGNS:
Any sign lawfully existing or under construction on the adoption date of this
title which does not conform to the provisions contained herein, may continue
to be maintained, but may not be replaced, structurally altered, reestablished
if discontinued or continued if destroyed or damaged to the extent of fifty
percent (50%) or more of its value. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)
11-8-7: SEPARABILITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this title
is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent
provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions. (Ord. 91-06, 8-28-1991)

11-2-2:A
   Building Frontage
Building frontage shall mean the horizontal width of a building fronting on a
street and measured between lines perpendicular to the street or perpendicular
to the cord line of a curved street.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4d46468b5e3242301e46c5e8ac6a2c179b0baa23/

   Store Frontage
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4d46468b5e3242301e46c5e8ac6a2c179b0baa23/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2111.gif]
 
Store frontage shall mean the length of any wall of a store which fronts a
street, customer parking area or customer entrance, but not including exterior
walls of service and loading areas.
   FIGURE
11-4-4:A
   Wall Sign Requirements
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/4d46468b5e3242301e46c5e8ac6a2c179b0baa23/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2113.gif]
 
   
All wall signs shall not be higher than the facia or parapet line of the
building, canopy or marquee to which they are attached. Except for wall signs
which are completely flush with the wall surface, the minimum clearance below
wall signs shall be ten feet (10') above any pedestrian walkway, fifteen feet
(15') above any driveway or road, nor below the soffit line of any canopy or
marquee. Wall signs located over landscaping features shall be three feet (3')
minimum above the grade level below said sign.

and six feet (6') above the roadway shall be placed or permitted to remain on
any corner lot within the triangular area formed by the street property corner
lines connecting them at points fifty feet (50') from the intersection of the
street lines, or in the case of a rounded corner, from the intersection of the
street property lines extended. The same sight line limitations regarding
height shall apply on any interior lot within the triangular area formed by the
street property line and the edge of the driveway and the line connecting them
at points ten feet (10') from the intersection of the property line and the
driveway.
