13-1-6: Seizure And Destruction Of Machines
13-1-7: Penalty
13-1-8: Severability
13-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context is otherwise indicated, the
following terms shall mean:
ACCESSORY AND SUBORDINATE USE AMUSEMENT DEVICE ESTABLISHMENT: The premises
where the coin operated amusement devices are located shall have a distinct and
primary business use and partially devoted to the use of between four (4) and
thirty five (35) coin operated amusement devices.
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any machine, which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token,
or similar object may be operated by the public generally for the use as a
game, entertainment or amusement whether or not registering a score and shall
include, but not be limited to, such devices as marble machines, pinball
machines, movie and video booths, video slot machines ("cherry pickers"), video
games, and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever
name by which they may be indicated. Incidental mechanical grab devices and
card game devices are deemed gambling devices and therefor are prohibited from
use in the village of Green Oaks. Amusement device shall not include lawfully
licensed video gaming terminals.
AMUSEMENT DEVICE ARCADE: An establishment exclusively devoted to the use of
between four (4) and one hundred ten (110) coin operated devices. Licenses for
such arcades shall only be issued to premises which have received a special use
permit for that purpose.
JUKEBOX: Any music vending machine, contrivance or device which, upon the
insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disk or key into a slot, crevice or
other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or may be operated, for
the emission of songs, music or similar amusement.
PERSON: As used herein shall be deemed to mean any individual, firm,
corporation, partnership or association which owns any such machine; the
person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business such
machine is placed for use by the public; the person, firm, corporation or
association having control over such machine; any person, firm, corporation or
association engaged in the business of distributing and/or servicing such
machines including the distributing, placing, leasing or selling thereof with
an agreement to maintain, service or supply such machines; provided, however,
that the payment of the fee hereinafter required by any such person, firm,
corporation or association enumerated herein shall be deemed compliance with
the requirement for payment of fee provided all other conditions hereof are
met.
PROPRIETARY LICENSE: A license issued under the terms provided in this chapter
to permit the installation and/or operation of more than four (4) coin operated
amusement devices in one location or business establishment.
RESTAURANT/BEVERAGE AMUSEMENT DEVICE ESTABLISHMENT: An establishment primarily
devoted to the sale of food and beverages and partially devoted to the use of
between four (4) and thirty five (35) coin operated amusement devices.
VENDING MACHINE: Shall include any mechanical device which is used for vending
any food, confection, cigarette, matches, drinks, services or anything else of
value and for which a profit accrues, or a fee remits, to the owner, or
proprietor, of such machine. This chapter shall include, but not be limited to,
machines activated by coin, token, slug, lever, remote control, key or payment
of any consideration. Vending machine shall not include lawfully licensed video
gaming terminals.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion
of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including,
but not limited to, video poker, line up, and blackjack, utilizing a video
display and microprocessors in which the player may receive free games,
receipts or credits which can be redeemed for cash. The definition of "video
gaming terminal" does not include a machine that directly dispenses coins,
cash, or tokens or is for amusement purposes only. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997; amd.
Ord. 2014-O-01, 3-26-2014)
13-1-2: REGULATIONS:
13-1-2-1: GAMBLING DEVICES NOT PERMITTED; EXCEPTION:
Nothing in this chapter shall in any way be construed to authorize, license, or
permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism that has been
judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to law,
or that may be contrary to any future laws of the state, except when such
gambling devices are licensed in accordance with the Illinois video gaming act
enacted July 13, 2009, and also permitted in accordance with this title. (Ord.
2014-O-01, 3-26-2014)
13-1-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
Any person displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any
"vending machine", "jukebox", or "amusement device" as herein defined in
section
13-1-1 of this chapter, shall be required to obtain a license from the village
upon payment of a license fee. Application for such license shall be made to
the village upon a form to be supplied by the village clerk for that purpose.
(Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-2-3: DISPLAY OF LICENSE FOR INDIVIDUAL MACHINES:
   A.   All licenses provided for herein, when issued, shall be evidenced by a
fee emblem which shall be affixed prominently and conspicuously to each machine
or device, or posted clearly in the premises where the machine is located.
   B.   Not more than one machine shall be operated under one license and the
applicant or licensee shall be required to secure a license for each machine
displayed or operated.
   C.   If the licensee shall move his place of business to another location
within the village, the license may be transferred to such new location upon
application to the village clerk, provided the new location shall be approved
in the manner provided in this section
13-1-2. A license shall not be transferable from person to person, nor from
machine to machine. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-2-4: MINIMUM SQUARE FOOT REQUIREMENTS:
Only one amusement device will be permitted up to the first two thousand
(2,000) square feet of floor space contained in the premises or place of
business in which such machine is to be located or placed. Any additional
placement of such device will require an additional one thousand (1,000) square
feet of floor space for each device. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-2-5: LIMITATION OF NUMBER OF AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
Not more than three (3) amusement devices shall be permitted on the premises or
place of business in which such devices are to be located or placed unless a
proprietary license has been granted. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-2-6: EXCEPTION:
Notwithstanding the foregoing limitations provided in the Sections of
13-1-2 of this Chapter, the Village may grant a proprietary license, as
provided in Section
13-1-3 of this Chapter, to authorize amusement devices exceeding the minimum
square footage requirements and limitation on number of amusement devices.
(Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-2-7: AGE RESTRICTIONS OF PLAYERS:
No automatic amusement device on the premises of a retail alcoholic liquor
establishment shall be played by anyone under the age of twenty one (21) years
of age unless such establishment is principally a restaurant, food store or
bowling alley. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-2-8: CIGARETTE VENDING MACHINES:
Nothing in this Chapter shall in any way be construed to allow cigarette
vending machines to be placed in violation of State or Federal tobacco rules.
To this end, cigarette vending machines may only be placed in locations where
persons under the age of eighteen (18) years are prohibited. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-
1997)
13-1-3: LICENSES:
13-1-3-1: PROPRIETARY LICENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to have within any premises in the Village
more than four (4) coin operated amusement devices without obtaining a
proprietary license for said premises.
   A.   There shall be three (3) classes of coin operated amusement machine and
device establishments which require a proprietary license.
      1.   An "amusement device arcade" shall require a Class A license.
      2.   A "restaurant/beverage amusement device establishment" shall require
a Class B license.
      3.   An "accessory and subordinate use amusement device establishment"
shall require a Class C license.
   B.   All holders of proprietary licenses shall be subject to the following
rules and regulations:
      1.   A proprietary license is usable only at the place and by the person
designated in the license and is not transferable.
      2.   The licensee shall be permitted to substitute and/or exchange
devices providing the total number of devices does not exceed the number
permitted by the proprietary license. The Village Clerk must be notified of
each transaction and an individual license shall be purchased for each new
machine. Notification to the Clerk shall include the name, dimensions, and
general operation of each machine which is added or removed from the premises.
Machine licenses are issued for a specific machine and are not transferable.
      3.   No amusement device shall be placed in any required exit path of
travel.
      4.   An adult manager shall be required to be present during all times
that the premises is open for business.
      5.   No person under twenty one (21) years of age shall be allowed to
play an amusement device licensed in a retail alcoholic liquor establishment,
unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, or unless the device is housed in a
specifically designated area removed from the liquor service area.
      6.   It shall be unlawful to permit gambling on the premises.
      7.   It shall be unlawful for any proprietary license holder to allow a
degree of noise to develop which would cause a disturbance to the adjacent or
surrounding uses such that the normal use of said adjacent or surrounding uses
would be damaged or unreasonably disturbed.
      8.   It shall be unlawful for any licensee or attendant to permit any
individual under the influence of alcohol or drugs to remain on the premises.
      9.   All licensees hereunder shall have the affirmative duty to report to
the Police Department any and all incidents or reports of a "disturbance of the
peace" as defined and regulated in this Code and which takes place within the
licensed premises or within one hundred feet (100') from the entrance. This
includes incidents both observed by or reported to the management of the
establishment. Failure to report to the Lake County Sheriff's Department shall
be deemed sufficient cause to revoke all licenses.
      10.   All licensees shall permanently and conspicuously post an occupancy
limit sign offered by the local fire protection district and shall adhere to
said limit.
      11.   All licensees shall:
         a.   Keep their premises clean and sanitary;
         b.   Provide waste receptacles;
         c.   Provide adequate and orderly parking for bicycles and motor
vehicles;
         d.   Ensure that all sidewalks and/or walkways outside the premises
are clear and open to pedestrian traffic;
         e.   Post any curfew law in force within the Village;
         f.   Open and operate the game room only during the hours that the
primary business establishment is open to the public;
         g.   Maintain and keep all machines in good repair and operating
condition; and
         h.   In the event of a malfunction of a machine, the operator of the
premises, his agents or employees on the premises shall furnish a refund to the
machine user.
      12.   A minimum of forty (40) square feet of floor area shall be devoted
to each amusement device. Such area shall include the machine, its immediate
area and may include the aisles.
   C.   All holders of Class A proprietary licenses shall also be subject to
the following additional rules and regulations:
      1.   The primary business on the premises shall be the use and operation
of the amusement devices. No Class A license shall be issued for operation on
any premises which have not been granted a special use permit for that use
under the provisions of Title 8 of this Code.
      2.   There shall be no permitted entry into the premises except from the
interior of an enclosed retail shopping center.
      3.   The proprietor shall, in a manner satisfactory to the Village
President, prevent the use or operation of any of the amusement devices by any
person under eighteen (18) years of age, unless they are accompanied by a
parent or an adult twenty one (21) years of age or older.
      4.   The sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor as defined in Chapter 10
of this Code on the licensed premises shall be prohibited.
      5.   The premises must be located in reasonable proximity to a security
office located within the enclosed retail shopping center. The exact distance
between such premises and the security office required shall be determined by
the Village Planning Commission in any findings and recommendations concerning
the special use permit application. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-3-2: APPLICATION:
The application for all licenses, including proprietary licenses shall contain
the following information:
   A.   Name and address of the applicant, date of birth and place of birth.
   B.   Prior criminal convictions of applicant, if any.
   C.   Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the
business conducted at that place.
   D.   Description of machine to be covered by the license, mechanical
features, name of manufacturer and serial number.
   E.   Name, address and date of birth of any and all officers of the
corporation.
   F.   Any convictions of criminal laws by officers of the corporation.
   G.   Any information that is required by the Village President and included
on said application or that may be required by the Village President at a later
date to conduct a proper investigation for purposes of this Chapter.
   H.   The application will be completed in full and with all questions
answered.
No such license shall be issued until the original application has been
completely filled out and referred to the Village President for investigation
and verification of the facts stated therein and the business methods of the
operator. Any omission on the application or untruthfulness of the applicant
shall be cause for the refusal or revocation of said license. Unless the
Village President shall find that the operator has been convicted of a felony
or that he has violated any law or ordinance imposing any tax, or if either the
owner or operator has employed coercive or illegal measures to promote the use
of this device, or that the place where said machine is to be used is not
qualified under the provisions of this Chapter or any other ordinance of the
Village, or that the applicant is not of good moral character, he shall return
said application to the Clerk of the Village with his approval. Otherwise he
shall return the application with a statement of his reasons for refusing to
approve the application.
Any person applying for an amusement device license, cigarette vending machine
or jukebox license shall make himself available to the Village officials for
purposes of being fingerprinted to determine criminal record, if any, of the
applicant. This requirement shall include officers or directors of any
corporate applicant. Failure to do so will justify refusal for issuance of
license.
Any person whose application has been rejected by reason of licensing
investigation shall have a right to appeal from such decision to the Village
Board within ten (10) days of date of rejection notice. The Board shall
establish a time and place for such hearing at which the applicant and his
attorney may be present, present witnesses and submit evidence. Following such
hearing, the Village Board shall have a right to confirm such rejection or to
order the license to be issued. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-3-3: INSPECTION:
Application for all licenses including proprietary licenses shall be made out
in duplicate, one copy being referred to the Village President and the other
copy to the Building Commissioner of the Village.
   A.   The Village President shall investigate the location wherein it is
proposed to operate such machine, ascertain if the applicant is a person of
good moral character, and either approve or disapprove the application.
   B.   The Building Commissioner shall inspect all wiring connections to the
machine, determine if the same comply with the Electrical Code of the Village,
and shall either approve or disapprove the application.
   C.   No license, including proprietary licenses, shall be issued to any
applicant unless approved by the Village President and the Building
Commissioner. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-3-4: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSEES:
No person who is under the age of twenty one (21) years, or who is not a
citizen of the United States shall be granted a license hereunder. (Ord. 97-08,
6-11-1997)
13-1-3-5: REVOCATION:
Every license issued under this Chapter is subject to the right, which is
hereby expressly reserved, to revoke the same should the licensee, directly or
indirectly, permit the operation of any vending machine, jukebox or amusement
device contrary to the provisions of this Chapter, the ordinances of the
Village, or the laws of the State. Said license may be revoked by the Board of
Trustees after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the
ordinance or law violations with which the licensee is charged, if, after a
hearing, the licensee is found to be guilty of such violations. Ten (10) days'
notice of the hearing shall be given to the licensee. At such hearing, the
licensee and his attorney may be present and may submit evidence or witnesses
in his defense. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-3-6: LICENSES FOR VENDING BULK FOOD OR BEVERAGES:
No license shall be issued for a vending machine which dispenses bulk food or
beverages or otherwise is subject to the provisions of the Lake County Board of
Health Ordinance, article XVI, as amended from time to time, relating to the
regulation of food and beverage vending machines, unless the machine and the
operator or owner shall have first complied in all respects with the provisions
of said Board of Health Ordinance, including, but not limited to, obtaining all
licenses, permits, and approvals required by the Lake County Board of Health to
operate such vending machine. When making application for a license for such
vending machines, the owner shall submit proof of compliance with the
provisions of said Board of Health Ordinance. Failure to maintain such
compliance, including, but not limited to, maintaining all licenses, permits
and approvals required thereunder, shall be grounds for revocation of the
license issued under this Chapter, as provided in Section
13-1-3-5 of this Chapter. The fee for all such machines shall be as set forth
in Section
13-1-4-2 of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-4: LICENSE FEES:
13-1-4-1: FEE FOR INDIVIDUAL MACHINES:
An annual fee for each calendar year is imposed upon all amusement devices,
jukeboxes and vending machines operated for gain or profit in the amount as
prescribed by Section
13-1-4-2 of this Chapter, as amended.
The fee shall be paid by the owner of the device to the Village Clerk. The
Village Clerk shall issue evidence of such payment of said fee, a self-adhesive
fee emblem to be placed on each device. Such emblem shall be issued to a
specific machine and shall bear the wording as may be prescribed by the Village
Board of Trustees. It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate said fee
emblem or to transfer said fee emblem to another machine during the year for
which it is issued.
It shall be unlawful for the owner of the machine and the owner or lessee of
any premises or person in control of such premises to permit the installation
or use of an amusement device, jukebox or vending machine within the Village
for gain or profit unless the fee has been paid and is evidenced by the fee
emblem affixed to the machine. Each such device shall be plainly labeled with
the name, address and telephone number of its owner. The owner of the machine
must apply for and be issued the license to operate the machine in the Village.
(Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-4-2: FEE SCHEDULE FOR INDIVIDUAL MACHINES:
An annual fee for each calendar year is imposed upon each amusement device,
jukebox and vending machine operated for gain or profit, said fee to be in the
following amount:
 
Machines with a fee of $0.24 or less $25.00 per machine
Machines with a fee of $0.25 or more 50.00 per machine
 
(Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-4-3: FEE SCHEDULE FOR PROPRIETARY LICENSES:
An annual fee for a proprietary license shall be as follows:
 
Class A establishment $40.00
Class B establishment 35.00
Class C establishment 30.00
 
The license fee per amusement device shall be in addition to the proprietary
license fee. The proprietary license fee shall be in addition to any other
business or alcoholic beverage fee required by the establishment. (Ord. 97-08,
6-11-1997)
13-1-5: FEE INCREASES:
Nothing herein shall in anyway be construed to eliminate the necessity for
public hearing prior to a license fee increase, as required by 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-55-1 et seq. Pursuant to said statutes, if a license fee
increase is proposed, the corporate authorities of the Village shall schedule
and hold a public hearing on the subject of the proposed increase. Notice of
the proposed hearing shall be mailed at least thirty (30) days before the
hearing to the last known address of each person holding such a license. At the
hearing, a sworn statement by the Village Administrator that such notice has
been mailed shall be prima facie evidence of such notice. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-
1997)
13-1-6: SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION OF MACHINES:
If any duly authorized enforcement officer of or for the Village shall have
reason to believe any amusement device is used as a gambling device, such
machine may be seized by the officer and impounded, and if upon trial of the
licensee or operator for allowing it to be used as a gambling device, said
licensee or operator be found guilty, such machine may be destroyed by order of
court, pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1 et seq.
If any duly authorized enforcement officer of or for the Village shall have
reasonable basis for believing any vending machine, jukebox or amusement device
is operating unlicensed, it may be seized by any duly authorized enforcement
officer and impounded. When a machine is impounded for failure to have or
display a license, the machine shall be held until the owner pays the
appropriate license fee and all costs of seizure, cartage and impounding,
including five dollars ($5.00) per day for storage. If the machine is not
licensed and costs paid within thirty (30) days after impounding, the machine
may be destroyed. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter upon conviction
thereof, in addition to the penalty of revocation of his license, shall be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that an offense continues
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
13-1-8: SEVERABILITY:
In the event that any section, clause, provision, or part of this Chapter shall
be found and determined to be invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, all
valid parts that are severable from the invalid parts will remain in full force
and effect. If any part of this Chapter is found to be invalid in any one or
more of its several applications, all valid applications that are severable
from the invalid application shall remain in effect. (Ord. 97-08, 6-11-1997)
CHAPTER 2
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
SECTION:
13-2-1: License Required
13-2-2: License Applications
13-2-3: Investigations
13-2-4: License Approval; Disapproval
13-2-5: License Term; Expiration; Renewal
13-2-6: Unlawful Use Of Licenses
13-2-7: Building And Premises
13-2-8: Location
13-2-9: Nuisances
13-2-10: Businesses Open To The Public
13-2-11: Inspections
13-2-12: Penalty; Enforcement
13-2-13: Suspension; Revocation Of License
13-2-14: Posting; Removal; Destruction Of License
13-2-15: Requirements For Additional Licenses
13-2-16: Adoption By Reference
13-2-17: License Fees; Required Licenses
13-2-18: Conflicts
13-2-19: Violations; Penalty; Nuisance
13-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall conduct, engage in, maintain, operate, carry on or
manage any business, occupation, activity or establishment, either by himself
or itself, or through an agent, employee or partner, for which a license is
required by this Chapter or by any other Village ordinance, without first
having obtained a license for such business, occupation, activity or
establishment.
   B.   Except as might be specifically set forth in other ordinances of the
Village, whenever a license is required for the maintenance, operation or
conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in
any activity or occupation, any person shall be subject to the requirements if
by himself or itself, or through an agent, employee or partner, he or it is
held forth as being engaged in the business, activity or occupation, or if he
or it solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively, or if he or it
performs or attempts to perform any part of such business, activity, or
occupation in the Village. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
   C.   The regulations and licensure requirements of this Chapter do not apply
to any person operating a "home occupation" which is permitted under the zoning
regulations of the Village including, but not limited to, Section
8-5-3 of this Code. (Ord. 98-16, 12-16-1998)
13-2-2: LICENSE APPLICATIONS:
   A.   Applications for all licenses shall be made to the Village
Administrator, in writing, on a form provided for that purpose, except as may
be otherwise provided.
   B.   If the applicant is an individual (sole proprietorship), the
application shall contain his name, residence address and residential telephone
number. If the applicant is a partnership or other noncorporate business
entity, the application shall contain the name and residential address and
residential telephone number of each partner, principal or member thereof. If
the applicant is a corporation, the application shall contain the name,
residential address and residential telephone number of each principal officer
and the registered agent thereof.
   C.   Each application also shall contain:
      1.   A designation of the type or kind of license desired (e.g.,
"business license");
      2.   The location or proposed location of the place of business,
occupation or activity; (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
      3.   The applicable fee to be paid as provided in Section
13-2-17 of this Chapter; (Ord. 98-05, 3-25-1998)
      4.   The number of the certificate of registration required under the
Retailers' Occupation Tax Act, Service Occupation Tax Act, and/or Use Tax Act,
if applicable; and
      5.   Such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance
of village officials in the evaluation of such application, including proof of
any insurance policy or bond if required by any ordinance of the village. (Ord.
97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-3: INVESTIGATIONS:
   A.   Where this chapter or village policy authorizes or requires an
investigation by any department or official of the village before the issuance
of a license, and requires the approval by such department or official
regarding the proper zoning location or condition of the premises in which the
business, occupation or activity for which a license is applied for, is to be
managed, conducted, operated or carried on, or regarding the condition and
nature of the equipment, any methods intended to be used by the applicant in
such business, occupation or activity, then the village administrator shall
transmit to the appropriate official or department such information necessary
for the required investigation or inspection.
   B.   The designated official or department shall:
      1.   Make all necessary investigation and inspections, and the results
thereof shall be reported in writing to the village administrator; and
      2.   Indicate on the application a recommendation for the approval or
disapproval thereof.
   C.   Upon receipt of all related investigative and inspection reports, if
any, the clerk shall forward such reports, together with the application, to
the village president for final determination. (Ord. 97-O-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-4: LICENSE APPROVAL; DISAPPROVAL:
   A.   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and related investigative and inspection reports, the village
president shall determine that the application is satisfactory, he shall
approve the application. Thereupon, the village administrator shall notify the
applicant that the application has been approved. The license shall be signed
by the village president, or, at his/her direction, the village administrator,
and then issued to the licensee.
   B.   If, after due consideration of the information contained within the
application and related investigative and inspection reports, the village
president shall determine that matters concerning the application are
unsatisfactory, the village president shall disapprove the application,
indicating the reasons therefor. Thereupon, the village administrator shall
notify the applicant that the application has not been approved and that no
license will be issued. (Ord. 97-O-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-5: LICENSE TERM; EXPIRATION; RENEWAL:
   A.   Each license shall indicate its term. All annual licenses shall be
operative and the license year for the village shall commence on January 1 of
each year. No license shall be granted for a period longer than one year.
Except where otherwise provided in this chapter, every license shall expire on
December 31 following the date of issuance.
   B.   The village administrator shall endeavor to notify each annual licensee
of the expiration of time on the license held by the licensee at least twenty
one (21) days prior to such expiration date; provided, however, that a failure
to make such notification or the licensee's failure to receive it shall not
exclude the licensee from the obligation to obtain a new license or a renewal.
   C.   Except as otherwise provided herein, each license may be renewed upon
proper application and payment of the required fee. The requirements and
procedures for granting and issuing a license renewal shall be the same as the
requirements and procedures for granting a new license. (Ord. 2006-O-03, 4-26-
2006)
13-2-6: UNLAWFUL USE OF LICENSES:
No license may be assigned, sold, loaned, transferred, used as collateral or
otherwise encumbered. No person shall use or display on the licensed premises
any license, certificate, tag, badge or sticker issued by the village to any
other person. (Ord. 97-O-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-7: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit shall
be issued for any purpose or activity if the premises or building to be used
for the purpose stated in the application does not fully comply with all
applicable ordinances and regulations of the village. (Ord. 97-O-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-8: LOCATION:
   A.   No license for the operation of a business, establishment or activity
in the village shall be construed to permit its operation in more than one
location in the Village; a separate license shall be required for each
location.
   B.   For the purpose of this Chapter, the existence of a single location
shall be evidenced by the fact that all buildings containing the principal or
lawful accessory uses:
      1.   Shall be connected or shall be located on the same lot or parcel;
      2.   Shall be operated and managed by the same person or owner; and
      3.   Shall be an establishment with the same classification.
   C.   The location of any licensed business or occupation, other than the
sale of alcoholic liquors, or the location of any permitted act, may be
changed, provided that the Village Administrator's office shall be given
sufficient notice of such intended change in location to determine that the
operation for which the license is required conforms with all applicable
ordinances and regulations of the Village at its new location. (Ord. 97-16, 9-
3-1997)
13-2-9: NUISANCES:
   A.   Prohibited: Generally, no business or establishment, whether or not
licensed, shall be so conducted or operated as to constitute a nuisance in
fact; and no building, vehicle, structure, yard, lot, premises, or part thereof
shall be used, kept, maintained or operated in connection with any business or
establishment so as to occasion any nuisance, or so as to be dangerous to life,
detrimental to health, or operated in violation of any local, State or Federal
laws.
   B.   Refuse Disposal:
      1.   Refuse Containers: All refuse which is placed for collection service
outside any building or structure must be kept in standard refuse containers
unless another type of container is approved by the Village due to the unusual
nature of the refuse produced by the business.
      2.   Refuse Removal: It shall be the duty of the occupant of every
building, structure or premises used or maintained in connection with any
business or occupation to cause all refuse produced therein to be removed at
his own cost and expense.
      3.   Removal By Business Or Occupations: Every person owning or
controlling any hotel, restaurant, cafe, retail food establishment or other
business or occupation, where more than thirty two (32) gallons of refuse is
normally produced weekly, shall cause all substances deposited in such
containers to be removed as often as shall be necessary, including daily
removal from his premises, to ensure the healthful environment surrounding such
establishment. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-10: BUSINESSES OPEN TO THE PUBLIC:
All business or commercial establishments licensed under this Chapter which
invite the public generally into their establishments for the purpose of
conducting business, commercial activity or any other activity licensed under
this Chapter, shall be subject to the following regulations in addition to all
other applicable ordinances, regulations and laws:
   A.   All business or commercial establishments subject to this Section shall
refrain from all deceptive trade practices as defined by State or Federal law
or regulation and shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations
regarding consumer protection and deceptive trade practices. In the event of
any such violation, the business license of the establishment may be revoked
pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter.
   B.   All licensees shall comply, at all times, with all applicable Federal,
State and local statutes, ordinances, resolutions and regulations. (Ord. 97-16,
9-3-1997)
13-2-11: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the
operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by
this Chapter, or any other ordinance of the Village upon probable cause that a
violation of law exists upon the premises, or are reasonably necessary to
assure compliance with the provisions of any ordinance or regulation of the
Village, or to determine violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the
licensee or the person in charge of the premises to admit thereto for the
purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the Village who is
duly authorized to make such inspection at any reasonable time that such
admission or entry is requested. By applying for a license hereunder, the
applicant agrees and consents to the provisions of this subsection.
   B.   Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably
necessary to assure compliance with the provisions of this Chapter, or of any
ordinance or regulations, or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty
of the licensee or person in charge of the premises to give to any duly
authorized officer or employee of the Village requesting the same, sufficient
samples of such material or commodity for such analysis upon official request.
   C.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the Village
President may revoke under the provisions of this Chapter the license of any
owner or operator of a licensed business in the Village who refuses to permit
any duly authorized officer or employee to make such inspection or to take any
adequate sample of said commodity, or who interferes with such officer or
employee while in the performance of his duties. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-12: PENALTY; ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Unless otherwise expressly provided, any person convicted of violating
any provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day
that a violation exists.
   B.   Whenever a person shall neglect or refuse to procure any license
required by this Chapter, or otherwise violates the terms of this Chapter, the
Village President is authorized to cause appropriate legal or equitable action
and proceedings to be instituted to enforce the license requirement.
   C.   The Village President shall take all necessary and appropriate action
to compel compliance with the regulatory provisions of this Chapter. When
necessary and expedient, he may call upon the appropriate law enforcement
official to assist in such enforcement. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-13: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   When the conduct or operation of any business, occupation, activity or
establishment, whether licensed or unlicensed, shall constitute a nuisance in
fact and a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general
welfare, or where the owner and/or operator of any such licensed business shall
have refused to allow an inspection of his premises or has refused to furnish a
sample of his goods for testing, the Village President shall be authorized to
summarily order the cessation of business and the closing of the premises until
the danger no longer exists or until the licensee provides adequate assurance
that such conditions or violations shall not be revived or renewed. In any
other case, when there has been a violation of any provision of this Chapter,
the Village President may suspend or revoke the license so issued.
   B.   Within ten (10) days after a license is suspended or revoked, the
Village President shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining whether
or not the license revocation should be annulled or modified and in the case of
a suspension, whether or not the suspension should be continued or converted to
a revocation.
   C.   Licenses issued by the Village, unless otherwise provided, may be
revoked or suspended by the Village President after notice and hearing as
provided in subsections D and E of this Section for any of the following
causes:
      1.   Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the
application for the license;
      2.   Any violation by the licensee of provisions of this Chapter or other
ordinances of the Village relating to the license, the subject matter of the
license or the premises occupied;
      3.   Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor where
such conviction indicates their inability to operate a safe, honest and
legitimate business operation within the Village;
      4.   Failure of the licensee to pay any fine, penalty or charge owed to
the Village;
      5.   Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling or any interference with
a duly authorized Municipal officer or employee while in the reasonable
performance of his duties in making such inspections, as provided herein;
      6.   Causing or allowing the licensed premises or any portion thereof to
become or remain a nuisance as defined in Section
13-2-9 of this Chapter.
Such revocation or continuation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and
imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other
applicable provisions of this chapter or other ordinances of the village.
   D.   Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time
and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified or registered
mail to the licensee at the address stated in the application at least five (5)
days prior to the date set for the hearing. The village president or his
designee may continue the hearing for good cause shown.
   E.   At the hearing, the village attorney shall present the complaint and
shall represent the village. The licensee shall be permitted counsel and shall
have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The village
president or his designee shall preside and shall render the decision. Strict
rules of evidence shall not be applicable.
   F.   A stenographically or electronically recorded record of the hearing
shall be kept. The village shall pay the cost of attendance fees of the
reporter and the cost of the transcript, if such transcript shall be ordered by
the village. The licensee shall pay the cost of any transcript or copy ordered
by him/her/it.
   G.   Within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not
later than ten (10) days after such conclusion, the village president shall
file a written decision in which he has summarized the evidence and has stated
the reasons for his decision. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-14: POSTING; REMOVAL; DESTRUCTION OF LICENSE:
   A.   It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in
the village to keep his license displayed at all times in a prominent place on
the premises, machine or vehicle used for such business. Upon request of the
village president or any person designated by him, the licensee shall produce
the license for inspection.
   B.   No person shall destroy, obliterate, take, remove or carry away without
the consent of the owner any license, certificate, plate, or sticker which has
been issued by the village except when such license, certificate or sticker has
been discontinued or the licensed premises have been abandoned. Nothing herein
shall prevent the village president or his duly authorized representative from
removing any license, certificate, plate, or sticker from the possession of a
former licensee, his premises, any vehicle or any machine when said license has
been revoked under the provisions of this code. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-15: REQUIREMENTS FOR ADDITIONAL LICENSES:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, each individual business or
commercial activity within the village shall be required to obtain only one
license, but shall be required to comply with all applicable regulations
contained in this chapter or elsewhere. The license fee required to be paid by
an individual business which is subject to two (2) or more licenses in this
chapter shall be the largest of those applicable. A business shall be
considered to be individual only if it is owned by identical persons or
entities, is contained within one single building and conducts activities which
are closely related. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-16: ADOPTION BY REFERENCE:
Whenever within this chapter any regulation or public record is adopted and
incorporated by reference, the manner of their adoption and incorporation shall
have complied with the provisions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes allowing
such incorporation and adoption. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-17: LICENSE FEES; REQUIRED LICENSES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for a business to operate within the village
without a business license required by this chapter.
   B.   Annual license fees under the terms of this chapter, for the
businesses, occupations, activities and uses set forth, shall be sixty five
dollars ($65.00) if purchased by January 31 of the license year. The license
fee shall be one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00) if purchased between January
31 and June 30 of the license year. If purchased on or after July 1 of the
license year, the license fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). The
license year shall be January 1 to December 31. The full license fee shall be
paid annually and no fee shall be prorated for a term of less than one year.
Proof of any bond or liability insurance policy required by this chapter shall
be provided with the license fee.
   C.   A license is required for the following businesses:
Amusements.
Animal sales.
Auctioneers and going out of business sales (at fixed locations within the
village).
Billiard table operators and bowling alleys.
Breweries.
Carters, expressmen and storage of carting and express vehicles and trailers.
Cigarette/tobacco dealers and cigarette vending machines.
Coffeehouses.
Cold storage establishments.
Dry cleaning establishments.
Explosive storage and handling.
Fire extinguisher service and repair.
Flammable and hazardous chemicals.
Flammable liquids; storage and handling.
Florists, plant shops.
Food establishments; where food is sold, eaten, or prepared.
Fuel oil, solid fuel dealers.
Gasoline filling stations; automotive vehicle wrecking and repair
establishments.
Hotels and motels.
Junk dealers.
Laundry and laundromats.
Livery stables.
Lumberyards and lumber storehouses.
Medical dispensaries.
Parking lot or public garage.
Pawnbrokers.
Retail sales.
Secondhand dealers and similar sales (excluding occasional garage sales by
persons who are not dealers).
Theaters and theatrics.
Video movie sales or rentals.
   D.   At any time on or after July 1 of each license year the village may
take any or all lawful action necessary to collect the license fee due under
this section including, but not limited to, placing the delinquent license fee
account for collection with a debt collection company. (Ord. 2013-O-04, 4-24-
2013; amd. Ord. 2021-O-22, 12-15-2021)
13-2-18: CONFLICTS:
The provisions of this chapter are not intended to supersede any other specific
ordinance which pertains to any specific other license or licensing procedure
or regulation. Where this chapter is in conflict with any other provision of
this code, the most restrictive provision shall apply. Where state statute
specifically supersedes this chapter, the state statute shall prevail. (Ord.
97-16, 9-3-1997)
13-2-19: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY; NUISANCE:
It is declared by the corporate authorities that the maintaining, operating or
continuation of any enterprise, activity or device requiring a license under
this chapter or any other ordinance without actual issuance to and possession
by the licensee of the license granted, is a public nuisance. Any such public
nuisance may be abated by an action for any or all of the remedies of penalty
pursuant to the penalty provisions of this chapter, temporary restraining
order, preliminary injunction, and permanent injunction or other equivalent
legal remedy. The remedies provided for herein and any other provision of law
are deemed cumulative and not exclusive. Each day that a violation of this
chapter shall exist shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 97-16, 9-3-
1997)
CHAPTER 3
ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENT REGULATIONS
SECTION:
13-3-1: Short Title
13-3-2: Definitions
13-3-3: Adult Use Commissioner; Commission
13-3-4: Adult Establishment Licenses Generally
13-3-5: Form; Submittal Of License Application
13-3-6: Processing Of License Application
13-3-7: Standards For Issuance Or Denial Of License
13-3-8: Inspections
13-3-9: Change In Information
13-3-10: Regulations Applicable To All Adult Entertainment Establishments
13-3-11: Special Regulations For Adult Booths
13-3-12: Special Regulations For Adult Cabarets
13-3-13: Special Regulations For Adult Stores
13-3-14: Special Regulations For Adult Theaters
13-3-15: Licensee Responsibility For Employees
13-3-16: License Revocation Or Suspension
13-3-17: Administrative Record
13-3-18: Employee Registration And Record Keeping
13-3-19: Penalty
